Many restaurants around Connecticut now allow patrons to bring their own bottle of wine, and in some cases, beer and hard liquor. Here is a list of some old favorites that have never charged corkage fees, along with some that have recently reduced or eliminated them.
Because of the sour economy, many restaurateurs across Connecticut have decided to reduce or eliminate their corkage fees.

I find it curious that in his Lives essay (March 22), Michael Krikorian reveals such a deep appreciation for Sarah Vaughan’s version of “Just a Little Lovin’ ” and yet didn’t think much about “pinching” that intellectual property by having his girlfriend’s son burn a copy to give away. Jerry could have easily sent him a link to a site where he could purchase it, and Krikorian could have done the same for EAllen4787. Then he could also feel good about compensating the artists who created such a beautiful work of art.

I am disturbed by Randy Cohen’s implication that pursuing sweeping change is a nobler pursuit than meeting the immediate needs of those in distress (The Ethicist, March 22). While those who work on the macro level seek financing and negotiate the government bureaucracy, a long-term proposition at best, surely those in need take immeasurable comfort in that bowl of soup. Let’s each give according to our talents and our hearts. The world’s problems need both the big-idea strategist and the human touch.

I have to agree with A. O. Scott when he writes that “in spite of the abundance of American movies, there is an awful lot of American life that remains off screen” (“Neo-Neo Realism,” March 22). As a sociologist and college educator, I often show films that illuminate a series of social problems and the human experience that results. It has been part of our American culture to search for a deeper understanding of our lives through art and particularly through the visual and emotional immediacy of film. But what do we find?.

The crossword on March 22 gave an erroneous clue for 57-Across, “Showcase Showdown Prize, Perhaps?” — for which the solution was “dinette set.” Such a prize could be awarded only during the “Showcase” portion of “The Price Is Right.” The “Showcase Showdown” is a preliminary round.

First I’d like to commend Michael Sokolove for his well-written article about the young basketball prodigy Allonzo Trier (March 22). As someone who has traversed this maze of elite youth basketball, albeit during simpler times, before moving on to play four years at Duke University and eventually for the Chicago Bulls (I was drafted in 1983), I found his observations and analysis extremely accurate.

BERNHEIM--Shirley, age 87, died peacefully on March 30, 2009 at The Lillian Booth Actors Fund Home in Englewood, NJ. She is survived by her loving brother, Paul Raphael, sister in-law, Norma, her nieces, Karen and Amy, and her nephew, Mark. Ms. Bernheim's marriage to her late husband, Edward Bernheim, ended in divorce. The family is grateful to her devoted friend, Jayne Dutil, and to all the staff at the Actors Fund Home who loved and cared so deeply for her. Described as one of the "Tough Old Broads" in Time Out New York (2001), following her role as potty-mouthed Frieda in the Broadway production of The Tale of the Allergist's Wife, Ms. Bernheim's career included film, television and stage appearances. We will miss her "mouth" and her spirit. The family requests that donations be made to the Actors Fund (actorsfund.org/support/donate). Arrangements for a memorial service are being made as of this writing. For Information: http://www.shirlbernheim.com

HARMON Elizabeth Hunt, beloved daughter of Frank and Judy Harmon of Pocatello, ID and cherished sister of Franklin Harmon of Albany, CA and Matthew Harmon of Los Angeles, CA, passed away Monday, March 23, 2009 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. A paleoanthropologist, Elizabeth was a faculty member in the Department of Anthropology at Hunter College--CUNY and a contributor to the New York Consortium in Evolutionary Primatology. She was a gifted teacher and scholar. Her research interests took her to Ethiopia every year where she co-directed a paleontological field project in the Rift Valley of Ethiopia. Elizabeth was born in 1965 in Laramie, WY and raised in Pocatello, ID. After graduating from Portland State University in Portland, OR, she spent several years as a field archaeologist in various areas of the world before entering Arizona State University where she earned her Ph.D. under the tutelage of the Institute of Human Origins. Elizabeth leaves behind many dear friends, colleagues, students and a legacy of work that has earned her the respect and admiration of her peers. Her family appreciates the many expressions of love and respect received, as they mourn the loss of her bright spirit.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''In the Mist, Pioneers Witness a First Pitch,'' March 30: While my daughter and I were one of the pioneers last Sunday at Citi Field, our explorations were cut short by the restricted access afforded to those seated on the Promenade level. Applying to college can be among the most bewildering experiences in the life of an American teenager. And it's no picnic for that teenager's family, either. That's why The New York Times created this new blog, which we hope will serve as a regular online companion and resource to those of you running this gantlet -- particularly high school juniors and seniors, as well as their parents and counselors, and even admissions officers. We have invited several seniors from high schools around the country to blog about their college selection process as they receive their acceptance letters. Here are excerpts from posts by two Connecticut students. Tyler K. Calder

BRESLAU Lawrence (Larry) D.,died at home Monday, March 23, 2009. Larry was born on December 18, 1930 in Albany, New York to Lillian and Ted Nachison. He received a B.A. from Cornell University in 1952, and an M.D. in 1959; a member of the first graduating class of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, New York City. This was followed by an internship and residency in psychiatry at Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich, and University Hospitals of Cleveland. A well-known psychiatrist, Dr. Breslau practiced in Cleveland from 1960 to 1987. In Baltimore he practiced until his death. While he maintained a private practice in general psychiatry through most of his career, his major contributions to the profession were in the area of geriatric psychiatry. A pioneer in the psychiatric treatment of the aged, Dr. Breslau described the "exaggerated helplessness" syndrome, which provided a new understanding of psychiatric disorders in the elderly, especially among those with early senile dementia and Alzheimer's disease. His work contributed to the development of geriatric psychiatry as a distinct sub-specialty. Dr. Breslau taught and mentored future generations of psychiatry residents, emphasizing treatment of the entire human being. Patients and staff reported his passion for psychiatry, and describe that his approach was guided by the common strains of warmth, gentleness, compassion, and frequent humor. Dr. Breslau's greatest influence was the respect and love of patients and colleagues who worked with him. Dr. Breslau is survived by his wife, Erica Sharp, his former wife Naomi Zeidel, and their three children Jonathan and Lisa; Daniel and Margaret; Joshua Breslau and Elizabeth Miller; seven grandchildren; and a sister Judith Moore. Contributions may be made to Kol HaLev, P.O. Box 16399, Baltimore, MD 21210 or Johns Hopkins University, sent to Johns Hopkins Medicine Fund, 100 N. Charles St., Suite 437, Baltimore, MD 21201.

ZOOM The soldier's body was found near the center of Gettysburg with no identification -- no regimental numbers on his cap, no corps badge on his jacket, no letters, no diary. Nothing save for an ambrotype (an early type of photograph popular in the late 1850s and 1860s) of three small children clutched in his hand. Within a few days the ambrotype came into the possession of Benjamin Schriver, a tavern keeper in the small town of Graeffenburg, about 13 miles west of Gettysburg. The details of how Schriver came into possession of the ambrotype have been lost to history. But the rest of the story survives. ... There is something magical and sad about chronicling the history of a man who went more than halfway around the world on a whaling ship and then died (presumably alone) in a small town, a couple of hundred miles from his home. It is possible to chart Amos Humiston's movements from the moment he joined the 154th New York Volunteer Infantry in Jamestown, N.Y., to Gettysburg, Pa. -- a winding, circuitous, ant-like path that might have meaning, but then again, might not. And even if we could chart it completely, does it bring us closer to Amos Humiston? Does it capture the essence of the man? Even if we knew where he was every minute of his waking life? Would that tell us who he is?

For a decade, the American League East belonged to the Yankees or the Boston Red Sox. Nobody else was competitive until last season, when the Tampa Bay Rays zipped past the game's glamour teams. Objects in the rearview mirror were much closer than they had appeared. With the Yankees ravaged by injuries, Tampa Bay held off Boston for the division title, and later nipped the Red Sox in a seven-game thriller for the pennant. Not bad for a team that had never exceeded 70 wins.

STEINGART--Jacob "Jack", longtime psychologist and Acting Team Leader for the Veterans Administration in East Los Angeles, died on March 26 at the age of 78. Born April 1, 1930 in New York City, Jack began to systematically pursue degrees from every available academic institution including Stuyvesant High School, City College of New York, New York University, The New School and Columbia University, where he received his doctorate in psychology. In 1974, Jack and his family moved to California where he also received an MBA from the Claremont Graduate School. Jack's career spanned from engineer at the Emerson Radio Corporation to industrial psychologist at IBM and the Atlantic Richfield Corporation. He also taught at California State University Fullerton and California State University Long Beach. Jack found his greatest happiness at the VA in East Los Angeles where he had the privilege of serving the veterans of the United States Armed Services who affectionately knew him as "Doctor Jack." He was a veteran of the United States Army as a Lieutenant in the Korean War. Jack is survived by Liz, his wife of 54 years, his son Benjamin of Oakland, CA, his son Jon and his wife Jenny of New York City, and his adoring grandchildren Leo and Ruby who loved their "Abuelito".

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about a Spanish judge's criminal inquiry into allegations that six Bush administration officials broke international laws banning torture misidentified, in some copies, a foreign defendant in a Miami federal case brought under a law that allows the United States to prosecute torture in other countries. The defendant in that case, concerning torture committed in Liberia, was Chuckie Taylor, also known as Charles Arthur Emmanuel, the son of former Liberian President Charles Taylor -- not the former president himself.

ENTERING A TOMB AT AL BARA, ONE OF THE DEAD CITIES NEAR ALEPPO, SYRIA, SEPT. 17, 2008 Carina Perry, a 35- year-old bookkeeper from Galway, Ireland. ''I'm a bit of a running-away-from-reality person. I'm in Asia for a year; I went to South America the year before last, and the year before that I went to Southeast Asia and Australia and New Zealand and Fiji and a bit of America. Once I go home, I just seem to want to plan my next trip. I didn't really know much about Syria. People view it as a kind of anti-West country, but it was amazing, people were so friendly. In the photo I'm at the Byzantine tombs. They're so well intact, and there were no other tourists anywhere. In any other part of the world, these places would be crowded. Generally, people think I'm trying to run away from life. I have friends from traveling who are just envious, and then I have friends from home who kind of think I'm crazy. My mom is very nervous about it, but she's happy for me to be happy doing what I really want.'' As told to Seth Kugel

FORREST--Rose E. Passed away at home in New York on Saturday, March 28, 2009. A lifelong New Yorker, she married Arthur (deceased 1994), her soulmate, in 1943. Rose was preceded by her brothers Joseph and Benjamin and her brother-in-law Abraham Brodsky. Survivors include her sister Aida Brodsky, sisters-in-law Eleanor and Ruth Ennis, nieces and nephews, great- nieces and nephews, a great- great-niece, two great-great-nephews, and lifelong friends who will miss her unique and fascinating presence.

Dance Claudia La Rocco

THE fashion photographer Mark Borthwick, whose images have appeared in provocative magazines like Purple, Self Service and Italian Vogue, has always had an unorthodox approach to his work. ''I like to take the fashion out it,'' he said. ''And make it more human.'' Which is to say, he eschews airbrushed glamour for a kind of carefree, sun-soaked innocence; not surprisingly, his new book, aptly titled ''Not in Fashion,'' is more akin to a journal than a glossy Rizzoli monograph. It features photos that span his two-decade career, including early fashion shots of a baby-faced Chloë Sevigny (far left) and Angela Lindvall (right). The pages are littered with newspaper clippings, hand-scrawled notes and family photos intentionally blown out by overexposing the film. ''As a photographer, you have so much control,'' Mr. Borthwick said. ''I like to liberate the image so it can breathe a little and allow people to feel and discover new things.''

EVDOKIMOVA-GREGORI--Eva, on April 2, 2009 in New York City. The world has lost and mourns deeply and forever not only universally recognized as one of the greatest ballerinas in the history of classical ballet, having the rare title of Prima Ballerina Assoluta, but equally recognizing as having such extraordinary personal qualities that were so pure, so generous, so admirable, so loving, so egoless with an endless spirit of good will, compassion and joy. Her refinement had no equal. Her list of professional and personal accomplishments can be found on a soon to be established website. Contact: evaevdokimova@aol.com for information. Eva Evdokimova-Gregori leaves behind her cherished husband Michael S. Gregori of Manhattan, her mother-in-law Katherine Gregori of Manhattan, her brother-in-law Peter Gregori, her nephew, Jacob Gregori and extended Gregori family and loving cousins, her loving and dear friends who Eva was eternally grateful to. A celebration of the life and work of Prima Ballerina Assoluta, Eva Evdokimova is being organized with all of the major ballet companies worldwide as well as a new autobiography and a trove of never released videos and films. A private service will be held. Interment at Woodlawn Cemetery. Thank you for everything, you are my heart and soul. I was so fortunate my love. I will always be with you.

UNLIKE, say, Dolce & Gabbana, Yigal Azrouël isn't known for amped-up glamour-puss clothing. His chic surfer girls are a bit more laid back; bustiers aren't a staple of their wardrobe. Yet, picking up on the budding lingerie-top trend (a look that, despite being tricky to wear, showed up in a slew of spring collections, including Prada and Lanvin, Thakoon and Opening Ceremony), Mr. Azrouël worked a bustier nicely into his resort collection, pairing it with a T-shirt and jeans. ''The idea was to take this very sexy garment and translate it to something more casual and cool, and wearable beyond the boudoir,'' he said.

Address: 94 Housatonic Avenue The Property: This house fronts the Housatonic River, and a recent two-story addition expanded the 1910 structure to more than 3,000 square feet. The original ground floor has three bedrooms, one bath, an eat-in kitchen and a living room. The second floor, which has its own entrance and can be used as an in-law apartment, has a great room, a galley kitchen, vaulted ceilings and a large bedroom with a full bath. The third floor loft, with a half bath, could be used as a bedroom. There is a back deck, patio and detached two-car garage. The property has its drawbacks: a strip of land at the base of the yard, closest to the water, is owned by the Pootatuck Yacht Club, which is next door. Also, this house does not have its own dock.

SLIVA--Thomas J.,of Manhattan, died February 21, 2009, at his home in the East Village where he lived for 36 years. Born, June 28, 1943, to Rudolph and Marion Sliva (deceased), in Yonkers, NY; raised and attended Catholic schools there. B.S., U. of North Dakota, Chemistry; Graduate work, U. of Utah. He is survived and profoundly missed by Vann Williams, Jr., his cherished and loving long-term companion and partner of 27 years; his beloved brothers, Edward Sliva and wife, Carolyn and Robert Sliva and wife, Karla; nieces, Susan, Annemarie (Thomas Moore, Jr.) and Maribeth (deceased) and nephew, Paul, and their children; his favorite aunt, Anne Hawkins; Kyra and Cassady Kissam to whom he was a beloved "uncle" and mentor; baby god-daughter, Angelina Fairley; his faithful cat companion, Mishka, and the many friends he held dear. Tom was Vice-President and Technical Director of DL Laboratories, in Brooklyn, NY, where he worked for 36 years. He will be deeply missed by everyone there, especially his Secretary of 22 years, Charmalyn Williams and Assistant Technical Advisor, Mario Lazaro, Jr., with whom he worked since 1973, and by his many associates in the field. Tom was very active in numerous professional trade organizations, most notably, American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM), and honored with several awards. His last, the 2006 ASTM International Award of Merit and accompanying title of Fellow, was the one he most treasured. He took great joy in the outdoors, the Adirondacks and the Northern California mountains and Coast, and loved hiking, fishing and discovering the natural world. He relished his homes away from home with friends in California and New Orleans. "He took life as a gift and gave it back twofold in the kindness and comfort he showed to everyone he knew." A Memorial will be held April 22nd at 4:00pm at Drama Guild America, 1601 Broadway (NYC). For details: Robert Sliva 914-462-2779

FOR years now, Ellen Israel of Kentshire Galleries has been collecting fanciful vintage handbags and displaying them, merely for effect, alongside the costume and estate jewelry that her family-owned business is known for. ''It was just to enhance the jewelry, to give it another dimension,'' she said. But when customers began taking an interest in them, Ms. Israel changed her tune. ''I thought: 'This is ridiculous. We should be offering them as well.' ''

HARRIS--Nathaniel C.,Jr. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Montclair Art Museum mark with great sorrow the loss of our beloved friend and President Emeritus Nathaniel C. Harris, Jr., and extend our condolences to Frazeal and her family. Nat lived a truly wonderful life full of grace, honor, service, and dignity. He loved the Montclair Art Museum with all his heart. His commanding eloquence, charm, and empathy guided us through historic expansion and leadership change. Nat's contagious confidence and indefatigable spirit serve as an eternal beacon of light for our entire Museum family.

BENJAMIN--John Townshend, of Oxford, died Sunday, March 22, 2009, at Memorial Hospital at Easton after a brief illness. He was 87. Born June 21, 1921, in Southampton, Long Island, NY, the son of the late Henry Rogers Benjamin, a Mayflower descendant and Dorothy Rennard Benjamin. He attended the Beauvais School and the Buckley School in New York City and concluded his preparatory education at St. Paul's School in Concord, NH with the Class of 1939. After graduating, Mr. Benjamin undertook aeronautical training, both elementary and advanced, at Roosevelt Field on Long Island, NY. Upon England's entry into World War II, he attempted to enlist in the Royal Canadian Air Force but was dismissed after failing to tell the enlistment officer he had not yet reached his majority. Upon entry of the United States into the war, Mr. Benjamin joined the United States Naval Air Force and after graduation from flight school became officer in the U.S. Marine Corps. As a Marine flyer he undertook further training in the San Francisco and Seattle areas and successfully flew 59 missions in the Pacific theatre and was awarded two Distinguished Flying Crosses. Piloting B-25 Mitchell bombers from the Pacific island of Ulithi he undertook numerous long range missions in order to bomb the major Japanese military bases on the island of Truk in the Caroline Islands. Mr. Benjamin was discharged at the end of the war after a brief recovery period at Camp Pendleton hospital from an infection contracted from the jungle climate. After leaving the service with the rank of Captain, Mr. Benjamin was employed by the Boeing Corporation in Seattle, but left the company after approximately two years to participate in the family automobile dealerships in Cali, Columbia. On his return from Cali, Mr. Benjamin managed his own widespread investments in the New York area. He was also active in wildcat oil drilling in the North Texas and Oklahoma regions. In 1958, Mr. Benjamin acquired a wooden 110-foot converted World War II Canadian Sub Chaser which he kept in the Miami River in Florida and on which he and his wife, Patricia Traer Benjamin cruised extensively in the United States, the Bahamas and Central America. In 1963, they relocated to Talbot County, residing first on Old Country Club Road in Easton and then in 1969 acquiring Long Point Farm in Oxford. Mr. Benjamin's marriage to Patty ended in divorce in 1972. He was remarried in 1974 to Florence Mackay of Los Angeles, CA. Mrs. Florence Benjamin preceded Mr. Benjamin in death, dying 1989. Mr. Benjamin loved Talbot County, and especially the shorefront scenery around Long Point Farm. He was active in many community organizations and was a generous benefactor of the YMCA of Talbot County. Mr. Benjamin is survived by his sister, Anne Benjamin Barry of Palm Desert, CA and Southampton, NY; his brother, William Evarts Benjamin II of Manalapan, FL and Mount Desert, Maine; his half-brother, Thomas Hyde Clarke of Cooperstown, NY; and by many nieces and nephews whom he always treated with affection and generosity. He was preceded in death by his older brother, Henry Rogers Benjamin, who died in 2004. Funeral services will be private and limited to the close family and friends. Memorial donations may be made to the YMCA of Talbot County and/or Hyde Hall Foundation, the former family home at Cooperstown, NY.

The change from winter to spring occurred in Manhattan last week. March went out like a lamb and April showers arrived right on cue. Daffodils, forsythias and crocuses bloomed in the parks. Children played games in an empty fountain in front of Bergdorf Goodman. Tourists came back with their luggage piled high. The Bryant Park carousel emerged from its winter slumber just in time for a spruce up: away went the animals to be brushed and curried. Poodles pranced in spring haircuts, fashion showed a stretch of bare leg, and a bicyclist revived a 1939 navy spring coat with a white collar and bows. A straw hat was sighted. A yellow coat echoed the many daffodils, and gray and silver sequins added sparkle to fashion. Sun worshipers returned

THE country's largest companies pump millions and millions of tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere every year, earning billions of dollars while doing so. Last week, two senior House Democrats outlined a plan to cap carbon dioxide emissions and force companies to trade carbon emission credits; this would turn what was long unregulated into a tightly controlled commodity. The Environmental Protection Agency wants a piece of the action as well and is preparing to exert regulatory control over greenhouse gases through the Clean Air Act.

Applying to college can be among the most bewildering experiences in the life of an American teenager. And it's no picnic for that teenager's family, either. That's why The New York Times created this new blog, which we hope will serve as a regular online companion and resource to those of you running this gantlet -- particularly high school juniors and seniors, as well as their parents and counselors, and even admissions officers. We have invited several seniors from high schools around the country to blog about their college selection process as they receive their acceptance letters. Here are excerpts from posts by one New Jersey student. Beth Zak-Cohen

ARON--Raymond J. "Ray", 84, of Bovina, NY passed away February 28, 2009, at home. The son of Michael and Sadie (Mindlin) Aron, he was born May 29, 1924, in Orange, NJ, receiving his education at Newark Art School, Newark College of Engineering and Pratt Institute, graduating post-war, 1948. A World War II US Army Air Corps veteran, he piloted B-17s, flying thirty-three missions, including three 1500 plane assaults on Berlin from England, returning on his 21st birthday as the war ended. He retired as Captain, U.S. Army Air Force Reserve. A graphic designer/visual communicator, Ray's post-war work included the Propaganda Department of the U.S. Department of State; publishing (House Beautiful magazine); packaging design and medical advertising; and work with many great advertising talents including Vic Tresoff, Will Burton, Herb Lubalin, Gene Federico, George Lois, and others. He co-founded Aron & Falcone in 1958 in New Jersey, of which Summit Communications agency was an offshoot. Achieving international recognition for design, packaging and visual communications with Bill Falcone over a twenty year period, he was an original founder and active board member of the N.J. Art Directors Club, and its scholarship programs. He retired in 1995 after free-lancing and a brief teaching career at Kean, Montclair, Fairleigh Dickinson Colleges and DuCret School of Art. Formerly of Maplewood, NJ, Ray moved to Bovina permanently in 1995. Surviving are his former wife of 33 years, Ria (Meyer) Aron; brothers Joel and Jon Aron; first wife, Ann (Bonk) Boslet and their children, Ramsey (Dale) Single, Jay (Heather) Aron, Judy (Tony) Sellaro; grandchildren, Raymond Sellaro and Hana Aron; and other relatives, including the Arons, Mindlins, Socolofs and Smiths. Contributions to Catskill Area Hospice in Delhi, NY will be appreciated.

Re ''Bad News, and More Bad News'' (March 15): I certainly do not want The Times to misrepresent what is happening in the world. But like it or not, the articles in The Times create as well as report the news. Soon we have a self-fulfilling prophecy where all the reported gloom and doom create more gloom and doom.

GANZ--Walter, 87, died at home in Santa Fe, NM on April 2, 2009. Born in Wiesbaden, Germany on December 2, 1921, Walter grew up in Mainz and Stuttgart and left Germany with his family in 1936, ahead of what became the Holocaust. The family settled in Chicago where he attended high school and the University of Chicago. He worked for the City News Bureau as a police reporter until drafted by the US Army in 1943. He became an instructor at a joint US-British intelligence school in London and following D-Day served as a translator, interrogator and intelligence analyst in the headquarters of the 12th Army Group, the top US command on the continent. After his discharge in 1945, he graduated in Political Science and International Relations from the University of Chicago in 1946. He then moved to Washington where he married Ruth Leone in 1947. Their first daughter, Diana, was born in 1949. After almost three years as an editor in the press section of the Civil Affairs Division at the Pentagon, he joined the CIA in 1949. He became the Editor of what is now known as the top secret Daily Intelligence Brief, first for President Truman and then President Eisenhower. A second daughter, Claudia, was born in 1958. He left the CIA in 1960 and moved to Englewood, NJ to operate a family-owned real estate business. In what he considered his greatest accomplishment while in business, he racially integrated the family's apartment houses. During this period he became active in the Civil Rights Campaign, the Ethical Culture movement as well as the Democratic Party. His work with Ethical Culture, a humanist religious movement, led to his becoming president of the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County and Executive Vice President of the American Ethical Union, the national umbrella organization of the Ethical Culture movement. He also served as Democratic Municipal Chairman of Englewood, and then was elected Councilman-at-Large and President of the Englewood City Council in 1971. in 1974, the Ganz family moved to Aspen, CO where they built a house on Red Mountain. Besides doing a lot of skiing, Walter became active in Aspen community affairs and with the Aspen Institute. He was elected to the Board of the Aspen Valley Community Hospital and became Chairman of the Board as well as President of the Board of Colorado West Regional Mental Health Center. Following the death of his older daughter, Diana in 1992 and his wife Ruth's move to the East Coast, he moved to Santa Fe in 1993, where he married Kate Wall in 1998. He also became active in Santa Fe and served on the boards of various community organizations, including the Santa Fe Community Foundation. He is survived by his beloved daughter Claudia of New York City and his wife Kate Wall Ganz of Santa Fe. His first wife, Ruth from whom he was divorced in 1995, died in 2004. In lieu of flowers for Walter Ganz contributions to Southwest Care Center would be gratefully accepted. A memorial in his home will be held at a later date.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Mets and Yankees Follow Well-Worn Path With New Old Parks,'' April 2: The article on retro ballparks did not mention the father of all retro ballparks, Larry Lucchino. PORTNOY--Sara Spiro, passed peacefully at home on April 3. Born January 11, 1926 to Marc Spiro, a schoolteacher and principal, and Gussie Raphael, a homemaker, Sara graduated from Hunter High School '43, Radcliffe College '46 and Columbia Law School '49. A pioneer for women in the law, Sara spent her early professional years with AT&T practicing labor and employment law. She was an active member of the Lexington Democratic Club advocating for political reform for New York City. In 1959, she married Alexander Portnoy. She and Al had two sons, William and Lawrence, and moved to White Plains where Sara volunteered her time for worthy causes. She was an attorney at and a Director of the Legal Aid Society of Westchester, a pro bono counselor to school boards and other community groups, a leader of the Westchester League of Women Voters, and a long-serving member of the City of White Plains Human Rights Commission. In 1972, Al was disabled by heart disease and he passed in 1976. Sara then returned to work, first part time for AT&T and then at Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn in the Labor and Employment Group. She was a partner there until her retirement in 1994. During her years at Proskauer, Sara represented, among others, AT&T, NBC, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, The Metropolitan Opera, The New York Times, the New York City Ballet, The Rockefeller University and the Muscular Dystrophy Association. Sara was also an active participant in the Bar Association of the City of New York, helping to found and chair its Public Service Network programs and serving on its Committees on the Homeless and on Retirement and Pro Bono Activities. On retirement, Sara continued her pro bono and community service efforts advising many non-profits and serving as a Director of the Children's Storefront School in Harlem, the Mosholu Montefiore Community Center in the Bronx and the Muscular Dystrophy Association. She was also a Director of her much loved South Fork Country Club in Amagansett. Sara spent all of her years surrounded by loving family. Her last several years were graced by regular Sunday night dinners and vacations with her growing family, summers in Amagansett which she loved for the good friends, the cool breezes and golf. Her last weeks were spent at home in comfort with family and friends. She is survived by sons William, president of a metals distribution company, and Lawrence, an attorney, daughters-in-law Ellen Rachlin and Philippa Feldman Portnoy and grandchildren Alex, Harry and Zachary Portnoy. She lost her only sibling, a sister Cissie Aidinoff in 1984. Funeral services will be held at Temple Emanu-el of New York, 5th Ave. and 65th St. on April 5, 2009 at 11am. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Mosholu Montefiore Community Center, 3450 Dekalb Avenue, Bronx New York, 10467 (attn: D. Bluestone) or The Children's Storefront, 61 East 129th Street, New York, NY 10035 (attn: D. Brewer).

NOT long ago, I was sitting in the central jury room at the Kings County Supreme Court in Brooklyn, waiting to find out if I would be deciding some poor soul's fate, when I looked at the clock: it was 11:20 a.m. Lunchtime would soon arrive, and I had no idea where to eat. So I did what any modern, technologically with-it wanderer would do. I turned to Twitter, the microblogging Web site that lets you post very short messages online and is, for better and for worse, growing at an incredible rate.

Re ''Those Persistent Anonymous Sources'' (March 22): In every job I have had in 45 years of journalism, anonymous sources have done their best to obscure and mislead to serve their own (or their bosses') interests, hiding disinformation behind a cloak of anonymity. Best is to treat them just as you would treat an anonymous letter: that is where reporting should start, not stop.

THE NEWS The Justice Department moved to void the conviction it won in October against former Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska after misconduct by prosecutors was uncovered. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Stevens, a Republican who was narrowly defeated for re-election days after the conviction, will not be retried, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said. Government lawyers said prosecutors had concealed evidence that raised significant doubts about the charges. Earlier instances of prosecutorial misconduct nearly led to a mistrial. The case had to do with gifts and services Mr. Stevens received but was accused of not reporting as required, including work on his home.

ON any other April 1, a headline that reads ''Rick Wagoner and Bob Lutz Leave General Motors'' might have seemed like one of those April Fool's spoof stories. But that was the bulletin of the day. G.M.'s chairman and product czar have, shockingly, left their respective offices within a day or two of each other. So when the New York auto show opens to the news media this week, G.M. will be introducing a new leadership team: Fritz Henderson, a G.M. management mainstay, as the chief executive, and a nonexecutive chairman, Kent Kresa, a retired aerospace executive.

FROM the growing clamor among shareholders for a greater say on pay, to the public excoriation of A.I.G. executives, the spotlight has been on executive compensation, perhaps as never before. The large bonuses paid to executives, particularly in the financial industry, have come under fire as having helped fuel the credit crisis. Yet even amid economic turmoil, some companies keep increasing pay for their top executives. While some on the following list saw their pay decline, as a group these executives saw their pay climb by an average of 21 percent. Granted, many companies we have become used to seeing on lists of the highest pay, particularly in the financial industry, were knocked out of the running last year, or even out of existence, like Lehman Brothers, whose chief was Richard Fuld. And there is one generous benefit that, for now, few executives can take advantage of. Because of generally falling stock prices, the options awards that form a large part of most executives' pay are now largely valueless -- at least until stocks rise again.

ENGELSON--Miriam (Mim), died March 30, 2009 at age 87 with her family present in California. Beloved wife of Howard for 67 years. Devoted mother of Carol, the late Ellen, Kathy and Erik; grandmother of Alexandra, Susan and Elisabeth; and great-grandmother of Chloe, Samantha, and Luke. Mim spent short periods in Florida, Georgia, and Indiana, and lived most of her life in New York. Already a grandmother, she proudly earned her B.A. degree in English and Teaching License from Queens College in NYC at age 58, and went on to teach in Great Neck, NY. Later she became the special assistant to the Japanese Ambassador to the United Nations and worked at the NY Metropolitan Museum of Art. Howard and Mim moved to Boston, where she volunteered at the Boston Athenaeum, and then to Half Moon Bay, CA. She served for a decade as a docent at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. She will be greatly missed for her love, spunk, flair, smarts, and savvy. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Osteoporosis Foundation.
Television Ginia Bellafante

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Voice of Yankee Stadium Could Retire Soon,'' April 2: Bob Sheppard's quiet dignity announcing at Yankee Stadium made us feel that seeing the ballgame was important, and it was. The game taught us that it is all about the team and not any individual player.

ORBACH--Elaine Cancilla. The Board of Directors, Medical Advisory Board and Staff of The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration mourn the passing of our generous supporter and good friend Elaine Cancilla Orbach. Thanks to her dedication to our mission, The Eye-Bank has been able to reach millions of New Yorkers with a message about the role eye donation plays in giving those in need the beautiful gift of sight. Her vibrant presence will be so greatly missed. Marilyn L. Castaldi, President, Board of Directors Sid Mandelbaum, M.D., Chairman, Medical Advisory Board Patricia Dahl, Executive Director/CEO

BIG corporations, buffeted by widespread economic pain and heightened scrutiny of lush compensation packages, appear to be paying attention to a longstanding complaint from shareholders: When it comes to executive pay, greed -- even the appearance of it -- is not good. Executive compensation for the highest-paid chief executives at public companies fell in 2008, the first such downturn in five years. And the bottom dropped out of the bonus pool, the incentive that angered investors after the controversial bonus payouts at the American International Group.

BRESLAU Lawrence (Larry) D.,died at home Monday, March 23, 2009. Larry was born on December 18, 1930 in Albany, New York to Lillian and Ted Nachison. He received a B.A. from Cornell University in 1952, and an M.D. in 1959; a member of the first graduating class of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, New York City. This was followed by an internship and residency in psychiatry at Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich, and University Hospitals of Cleveland. A well-known psychiatrist, Dr. Breslau practiced in Cleveland from 1960 to 1987. In Baltimore he practiced until his death. While he maintained a private practice in general psychiatry through most of his career, his major contributions to the profession were in the area of geriatric psychiatry. A pioneer in the psychiatric treatment of the aged, Dr. Breslau described the "exaggerated helplessness" syndrome, which provided a new understanding of psychiatric disorders in the elderly, especially among those with early senile dementia and Alzheimer's disease. His work contributed to the development of geriatric psychiatry as a distinct sub-specialty. Dr. Breslau taught and mentored future generations of psychiatry residents, emphasizing treatment of the entire human being. Patients and staff reported his passion for psychiatry, and describe that his approach was guided by the common strains of warmth, gentleness, compassion, and frequent humor. Dr. Breslau's greatest influence was the respect and love of patients and colleagues who worked with him. Dr. Breslau is survived by his wife, Erica Sharp, his former wife Naomi Zeidel, and their three children Jonathan and Lisa; Daniel and Margaret; Joshua Breslau and Elizabeth Miller; seven grandchildren; and a sister Judith Moore. Contributions may be made to Kol HaLev, P.O. Box 16399, Baltimore, MD 21210 or Johns Hopkins University, sent to Johns Hopkins Medicine Fund, 100 N. Charles St., Suite 437, Baltimore, MD 21201.

Re ''No Comment. But You Didn't Hear It From Me'' (March 29): I'm the part-time writing coach at the Washington bureau of The Associated Press. I share your concern about the ubiquity of quotes from anonymous sources. One way to curtail their use is to insist that reporters paraphrase what they use from sources who demand anonymity. If the source's quote contains real information, paraphrasing it won't be difficult; reporters do that all the time. But if the quote is propaganda, no good reporter would have an easy time putting it in his own words.

KEIRANS--John Peter, died March 31, 2009. Born January 30, 1952 in New York, NY, John is survived by his beloved wife, Kathleen McHugh, cherished daughters Maeve and Sinead, brother Patrick, and aunt Margaret Keirans. John retired following twenty years in the United States Secret Service. Visitation will be at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, New York, NY 10128 on Friday, April 3, 2009 from 2:00 to 4:00pm and from 6:00 to 8:00pm. Memorial Service will be held on Monday, April 6, 2009 at the United Nations Church Center, 777 United Nations Plaza (across from the United Nations at 44th St. and 1st Ave.), New York, NY at 6:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Colgate University (Hamilton, NY) or Trinity School (New York, NY) in John's name, in honor of the boundless pride John took in the accomplishments of his daughters.

EGAN--Robert J. Longtime resident of Greenwich Village since 1957, died at the age of 91 on March 26, 2009. He is survived by his wife Adele Egan and sister Nae O'Connor and brother Paul Egan, several nieces and nephews from Springfield, MA where he was born. He served five years in the US Army Air Force during WWII. He organized the 11th Street Action Block Association in the mid 1970s with the help of several residents on the block he had several trees planted. He started newspaper recycling on the block with the help of Girl Scouts. He was an artist, a translator and in his youth toured as an actor in Shakespeare's plays. He loved music and was a radio DJ in Texas during the early 1950s. He attended the University of Southern California and the Arts Students League in New York City.

FOR the last few months, I've been getting e-mail messages from Ford public relations, alerting me to the new Fusion Hybrid's excellent fuel mileage and its Facebook campaign for the upcoming Fiesta. But it's tough getting good news out when there's so much desperate news out there. So it doesn't surprise me that Alan Mulally, Ford's chief executive, and Bill Ford, the executive chairman, wanted to get their word out on the same day that President Obama issued an ultimatum to G.M. and Chrysler.

THE auction later this month of Michael Jackson's personal belongings has piqued the interest of fashion followers. Among the 2,000 lots from Neverland Ranch are the kind of broad-shouldered jackets and crystal-adorned accessories that have, in no indirect way, served as inspiration for the insanely coveted Balmain collections. And many are likely to be much lower in price than Balmain's. A rhinestone belt worn by Mr. Jackson on his 1979 Destiny tour has an estimated value of $400 to $600; a black wool military jacket (right) worn to visit a Romanian orphanage -- the photo to prove it, included -- is set at $800 to $1,200; and Mr. Jackson's crystal-studded gloves (not seen at Balmain, but fabulous no less) have an estimate of $1,500 each.

Having staged his share of aerial dogfights in an outer space movie or two, George Lucas will soon be pitting warplanes of a different era against each other in “Red Tails,” a fictional film about the Tuskegee Airmen of World War II that his Lucasfilm studio is producing. In a release on Monday, Lucasfilm said that the movie, about the all-black crew, would star Terrence Howard (of “Iron Man” and “Hustle and Flow”), Cuba Gooding Jr. (“Jerry Maguire”), Nate Parker (“The Secret Life of Bees”) and Bryan Cranston (“Breaking Bad”). Other cast members include Tristan Wilds (“The Wire,” “90210”), Cliff Smith (better known as Method Man) and Ne-Yo. The film is to be directed by Anthony Hemingway (a veteran of “The Wire” and “Battlestar Galactica”) and written by John Ridley (who had a hand in “Three Kings”). A release date was not announced. It’s the first Lucasfilm feature film unrelated to the “Star Wars” and “Indiana Jones” franchises in 15 years.
“South Pacific” looks good for its age.

A Hong Kong computer technician pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges that he had illegally copied and circulated explicit photos from an actor’s hard drive in a case that scandalized the Asian entertainment industry, Agence France-Presse reported. In 2008, Sze Ho-chun, an employee of a Kowloon computer shop, was among nine people arrested by the Hong Kong police after photos and videos began appearing on the Internet depicting Edison Chen, a singer, actor and record producer, in sexually explicit scenes with what appeared to be several of Asia’s best known pop stars. At the start of a 10-day trial at the Kowloon City Magistracy, prosecutors said that Mr. Sze obtained about 1,300 photos of Mr. Chen when the singer brought his computer to a repair shop in 2006, and that Mr. Tze put the images on CDs for other customers. At the time of the arrests, Mr. Chen apologized for the harm the photos may have caused and asked anyone possessing them on their computers to delete them.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Monday morning.

Advertisements placed by Warner Brothers warned Bollywood film producers not to proceed with a planned Hindi remake of “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button,” Agence France-Press reported. Last month, The Times of India said that the Bollywood actors Akshay Kumar and Aishwarya Rai would star in a film called “Action Replay,” about a man who ages in reverse. The plot appears to mirror “Benjamin Button,” the David Fincher film that starred Brad Pitt as a man who is born elderly and dies as a baby; that movie was co-produced by Warner Brothers and Paramount. In the advertisements, which appeared in The Times of India and local trade publications on Monday, a New Delhi law firm said that it would pursue legal action against any film made “either in English or Hindi or other language, having a similar script, screenplay or story line or character sketches or interplay of characters or sequence of events” to “Benjamin Button,” according to Agence France-Press.

As previous experience has taught us, some performers cannot be best represented by words on a page. Their worldviews are just too expansive, their thoughts about the artistic life and the search for truth too all-encompassing to be consolidated into a few quotations for a newspaper article or a blog post.

The latest extension of the SoHo Playhouse’s production of “Krapp, 39,” its one-man show starring Michael Laurence as a man fixated on his 39th birthday and Samuel Beckett’s “Krapp’s Last Tape,” is good news and bad news for Mr. Laurence. The playhouse said that the show would play through May 31, which means that Mr. Laurence — who is also understudying the roles of Peter and Simeon in the coming Broadway transfer of “Desire Under the Elms” — will be doing double duty for a few weeks when that show opens on April 27. As a result, “Krapp, 39,” will now be performed on Thursday through Sunday at 5 p.m., and on Sunday and Monday at 7:30 p.m. so Mr. Laurence can fulfill both obligations.

CINCINNATI -- Francisco Rodriguez prepares for work alone. He sits in front of his locker, his noise-canceling headphones plugged in, and watches the flurry of pre-game activity while hardly moving. Even though he cannot be certain that he will be called up, Rodriguez knows when he will pitch. The ninth inning is his domain, and Rodriguez needed only 10 pitches to dispatch of the Reds on Monday in closing out the Mets' 2-1 victory.

The Los Angeles County Museum of Art and Los Angeles Art Weekend came together this past Saturday night to host a party in conjunction with the museum's current exhibit, "Art of Two Germanys: Cold War Culture." Nearly 300 paintings, sculptures, photographs and installations were featured by 120 artists, Martin Kippenberger and Gerhard Richter among them, but the real star of the night was Lacma itself. The museum's entrance features Chris Burden's ''Urban Light'' installation, which incorporates more than 200 restored cast-iron streetlamps from Los Angeles County -- which, fittingly, feels like a movie set. Lacma's outdoor lobby was transformed into a nightclub, albeit one with an eclectic crowd of art lovers, scenesters and those who looked to be German tourists, hosted by the Berlin D.J./V.J.'s Safy Sniper and Christine Lang. Billed as "Late Night Art," the evening featured music and readings along with the exhibit, which runs through April 19.

Last month, the Terrafugia Transition made its first flight at Plattsburgh International Airport in New York. The Transition didn't break any speed records -- it's powered by a simple 1.3-liter 4-cylinder aircraft engine with just 100 horsepower -- but what made the flight so special was what happened before and after the flight -- it was driven on public roads.

Thinking of buying an apartment in NYC? If you're lucky enough to answer "yes" to that question, you might want to try our new Real Estate API. Using sales data from the NYC Department of Finance (going back to 2003) and Times classified listings (back to 2007), we've created an interesting database for these uncertain times. Have you ever wondered what the average apartment is worth in your current neighborhood? Or what you'll pay for a similar apartment if you decide to move to Brooklyn? This API will help you answer those questions and more.

A while ago I was e-brainstorming with Mark about what to do with some fragrant chanterelles he'd bought. Eggs and mushrooms are a combination that's hard to beat, so I suggested sautéing them and tossing them with spaetzle -- those appealing little blobs of egg/milk/flour batter, but Mark was in Paris, where the bread is so good that adding other starches seemed to him like a waste of effort. Me, I'd go for the extra starch anytime, but I saw his point. So, I said, why not tear up some of that good bread, crisp the shreds in olive oil or butter and mix them with the cooked mushrooms? Like Spanish (not Tex-Mex) migas. Kind of.

I never assumed that being a background actor would impart any amount of prestige to my protracted period of unemployment. But I did expect a certain degree of professionalism, if not dignity, to the experience, which, after 10 hours on a shabby set in Queens, I can declare with assurance was devoid of either. My somewhat whimsical, always irrational friend Colin had recommended that I register with a Manhattan casting agency, as he had done when he was unemployed, as an entertaining pick-me-up until I found another editing job. But I quickly realized the work would be neither entertaining nor a pick-me-up: my first open call was rank with a desperation for fame and fortune among the other extras. Pimply young post-grads nervously checked their portfolio photos while a few heavily made-up women unabashedly took every opportunity to flirt with the agency associate.

In his review of "The Letters of Samuel Beckett" in yesterday's Book Review, Joseph O'Neill said about Beckett the correspondent, "He is capable of great enthusiasm - for Austen, Sade, Sainte-Beuve, Schopenhauer - and for all his pessimism and bile he is a fundamental enemy of cynicism." Anthony Cronin, in his biography "Samuel Beckett: The Last Modernist," points out that "Schopenhauer was an important discovery for him, perhaps indeed the most important literary discovery of his life." According to Cronin, "what attracted him in the first place was Schopenhauer's 'intellectual justification of unhappiness - the greatest that has ever been attempted.'"

Perched 4,200 feet in the southern Himalayas, the Nauni-Majgoan Panchayat, a village council overseeing nine hamlets in India's Himachal Pradesh state, is on the tipping point of climate change. On the peaks above, the Chhota Shigri glacier has been receding at an accelerated pace; on the road below, the village of Solan has morphed into a small city replete with concrete office buildings and business lunches. Demand for water - to spin hydroelectric generators, to irrigate crops and for residential use - is soaring throughout the area.

Hollywood correspondent Brooks Barnes takes a look in today's New York Times at Pixar's latest animated feature, "Up." It's become almost an annual ritual for Wall Street analysts and merchandisine executives to bemoan Pixar's penchant for ambitious and artsy fare. Would people go see "Ratatouille," a movie about a rat working in a kitchen? Would they go see "WALL-E," about a robot alone on a garbage-strewn planet with almost no dialogue? Both times, they fretted, and both times the people showed up. And both films won Oscars for best animated film. This time, "Up" is about an old codger who sends a flock of balloons up his chimney and floats his house away, with a portly boy stowing away. Will audiences show up and buy merchandise? Does anyone dare to bet against Pixar?

As a possible peace offering in the long-simmering New York-New Jersey feud, the Tribeca Film Festival will host the first screenings of the documentary "Bon Jovi: When We Were Beautiful," about the Sayreville, N.J.-born rock band. It will be shown as a work in progress on April 29, April 30 and May 2. (The band and its hair will be performing at the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival on May 2.) The documentary, directed by Phil Griffin, includes interviews and behind-the-scenes footage from the band's Lost Highway tour. Among other music-themed films, this year's Tribeca festival will also include the New York premiere of Spike Lee's documentary of the rock musical "Passing Strange." The festival runs April 22 through May 3.

The Pamplemousse will not run in the Kentucky Derby next month, although the colt’s racing career is not over. The Pamplemousse was scratched because of a tendon problem hours before Saturday’s $750,000 Santa Anita Derby, in which he was the 9-5 morning-line favorite.

Paul Casey won the Shell Houston Open in Humble, Tex., for his first PGA Tour victory, beating J. B. Holmes with a bogey on the first playoff hole. Casey, a 31-year-old Englishman, has nine international victories but had never won in the United States. Holmes hooked his tee shot into the pond on the playoff hole. He needed a win to earn a trip to this week’s Masters; he is the only player from last year’s Ryder Cup who failed to qualify. Casey bogeyed the 18th hole in regulation, completing a round of 72 and tying Holmes (69) at 11 under par.

HARRIS--Nathaniel C.,Jr. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Montclair Art Museum mark with great sorrow the loss of our beloved friend and President Emeritus Nathaniel C. Harris, Jr., and extend our condolences to Frazeal and her family. Nat lived a truly wonderful life full of grace, honor, service, and dignity. He loved the Montclair Art Museum with all his heart. His commanding eloquence, charm, and empathy guided us through historic expansion and leadership change. Nat's contagious confidence and indefatigable spirit serve as an eternal beacon of light for our entire Museum family.

PARKER--Seena. The Workmen's Circle family mourns the passing of our cherished friend and activist. Her life and our organization were intertwined from her early days as a camper in Kinder Ring, a student in our shuln and a branch activist, to her later role as a many-term member of the NEB and Vice President. She served on and chaired many committees, presently as Chair of the NY Triple Benefits Committee. A retired NYC physical education teacher, she worked on the waterfront and as Cultural Director in Kinder Ring for many years. Our devoted friend will be sorely missed in our councils and activities. Sincerest condolences to son Jeremy, sister Maxine Greenspan, special friend Barry Press and the family. Robert Kaplan-President Ann Toback-Exec Dir.

With so much data in the annals of baseball, so many games and players and sets of skills, it is tempting to think everything can be quantified and each player can be compared with someone else. It is rare to find an outlier, a player unlike any who has come before. The Yankees have a big one in C. C. Sabathia, who makes his regular-season debut for the team on Monday afternoon in Baltimore. The Yankees gave him the most money ever guaranteed to a pitcher -- $161 million for seven years -- without any precedent to study.

Bobby Vaughn is from Santa Cruz, legendary in California for its renegade surf culture and rebel wave riders. Mr. Vaughn says that the Rockaways in Queens have all the ingredients to be the next Santa Cruz: good waves, public housing projects and a growing surf culture. His main problem with the Rockaway surf scene is that it has not embraced its inner gangster.

EVDOKIMOVA-GREGORI--Eva, on April 3, 2009 in New York City. The world has lost and mourns deeply and forever not only universally recognized as one of the greatest ballerinas in the history of classical ballet, having the rare title of Prima Ballerina Assoluta, but equally recognizing as having such extraordinary personal qualities that were so pure, so generous, so admirable, so loving, so egoless with an endless spirit of good will, compassion and joy. Her refinement had no equal. Her list of professional and personal accomplishments can be found on a soon to be established website. Contact: evaevdokimova@aol.com for information. Eva Evdokimova-Gregori leaves behind her cherished husband Michael S. Gregori of Manhattan, her mother-in-law Katherine Gregori of Manhattan, her brother-in-law Peter Gregori, her nephew, Jacob Gregori and extended Gregori family and loving cousins, her loving and dear friends who Eva was eternally grateful to. A celebration of the life and work of Prima Ballerina Assoluta, Eva Evdokimova is being organized with all of the major ballet companies worldwide as well as a new autobiography and a trove of never released videos and films. A private service will be held. Interment at Woodlawn Cemetery. Thank you for everything, you are my heart and soul. I was so fortunate my love. I will always be with you.

Hours after North Korea's missile test, President Obama on Sunday called for new United Nations sanctions and laid out a new approach to American nuclear disarmament policy -- one intended to strengthen the United States and its allies in halting proliferation. ''In a strange turn of history, the threat of global nuclear war has gone down, but the risk of a nuclear attack has gone up,'' Mr. Obama told a huge crowd in Prague's central square. ''Black market trade in nuclear secrets and nuclear materials abound. The technology to build a bomb has spread.''

SMITH--Philo, of Greenwich, CT, 81, founder of Philo Smith and Co., Inc., of Stamford, died on April 1, 2009 at Stamford Hospital of severe pneumonia. A graduate of Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, NJ, he received his Bachelor's degree from Yale University, and his MBA from New York University Graduate School of Business Administration, now called the Stern School. Mr. Smith started his career at Lord Abbett & Co., and held positions with the J. Henry Schroeder Banking Corporation and with Dominick & Dominick as an insurance stock specialist before founding the investment banking firm in Stamford that bears his name in 1962. He is survived by his wife Andie and by three sons: Gregory N. Smith of Peekskill, NY; Jonathan C. Smith of Ridgefield, CT; and Adam T. Smith of San Francisco, CA. A fourth son, Timothy T. Smith, predeceased him. Mr. Smith is also survived by two stepdaughters, Victoria Keziah of Boulder, CO, and Dr. Amy Kindred of Boston, MA, and by seven grandchildren, the oldest of whom, Robert C. Smith of Norwalk, CT, is Chairman of Touchpoint Securities. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church in Greenwich on Tuesday, April 7, at 11am In lieu of flowers please make charitable donations to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation at http://pdf.org

Phone Applications for Blind Users Touch-screen phones may seem like a forbidding barrier for blind users, who often rely on tactile clues to feel their way around. But a pair of engineers at Google, T.V. Raman, who is blind, and Charles Chen, who is not, have developed software that makes the touch-screen T-Mobile G1, which uses Google's Android software, more accessible to blind users. They hope the technology will also be useful to anyone, like drivers, who needs to operate a phone without looking at the screen.

Izzo acknowledges that, on paper, this rematch is a mismatch.

10 P.M. (13, 49) HOUSE OF LIFE: THE OLD JEWISH CEMETERY IN PRAGUE Crowded with 12 layers of graves and some 100,000 bodies, the Old Jewish Cemetery in Prague, above, has survived Nazi occupation, Communist neglect, pogroms, floods, fires, assimilation and an urban clearing project that destroyed much of the ancient Jewish Quarter it once served. This documentary collaboration between the filmmaker Allan Miller and the artist Mark Podwal traverses the past and present of a cemetery that Arno Parik, a curator at the Jewish Museum in Prague, calls the ''Westminster Abbey of the Jewish people.'' Claire Bloom narrates. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYEliot Spitzer is interviewed. Mary Ann Zoellner and Alicia Ybarbo discuss their book, ''Today's Moms''; Kathy Ireland talks about her book ''Real Solutions for Busy Moms.'' Judith Owen performs.

LEVY--Joel H. The Forward Association, its board and staff, mourn the sudden and untimely death of our colleague, board member and cherished friend Joel Levy on April 3 in Washington, DC. As our radio counsel for over three decades, he conceived and engineered a series of radio asset sales that have enabled us to continue publishing the Yiddish Forverts, now beginning its 113th year, to launch the English-language Forward in 1990, and, more recently, to assure the Forward's independence and growth as an award-winning weekly and web site covering today's Jewish story. Our condolences to Felicia, his dear wife, and to their children, David, Elizabeth and Seth, and their families. May his memory be for a blessing. Jacob Morowitz, President Samuel Norich, Exec. Dir.

LADY SOVEREIGN ''Jigsaw'' (Midget/EMI) At one point in ''Guitar,'' a track on this, her second album, Lady Sovereign complains aloud about the duties of her office. ''I feel like not tryin' to do/What I'm supposed to do today,'' she raps. ''A couple of interviews, a photo shoot/A show to do, promote new tunes.'' For some reason, she muses, it isn't all as fun as it seemed just yesterday, when her image was on a billboard looming over Times Square.

On a sun-kissed February afternoon while golfing with some Mets teammates in Port St. Lucie, Fla., Johan Santana lightened the mood of an already casual round. As Oliver Pérez confused a beverage cart operator by speaking gibberish, Santana moseyed over and acted as his interpreter. Pérez got his Diet Pepsi and a Snickers bar. ''One of the funniest things I've ever seen,'' said John Maine, who called Santana one of the funniest people on the team.

In a legal response filed in a Los Angeles court on Monday, the British rock band Coldplay denied that its song “Viva La Vida” had illegally copied portions of the song “If I Could Fly” by the rock guitarist Joe Satriani, The Associated Press reported. In December, Mr. Satriani filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against Coldplay, which in February won the song of the year Grammy Award for “Viva La Vida.” At the time the suit was filed, Coldplay issued a statement saying the resemblance between the songs was “entirely coincidental” and that “Joe Satriani is a great musician.” But in its legal filing, the band has changed its tune, saying that “If I Could Fly” should not receive copyright protection because it “lacks originality,” The A.P. said.

The J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles said Tuesday that it would return to Italy a fragment of an ancient Roman fresco that had been in the museum’s collection since 1996. In a news release, Michael Brand, the director of the Getty, said that the museum decided to return the fragment, which dates to the 1st century B.C. and depicts a landscape scene, after seeing a published image of another fragment of the fresco being returned to Italy by a private collector. “This image placed our landscape fresco alongside this newly repatriated fragment,” Mr. Brand said a statement. “Seeing these fragments together made it clear that the two were part of the same wall design and belonged together.” The Getty said that its fragment had been removed from its display at the Getty Villa and would be returned to the Italian Ministry of Culture in May.

In an era of economic uncertainty and consolidation, even the short story could use a little additional support: the Anchor Books imprint of Random House said that it had partnered with the literary and human rights organization the PEN American Center and would rename its annual “O. Henry Prize Stories” collection the “PEN/O. Henry Prize Stories.” In a news release, Anchor Books said that the new name would take effect with the 2009 story collection, which is edited by Laura Furman and features selections juried by A.S. Byatt, Tim O’Brien and Anthony Doerr and will be published on May 5. The first collection of O. A new wooden water tank went up last week atop 202 West 40th Street in Manhattan, through the efforts of the Rosenwach Tank Company of Long Island City, Queens. Every building at least 80 feet tall in New York City must have a water reservoir to meet the fire codes, and water tanks are also used to provide water service. A large office building can use 40,000 gallons of water an hour, Rosenwach says.

MUMBAI | As Mumbai's classical architecture gives way to skyscrapers, the curious traveler needs to be quick to see those parts of old Bombay that still remain. There were once Iranian cafes at nearly every corner in south Mumbai. Originated by Iranian immigrants in the 19th century, they provided cheap food and good company in a leisurely - though often rather grimy - setting. Now many have vanished, and others have been converted into bars.

As linguistic phenomena go, I've always been fascinated - and baffled - by the existence of Cockney rhyming slang: who comes up with these rhymes, and how do they become widespread enough to enter common usage? Top executives at the large Indian outsourcing company Satyam Computer Services did not act alone when they committed a multibillion-dollar fraud that left the business struggling for survival: They apparently enlisted a team in the company's finance department to help them, The New York Times's Heather Timmons writes.

Dermot Mannion resigned Monday as chief executive of Aer Lingus, ending a four-year tenure during which he took the Irish airline public and battled to keep it out of the hands of an aggressive rival, Ryanair, but also failed to lift its share price, The New York Times's Caroline Brothers reported.

Sean Miller of Xavier has accepted the head coaching job at Arizona, ending the Wildcats’ sometimes frustrating search for a high-profile replacement for the Hall of Famer Lute Olson. The university announced the hiring after a confusing few hours in which it was first reported by several news media outlets that Miller had turned down the job. Miller, 40, was scheduled to be introduced Tuesday at a news conference in Tucson. He led the Musketeers to the Round of 8 of the N.C.A.A. tournament last year and received a contract extension through the 2017-18 season. Xavier reached the Round of 16 this season. ¶Memphis has hired Josh Pastner, an assistant under John Calipari, as the Tigers’ coach. The university scheduled a news conference for Tuesday to introduce Pastner, 31. Calipari left Memphis for Kentucky last week after nine seasons with the Tigers. Pastner, who is regarded as a top recruiter, worked one year under Calipari after six years as an assistant at Arizona. memphis.
In her WTA Tour debut, Madison Keys, 14, upset Alla Kudryavtseva of Russia, 7-5, 6-4, in the opening round of The MPS Group Championships in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla.Kudryavtseva is ranked 81st.
Baseball will be adding a women’s component to its bid to be reinstated for the 2016 Olympics, after failing to unite with women’s softball.

Manu Ginóbili of the San Antonio Spurs will be out for the rest of the season after scans showed his injured right ankle had become worse. Ginóbili missed 19 games after the All-Star break before coming back late last month.

Quarterback Jeff Garcia agreed to a deal with the Oakland Raiders, who said Garcia would immediately join the starter JaMarcus Russell in the team’s off-season program. Garcia, 39, spent the past two seasons with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, starting 24 games and leading them to the playoffs. He was not re-signed.

Richard Petty, the 71-year-old king of stock-car racing, said he would field a car in the Indianapolis 500 for the first time on May 24. John Andretti will drive the car, which will carry Petty’s famous No. 43 and a red and blue paint scheme similar to the cars Petty raced. Petty won 200 races at Nascar’s top level but never competed in the Indy 500 because it was held on the same day as the Coca-Cola 600. He attended the Indy 500 for the first time last year.

Maybe it's our renewed appreciation of Memphis design or the profusion of '80s-inspired looks that have been showing up on the runways lately (see: Marc Jacobs, London Fashion Week), but I was suddenly and pleasantly reminded of the highly amusing antics of the Mexican trio Flans. The girls made their big-haired debut in 1985 and had a strong five-year run, thanks in part to their out-of-control looks. (It can't be a coincidence that one of their biggest hits, titled "No Controles," tackled the pressing issue of sartorial emancipation.) What's not to love about Latin America's answer to Bananarama?

A native of Severna Park, Md., Teixeira signed an eight-year, $180 million contract with the Yankees last winter, rejecting an offer from the Orioles for less money and fewer years. Predictably, he was jeered as a sellout.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Juilliard String Quartet at Alice Tully Hall tonight, using information from Juilliard, misstated the violinist Joel Smirnoff’s history with the quartet. He joined in 1986 and has been first violinist since 1997. He has not been first violinist since 1974.

Because of an editing error, a Sports of The Times column on Saturday, about the new ballparks for the Yankees and the Mets, erroneously attributed, in some editions, an observation to Joe Girardi, the Yankees’ manager, after his team won an exhibition game in its new home. He did not say, “The bleacher fans chanted the names of the starters; Ronan Tynan sang ‘God Bless America’ in person; and Sinatra delivered ‘New York, New York’ after the last out, although not in person.” Those were the columnist’s own words.

An article on Monday about the growing number of the unemployed seeking work as film and television extras in New York misstated part of the name of one Manhattan casting agency in some editions. It is the Extra Talent Agency, not Extra Talent Management.

An article on Thursday about restrictions on campaign advertisements by challengers to the incumbent mayor of Sochi, the Russian city that is the site of the 2014 Winter Olympic Games, misspelled the surname of a representative of Golos, an election-monitoring group, who said the restrictions violate the principle of free elections. He is Andrei Y. Buzin, not Bunin.

A capsule summary on Monday for a music review about two concerts by the St. Louis Symphony, including one at Zankel Hall where the conductor, David Robertson, filled in for an absent singer, misstated the date of that concert. While the orchestra also performed on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, the concert at which Mr. Robertson sang was on Friday night, not Saturday.

Carrie Underwood, above, was the big winner at Sunday night’s Academy of Country Music Awards, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Underwood, the former “American Idol” champion, was the first woman to receive the academy’s entertainer of the year award since the Dixie Chicks took the prize in 2000, denying Kenny Chesney’s bid to capture the honor for a fifth consecutive year. Other winners at the ceremony, which was held at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas, included Taylor Swift, who won album of the year for her second album, “Fearless”; Jamey Johnson, who picked up song of the year for “In Color”; Trace Adkins, who was awarded single of the year for “You’re Gonna Miss This”; and Sugarland, which won vocal duo of the year, unseating the frequent victors, Brooks & Dunn, in that category.
The TriBeCa Film Festival will host the first screenings of the documentary “Bon Jovi: When We Were Beautiful.”

David Byrne, above, will perform a free concert at the Prospect Park Bandshell in Brooklyn on June 8 at the opening night of the Celebrate Brooklyn! festival, the event’s producers said Monday in a news release. Mr. Byrne, who is on a world tour called “Songs of David Byrne and Brian Eno,” will play the concert after the festival’s Green Gala, held annually by the nonprofit arts organization BRIC Arts to support free summer performances in Prospect Park and promote environmentally friendly activities. The concert is scheduled for 8 p.m. and admission is free, though a $3 donation is suggested. The festival will announce its full lineup on May 4.

A Hong Kong computer technician pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges that he had illegally copied and circulated explicit photos from an actor’s hard drive in a case that scandalized the Asian entertainment industry, Agence France-Presse reported. In 2008 Sze Ho Chun, an employee of a Kowloon computer shop, was among nine people arrested by the Hong Kong police after photos and videos began appearing on the Internet depicting Edison Chen, above, a singer, actor and record producer, in sexually explicit scenes with what appeared to be several of Asia’s best known pop stars. At the start of the trial at the Kowloon City Magistracy prosecutors said that Mr. Sze obtained about 1,300 photos of Mr. Chen when the singer took his computer to a repair shop in 2006, and that Mr. Sze put the images on CDs for other customers. At the time of the arrests Mr. Chen apologized for the harm the photos may have caused and asked anyone possessing them on their computers to delete them.
CBS’s broadcast of the Academy of Country Music Awards attracted 14.8 million viewers on Sunday night, an increase of 3 million over last year and easily the night’s largest audience.

The latest extension of the SoHo Playhouse’s production of “Krapp, 39,” its one-man show starring Michael Laurence as a man fixated on his 39th birthday and Samuel Beckett’s “Krapp’s Last Tape,” is good news and bad news for Mr. Laurence. The playhouse said that the show would be performed through May 31, which means that Mr. Laurence — who is also understudying the roles of Peter and Simeon in the coming Broadway transfer of “Desire Under the Elms” — will be doing double duty for a few weeks when that show opens on April 27. As a result “Krapp, 39,” will now be shown Thursday through Sunday at 5 p.m., and on Sunday and Monday at 7:30 p.m. so Mr. Laurence can fulfill both obligations.

On a No. 2 train heading to Brooklyn one evening last week, a disheveled man stepped onto the car and began a speech with that phrase familiar to all New York subway riders: ''Excuse me, ladies and gentlemen!'' But instead of asking for money outright, he held up a white plastic bag and offered sandwiches to any hungry people on the train. If anyone wished to donate to his sandwich-distribution cause, he added, he'd happily take cash.

HARRIS--Nathaniel C.,Jr. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Montclair Art Museum mark with great sorrow the loss of our beloved friend and President Emeritus Nathaniel C. Harris, Jr., and extend our condolences to Frazeal and her family. Nat lived a truly wonderful life full of grace, honor, service, and dignity. He loved the Montclair Art Museum with all his heart. His commanding eloquence, charm, and empathy guided us through historic expansion and leadership change. Nat's contagious confidence and indefatigable spirit serve as an eternal beacon of light for our entire Museum family.

Los Angeles Dodgers center fielder Matt Kemp was gazing around the visitors' clubhouse Monday afternoon, marveling at how his new contact lenses had improved his eyesight. After he was recently found to have astigmatism, the new lenses have allowed him to decipher the rotation on pitches more quickly. But a baseball is not the only thing that has come into sharper focus for Kemp. So have the Dodgers' prospects.
