When the Yankees opened the season in Baltimore on Monday, Alex Rodriguez, baseball's highest-paid player, was riding a stationary bike at a high-priced athletic club in Aspen, Colo. For Rodriguez, this was certainly a most atypical opening day. Then again, it fits right in with his odd spring. Since having surgery March 9 in Vail, Rodriguez has been rehabilitating there, and in Aspen. During that time, his name has generated headlines in New York for, among other things, an eye-raising photo spread in Details magazine and accusations linking him to the same escort service used by former Gov. Eliot Spitzer.

ALLEN--Catherine M.,Manhattan, NY, died peacefully on April 5 at home. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Kay graduated from St. Joseph's College for Women and was assistant to the President at Guy Carpenter Re-Insurance. Upon her retirement, Kay worked voluntarily at her church and was former Treasurer of The Ladies of Charity of the Archdiocese of New York. Kay was a devoted aunt to multiple generations of nieces and nephews who loved her dearly. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28th St. Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9; Mass of the Resurrection at The Church of St. John the Evangelist, 10am, Wednesday.
KORDA--William, on April 5, 2009. Beloved husband of the late Reva. Devoted father of Natasha and Josh. Services Wednesday, 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

GAVALES--George, 70, died peacefully at home in New York on Saturday, April 4. He is survived by his loving companion of 17 years, Jacalyn Brown. He is also survived by his daughter, Lisa Gavales-Connors and her husband John, granddaughter Linda Alice, niece Diana and brother Emmanuel. He was gracious, outgoing and a boon companion to all who knew him. He will be reposing 2-4pm and 7-9pm Tuesday, April 7th at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave. Services will be held on Wednesday, April 8th at 12pm at the Greek Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St.

EVDOKIMOVA-GREGORI--Eva. We mourn the passing of our dear friend, Eva. Her beauty and grace on stage were surpassed only by her generosity and spirit as a person. GELLER--David, adorable, loving husband of Bonnie G. died on April 6, 2009. He was 95. He is also survived by his children, Stephen, Andrew and Lydia Glucksberg; daughters-in-law Susan and Mary Jane; son-in-law Steven; grandchildren Meredith, Michael, Jonathan, Jeffrey, Jason, Richard and Joshua; sisters-in-law Diane G. Kranz and Phyllis King; brother-in-law Barry. David was known for his business "deals." He thrived on them. He was a living legend. He was working up until the time that he suffered a massive stroke. We will never forget this remarkable man and the stories about him will go on forever. Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, at 9:00am on Wednesday, April 8, 2009. Contributions in his memory would be greatly appreciated to: Mount Sinai School of Medicine- Cardiology Dept. (Dr. Jose Meller Funds); Mount Sinai School of Medicine- Ophthalmology Dept. (Podos Research Fund); Prostate Action, Inc. (on behalf of Dr. Alex Kirschenbaum); Terra Form, Inc. (on behalf of Dr. Tina Dobsevage). The family will receive friends at his home on Wednesday, April 8 after the interment and on Thursday and Friday, April 9th and 10th, from 11am-7pm.

WOLL--Yael, died at age 85. Son of Harry and Rivka Woll, he was raised in the Bronx and was a USAF veteran, a film director who won the Cannes Film Festival Award for Best New Director, a graduate of and later a professor at City College of New York, where he served as the Director of the Institute of Film Techniques. He was President of New Directions Film Co., Vice President of the Directors Guild of America and a member of the Friars and Players Clubs. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Marian, sister, Ahuva Soifer, daughter, Deborah Woll, and her husband, Gary Brown, daughter, Susan Woll and her Clowder eight, son, David Woll, and his wife, Kristen, three grandchildren, Joseph, David and Charles, and loving nieces and nephews. His spirit will live in our hearts forever.

GORDON--Ruth J.,died peacefully in her home in Boca Raton, FL on April 6th. She was predeceased by her husband Louis of 60 years. She is survived by sons Kenneth and Paul and her grandchildren Jodie, Andrew, Ben and Miriam. Services graveside, 11:00 am, Wednesday, April 8, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, 80 Commerce St., Hawthorne, NY.

LEWIS--Robert M.,74, on March 31, 2009, in Merritt Island, FL. He retired from the U.S. Department of Energy where he held senior management positions. As a volunteer officer in the Military Affiliated Radio System he received recognition from the U.S. Army for his services. He was loved and admired by all who knew him. He is survived by his wife Jacqueline Lewis. Other survivors include his sons Anthony and Leslie and daughters Ruth Ball and Barbara Yanko.

Whenever a coaching job in major college basketball or the N.B.A. opens up, Tom Izzo is often mentioned as a candidate. But he has remained at Michigan State. ''I love the Dukes, Carolinas, Kentuckys, Kansas,'' said Izzo, in his 14th season with the Spartans. ''I'm not going to see that in my lifetime because they've done it for so many years, but I love aspiring to be those.'' THAYER EVANS

Funeral noon Monday April 6th at Plaza Chapel 91st and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in Seena's memory can be made to the Workmen's Circle Division of ORT.

NELSON--John C. "Larry" on April 4, 2009. He served on the Board of the Henry Street Settlement and helped save St. Peter's Church in the City Corp. Building. Beloved husband of Barbara, loving father of Karen, Diana, John, Jim and Kristin, father-in-law of Danny Greenberg, Tim Fitzpatrick, Laura Nelson and Gary Kleiman, cherished grandfather of Ilana, Mara, Caleb, Hope, Katie, Chris, Silas, Luke, Matthew and Wes. Services Tuesday 2pm at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

BLOCK--Adrienne Fried, on April 5, 2009. Cherished mother of Barbara and Linda Fried and mother-in-law of Joe Bankman and Joseph Margolick. Beloved grandmother of Jonathan, Alexander, Samuel and Gabriel and stepmother of Elizabeth and Ruth Block. Loving wife of the late Arthur L. Block. Musicologist, biographer, feminist scholar. Visionary, mentor and guide, devoted friend and colleague to many. She lived a life of brilliance, principled commitment to social justice, grace and integrity. We were blessed to have her, and will carry her with us forever. Memorial gathering in her honor on April 16 at 1:15 pm at Riverside Funeral Home at 180 West 76 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to Adrienne Fried Block Fellowship, Society for American Music, Stephen Foster Memorial, U. of Pitts- burgh, Pittsburgh, PA 15260.

As soon as Mark Teixeira stepped from the Yankees' dugout before Monday's game, the fans at Camden Yards let him know this was not home sweet home. A native of Severna Park, Md., Teixeira signed an eight-year, $180 million contract with the Yankees last winter, rejecting an offer from the Orioles for less money and fewer years. Predictably, he was jeered as a sellout. ''I think anybody in my position would have done the same thing,'' Teixeira said. ''It's not a crazy decision I made.''

A critical lifeline to the new World Trade Center from the old Hudson River -- four water pipes large enough to crawl through -- is nearing completion along West Street. The pipes will deliver river water -- up to 30,000 gallons a minute -- to the center's $200-million chiller plant, scheduled to start cooling and dehumidifying air in 2011. That will help make the National September 11 Memorial and Museum as well as the transportation hub and concourses comfortable.

ENGELSON--Miriam (Mim), died March 30, 2009 at age 87 with her family present in California. Beloved wife of Howard for 67 years. Devoted mother of Carol, the late Ellen, Kathy and Erik; grandmother of Alexandra, Susan and Elisabeth; and great-grandmother of Chloe, Samantha, and Luke. Mim spent short periods in Florida, Georgia, and Indiana, and lived most of her life in New York. Already a grandmother, she proudly earned her B.A. degree in English and Teaching License from Queens College in NYC at age 58, and went on to teach in Great Neck, NY. Later she became the special assistant to the Japanese Ambassador to the United Nations and worked at the NY Metropolitan Museum of Art. Howard and Mim moved to Boston, where she volunteered at the Boston Athenaeum, and then to Half Moon Bay, CA. She served for a decade as a docent at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. She will be greatly missed for her love, spunk, flair, smarts, and savvy. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Osteoporosis Foundation.
HANLEY--Charles J. April 7, 1977. We are forever grateful for having had such a wonderful father. Ed, Kathy, Charlie and Tim

It is hard to miss the news: the stock market has been on a bit of a roll lately. But with far less fanfare, the credit markets, where the financial crisis began, are also showing signs of a spring awakening. Companies with good credit are borrowing more money in the bond markets. Confidence in the banking industry seems to be returning, despite the daily ups and downs of financial shares. Even junk bonds, the high-risk corporate debt instruments, are luring brave souls again.

COWELL--Gigi Carrier, 71, passed away on March 19, 2009 at her home in New York City. Born in New Rochelle , NY she lived most of her life in Miami Beach, FL. Gigi was a multi-talented person, having been a fashion model, a sculptor, a licensed building contractor, an actress, and a television personality. She was an astute stock trader, having won the U.S. Trading Championship in 1989. She was also an avid automobile collector, winning top prize in the Miami auto show in 1974 for having restored a 1966 Pinin-Farina 404 convertible. In her later years she helped songwriter Shirley Cowell produce her music and she was actively involved in philanthropic work. She is survived by her brother Leonard Carrier, his wife Claire, and their children, Samuel Carrier and Erica Kampert. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., Thursday 4pm with entombment in a private family mausoleum at Woodlawn Cemetery in Miami.

NELSON--John C. "Larry." The Board of Directors and staff of Henry Street Settlement mourn the death of Larry Nelson, a member of our Board since 1982. He served as Board Vice Chairman and Chairman of the Executive Committee, and was a dedicated supporter of Henry Street programs. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family.
GELLER--David. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York mourns the death of our cherished member, and extends our deepest sym- pathy to his family.
DRAKE--Michael D.,81, of Belleville, NJ, died April 3, 2009. A West Point graduate (1954), his loving family, and many friends will miss him dearly.

SMITH--Philo, of Greenwich, CT, 81, founder of Philo Smith and Co., Inc., of Stamford, died on April 1, 2009 at Stamford Hospital of severe pneumonia. A graduate of Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, NJ, he received his Bachelor's degree from Yale University, and his MBA from New York University Graduate School of Business Administration, now called the Stern School. Mr. Smith started his career at Lord Abbett & Co., and held positions with the J. Henry Schroeder Banking Corporation and with Dominick & Dominick as an insurance stock specialist before founding the investment banking firm in Stamford that bears his name in 1962. He is survived by his wife Andie and by three sons: Gregory N. Smith of Peekskill, NY; Jonathan C. Smith of Ridgefield, CT; and Adam T. Smith of San Francisco, CA. A fourth son, Timothy T. Smith, predeceased him. Mr. Smith is also survived by two stepdaughters, Victoria Keziah of Boulder, CO, and Dr. Amy Kindred of Boston, MA, and by seven grandchildren, the oldest of whom, Robert C. Smith of Norwalk, CT, is Chairman of Touchpoint Securities. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church in Greenwich on Tuesday, April 7, at 11am In lieu of flowers please make charitable donations to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation at http://pdf.org

''I was kind of thrown into some big spots, some big at-bats early, so hopefully I have a little confidence moving forward,'' he said.

As the new baseball season begins, it’s only fitting that HBO would announce Wednesday that it has ordered a second season of “Eastbound & Down,” its pitch-black comedy series about Kenny Powers, a totally fictional, relentlessly self-absorbed ex-major league pitcher (played with relish by Danny McBride).

Laurie Metcalf, who won three Emmys on ABC’s “Roseanne” and most recently played on Broadway in David Mamet’s “November,” has signed to star as the matriarch Kate Jerome in the upcoming Broadway revivals of Neil Simon’s autobiographical plays “Brighton Beach Memoirs” and “Broadway Bound,” the producer Emanuel Azenberg announced Wednesday.

The New York Theater Workshop has announced Delroy Lindo, Roslyn Ruff, and Garret Dillahunt will star in its final production of the season, Naomi Wallace’s “Things of Dry Hours,” which Ruben Santiago-Hudson will direct.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Wednesday morning.

Updated | 11:54 a.m. The Mexican tenor Rolando Villazón has withdrawn from his remaining performances of “L’Elisir d’Amore” at the Metropolitan Opera, citing his bout with an acute case of laryngitis, the Met said in a news release. Mr. Villazón was scheduled to sing the role of Nemorino in the Donizetti opera on Wednesday and Saturday, as well as on April 15 and 18. Instead, Barry Banks, who recently sang the role of Elvino in the Met’s production of “La Sonnambula,” will sing Nemorino on Wednesday; Dimitri Pittas, who sang the role of Tamino in “The Magic Flute” at the Met in 2008, and sang Macduff in 2007 in the Met’s new production of Verdi’s “Macbeth,” will sing Nemorino on Saturday, and on April 15 and 18. Joseph Calleja is scheduled to sing the role on April 22.

The following news item is recommended only for devotees of Michael Cera, the charmingly awkward star of “Juno” and “Superbad”: in the category of good news, Overture Films said in a release that it had acquired Nicholas Jasenovec’s independent movie “Paper Heart,” which stars Charlyne Yi (of “Knocked Up”) and Mr. Cera as an unlikely couple who meet during the making of a documentary about love. The movie, which won the Waldo Salt Award for best screenplay at the Sundance Film Festival, is scheduled to be released in New York and Los Angeles on Aug. 7. In the category of mixed news, The Hollywood Reporter said that an appeals board at the Motion Picture Association of America had upheld its decision to give an R rating to the Harold Ramis comedy “Year One.” That movie, which opens on June 19, stars Jack Black and Mr. Cera as cavemen attempting to adjust to the modern-ancient world. Its producers were seeking a teen-friendly PG-13 rating.

The Los Angeles County district attorney’s office said Tuesday that it did not have enough evidence to file charges against a choreographer suspected of sexually assaulting his students, The Associated Press reported. On Saturday, the police arrested Alex Da Silva, a dancer, choreographer and teacher who has appeared on the Fox reality series “So You Think You Can Dance,” after a woman accused him of luring her into his home and raping her; the Los Angeles Police Department said that Mr. Da Silva had been accused of similar crimes in three separate incidents dating to 2003, but that prosecutors had not filed charges. The A.P. said that Mr. Da Silva was being held on a $3.8 million bond but was expected to be released from jail on Tuesday.

Daniel Barenboim is scheduled to give his long-awaited first performance in Egypt at the Cairo Opera House on April 16, the Austrian Embassy in Cairo said in a news release. Mr. Barenboim, the conductor and pianist, had planned to make his Egyptian debut in January as part of a worldwide tour with the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, the Arab-Israeli group he founded with the writer Edward Said. But that concert was canceled out of concern for the performers’ safety because of fighting in Gaza. In its release the Austrian Embassy said that at the April 16 concert, an initiative of the former Austrian foreign minister Ursula Plassnik, Mr. Barenboim would play solo piano pieces and conduct the Cairo Symphony Orchestra in a performance of Beethoven’s Symphony No. 5. An outspoken advocate of Palestinian rights, Mr. Barenboim announced last year that he had accepted honorary Palestinian citizenship.

While we might have assumed that something called the Keith Richards Blues Collection would lay strewn across the floor of the Rolling Stones guitarist’s home, the collection, which is part of the ARChive of Contemporary Music, stands to receive much better treatment. On Tuesday, Columbia University announced that it would integrate the resources of the ARChive, a not-for-profit music research center in TriBeCa that holds over 2 million sound recordings, into the university’s arts programming and other activities. In a news release, Columbia said that its libraries department and its Arts Initiative Group would work with the ARChive to develop new projects that would use its resources, which also include more than 3 million photographs, books, videos, press kits and other pieces of memorabilia.

New albums by Keith Urban, Prince and Diana Krall took the top spots on this week’s Billboard chart. Mr. Urban, the New Zealand-born, Australian-raised, Nashville-influenced country singer, reached No. 1 for the first time with “Defying Gravity” (Capitol Nashville), which sold 172,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Prince’s triple album “LotusFlow3r” (NPG), available at Target stores (for $12) and on the Web (for $77, with perks, at lotusflow3r.com), was second with 168,000. Diana Krall sold 104,000 copies of “Quiet Nights” (Verve) to reach No. 3, her highest-ever chart position. “UGK 4 Life” (Jive), the new release by UGK, the Texas rap duo whose member Pimp C died in late 2007, opened at No. 6 with 76,000 sales, and Flo Rida‘s “R.O.O.T.S.” (Atlantic) bowed at No. 8 with 55,000. Last week’s top seller, the pop compilation “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 30, fell to No. 4 with just over 87,000 sales, and the soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) fell three places to No. 5, with just under 87,000.

BALTIMORE - When I was growing up, my friend John used to love the first week of the baseball season for the ridiculous projections that come with it. Cecil Fielder might hit four homers in the first five games, and John would do the math. "At this pace, he'd have 130 homers!" he'd say, laughing. "That would crush the record."
At the New York International Auto Show, small start-up companies are fighting for traction in the slowly emerging electric car market.  Lawrence Ulrich reports.

My Thursday column argues that Europe and America are on the cusp of granting broader legal rights and protections to animals, particularly livestock and poultry on factory farms. As far as I know, the first legislative proposal to protect animals came before the British parliament in 1821; it was a bill to ban abuse of horses, and it led to howls of laughter from MPs when it was introduced. One member protested that parliament would next be called to protect dogs, or even cats. Now, as I wrote, Europe is moving to protect chickens from abusive lives in cages.

This is the fifth collaboration for Patrick Blindauer and Tony Orbach, and their first that isn't a Sunday. An earlier joint effort resulted in one of the most memorable puzzles from last year, "Forward Thinking" (Across Lite, Solution). Try it before looking at the answers.

The devastating earthquake that struck the Abruzzo region of Italy has caused 260 deaths and left almost 30,000 people homeless, so it may seem trivial to wonder how Abruzzo's wine industry has fared. Yet life will go on, so it's important to ask how the catastrophe has affected the future of the wine business, which had been making great progress in recent years.

Resistance is growing to Time Warner Cable's plans to impose limits on how much its broadband customers can download. Consumers are not only complaining, but they are also organizing on Web sites like stopthecap.com. Politicians in Texas, North Carolina and New York have spoken out against the idea. And perhaps most surprisingly, some on Wall Street see the move as a hint that Time Warner may be under financial pressure.

I hate to say it, but nothing really inspires me about the traditional American Easter dinner -- ham or lamb, maybe some asparagus or green bean casserole. Yawn. But when I started dating my husband, Andy, he raved about his family's Easter meal. They're Polish, and he could not stop talking about his father's borscht. Now, I'd had borscht before and didn't really feel the desire to ever relive the experience. But, as I soon came to find out, this special Easter borscht (or barszcz, if you want to go with the Polish spelling) is white, slightly sour, creamy and delicious, rather than the cloying sweetness of the red-beet borscht most people know.

AMSTERDAM | Springtime in Amsterdam brings more than just tulips: the city's independent theaters also bloom with festivals of all different kinds. The S.E.C. is putting out for comment a bunch of possible short-selling restrictions today. There are several variations on two ideas. First is an uptick rule, like one we used to have, that bars short-selling at a price lower than the last different price. Second is some type of circuit breaker, like barring further short sales of a particular stock on a day that stock has fallen 10 percent.

Grab yourself a couple of good grapefruits and some other citrus while you still can -- the season is almost over -- and make yourself some xec, the terrific Mayan salsa, often served with fish and featured in today's Minimalist column. Do not limit its use to fish -- it's too good for that. There's a little habanero kick in there that really makes it special.

Almost a year ago, Brad Silberling, director of Universal's upcoming "Land of the Lost," had his crew filming dozens of young sprites as they ran up and rolled down the little hills just above the La Brea Tar Pits, about a block from The Times' bureau here in Los Angeles. At the time, it seemed like a fool-hardy exercise. Across the street from the pits, the councils of the Screen Actors Guild were then roiling with debate about whether to strike, as the union's contract was about to expire, on June 30.

PARIS | Back in the day, having your portrait taken by Andy Warhol was a gateway to instant glamor. "Warhol's Wide World" is a retrospective of around 200 of the artist's portraits, running until July 13 at the Grand Palais in Paris. It unites Warhol's iconic pictures of celebrities with his commissioned portraits, many of them on public display for the first time.

A new City Council proposal would close a loophole that is allowing real estate agents to crowd sidewalks with sandwich board signs. Right now, the law fines tenants and property owners for putting the advertising boards and other obstructions in front of their properties on the sidewalk.
An unidentified tiny object appeared on Chrysler's auto show stage minutes before it unveiled a new Jeep Grand Cherokee. This cute blue pod was a Fiat 500.

The London Knights advanced to the Western Conference final of the Ontario Hockey League for the fifth time in six years on Tuesday night, completing a sweep of the Saginaw Spirit with a 5-3 victory. Nobel Prize-winning economists like Joseph E. Stiglitz and Paul Krugman, also a New York Times columnist, have been harshly critical of the Treasury's public-private investment program (or P-Pip, for short) to remove toxic assets from banks' balance sheets. Broadly speaking, these economists worry that the taxpayers are getting a raw deal because they are taking most of the risk and receiving little benefit from the government program.

Nissan was two days too late. Sunday, with temperatures in the high-60s, would've been the perfect day for Nissan to introduce its new 370Z Roadster. New York City's diversity, often extolled as one its greatest assets, also presents challenges to the Census Bureau as it gears up for another count next year. New York City residents had only a 55 percent response rate to the 2000 census, well below the average of 67 percent nationwide.

Our highways are haunted with unfulfilled visions, from electric station-cars to statewide hydrogen-refueling networks.

The electric system at mid-century will have a lot more renewable energy than it does today, but coal and nuclear power together will still supply two-thirds of the energy, according to a new study from the Electric Power Research Institute, a consortium supported by both government- and investor-owned utilities.

New York City subway cars are not exactly known as good spots for communal gatherings. But the No. 7 train that trundled out of Times Square one recent Saturday afternoon was crammed with chummy straphangers with a common purpose. The riders, who clambered over one another to snag pizza slices from a folding table while a musician strummed a guitar, were all members of CouchSurfing.com.

In a transaction that would create the nation's largest home builder, Pulte Homes and Centex said Wednesday that they would merge in a $1.3 billion stock-for-stock deal. The companies valued the transaction at $3.1 billion, including $1.8 billion in debt.

It became clear recently that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey -- in its efforts to attract tenants to what will be the tallest skyscraper in New York City -- was deliberately replacing the name "Freedom Tower" in public references to the building with a more straightforward designation."Many will always refer to it as the Freedom Tower," Stephen Sigmund, the chief of public and government affairs at the authority, wrote in an e-mail message. "But as the building moves out of the planning stage and into full construction and leasing (the building is now 10 stories above ground), we believe that, going forward, it is most practical to market the building as 1 World Trade Center."

Hari Kumar, a founding partner of New York-based asset manager TPG-Axon Capital Management, is hanging his own hedge fund shingle, after he and his partner ponied up $75 million of their own money to open the firm, Bloomberg News reported.

A long time ago, pranksters could call someone, ask if the refrigerator is running and stand a reasonable chance that the target was in the kitchen next to the refrigerator. Now a new set of software tools lets a cellphone owner track a home's electricity use from wherever she is.

Five years ago, Lewisburg, Tenn., a small factory town, was struggling to pay the interest on a bond for new sewers. Bob Phillips, Lewisburg's part-time mayor and full-time pharmacist, was urged by the town's financial adviser, an investment bank named Morgan Keegan & Company, to engage in a complex financial transaction to lower interest rates.

If Marriott closes its deal to buy The Greenbrier Resort, the playground for the prominent and rich, among the nearly $142 million worth of assets it will inherit are a $3,823 potato peeler, a $205 fudge warmer and Beretta white onyx shotguns worth $6,666, according to financial statements filed before a federal bankruptcy hearing Wednesday.
American International Group's aircraft leasing unit is in talks over a $5 billion credit line from the New York Federal Reserve that could be used to aid in its sale, The Financial Times reported.

Asserting that Ireland must restore international confidence in its debt-laden economy, Finance Minister Brian Lenihan announced an emergency budget plan Tuesday that included creation of a so-called bad bank to buy problem loans from Irish lenders, along with higher taxes and lower government spending to try to bring the deficit in line.

The ruler of Dubai is being investigated by equestrian authorities after a horse he owns and rides failed doping tests after two races. The ruler, Sheik Mohammed, said he accepted full responsibility. The drug use came to light following testing by his staff after endurance races this year in Bahrain and Dubai.

The son of the Hall of Famer John Elway is leaving the Arizona State football program, the university confirmed. Jack Elway plans to remain a student at the college. Sun Devils Coach Dennis Erickson told The Arizona Republic on Monday, “He’s just tired of football and wants to do something else with his life.”.

The Sacramento police have arrested two men on charges related to the theft of a bicycle belonging to Lance Armstrong. Officers said they arrested Lee Crider, 39, and Le Dung, 34. The officers said Crider stole Armstrong’s time-trial bike from the back of a rental truck in February during the Tour of California, then sold it to Le, who turned it in to the police four days after it was reported stolen.

Porto earned a 2-2 tie at Manchester United in the first leg of the European Champions League quarterfinals. United trailed for the first time in its title defense when Jonny Evans’s poor clearance led to Cristian Rodriguez’s fourth-minute goal. Wayne Rooney took advantage of a bad backpass from Bruno Alves to tie the score in the 15th. Carlos Tevez put Manchester United ahead in the 85th, but the Porto substitute Mariano Gonzalez beat goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar in the 89th.
Two senior American officials came under withering public criticism, particularly over the issue of U.S. missile attacks in Pakistan’s tribal areas.

The Books of The Times review on March 23, about “Power Rules: How Common Sense Can Rescue American Foreign Policy,” by Leslie H. Gelb, misstated the amount of energy Canada supplies to the United States in a passage about the need for powerful countries to act together on global climate change. Canada supplies about one-quarter of the United States’ energy imports, not about one-quarter of its energy requirements.

A brief article in The Caucus column last Wednesday about Newt Gingrich’s conversion to Catholicism referred incorrectly to James Dobson, who had interviewed Mr. Gingrich, a former speaker of the House, on his radio program. Dr. Dobson, the founder of Focus on the Family, is an evangelical Christian leader who has a doctorate in child development; he is not a minister. In a legal response filed in a Los Angeles court on Monday, the British rock band Coldplay denied that its song “Viva la Vida” had illegally copied portions of the song “If I Could Fly” by the rock guitarist Joe Satriani, The Associated Press reported. In December Mr. Satriani filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against Coldplay, which in February won the song-of-the-year Grammy Award for “Viva la Vida.” At the time the suit was filed, Coldplay (Chris Martin, lead singer, above) said the resemblance between the songs was “entirely coincidental” and that “Joe Satriani is a great musician.” But in its legal filing, the band has changed its tune, saying that “If I Could Fly” should not receive copyright protection because it “lacks originality,” The Associated Press said.

North Carolina’s victory over Michigan State in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament final on Monday delivered strong ratings for CBS, but the less-than-competitive game helped ABC edge past CBS as the night’s most-watched network. According to Nielsen’s preliminary ratings estimates, CBS’s live coverage attracted just more than 16 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m.; on ABC, 19.6 million viewers tuned in “Dancing With the Stars” from 8 to 9:30. Fox was third in total viewers for the night, drawing 11 million for “24” and 13 million for an episode of “House” featuring the surprise departure of Kal Penn, who plays Dr. Lawrence Kutner. (The actor left the show to take a job in the White House Office of Public Liaison.) NBC finished in fourth place.

The musicians of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra have agreed to pay cuts for the remainder of this season and for the next two. The cuts are among the first approved by an orchestra union at a time when music institutions are under severe pressure to reduce expenses amid the recession. Atlanta Symphony staff members have already had pay reductions imposed, an increasingly common move elsewhere. For the players, pay will be reduced by 5 percent this season and the next, and by 3.8 percent the following season. The music director, Robert Spano, is taking a 7 percent cut this season and a 14 percent cut next season. Several orchestra positions will remain unfilled, with substitutes filling in.
Columbia’s Graduate School of Journalism and the Nieman Foundation at Harvard announced the winners of the Lukas Prize Project Awards, given to works of literary nonfiction.
The J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles said that it would return to Italy a fragment of an ancient Roman fresco that has been in its collection since 1996.

The R&B singer Chris Brown pleaded not guilty on Monday afternoon in Los Angeles to charges of felony assault and making criminal threats stemming from a February altercation with his companion, the pop star Rihanna, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brown, above, was charged last month with two felonies — assault likely to cause bodily injury and making criminal threats — after his arrest for a Feb. 8 incident in which he fought with Rihanna in his car. At that time he was booked on suspicion of making a criminal threat and released on bail. Donald Etra, a lawyer for Rihanna, said that she hoped a plea deal would be worked out before any hearings or a trial, but that she would testify if necessary. If convicted, Mr. Brown could face up to five years in prison.

Having staged his share of aerial dogfights in an outer space movie or two, George Lucas, right, will soon be pitting warplanes of a different era against each other in “Red Tails,” a fictional film about the Tuskegee Airmen of World War II that his Lucasfilm studio is producing. In a news release, Lucasfilm said that the movie would star Terrence Howard, Cuba Gooding Jr., Nate Parker and Bryan Cranston. The film is to be directed by Anthony Hemingway (a veteran of “The Wire” and “Battlestar Galactica”) and written by John Ridley (who had a hand in “Three Kings”). A release date has not been announced. It’s the first Lucasfilm feature film unrelated to the “Star Wars” and “Indiana Jones” franchises in 15 years.

NELSON--John C. The entire staff of Mitsui Fudosan America, Inc. mourns the death of John C. CULLMAN--Dorothy. The Board of Directors and staff of Jazz at Lincoln Center mark with sadness the passing of Dorothy Cullman. Dorothy, with her husband Lewis, provided Jazz with visionary leadership support when we needed it most, and we remain deeply grateful. Our thoughts are with Lewis and their entire family. Wynton Marsalis, Artistic Director Lisa Schiff, Chairman of the Board Gordon J. Davis, Founding Chairman Adrian Ellis, Executive Director

GELLER--David, adorable, loving husband of Bonnie G. died on April 6, 2009. He was 95. He is also survived by his children, Stephen, Andrew and Lydia Glucksberg; daughters-in-law Susan and Mary Jane; son-in-law Steven; grandchildren Meredith, Michael, Jonathan, Jeffrey, Jason, Richard and Joshua; sisters-in-law Diane G. Kranz and Phyllis King; brother-in-law Barry. David was known for his business "deals." He thrived on them. He was a living legend. He was working up until the time that he suffered a massive stroke. We will never forget this remarkable man and the stories about him will go on forever. Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, at 9:00am on Wednesday, April 8, 2009. Contributions in his memory would be greatly appreciated to: Mount Sinai School of Medicine- Cardiology Dept. (Dr. Jose Meller Funds); Mount Sinai School of Medicine- Ophthalmology Dept. (Podos Research Fund); Prostate Action, Inc. (on behalf of Dr. Alex Kirschenbaum); Terra Form, Inc. (on behalf of Dr. Tina Dobsevage). The family will receive friends at his home on Wednesday, April 8 after the interment and on Thursday and Friday, April 9th and 10th, from 11am-7pm.

CULLMAN--Dorothy. It is with profound sadness that the members of The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art have learned of the passing of our beloved member Dorothy Cullman. Dorothy has been an integral part of the International Council since she became a member, along with her husband Lewis, in 1971. Her exciting and wonderfully creative spirit have been an inspiration to her many friends from all over the world, and to communities and institutions throughout New York City and beyond. We send our deepest sympathy to Lewis and her family. Brian Urquhart, Chair Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chair Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

CULLMAN--Dorothy. We met Dorothy and Lewis through Dorothy's sister Marjorie Talalay, who we had a great deal of fondness for and to whom we are so grateful for introducing us to this marvelous couple. Dorothy meant so much to us, as she had so many passions and interests, which she pursued relentlessly throughout her life. She always committed herself to what she cared about, including her wonderful and loving family. Knowing her made a big difference in our lives and we will miss her enormously. Our special love goes out to Lewis. Agnes Gund and Daniel Shapiro

BLOCK--Adrienne Fried, on April 5, 2009. Cherished mother of Barbara and Linda Fried and mother-in-law of Joe Bankman and Joseph Margolick. Beloved grandmother of Jonathan, Alexander, Samuel and Gabriel and stepmother of Elizabeth and Ruth Block. Loving wife of the late Arthur L. Block. Musicologist, biographer, feminist scholar. Visionary, mentor and guide, devoted friend and colleague to many. She lived a life of brilliance, principled commitment to social justice, grace and integrity. We were blessed to have her, and will carry her with us forever. Memorial gathering in her honor on April 16 at 1:15 pm at Riverside Funeral Home at 180 West 76 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to Adrienne Fried Block Fellowship, Society for American Music, Stephen Foster Memorial, U. of Pitts- burgh, Pittsburgh, PA 15260.

From ''The Occasional Shout-Out: The Smith,'' by Frank Bruni on Diner's Journal: A restaurant doesn't have to be particularly good to be worthwhile (maybe the better word is ''useful'') under the right circumstances. And for what I needed when I needed it, the Smith -- 55 Third Avenue, near 11th Street; (212) 420-9800 -- served me well.

THAYER--Dr. Stephen, of New York City passed away April 2, 2009 at age 71. Accomplished Professor of Psychology at City College of New York and private practice psychologist for 43 years. He is survived by his wife Doke; son Andrew and wife Leslie; daughter Colette; three grandchildren, Casey, Zak and Phillip, and sister Linda and husband Lenny. He will be sorely missed for his loving kindness, sharp wit, great sense of humor and intelligence. Donations can be made to Lung Cancer Research or Smoking Cessation Programs.

HAUPTFUHRER--Barbara Barnes, 80, died peacefully on Tuesday, April 7, in Charlotte, North Carolina of a rare lung disease. She was one of the country's earliest woman directors of major corporations, including The Vanguard Group of Investment Companies and each of the mutual funds in the Group, the Raytheon Company, Owens-Illinois, Inc., The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Knight-Ridder, Inc., J. Walter Thompson Co. (later JWT Group, Inc.) General Public Utilities, Alco Standard Corp. (later IKON Office Systems) and The Massachusetts Mutual Financial Group. She was also a Trustee (and Trustee Emerita) of Wellesley College, the Markle Foundation, Salem Academy and College, the Committee for Economic Development, the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society and the Ladies Professional Golf Association. She was also an officer or trustee of many not-for-profit community organizations in the Philadelphia area. She was described by a corporate officer as "always asking the toughest questions in a velvet voice." Mrs. Hauptfuhrer was born in Greensboro, North Carolina, on October 11, 1928, the daughter of J. Foster Barnes and Myrtle Preyer Barnes. She grew up in Durham, North Carolina, where her father was director of choral music at Duke University. She was married to George J. Hauptfuhrer, Jr., on September 9, 1950, and they lived in the Philadelphia area for more than 50 years, where he was chairman of the law firm of Dechert, Price and Rhoads. She is survived by her husband, their two sons, George J. Hauptfuhrer III (wife Sally) of Atlanta, W. Barnes Hauptfuhrer (wife Cammie) of Charlotte and five grandchildren: Barbara Barnes, William Tuck, Foster Barnes, George Lawson and Dillon Robinson. Mrs. Hauptfuhrer's principal interest was her family. She traveled extensively with her husband and her family. Mrs. Hauptfuhrer graduated from Salem Academy and entered Wellesley College at age 16. She graduated with honors in 1949 from Wellesley College and was president of her class. Her honors thesis was entitled "The Changing Socio-Economic Status of Women." Wellesley's annual Scholar-Athlete award is named for her. Prior to her service as a Trustee, Mrs. Hauptfuhrer served as President of the Wellesley College Alumnae Association for three years. She received Salem Academy's first Distinguished Service Award. In Philadelphia, Mrs. Hauptfuhrer became the youngest president of the Junior League of Philadelphia and the first non-Philadelphian. Two of the projects begun under her presidency in 1958-60 remain today: Wheels, Inc. and the Junior Museum at the Academy of Natural Sciences. The Hauptfuhrers moved to Vero Beach, Florida, in 1990. In the fall of 2007 they also purchased an apartment at The Cypress in Charlotte, North Carolina. Mrs. Hauptfuhrer was a member of Huntingdon Valley Country Club (Pennsylvania), Quail Hollow (North Carolina), Roaring Gap Club (North Carolina) and John's Island Club (Florida), where she served as Vice President of the Board. For many years, she played on the Huntingdon Valley women's golf and tennis teams. She won the Roaring Gap Women's Golf championship 21 times. She was also a member of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, April 18 at 2:00pm, at the Community Church of Vero Beach, where the Hauptfuhrers are members. Following the church service, a reception will be held at the John's Island Club. Graveside services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Wellesley College, Duke University Chapel (Friends of the Chapel), The Vero Beach Community Church or the Levine & Dickson Hospice House of Hospice & Palliative Care Charlotte Region.

CULLMAN--Dorothy. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend Dorothy Cullman. Her generosity, passion, wit, elegance, and style will be missed throughout the Museum, as well as throughout the philanthropic community. Lewis and Dorothy Cullman have been visionary benefactors to the arts, sciences, and education and their generosity is distinguished by a deep personal involvement and encouragement of others to support the causes that they love. The Cullmans' support of MoMA began in 1971 when they joined the Museum's International Council, and Lewis has always credited Dorothy, who was more familiar with modern art at the time, for his involvement in the art world and with MoMA. The Cullmans' generosity to MoMA established The Lewis B. and Dorothy Cullman Education and Research Building, which completed the Museum's expansion and renovation project and crystallized MoMA's dual missions of art and education. Their support has also made possible The Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Gallery in the Museum's Philip Johnson Architecture and Design Galleries, and The Lewis B. and Dorothy Cullman Foundation has endowed a number of education programs at the Museum. Dorothy was a member of The International Council, Architecture and Design Committee, Library Council, and Chairman's Council. Dorothy was a television producer and an avid supporter of writers, artists, and human rights efforts. She served on the boards of numerous not-for-profit organizations and was instrumental in bringing many arts and culture programs to public television by supporting Thirteen WNET. She was a great philanthropist, a committed and inspirational leader, and the best and most beloved of friends. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband Lewis and to their family. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

A new wooden water tank went up last week atop 202 West 40th Street in Manhattan, through the efforts of the Rosenwach Tank Company of Long Island City, Queens. Every building more than 80 feet tall in New York City must have a water reservoir to meet the fire codes, and water tanks also provide water service. Andrew Rosenwach, the president of the company, which was founded in 1866, says his workers build 200 to 300 cedar tanks a year and can erect one in a single day. Rosenwach, one of two companies in New York City that build wooden water tanks, also mills its own lumber in the city -- in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Slide show: nytimes.com/cityroom.

9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) GLASS: A PORTRAIT OF PHILIP IN 12 PARTS In 2005 Scott Hicks begin filming the composer Philip Glass, left, in honor of his 70th birthday, in 2007. For 18 months Mr. Hicks followed Mr. Glass across three continents -- from his annual ride on the Coney Island Cyclone to the premiere of his opera ''Waiting for the Barbarians'' in Germany to a performance with a didgeridoo virtuoso in Australia. This ''American Masters'' documentary looks at Mr. Glass's greatest and most controversial works through performance footage of ''Einstein on the Beach,'' his collaboration with Robert Wilson, and interviews with the theater director JoAnne Akalaitis, Mr. Glass's first wife; Holly Critchlow, his fourth; the artist Chuck Close; the musician Nico Muhly; and the film directors Woody Allen, Errol Morris, Godfrey Reggio and Martin Scorsese. 7:30 P.M. (TCM) MORRIS ENGEL: THE INDEPENDENT Raised in Brooklyn by his widowed mother, Morris Engel went on to create films starring young protagonists, raised by single mothers, for whom glints of happiness can be found in the presence of substitute fathers. This tribute begins with a documentary about the filmmaker by his daughter, Mary Engel, followed at 8 by ''Little Fugitive'' (1953), directed with his wife, Ruth Orkin, which was acknowledged by François Truffaut to be a major inspiration for the French New Wave. ''Lovers and Lollipops'' (1956) continues at 9:30, ''Weddings and Babies'' (1958) at 11, and ''Ruth Orkin: Frames of Life,'' Ms. Engel's documentary about her mother, at 12:30 a.m.

CULLMAN--Dorothy. It is with profound sadness and deep affection that the Trustees and the entire community of the American Museum of Natural History mourn the death of our beloved Dorothy Cullman, an extraordinary human being, a deeply admired longtime Trustee, and, together with her husband and partner Lewis, a legendary philanthropist at the Museum, throughout New York City, and beyond. During a historic time in the life of the Museum, Dorothy was among the Museum's most engaged Trustees and, with Lewis, most generous benefactors, supporting the full range of the Museum's work, from pioneering support of our collaborative scientific research through the establishment of the Cullman Program for Molecular Systematics Studies, to the magnificent Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Hall of the Universe. She also sought to deepen the fruitful dialogue between the arts and science. We have been tremendously privileged to benefit from Dorothy's keen intellect, boundless curiosity, distinctive wit, and, most of all, passionate heart for the Museum, its mission, and its people. She was a dear friend and treasured partner and a light has gone out in our lives. But like the stars showcased in the Cullman Hall that she and Lewis made possible, her spirit and legacy will burn brightly forever as a beacon to us all. The entire Museum community mourns the loss of the truly exceptional Dorothy, and sends deep and heartfelt condolences to her husband Lewis, sons William and Frederick, grandchildren, and the entire Cullman family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

North Carolina's 89-72 victory over Michigan State to win the N.C.A.A. men's basketball championship Monday night on CBS generated a 10.8 rating, 11 percent below last year's, and the lowest rating for the event recorded by Nielsen Media. The game's average viewership of 17.6 million fell 10 percent from last year, and was the third lowest ever. The full tournament produced a 5.7 rating, up from 5.6 last year. Pittsburgh Coach Jamie Dixon has been named the Naismith men's coach of the year after leading the Panthers to a university-record 31 victories and the N.C.A.A. tournament's Round of 8. CULLMAN Dorothy. The Trustees and the staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of Dorothy Cullman, one of the most dedicated members of the Library family, who, along with her devoted husband Lewis, was one of the nation's leading philanthropists in the arts, culture, and education. She was a tremendously loyal and generous friend of the Library. She served as a Trustee for nearly two decades. Her energetic involvement had a far-reaching effect on the Library and the millions of people it serves. Dorothy and Lewis have helped propel the Library into the 21st century and allowed us to offer our extraordinary collections and services in exciting new facil ties in bold new ways. We are tremendously proud that our Trustees have named some of the Library's most outstanding facilities in Dorothy and Lewis's honor: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center, our unparalleled library on music, theatre, and dance; the Lewis B. and Dorothy Cullman Circulating Library and Reading Room at our the Science, Industry and Business Library, one of the Library's four major research centers; and the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers, housing our international fellowship program, created in honor of Brooke Russell Astor. The generosity that Dorothy and Lewis have shared has changed the landscape of New York and will have a lasting impact on our nation's cultural and intellectual life. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lewis, her sons Frederick and Bruce W. Benenson, and all of her family and friends. Catherine C. Marron, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

Germany’s culture minister said that ending the nation’s longstanding practice of restoring artwork stolen by Nazis to Holocaust victims and their descendants was “out of the question,” Bloomberg News reported. The minister, Bernd Neumann, was responding to remarks made in Der Spiegel by Norman Rosenthal, the former exhibitions secretary of the Royal Academy of Arts in London, who said that such restitutions should end. “You cannot make up for anything by returning a small amount of art,” Mr. Rosenthal told Der Spiegel, “and one should not want to create this impression.” Mr. Rosenthal, who is Jewish and the son of refugees from Germany and Slovakia, was explaining a similar argument he made in an article in The Art Newspaper. In a statement, Mr. Neumann said that Germany “will continue to push for the identification of looted art in public collections and to reach a settlement with the rightful owner or the heirs,” according to Bloomberg News.

For all the responses that the work of Charles Darwin has elicited, he’s probably never been honored by a techno composer before. But that will change when the BBC Concert Orchestra performs a work by the drum and bass artist Goldie celebrating the 150th anniversary of “On the Origin of Species” as part of the annual BBC Promenade Concerts, Agence France-Presse reported. Among the other highlights of the eight-week performance series better known as the Proms, which begins at Royal Albert Hall on July 17, is an “Indian Voices” day on Aug. 16 and a concert by the Ukulele Orchestra of Great Britain (performing everything from Wagner‘s “The Ride of the Valkyries” to the Sex Pistols‘ “Anarchy in the UK”). The series concludes Sept. 12 with five open-air concerts in London, Manchester, Glasgow, Swansea and Hillsborough Castle in Northern Ireland.

J.K. Rowling will no longer serve as patron of the Multiple Sclerosis Society Scotland, saying that she had been unable to resolve a dispute between the group’s national office in Edinburgh and its management in London, BBC News reported. In a statement, Ms. Rowling, the author of the best-selling “Harry Potter” novels, said, “I cannot, in good conscience, continue to be the public face of a charity that is changing beyond recognition from the one with which I have been so proud to be associated.” Ms. Rowling, whose mother suffered from multiple sclerosis, had been a supporter of the charity for nearly a decade. She said that she would continue to support other research for the disease, including a project she helped fund at the University of Edinburgh. A spokesman for the society said that the group was undergoing a governance review, and was sorry for Ms. Rowling’s departure.

The Catamounts put together three goals to storm into the lead, but B.U. got a late power-play goal to even the score, 3-3, and erase Vermont's momentum heading into the third.The sophomore wing Wahsontiio Stacey tricked defenseman Colby Cohen, first moving inside, then out, to create space before firing a wrist-shot that beat the Terriers goalie Kieran Millan five-hole to make the score 2-1. Vermont tied it up with a flurry in front of the net on a power play. Hobey Baker finalist Viktor Stalberg had a point-blank chance that Millan somehow saved, but Drew MacKenzie gathered the puck and fed Justin Milo waiting at the far post for the finish.

WASHINGTON -- Miami put together plenty of chances in the first period of the N.C.A.A. Division I men's Frozen Four, but Bemidji State goalie Matt Dalton is keeping the Beavers in the game through the scoreless first period. Though shots are tied, 12-12, the Redhawks have had a distinct edge in terms of quality chances, making Dalton scramble around in the crease to keep pucks out early on.Chris Wideman's slap shot from above the left circle caromed off Dalton and over to Pat Cannone, who had a clear shooting lane but rattled the puck off the outside of the net. The game began with a slow pace, but by the end of the first Miami was challenging with consistency. Dalton's quick glove snagged hard shots from forwards Andy Miele and Justin Mercier in the final two minutes, getting a rise out of a crowd eager to cheer on the underdog Beavers.

I see that the Obama hound hounds are baying about an imminent arrival. My bet is that it will be a Portuguese water dog, justified in part because the PWD, as they are sometimes known, did not cause Malia to go into full allergic melt down in one or more unannounced trial runs. If that's true, the dog is unlikely to come from a pound, but could come from the breed rescue group. PWDs are not abundant, and the club is highly active and protective--it's been a leader in genetic research, due to a plant geneticist in Utah, Karl Gordon Lark, who decided to find out why his beloved PWD died young. If not a rescue, and there are plenty of reasons not to go that route, even if a dog were available, then it will come from a breeder--that's my bet--and the animal welfare groups will howl. Not a thing new about that. They have to howl about something. I say let the Obamas have the dog of their choosing. Anyway, those are guesses. I have no insider knowledge on this one. We'll see.

PARIS | Cheerleaders, cupcakes and country music are hitting the city of cabaret, crème brulée and Chanel. From this Saturday, April 11, through May 10, the Jardin d'Acclimatation, a 49-acre children's park in the northern part of the Bois de Boulogne, is hosting a red-white-and-blue celebration called "Des Américains à Paris," or "Americans in Paris." For an entrance fee of only 2.70 euros, American expats hankering for a bit of home, tourists looking for a shot of kitsch in the capital of European refinement, or anyone with a renewed enthusiasm for all things American will want to consider this unlikely Parisian detour.

You walk through a dark foyer and into a cavernous room, lit only by a ragtag collection of colored lamps. The walls brim with every imaginable junk shop treasure: old paperbacks, kitschy sculptures, vintage posters, ancient appliances. One corner is home to row upon row of broken televisions, radios and even a few prehistoric computers. Eerily deconstructed musical instruments lay about; a striking, if motley, collection of paintings has built up on the other edge of the room. A stern young man stands behind the bar, pouring coffee. In the back, on a raised platform, a black-clad figure pounds a brooding tune on the grand piano.

Another ambitious literary Web site has just launched, recession be damned. As John Williams explains in his editor's note, The Second Pass is meant to be an online evolution of the sort of book reviewing found -increasingly, once found - in newspapers. That is: many bylines, many books, catholic taste. And because the Web has made second-hand books so easy to track down and purchase, their mix will include fresh takes on older books as well. New material includes reviews of "The Accordionist's Son," by Bernardo Atxaga; "Forever Blue," by Michael D'Antonio and "Lowboy," by John Wray. The Backlist makes a case for books like "Eve's Hollywood," an out-of-print "commingling of fiction and memoir" about a young woman in Los Angeles, by Eve Babitz (1971). The link is worth clicking for the photo alone.

BEIJING | What's interesting about "Ai Weiwei: New York Photographs 1983-1993" at the Three Shadows Photography Art Centre, in Beijing, is that the Americans I know who have visited the exhibit, particularly those born and raised in New York, tend to focus on the location photos: the raw, grimy East Village sidewalks; Tompkins Square Park with its anti-gentrification protesters and drag queens; shirtless students at St. Marks Place; the bums on the Bowery and the gritty sidewalks and graffiti-covered subway cars that inspired "Stranger Than Paradise," Jim Jarmusch's 1984 film set partially in New York City. They are drawn to them precisely because they induce feelings of nostalgia for 1980s New York.

Updated, 8:20 p.m. | A humpback whale was spotted in New York Harbor near Verrazano Narrows Bridge, the United States Coast Guard said on Thursday morning. The authorities observed the 30-foot animal for several hours and set up a security perimeter to protect it from ships in the active corridor. In the early evening, the authorities reported that the whale had headed out to sea south of Coney island.The whale, which was first reported to the authorities via a resident's phone call around 8 a.m., did not appear to be injured or entangled (unlike another recent whale sighting in the region in February).

It's looking to be a crowded Easter Weekend at the box office, with three major releases hoping to unseat last weekend's "Fast & Furious" at the top of the charts. The likeliest candidate appears to be "Hannah Montana: The Movie," which is opening in 3,118 theaters in North America and hopes to transfer the wildly popular television hit to the big screen. But Seth Rogen will also be back in "Observe and Report," playing a delusional mall cop, opening in 2,727 theaters, and "Drangonball Evolution," based on a popular Japanese cartoon series, opens in 2,100 theaters.

CINCINNATI -- It's Weather Day here at Great American Ball Park, where the sun is shining and it's a crisp 44 degrees, possibly heading up to 63. That could be good news -- or not, who knows? -- for Oliver Perez, who attributed his dreadful tune-up Saturday against Boston (two hits, four walks, six runs in one-third of an inning) to the cold temperatures and winds. He said he had trouble gripping the ball. The five pitchers who followed him gave up three runs in eight and one-third innings, so maybe they didn't have quite as much trouble as he did.

John Holdren, President Obama's science adviser, began speaking to the media on Wednesday for the first time. The Associated Press emphasized some statements he made in support of testing ways to counteract global warming through what has become known as "geo-engineering" -- emergency interventions to cool the atmosphere should less drastic measures fail. Dr. Holdren said that the Associated Press article implied incorrectly that this strategy for climate management was under serious consideration at the White House. This is not the case, he said in an email distributed to a variety of scientists and other contacts last night:

Update | 10:03 a.m. On Thursday, the North Korean state media announced that the country had decided to keep its leadership structure intact -- with the rarely seen Kim Jong-il formally serving as chairman of the country's most powerful agency, while his late father, Kim Il-sung, remains "eternal president." Earlier this week, a town in Missouri made a similar decision, though by democratic means, voting to re-elect its mayor four weeks after his death.

Mulally, said he would mortgage all the company's assets for billions of dollars in loans to finance an overhaul of the troubled automaker. Although the economy was healthy then, Mr. Mulally said the money would give Ford "a cushion to protect for a recession or other unexpected event."

Coty, which owns Nautica's perfume license, presents the brand's recently launched masculine scent Oceans as a major environmental revolution. As with all public relations, the press release offers the usual gnomic pronouncements - something about "celebrating man's unity with the water." (Whatever.) It's easy to imagine 20 people at the brand's P.R. agency producing copy, apparently straight-faced, like "The launch of Nautica Oceans marks a true wave of change" and "[it] raises the tide for ... fragrance." They then attribute this "quote" to poor Bernd Beetz, Coty's German C.E.O., who was doubtless unaware of the state of his English. Even the cardboard packaging sports the message "Carton made with wind power in a carbon neutral facility."
Term jokingly used by a Hong Kong writer to describe the Philippines.

Earnhardt-Ganassi Racing has shuttered the No. 8 car driven by Aric Almirola because of a lack of funding. Almirola and the car started this season without full sponsorship, and the team owner Chip Ganassi had not ruled out closing the team. The No. 8 was the centerpiece at Dale Earnhardt Inc. before the team merged with Ganassi last November. Almirola is 37th in the Sprint Cup standings, with a season-best finish of 21st at Atlanta last month.

DeJuan Blair of Pittsburgh said Wednesday that he would declare for the N.B.A. draft and that he had begun hiring representatives, ending any possibility that he could return for his junior season. Blair was projected as a middle to late first-round pick. Blair, the only Pittsburgh player in 50 years to make first-team all-American, could have returned to the Panthers if he did not hire an agent or any other representative.

Charitable Man will make his 3-year-old debut during Saturday’s Grade 1, $750,000 Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland and was made the 4-1 third choice and drew the No. 9 post in the field of 11. Charitable Man has not raced since sustaining a fracture in his shin while training in September, cutting short a promising 2-year-old campaign.

Siena Coach Fran McCaffery, who had two years left on his contract, announced that he had signed an eight-year deal. The terms were not released. Dinara Safina will overtake Serena Williams for the No. 1 ranking later this month. The WTA Tour said Safina would rise to No. 1 for the first time in her career in the April 20 rankings. Safina is the younger sister of the former men’s No. 1 Marat Safin. They are the first brother and sister to be No. 1. Safina was the runner-up at the 2008 French Open to Ana Ivanovic and at the 2009 Australian Open to Williams.

A 41-year-old Chicago woman pleaded not guilty to charges she killed the pregnant girlfriend of the former Bears safety Shaun Gayle. Prosecutors say Marni Yang shot Rhoni Reuter, 42, because she was jealous of Reuter’s relationship with Gayle.

The New York State Summer School of the Arts, which offers monthlong training programs in music, theater, dance, and visual arts, had its spending authority cut by 10 percent from the previous year, to $1.59 million. That’s a much smaller reduction than had been feared, but it will require the school, which is financed partly by the state and partly through tuition, to reduce the number of students this year by 100, to about 425, according to Jeremy Johannesen, the executive director of the nonprofit New York State Alliance for Arts Education, which works closely with the summer school. After word went out last month of a possible 50 percent cut in the budget, alumni, parents and teachers protested through Facebook groups, online petitions and calls to legislators.

New albums by Keith Urban, Prince and Diana Krall took the top three spots on this week’s Billboard chart. Mr. Urban, the New Zealand-born, Australian-raised, Nashville-influenced country singer, reached No. 1 for the first time with “Defying Gravity” (Capitol Nashville), which sold 172,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Prince’s triple album “LotusFlow3r” (NPG), available at Target stores (for $12) and on the Web (for $77, with perks, at lotusflow3r.com), was second with 168,000. Diana Krall sold 104,000 copies of “Quiet Nights” (Verve) to reach No. 3, her highest-ever chart position. “UGK 4 Life” (Jive), the new release by UGK, the Texas rap duo whose member Pimp C died in late 2007, opened at No. 6 with 76,000 sales, and Flo Rida’s “R.O.O.T.S.” (Atlantic) bowed at No. 8 with 55,000. Last week’s top seller, the pop compilation “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 30, fell to No. 4 with just over 87,000 sales, and the soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) fell three places to No. 5, with just under 87,000.

Three Smithsonian Institution museums will extend their hours through at least Labor Day, The Associated Press reported. The National Air and Space Museum and National Museum of Natural History will remain open until 7:30 p.m. each day, and the National Museum of American History will stay open until at least 6:30 p.m. each day. All three museums open daily at 10 a.m. and had closed at 5:30 p.m.

The Mexican tenor Rolando Villazón, right, has withdrawn from his remaining performances of “L’Elisir d’Amore” at the Metropolitan Opera, citing an acute case of laryngitis, the house said in a news release. Mr. Villazón was scheduled to sing the role of Nemorino in the Donizetti opera on Wednesday and Saturday, as well as on April 15 and 18. Instead Barry Banks, who recently sang the role of Elvino in the Met’s production of “La Sonnambula,” will sing Nemorino on Wednesday night; Dimitri Pittas, who sang the role of Tamino in “The Magic Flute” at the Met in 2008, and Macduff in 2007 in the Met’s new production of Verdi’s “Macbeth,” will sing Nemorino on Saturday, and on April 15 and 18. Joseph Calleja, as previously scheduled, will sing the role on April 22.

Daniel Barenboim, below, is scheduled to give his long-awaited first performance in Egypt at the Cairo Opera House on April 16, the Austrian Embassy in Cairo said. Mr. Barenboim, the conductor and pianist, had planned to make his Egyptian debut in January as part of a world tour with the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, the Arab-Israeli group he founded with the writer Edward Said. But that concert was canceled out of concern for the performers’ safety because of fighting in Gaza. The Austrian Embassy said that at the April 16 concert, an initiative of the former Austrian foreign minister Ursula Plassnik, Mr. Barenboim would play piano pieces and conduct the Cairo Symphony Orchestra in Beethoven’s Symphony No. 5. An advocate of Palestinian rights, he announced last year that he had accepted honorary Palestinian citizenship.

Laurie Metcalf, below, who won three Emmys on ABC’s “Roseanne” and most recently played on Broadway in David Mamet’s “November,” has signed to star as the matriarch Kate Jerome in the Broadway revivals of Neil Simon’s autobiographical plays “Brighton Beach Memoirs” and “Broadway Bound,” the producer Emanuel Azenberg, said Wednesday. “Brighton Beach,” which ran for 1,300 performances in the 1980s and starred Elizabeth Franz as Kate and Matthew Broderick as her son Eugene, is scheduled to begin rehearsals on Aug. 15 and start previews in September. Once it opens in mid-October, rehearsals for “Broadway Bound” will begin, with a target of opening in mid-December. The two plays will then run in repertory. David Cromer will direct both.

Highlights: Several tightly knit clusters of venues will dot downtown, with the focus on a redeveloped shoreline of Tokyo Bay. The Olympic village will be built on the water. The city has one of the most efficient public transportation systems in the world. Last June, the bid finished first in the I.O.C.’s technical evaluation.

Highlights: Looking to host South America’s first Olympics, the city is touting its natural beauty, but also its proven ability to host big sporting events. The 2007 Pan American Games were held there, but even more important will be the 2014 World Cup. Organizers say hosting the World Cup ensures that infrastructure projects and improvements will be ready for 2016.

Highlights: The city was a strong contender to host the 2012 Olympics and for 2016, it has fine-tuned its bid that officials call an “Olympic fiesta.” The events will be held in two main zones: the Core Zone, which will include the Olympic Stadium, and the River Zone, a part of the riverbank which will be reclaimed for public use. Former International Olympic Committee president Juan Antonio Samaranch of Spain, who retains some influence among I.O.C. members, supports the bid.

Highlights: The shoreline of Lake Michigan and century-old parks would provide a natural setting for the Games, with the city’s dramatic skyline as the backdrop. Many of the venues are in or near the heart of the city, within walking distance of downtown. President Barack Obama, a longtime Chicago resident, is a high-profile supporter of the bid. Grant Park, site of his presidential acceptance speech, would be a main gathering place during the Olympics.
In uncertain economic times, in a tight race, Chicago’s Olympic bid simply cannot rest on the help of cheerleaders, even those as prominent as President Obama.

An international war crimes court on Wednesday sentenced three top leaders of the Revolutionary United Front in Sierra Leone to long prison terms for atrocities committed during the country's decade-long civil war of the 1990s. The Special Court for Sierra Leone in Freetown sentenced Issa Hassan Sesay to 52 years, Morris Kallon to 40 years and Augustine Gbao to 25 years.

The Coney Island Journal article on Saturday, about preparations for the new season at the amusement park area amid erroneous reports of its death, said workers were changing light bulbs on the Thunderbolt, as did a picture caption in some editions. The Thunderbolt is a ride featuring connected cars that travel around a circular, undulating track. The article was not referring to the Thunderbolt roller coaster, a famous ride at Coney Island that was demolished in 2000.

In their largest show of power so far, supporters of former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra massed in central Bangkok on Wednesday and demanded that the government resign. Wearing the red shirts of Thaksin loyalists, the demonstrators streamed into Bangkok throughout the day from his political strongholds in the rural north and northeast, and by early evening the police estimated that the crowds numbered 100,000. The protests began two weeks ago, and last week were drawing about 30,000 people.

Sum Touch has stopped trying to tell her grandchildren about the killings, starvation and terror she lived through when a Communist Khmer Rouge regime ravaged Cambodia 30 years ago. ''It seems that even if I tell them they don't believe what I say,'' said Mrs. Sum Touch, 71, who lost many members of her family. ''It hurts my heart that they don't know what happened.''

10 P.M. (Fine Living) HOW TO FIND A HUSBAND Sally Gray, a 37-year-old British reporter and television host, decides to put an end to her singlehood by devoting 10 weeks to dating her way through 50 men, armed with instructions from family, friends, a vicar and a relationship expert who advises her to concoct a sassy online profile -- a threesome, anyone? -- while behaving like a good girl on the first date. Ms. Gray, above with a possibility, adds her own touch to this reality show by donning a ring engraved with the word ''single.'' 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Billy Ray Cyrus is a guest. Other segments look at divorce celebrations, parting ways with a hairdresser and Michelle Obama's fashion during her first overseas trip as first lady.

An Iraqi baby rescued from the wreckage of a car bombing in Baghdad on Tuesday that killed his mother and seven others was claimed Wednesday by his maternal uncle, according to residents of the neighborhood of Kadhimiya, where the attack occurred. The baby is about 6 months old.

CULLMAN--Dorothy. The Faculty and Staff of the Lewis B. and Dorothy Cullman Program for Molecular Systematics at The New York Botanical Garden are saddened by the passing of our esteemed friend Dorothy Cullman. Dorothy and her husband, Lewis B. Cullman, were frequent and welcome guests in the Cullman Laboratory. Dorothy loved to pursue the research process, always seeking to understand how research was conducted in addition to knowing the results. She would not allow us to gloss over conclusions, asking questions without fail until she had a satisfactory answer. She loved knowing the details. It was not enough to tell her that using the methods of molecular biology to reconstruct the evolutionary Tree of Life would provide useful conclusions to be employed by a broad scientific community. She wanted to know what that community was and how they used the information. Of course, her queries made us think more broadly about the applications of our work. We looked forward to Dorothy's visits, loved her penetrating questions, and took delight from her enthusiasm at being among staff and students working in the lab. We will miss her. We extend our deepest condolences to Lewis and their family. Dennis W. Stevenson, Ph.D., Vice President for Botanical Science Amy Litt, Ph.D., Director of Plant Genomics and Cullman Curator Gregory Plunkett, Ph.D., Director of the Lewis B. and Dorothy Cullman Program for Molecular Systematics and Cullman Curator The New York Botanical Garden

ZINBERG--Samuel, M.D. Dr. Patrick Borgen and the Department of Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, New York, mourn the passing of one of the founding surgeons of the Department. Dr. Zinberg was one of the most eminent and proficient of surgeons and his contributions to this Department will be remembered for years to come. He was a source of pride and inspiration to generations of surgeons. Beyond his surgical and academic accomplishments, he was truly a "Gentleman's gentleman". We offer our condolences to his loved ones on their loss.

KOVACIC--Jerald J.,a renowned leader in the application of algebraic techniques to differential equations theory died at his home of glioblastoma multiforme on April 1, 2009. He was 68. He died in the care of his loving partner and now husband of 32 years, Daniel J. Kiser. The famed Kovacic algorithm for solving second order linear ordinary differential equations has been implemented in commercial and open source scientific software. It is a breakthrough procedure for computing the algebraic group associated with the equation, called its differential Galois group. Dr. Kovacic received his Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1968. He was an assistant professor at Princeton University from 1968 until 1970. He taught at Lehman College, Fordham University, and Brooklyn College. From 1981 to 2001, he was computer programmer and technical director at JYACC, a computer services firm in NYC. Jerald was working on the challenging task of laying the foundations for a new geometry of differential equations, modeled on algebraic geometry. He was webmaster and defacto technical director of the Kolchin Seminar in Differential Algebra (KSDA), Graduate Center, CUNY. Memorial Service Friday, April 24, 6:30pm at his home. Contributions to City College/KSDA; c/o Dan Kiser, Inc, 307 7th Avenue 1405 New York, NY 10001.

CONN--Maxine "Mickey" Georgette Phillips, born 11 August, 1925, died 2 April, 2009. Beloved widow of Alexander Conn, daughter of Frederic and Hetty, sister of Mali, and respected and beloved mother of Laurie, Paul, Stephen and Peter. A strong and intelligent woman, a graduate of Cornell and NYU, she edited several magazines in the 1940s before marrying Herbert Storfer and joining the executives of Parfum Corday. She continued to work as a marketing executive in the cosmetics industry until she retired to become a full time Mom in the 1960s. Memorial services will be held at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains on Monday, April 13 at 1pm. The family requests donations are sent to the Alzheimer's Association in lieu of flowers.
