CULLMAN Dorothy. The Trustees and the staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of Dorothy Cullman, one of the most dedicated members of the Library family, who, along with her devoted husband Lewis, was one of the nation's leading philanthropists in the arts, culture, and education. She was a tremendously loyal and generous friend of the Library. She served as a Trustee for nearly two decades. Her energetic involvement had a far-reaching effect on the Library and the millions of people it serves. Dorothy and Lewis have helped propel the Library into the 21st century and allowed us to offer our extraordinary collections and services in exciting new facil ties in bold new ways. We are tremendously proud that our Trustees have named some of the Library's most outstanding facilities in Dorothy and Lewis's honor: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center, our unparalleled library on music, theatre, and dance; the Lewis B. and Dorothy Cullman Circulating Library and Reading Room at our the Science, Industry and Business Library, one of the Library's four major research centers; and the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers, housing our international fellowship program, created in honor of Brooke Russell Astor. The generosity that Dorothy and Lewis have shared has changed the landscape of New York and will have a lasting impact on our nation's cultural and intellectual life. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lewis, her sons Frederick and Bruce W. Benenson, and all of her family and friends. Catherine C. Marron, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

PEYSER--Dr. Harry, D.D.S.,of Yonkers. Beloved husband of the late Joan. Devoted father of Richard and Alison, Robert and Lorraine Gutierrez. Loving grandfather of Eric, Athena and Julia and great-grandfather of Hunter and Alec. Dear brother of Ruth Haas. Service Friday, 11:30am at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY. Kindly forward contributions to: Calvary Hospital, Calvary Fund, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

CULLMAN--Dorothy. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the passing of our esteemed friend and benefactor Dorothy Cullman, a magnanimous philanthropist legendary for her support of the arts, education, and science. At Rockefeller, Dorothy and her husband, Lewis, endowed the Irene Diamond Professorship, which is named in honor of the Cullmans' friend and fellow philanthropist Irene Diamond. This chair is currently held by David D. Ho, M.D., an internationally renowned AIDS researcher. Dorothy will be greatly missed at the University and throughout the philanthropic community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lewis and to Dorothy's entire family. Russell L. Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Paul Nurse, President David D. Ho, M.D., Irene Diamond Professor

CULLMAN--Dorothy. The Board and Staff of The New York Botanical Garden are deeply saddened by the loss of our longtime friend Dorothy Cullman, wife of Lewis B. Cullman, Senior Vice Chairman of the Board. As a founding member of the Botanical Science Committee, Dorothy's intellectual and philanthropic interests were very broad and included a wide range of science research efforts at the Garden. Together Dorothy and Lewis founded the Lewis B. and Dorothy Cullman Program for Molecular Systematics, providing our scientists with state-of-the-art facilities and cutting-edge technologies for botanical research. In addition to a trip to the Amazon, we shared many adventures over the decades. Dorothy was well known for her pithy wit, inimitable style, and passionate support of cultural endeavors. She adored The Orchid Show and other aesthetic and artistic aspects of the Garden. In 2004 Dorothy and Lewis received the Founders Award, honoring and acknowledging their concern for the environment and participation in a variety of ways to help improve Earth's delicate balance for all humankind. She was also an ardent advocate and supporter of writers and artists as well as human rights issues, leaving an august legacy of social compassion and inspiring generosity. Dorothy felt and exuded a genuine obligation to give back, and her commitment to organizations and causes she believed in was unwavering. We express our sincere condolences to her beloved husband, Lewis, and their family. Wilson Nolen, Chairman of the Board Gregory Long, President and CEO James Miller, Ph.D., Dean and Vice President for Science The New York Botanical Garden

These are strange and difficult times if you consider yourself a Wolverine fan. The popular mutant has been turning up everywhere lately, but for the wrong reasons. Last week, an early cut of the upcoming film “X-Men Origins: Wolverine” found it way onto the Internet and was downloaded over a million times. With reaction to the leak reaching a fever pitch, it’s no surprise that Marvel’s “Wolverine: Origin” claims the No. 5 spot on our paperback list.

The civility and hospitality that Canada is known for was in short supply at a Thursday night concert performed in Toronto by Billy Bob Thornton and his band, the Boxmasters, The Toronto Star reported. The performance came one day after Mr. Thornton gave a cantankerous interview to Canada’s public CBC radio, in which he frequently responded to the questions of his interviewer, Jian Ghomeshi, with silence or non sequiturs. (Asked what music he listened to when he was young, Mr. Thornton replied with an answer about the magazine Famous Monsters of Filmland.) Appearing Thursday at Massey Hall, Mr. Thornton was greeted with numerous boos and taunts of “Here comes the gravy!” (a response to Mr. Thorton’s claim in the interview that Canadian audiences are “mashed potatoes with no gravy”). The performer told the audience that he was displeased that Mr. Ghomeshi ignored a request not to discuss Mr. Thornton’s film career in the interview. “I don’t really like sensationalism,” Mr. Thortnon said, according to The Star. “If you look someone in the eyes and promise them something, and you don’t do it, you don’t get the interview. That’s the way it goes.”
What we’re reading (and watching) on Friday morning.

SAN FRANCISCO — In its second guerrilla-style gig of the week, the rock band Green Day unveiled songs from its new album, “21st Century Breakdown,” due in May. The band, which is from the Bay Area, booked the DNA Lounge, a 500-capacity club here, just 24 hours in advance and alerted fans six hours before the 10 p.m. start time. Tickets sold out in 20 minutes. The intimate space let the band — which routinely plays stadiums — get personal, with the members grabbing outstretched hands, taking requests and crowd surfing.

If you’re assembling a Broadway show about country music, you might as well start by casting a country-music star: the producers of the planned Broadway show “Pure Country,” adapted from the 1992 movie about a music star in search of authenticity, said that they had cast the musician Joe Nichols in the lead role. In a release, the producer Randall L. Wreghitt said that Mr. Nichols, whose albums include the 2007 best-seller “Real Things,” would play the central character portrayed by George Strait in the film. (In the movie, the character was named Dusty; in the show, he will be named Rusty.) Mr. Wreghitt said that the show was still securing financing but was planned for an early 2010 opening. The “Pure Country” musical will be directed by Peter Masterson (“The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas”), who is writing the book with Rex McGee (the original film’s screenwriter); the music is by Steve Dorff and the lyrics are by John Bettis.

The Corcoran Gallery of Art announced Thursday that it had eliminated 14 positions at the Washington museum and its College of Art + Design, and a total of 18 jobs over all this month. In a news release, the Corcoran said that the positions eliminated ranged from entry-level jobs to senior management, and that the job reductions represented 5.6 percent of its total full- and part-time staff. The museum said that it was also instituting other cost-cutting measures in response to the economic slowdown, including an extension of its hiring freeze and the suspension of its employer contributions to workers’ pension plans starting in May. In a statement, Paul Greenhalgh, the director and president of the Corcoran, said that its coming exhibitions and building restorations would continue as planned.

In uncertain times for newspapers, readers of The Courier-Journal in Louisville, Ky., might be forgiven for wondering if what they saw when they looked at Friday’s front page was a cost-cutting measure: all the words and even the pictures on the printed page had been hand-drawn, down to the weather box and the captions. But the transformation was the work of the Turkish artist Serkan Ozkaya, who has done the same thing to parts or whole pages with the cooperation of several other newspapers around the world (including The New York Times) to create what he describes as cheap, unexpected mass-produced works of art. The latest newspaper drawing – Mr. Ozkaya renders the page with the help of assistants after it has been laid out by editors and the drawing is then printed – is the first project of a new nonprofit, noncollecting art organization called artwithoutwalls, founded in Louisville by the art collectors Steve Wilson and Laura Lee Brown to help artists create works in nontraditional settings around the country. One of the organization’s next projects will be a collaboration with the Park Avenue Armory in New York.

The YouTube Symphony Orchestra has settled on the program for its concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, most of it to be conducted by its artistic adviser, Michael Tilson Thomas. It is a colorful hodgepodge, not all of it orchestral and much of it reflecting Mr. Thomas’s predilections. It ranges from the very old (Giovanni Gabrieli’s Canzon Septimi Toni No. 2) to the very new (works by Tan Dun and Mason Bates) and includes a healthy dose of classic symphonic fare: the Allegro giocoso from Brahms’s Fourth Symphony, “Nuages” from Debussy’s “Nocturnes,” the finale from Tchaikovsky’s Fourth Symphony. Yuja Wang is the piano soloist in the Scherzo from Prokofiev’s Concerto No. 2; Gil Shaham, the violin soloist in the finale from Mozart’s Concerto No. 5; and Measha Brueggergosman, the soprano soloist in John Cage’s “Aria With Renga.” There is also music by Bach (for unaccompanied cello), Dvorak, Wagner, Rachmaninoff (for piano, six hands), Villa-Lobos and Lou Harrison. The orchestra — more than 90 players from more than 30 countries, selected through auditions posted on YouTube — is to gather for its first rehearsal on Monday morning at the Juilliard School. The players had better be over their jet lag and well rested.
Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete stories.)

“The Metal Children,” a new play by Adam Rapp, and “The Scottsboro Boys,” one of the last musical projects by the team of John Kander and Fred Ebb (“Cabaret,” “Chicago”), are among the highlights of the Vineyard Theater’s 2009-2010 season, the theater announced on Friday. First up in September will be “A Boy and His Soul,” written and performed by Colman Domingo (who performed in “Passing Strange”). Mr. Rapp, a Pulitzer Prize finalist for his play “Red Light Winter,” will direct his “Metal Children” next winter. The Vineyard will co-produce a new musical, “The Burnt Part Boys,” with Playwrights Horizons next spring. “The Scottsboro Boys” will receive a developmental production at the Vineyard in 2010, directed and choreographed by Susan Stroman (“The Producers,” “Contact”).

“Trust Me,” a comedy-drama about a make-believe advertising agency in Chicago, was canceled by TNT on Friday after a single season. It “achieved creative success,” said Michael Wright, executive vice president and head of programming for TNT, TBS and TCM in Atlanta. “It just didn’t find an audience.” According to ratings data from TNT, a Time Warner cable channel, “Trust Me” drew only about 1.4 million viewers for each episode during its 13-episode season, which started in January and ended on Tuesday. The series featured Eric McCormack and Tom Cavanagh as creative executives at the imaginary agency. “People sometimes lament there’s so much drama built around doctors and lawyers and police,” Mr. Wright said, but it may be that the world of advertising is “not as accessible a subject as other subjects on television.” The acclaimed drama about advertising on AMC, “Mad Men,” also draws a smaller audience than procedural dramas. Turner Entertainment, which oversees TNT, integrated real products into the scripts of “Trust Me” as part of advertising sales packages; the characters at the agency, Rothman Greene & Mohr, worked on campaigns for brands including Dove.

Dan Aykroyd practically dove into a conference room at a Midtown hotel earlier this week to discuss the June arrival of “Ghostbusters: The Video Game.” The 15 or so journalists present were happy enough to be there, but it didn’t hurt that Mr. Aykroyd showed up with a case of a brand of vodka he is promoting. “Somewhere we’ll figure out a way where people can play the game and sip the vodka,” he said, to laughs.

In Friday’s New York Times, Holland Cotter reviewed “The Generational: Younger Than Jesus,” at the New Museum that includes work only by artists 33 or younger. Among the works he mentioned was Liz Glynn’s “24 Hour Roman Reconstruction Project, or, Building Rome in a Day,” in which the artist and a team of collaborators built a model of the Italian capital in the museum’s lobby and then destroyed it. We’d intended to include video of this project in the online version of Mr. Cotter’s story but, due to various technical issues and perhaps the interference of certain ancient Roman deities, were unable to do so until now. The video appears below and in Mr. Cotter’s review here.

The following teams have three quality starts: Pittsburgh, San Diego, Los Angeles Angels and Kansas City. The Mets, through three games, have none.

MADRID | An exhibition of a little-known Brazilian painter has become the sleeper hit of the spring art season in Madrid. Though she may not yet be a household name, Tarsila do Amaral (1886-1973) has long been a darling of Latin-American modern art specialists and seems on the verge of gaining much broader recognition. On view at the Juan March Foundation (Castelló 77; 34-91-435-4240; admission is free) through May 3, the exhibition includes about 100 works by Amaral, as well as a selection of Amazonian tribal art and works from the Portuguese colonial period.

One day, two of Dawn Meehan's many children decided to play baseball in the house. That led to a broken light fixture, which Dawn began to sweep up, but she was distracted by shouts that her daughter had tried to flush a pull-up diaper, causing the bathroom to flood. Over the next few hours, all before she'd had time for a cup of coffee, Dawn ran from one half-solved problem to the next: yogurt smeared on the television, an escaped hermit crab in the toy pile, a baby covered in maple syrup, crayon on the living room walls, a three-year-old eating puppy chow, a hole knocked into the bathroom wall.

My approach to visiting schools has always been focused on the people I meet, and I heard a wide variety of opinions at both Harvard and Yale. Barack Obama looks good on YouTube - and on Joost, BarackTV, Eyeblast, DailyMotion, Hulu and nearly all the other online depots that play video of him. Sure, he comes off less well on Teleprompter President, a Web site devoted to Obama satire and bloopers. And several YouTube recutters made hay of the president's seeming slight of the Special Olympics during his appearance on "The Tonight Show." But the president's overall virtuosity on the visual Internet is remarkable, and significant, as millions of people now behold, scrutinize and evaluate public figures chiefly in online video clips.

"Nothing is certain but death and taxes," Benjamin Franklin penned in 1789, anticipating the annual agonies of tax day. But it's a little less clear where our tax dollars will end up each year. The president submits a new budget every February: scuttling programs, creating new ones, shrinking spending on some departments and pumping up others. All the budget information is publicly available - if you're willing to sift through thousands of pages of government documents. For the curious taxpayer whose patience for paperwork ends at line 75 on Form 1040, the designer Jess Bachman offers "Death and Taxes," a six-square-foot infographic that organizes the minutiae of the federal discretionary budget into a single, sprawling bubble diagram.

At age 35, Deputy Mayor Edward Skyler has become one of the most powerful men in the city. He oversees the city's most highly visible departments (and the ones that New Yorkers judge the effectiveness of government): Police, Fire, Sanitation and Transportation. He coordinated the cleanup after the steam pipe exploded near Grand Central Terminal in 2007. He oversaw the search for DNA when human remains were discovered inside a manhole at ground zero. He revamped the troubled Buildings Department after the collapse of construction cranes. "He has very quietly become the guy who is running the city," a colleague says.

The No. 1549 Patrick Harten will wear on his chest for the Boston Marathon is no ordinary bib assignment: Race organizers gave it to Harten, a New York air traffic controller, to honor his role in the safe landing of US Airways Flight 1549 in the Hudson River. Harten, who began running three years ago, wrote to Boston Marathon organizers last month, requesting the number. Race organizers do not generally allow runners to pick their bib numbers for fear of opening the door to every hoofer with a lucky number.

Old Fashioned can rejoin the list of Kentucky Derby contenders with a strong showing in the Arkansas Derby on Saturday. Old Fashioned, trained by Larry Jones, was made the 9-5 favorite in the 10-horse field entered in the mile-and-an-eighth race.

Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun said he planned to return for a 24th season at the university. Calhoun’s Huskies finished the season at 31-5, losing in the national semifinals to Michigan State. Several off-the-court issues had prompted questions about Calhoun’s future, including an investigation into UConn’s recruitment of the former player Nate Miles. Calhoun has acknowledged that he or his staff may have made mistakes in recruiting Miles. Calhoun also has been treated for cancer three times during his UConn career, including last summer when he successfully battled skin cancer.

Terrell Owens showed up for the Buffalo Bills’ voluntary workout sessions a few weeks late and wondered what all the fuss was about. With a shrug of his shoulders, Owens noted that he was not the first or only N.F.L. player to miss a session in which attendance is not mandatory. “That’s what’s so frustrating about the whole thing, is that everybody nitpicks at anything and everything I do,” said Owens, who is with his fourth team now that he has signed a one-year, $6.5 million contract with the Bills. ¶Florida’s attorney general sued a company that makes a Michael Vick dog toy, claiming proceeds from the sale were never donated to animal shelters as promised by the company. The lawsuit also claims the toy was not manufactured in the United States, as the Jacksonville-based Showbiz Promotions advertised, and consumers complained about delivery delays. Vick is serving prison time for bankrolling a dogfighting operation in Georgia and Virginia. vicktoy.

Panther Racing has hired the veteran Scott Sharp to drive in the Indianapolis 500. Sharp, the 2001 pole starter, last drove in the Indy Racing League’s IndyCar Series in 2007 with Rahal Letterman Racing. He currently drives in the American Le Mans sports car series, and his deal with Panther is for only the Indy 500, where his teammate will be Dan Wheldon, the 2005 winner. Sharp, 41, was one of the original I.R.L. drivers in 1996 and still holds the series record with 146 career starts. He also has won nine races, most recently in 2005 at Kentucky Speedway. His best finish in 13 starts at Indianapolis was sixth in 2007.

ROSE--Frances Bailen, M.D.,on April 4th, 2009 at the age of 99. Beloved wife of Dr. O. Alan Rose, deceased mother of Susan Burns. Dr. Rose was born in Boston, MA, graduated from Simmons College and received her M.D. from NY University College of Medicine. Dr. Rose served her internship and residency at Bellevue Hospital. She continued on faculty of NY University for many years, was a Fellow of Academy of Medicine and the United States Public Health Service and was a consulting cardiologist at NYC Department of Health. Dr. Rose leaves her daughter, Susan Burns of Kissimmee, FL and two grandsons, Joseph Sarmiento and James Sarmiento. She will be remembered by friends and associates for her cheer and wit.

CULLMAN--Dorothy. With great sadness, the Trustees and staff of Enterprise Community Partners mourn the passing of Dorothy Cullman, who served as our Trustee and, along with her husband Lewis, was a great friend and a dedicated supporter of our affordable housing work. Dorothy cared deeply about improving the lives of poor and homeless families. By leading the Cullman Challenge with Lewis, she helped Enterprise build an invaluable reserve fund that ensures we can continue creating and preserving affordable homes and thriving communities long into the future. With her trademark candor, creativity and hard-hitting questions, she continually pressed us to do more. In recognition of their visionary leadership, we were privileged to honor Dorothy and Lewis with the James W. Rouse Civic Medal of Honor last year. Dorothy's dedication and generosity made a huge impact on the lives of New Yorkers in need, and she will be long remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lewis and the entire family. Norman B. Rice, Chairman Doris W. Koo, President & CEO William R. Frey, Executive Vice President Enterprise Community Partners, Inc.

Colony Capital, the private equity firm focused on real estate, has broken off talks with the troubled casino operator MGM Mirage about a potential loan to it, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday. The decision by Colony means that MGM Mirage must find alternative ways to raise enough money to pay off more than $13 billion in debt and to complete the construction of its CityCenter development in Las Vegas. MGM Mirage is locked in a dispute with Dubai World, its partner in CityCenter.

President Obama and guests celebrated Passover on Thursday evening with what White House officials believe to be the first Passover seder dinner held by an American president. Mr. Obama is not Jewish, but while traveling through Pennsylvania during the presidential campaign last year he surprised his aides by joining an impromptu Passover seder held by campaign workers in a ballroom of a Harrisburg hotel, so he decided to treat the group to a dinner this year in his new surroundings.

CULLMAN Dorothy. The Trustees and the staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of Dorothy Cullman, one of the most dedicated members of the Library family, who, along with her devoted husband Lewis, was one of the nation's leading philanthropists in the arts, culture, and education. She was a tremendously loyal and generous friend of the Library. She served as a Trustee for nearly two decades. Her energetic involvement had a far-reaching effect on the Library and the millions of people it serves. Dorothy and Lewis have helped propel the Library into the 21st century and allowed us to offer our extraordinary collections and services in exciting new facil ties in bold new ways. We are tremendously proud that our Trustees have named some of the Library's most outstanding facilities in Dorothy and Lewis's honor: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center, our unparalleled library on music, theatre, and dance; the Lewis B. and Dorothy Cullman Circulating Library and Reading Room at our the Science, Industry and Business Library, one of the Library's four major research centers; and the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers, housing our international fellowship program, created in honor of Brooke Russell Astor. The generosity that Dorothy and Lewis have shared has changed the landscape of New York and will have a lasting impact on our nation's cultural and intellectual life. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lewis, her sons Frederick and Bruce W. Benenson, and all of her family and friends. Catherine C. Marron, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

The death toll from the Italian earthquake rose to 281 on Thursday, Italian news media reported. Rescue workers continued to remove dead bodies from buildings, as aftershocks hampered salvage operations and kept tensions in the area high. In Rome, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, left, said the government had set aside $93 million in funds for the civil protection agency, which is coordinating the emergency response in the ravaged region. The government has allocated $133 million so far to assist the victims, including 28,000 people living in temporary housing.

On a perfect spring day, both President Obama and his wife, Michelle, were conducting business on Thursday on the South Lawn of the White House. At a picnic table next to the swings installed for the Obama children, the president was meeting with Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton. Down at the new White House kitchen garden, the first lady and Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack, shown below, were helping a group of children plant seedlings as part of an effort to get them -- and everyone else -- to eat more fruits and vegetables.

Nick Swisher had three hits Thursday, which meant that three times, he pointed to the sky with both index fingers. It is one of Swisher's tributes to his grandparents, Betty and Donald Swisher. After every hit, he points. Swisher also has his grandmother's initials -- BLS -- tattooed on the left side of his chest, and he writes her initials and his grandfather's -- DES -- on the knob of his bat.

The Indian Ocean standoff between an $800 million United States Navy destroyer and four pirates bobbing in a lifeboat showed the limits of the world's most powerful military as it faces a booming pirate economy in a treacherous patch of international waters. Driven solely by economic gain, not politics or religion, the band of pirates who captured an American merchant ship's captain on Wednesday are an unconventional foe for the American military. In recent years, they have shrewdly extorted millions of dollars from international shipping companies; to help negotiate the captain's release, the Navy turned for advice on Thursday to an F.B.I. hostage rescue team, practiced in a patient approach.

Loving wife of Murray to whom she was married at the Tavern on the Green almost sixty years ago. Devoted mother of Matthew (Elizabeth Taub) of New York City and Jean Stevens (Alec) of Westport, CT. Beloved grandmother of Benjamin and Harry Stevens and Daniel and Jonathan Warschauer. Favorite aunt, great aunt, cousin and friend to many. Graduate of Erasmus Hall High School and Brooklyn College. Former social worker at Family Service of Nassau County and JASA of Long Beach. Ballet, symphony, theater, tennis fan and book lover. Graveside services private. Memorial service in late spring. No flowers please. Donations to Doctors Without Borders, one of her favorite charities, are welcome.

CULLMAN--Dorothy. The Trustees of Neurosciences Research Foundation and the scientists and the staff of The Neurosciences Institute in La Jolla are deeply saddened by the passing of Dorothy Cullman, our dear friend and benefactor. Dorothy Cullman, along with her husband Lewis, has made a profound and permanent mark on the world through volunteerism and philanthropy. The Neurosciences Institute is deeply grateful and honored to be one of the many organizations transformed by their generosity. The Cullmans' commitment and support has enabled scientists at The Neurosciences Institute to make great progress in understanding how the brain works. This progress is certain to lead, eventually, to the development of better therapies and treatments for disorders of the brain and to enhancement of learning processes. Our gratitude and admiration for Dorothy Cullman are beyond measure, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to her family and to all she touched over her remarkable lifetime. William D. Walsh, Chairman Gerald M. Edelman, President W. Einar Gall, Research Director Rachel A. Jonte, Director of Institute Relations

MYERS--W. P. Laird. The Staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) notes with sadness the death of its esteemed colleague, W. P. Laird Myers, M.D. Dr. Myers served at MSKCC for 37 years (from 1952 to 1989). He was Chair of the Department of Medicine from 1967 to 1977, when he was appointed Chairman of Clinical Educational Affairs for Memorial Hospital. He also held the Eugene W. Kettering Chair of Education. In a career that encompassed patient care, research, and education, Dr. Myers was instrumental in broadening graduate and undergraduate medical school curricula to include training in oncology, and he developed a pioneering program requiring rotation to an oncology service as part of the training of doctors specializing in internal medicine. As Chair of the Department of Medicine, he expanded its services from the delivery of cancer care to include all sub-specialities of internal medicine, initiated a transition to a full-time faculty staff model, and set policy for a single physician of record for every patient. Dr. Myers was a model physician, caring for many patients, and mentoring and teaching innumerable medical students and physicians in training. We extend our condolences to his wife, Katharine, and his family. Robert E. Wittes Physician-in-Chief George J. Bosl Chair, Department of Medicine Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

Japan announced its biggest-ever economic stimulus plan on Thursday, a $154 billion package of subsidies and tax breaks that aims to stem a deepening recession in the world's second-largest economy. Prime Minister Taro Aso also outlined an ambitious long-term economic strategy that he said would make Japan a global leader in green technology like solar energy and electric cars.

KAY Martin L. Surrounded by his adoring family, Marty passed away on April 8, at the age of 87 after a long and inspirational bout with Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease. He was always a man of great character, intelligence, generosity and loyalty. He was an unwaveringly devoted husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather; always there for his family as a selfless, unconditionally loving mentor and coach. More importantly, he led and taught by example. His refusal to bow to adversity, particularly evident in recent years, has provided an indelible lesson of tenacity and perseverance to all those fortunate enough to know him. Born December 19, 1921 to Martin and Henrietta Katzenstein in New York City, he was the adored younger brother to Ruth (Reiss) and Robert Kay. He attended Horace Mann High School and went on to Cornell University, where he studied engineering. Married to Dickie Sloman in 1952, they spent the next 57 years together in what can only be characterized as the perfect relationship. In retirement, Marty and Dickie traveled together, played tennis and bridge and participated in numerous volunteer roles with United and White Plains Hospitals and Meals on Wheels. Marty's children, Patty (Raddock), Peter and Kathy (Gutner) were always at the center of his world and his pride in them was boundless. His love and friendship also made him Dad to their spouses Steve, Sheri and Richard. Marty had a special relationship with his 10 grandchildren. He loved talking to them and in later years, just being able to sit and watch them play together brought him enormous happiness. In 1945 Marty took over the reins of his grandfather's company, L. Katzenstein & Co. and ran it successfully for the next 45 years. Marty was a loyal and loving friend to all. For enjoyment, Marty loved playing tennis and bridge at Quaker Ridge Country Club, doing the Sunday Times crossword puzzle, and rooting for all New York pro teams (he was always a big baseball fan and equally loved the Yankees and Mets). Marty was a member of the King Solomon Lodge for 67 years. His optimism and courage are legacies that will be carried by the generations, present and future, that he helped to create. His family and friends celebrate his life and will dearly miss this extraordinary person. A memorial service will be held at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY 10601 on Saturday, April 11 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hospice of Westchester, 311 North Street, Suite 204, White Plains, NY 10605 or White Plains Hospital, Davis Avenue at East Post Road, White Plains, NY 10601.

Thousands of Iraqis marched on central Baghdad on Thursday to mark the sixth anniversary of the fall of the city to American forces and the execution of Ayatollah Muhammad Bakr al-Sadr, a Shiite cleric who was killed under Saddam Hussein in 1980. The demonstration was organized by followers of the ayatollah's son-in-law, the Shiite Cleric Moktada al-Sadr, but it also included Sunni Arabs and Turkmens. The crowd demanded that American troops withdraw from Iraq.

Graveside service Friday, April 10, 2009 at 11am at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Contributions may be made to the Weiss Foundation, P.O. Box 3, North Bergen, NJ 07047 in Sonia's name.

Each morning this week, The Choice has been publishing responses by Mark Kantrowitz of FinAid.org and FastWeb.com (a scholarship search site) to selected reader questions about financial aid. This is the sixth, and last, installment. In some instances, the questions below have been edited for space or style.

KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- The way Nick Swisher is playing right now (7 for 13, with two homers and nine runs batted in), the Yankees' November deal for him looks like a steal. They shipped infielder Wilson Betemit, a player they significantly overrated, and the minor league pitchers Jeff Marquez and Jhonny Nunez to the White Sox, who were eager to dump the $22 million they owed Swisher through 2011.

WASHINGTON -- Down by two goals with one minute to go in the national championship game, Boston University was right at home. Despite long odds, the Terriers staged a wild, extra-attacker scramble to claw back with two last-minute goals, then completed the comeback on Colby Cohen's overtime slap shot to beat Miami University, 4-3, and win the Division I men's title at the Verizon Center.

Josh Ruxin is the director of Rwanda Works and a Columbia University expert on public health who has spent the last few years living in Rwanda. He's an unusual mix of academic expert and mud-between-the-toes aid worker. This piece was co-written with Michael Brotchner, executive director of Orphans of Rwanda.
Boston University has just won the national title in N.C.A.A. Division I men's hockey. The details of the overtime session, and a wrapup of the whole weekend, will follow shortly.

WASHINGTON -- After three No. 1 seeds went down in the opening round, two teams mounted comebacks from two-goal deficits to win. After two overtime games and another that went to two overtimes, how could the Frozen Four live up to the first weekend of the N.C.A.A. hockey tournament?

WASHINGTON -- There was one minute left in regulation time. Miami held a two-goal lead and was one minute away from winning its first national championship. Somehow, some way, the Terriers clawed, scrambled and came away with two goals to tie the score, 3-3, extending the national championship game into overtime.The RedHawks took a 2-1 lead on a goal from Tommy Wingels that came on the rebound of a Carter Camper shot with 7 minutes 29 seconds to go. Trent Vogelhuber scored on a rifle from the high slot three minutes later and the life looked to be snatched from B.U.'s season.

Reporter David Segal looks at the town that might have lost more money per square mile than any other
in the country because of the downturn in the economy and the Ponzi scheming of Bernie Madoff.
WASHINGTON -- Miami got an early goal to even things up and despite a flurry of chances for both teams throughout the rest of the period, the title game heads into the second intermission tied, 1-1.

WASHINGTON -- Boston University is up, 1-0, after one period in the national championship game on a goal from the freshman wing Chris Connolly. After a slow start full of neutral-zone action between B.U. and Miami, the Terriers began to string together passes and weave the puck through center-ice to create offensive chances.The goal came on a lucky bounce, when David Warsofsky threw a puck into traffic from the left point that deflected off RedHawks center Trent Vogelhuber and down into the crease. The freshman goalie Cody Reichard did his best to get a glove on the puck and freeze it, but Connolly swooped in to jam it out of his reach and into the net with 4 minutes 45 seconds to go in the period.
It's down to the Miami RedHawks and the Boston University Terriers for the national championship in N.C.A.A. Division I men's hockey.

WASHINGTON -- College hockey fans turned the streets surrounding the Verizon Center red and white, as Miami and Boston University prepared to play each other for the N.C.A.A. Division I men's national championship.

KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- The Yankees planned to give Johnny Damon the night off Saturday, with Nick Swisher playing left field and Mark Teixeira at first base. But about 30 minutes before game time, Teixeira was scratched with a sore left wrist.

The Boston Bruins went out of the Presidents' Trophy race with a whimper on Saturday, losing in Buffalo to the Sabres by 6-1. The B's had to win their last two games to have a shot at the Prez, so that's that. • San Jose celebrated their first Presidents' Trophy by, um, losing in Los Angeles, 4-3. • In any case, in the 14 post-seasons since the current playoff format was installed in 1994, the Prez winner has reached the semifinals 11 times and the Stanley Cup final 6 times, winning the cup on 5 occasions.

President Obama's unscheduled visit to Iraq suggests a president determined to see a war zone first hand and draw his own conclusions. Lincoln availed himself of that opportunity during the Civil War, but the most pertinent example may be Dwight D. Eisenhower, who toured the battlefront in Korea shortly before his inauguration. Ike had pledged to go to Korea if elected, and most voters assumed that the supreme commander - who had so effectively defeated the German Wehrmacht - would quickly dispatch the North Koreans and their Chinese allies.

KANSAS CITY, Mo. - When I got back to my hotel Friday night, Game 6 of the 1977 World Series was playing on ESPN Classic. That, of course, was the game that made Reggie Jackson Mr. October. He hit three home runs against the Los Angeles Dodgers to clinch the championship.

MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. -- The lasting image from the Mets' farewell ceremony at Shea Stadium last Sept. 28 is of Tom Seaver and Mike Piazza walking toward the center-field fence and out of the ballpark, arms around each other, in a fittingly moving ending to a emotional day. Seaver threw the final pitch at Shea to Piazza, and they will come full circle on Monday night, when the Mets play their first regular-season game at Citi Field, against the San Diego Padres. Just like seven months ago, Piazza will catch the ceremonial pitch from Seaver, who said he only hoped he could reach him.

Lax enforcement of building codes appears to be one reason.

Conference USA has signed an agreement to send one of its teams to this year’s Hawaii Bowl. The runner-up in the Conference USA championship game or another selection will be invited to take on a Western Athletic Conference team — Hawaii if it is bowl eligible — in the bowl on Dec. 24.

The high school coach who was fired after his girls basketball team won a game by 100-0 said he felt no need to apologize because he “did everything the right way.” Micah Grimes, who was fired days after the Covenant School of Dallas made national headlines with the victory against Dallas Academy in January, told ESPN in his first televised interview that he realized the inferiority of the opponent.

The Boston University senior defenseman Matt Gilroy received the Hobey Baker Memorial Award on Friday night as college hockey’s top player. Gilroy is the second Boston University player to win the award, after the Rangers’ Chris Drury in 1998. Gilroy was selected over his teammate Colin Wilson, a forward, and Northeastern goaltender Brad Thiessen. Gilroy walked on as a freshman but is now a team captain. The Terriers play Miami University on Saturday night in the N.C.A.A. title game.

Jurors in Miami began deliberating Friday on tax evasion charges against the racecar driver Hélio Castroneves and two advisers. In closing arguments, prosecutors said Castroneves, his sister and business manager Katiucia Castroneves, and the Michigan lawyer Alan Miller conspired to evade millions in taxes. Jurors deliberated for about two and a half hours before adjourning until Monday morning. If convicted, Castroneves, his sister and Miller each could face more than six years in prison.
NFL Network and Dish Network announced a settlement that ends a lawsuit over how the satellite provider broadcasts the channel

Lance Armstrong said he thought French doping officials would bar him from this year’s Tour de France because of a report that he violated protocols during a recent drug test. In a video statement on his Web site, Armstrong said there was a “very high likelihood” he would not be allowed to race for an eighth Tour de France title. The French drug testing agency has said it could punish Armstrong, who said the drug tests came back negative.

The team that beat them, Minnesota, stayed alive -- until the Ducks earned a playoff berth with a regulation tie (which later became a shootout win). • That completes the post-season lineup, leaving only the Presidents' Trophy race up for grabs:

A review of the novel “A Fortunate Age” on Page 12 this weekend refers incorrectly to the author, Joanna Smith Rakoff, at several points. As correctly noted elsewhere in the review, she is Rakoff — not Smith.

An article on Wednesday about the stripping of fixtures from a vacant 16,000-square-foot house in the San Diego County community of Olivenhain referred incorrectly to the area. Olivenhain is part of the City of Encinitas; it is not an unincorporated community.

A picture caption on Page 21 this weekend with the continuation of the cover article about the Grateful Dead misstates the date of the concert shown. The show in Hartford took place in May 1977, not 2007.

An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing on Friday about performances of “Treasure Island” by the Literally Alive Children’s Theater, using information provided by the theater, erroneously included two days among those on which the show will be performed. While performances are scheduled for the remaining Saturdays and Sundays of the show’s run through May 10 at the Players Theater in Greenwich Village, as well as next Wednesday and Thursday, it will not be performed today and tomorrow.

2 P.M. (13) APPALACHIA: A HISTORY OF MOUNTAINS AND PEOPLE The mountains of Appalachia are some of the oldest in the world, and home to one of the most diverse ecosystems. But its land and people have endured immense exploitation in the name of industrialization. This four-part series, directed by Ross Spears, examines Appalachia's natural riches and the impact they have had on the region's inhabitants through interviews with the scientist E. O. Wilson and the author Barbara Kingsolver. Sissy Spacek narrates. NOON (13) THE OPEN MIND Dr. David A. Hamburg, the psychiatrist and a president emeritus of the Carnegie Corporation, discusses his book ''Preventing Genocide: Practical Steps Toward Early Detection and Effective Action.''

The New York State Police charged Ernie Paragallo, a prominent New York thoroughbred breeder and owner, with 22 counts of animal cruelty on Friday for neglecting the horses on his breeding farm. Each count carries a punishment of up to a year in prison and a $1,000 fine. Paragallo, 51, was arraigned Friday before the Coxsackie Town Justice Thomas Fori. He was sent to the Greene County Jail in lieu of $5,000 cash or a $10,000 bond bail.

DOMANSKY--Harry Bel, husband of Sophie; devoted father of Martin and Paula Domansky; cherished grandfather of Elissa and Scott; adored great-grandfather of Olivia, David, Remy and Jordan. Holocost survivor, lover of the state of Israel, involved in many Jewish Philintropic organizations. Harry loved and cared for everyone. Service Sunday, April 12, Parkside Chapel 12 Noon 98-60 Queens Blvd., Rego Park, NY.

CULLMAN--Dorothy. The cultural and civic life of our city is that much richer because of Dorothy's activism and generosity. Our hearts go out to her beloved husband Lewis and to her sons and grandchildren. The Municipal Art Society of New York

YOUNG--Jane Jaffe, Ph.D. Professor of English at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, where, for 43 years, she taught composition, literature, and film. As chapter chair of the faculty union, the Professional Staff Congress, since 2001, she advocated effectively for the rights of her colleagues and was choosen Member of the Year for Higher Education by the New York State United Teachers in 2007. A freelance writer and poet, she published articles in academic journals and in New York Magazine, the Village Voice, the Daily News, and Newsday. At the age of nineteen, she won the Mayoral Peotry Award for her poem "Kaleidescope," along with now-famous author Erica Long. Her book, D.H. Lawrence on Screen, studied the ways in which filmmakers adapted the stylistic elements of "The Rocking-Horse Winner," Sons and Lovers, and Women in Love to Lawrence's literary style. Critic John Simon wrote that "her conclusions are of equal value to Lawrence scholars, film students, and all others who care about film and fiction and their fascinating interplay." She graduated from the High School of Music and Art, received her B.A. degree Phi Beta Kappa from the City College of New York, earned a master's degree at Harvard University, and completed her Ph.D. at New York University. She died at home surrounded by loving family and friends. She is survived by her life partner, Phil Eggers, daughter Victoria Young Salganik, son-in-law Jonas Salganik, granddaughter Natasha Rose Salganik, stepson David Eggar, stepdaughter Cynthia Wendy Eggers Butler and husband Sean Butler, and stepson Michael Eggers. A service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, on Sunday, April 12 at 2:30pm. Contributions may be made in lieu of flowers to the Mesothelioma Applied research Foundation (MARF), P.O. Box 91840, Santa Barbara, CA 93190-1840.

GORDON--Joseph, M.D.,FACS, April 9, 2009 of Medford, NJ. Husband of Marjorie (nee Haajanen) Gordon. Father of David Gordon, Daniel Gordon, Derek Gordon, Amy (Andrew) Rodriguez and Seth (Amy) Gordon. Grandfather of five. Services Sunday, 1:00pm at Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., Cherry Hill, NJ. The family will return to the home of Amy and Andrew Rodriguez. Contributions may be made to the New Jersey Audubon Society or a memorial fund to be established at Temple Emanuel of Beverly Hills, CA.

DAVIDSON--Caroline Mae on April 10, 2009, of Forest Hills, NY. Practicing criminal lawyer for 70 years. Beloved wife of the late Herbert; loving mother of Richard and the late Steven; grandmother of Darcie and Sarah; great-grandmother of Layla. A gathering and reflections at Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, Sunday, April 12, 11am.

KAUFMAN--Sheila Kelley, on April 8, 2009. Beloved wife of Robert M. Kaufman; devoted daughter of the late William J. Kelley and the late Jane Seymour Kelley; loving sister of the late Donald Seymour Kelley; dear friend of Otelia Nicholson. The Yankees are the visitors for three home openers on this trip, and each one is special. In Baltimore, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. threw out the first pitch. In Tampa, Fla., on Monday, the Rays will presumably raise their American League championship banner. And here in Kansas City, we have the first game at the New K. That would be Kauffman Stadium, looking spiffy after a $250 million renovation and expansion. The stadium was far ahead of its time when it opened as Royals Stadium in 1973, a baseball-only facility at a time when multipurpose parks were popular. Now Kauffman, one of baseball's best sites, looks better than ever.

CULLMAN--Dorothy. The Trustees and staff of the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, NY are saddened by the passing of Dorothy Cullman who, with her beloved husband Lewis, made an extraordinary commitment to the cultural and educational life of Long Island's East End through the establishment of the Lewis B. and Dorothy Cullman Chief Curator, Art and Education position at the Parrish Art Museum. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Lewis and to the entire Cullman family.
LEHMAN--John. Congregation Emanu-El of the city of New York mourns the death of our longtime and cherished member, and extends deepest sympathy to his family.

LEHMAN--John E.,age 91, died peacefully at home on April 9. Beloved husband of Peggy S., devoted father of John and Doug, cherished father-in-law of Betsey and Marjorie, and treasured grandfather of Geoffrey, Julie, Dana and Michael. He had a long career as a partner in the firm of William E. Lehman Architects. His goodness, loving-kindness, unselfishness and compassion will remain in our hearts, our poet laureate, whose effortless good humor brought delight to all who knew him. Services private.

DALLAL--Frederic, on April 6th. Loving father of Hilarie and Jeff, grandfather, brother and uncle, dear friend to so many. Memorial service Sunday, April 12, 2pm at Riverside, 180 W. 76th St. Contributions can be made in his honor to Friends of Israel Defense Forces.

Toyota Scions on display at the New York International Auto Show. Scions were among the many new small cars that automakers hope will revive their sales. The show, which opened Friday at the Jacob Javitz Convention Center, will continue through April 19.

STERN--Michael. The Directors of the Zachary and Elizabeth M. Fisher Alzheimer's Disease Program, NYU School of Medicine, are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, Michael Stern. He contributed greatly to our research and findings which have been helping millions of persons with Alzheimer's and their families. We and those we serve will be forever grateful for his unwavering, longstanding support. A visionary and a renaissance man, he led a rich, full, and exemplary life. We will dearly miss him. We send our deepest sympathies to his son, Michael, daughter, Margaret, and granddaughter, Margaret Ann. Dr. Barry Reisberg, Director Dr. Sunnie Kenowsky, Co-director Fisher Alzheimer's Disease Program, NYU School of Medicine

LOS ANGELES — It’s always hard to figure out what to give someone special as a farewell present. But the officers and board members of the Los Angeles Philharmonic came up with an ideal gift for Esa-Pekka Salonen, who is about to step down as the orchestra’s music director after 17 years. They have established the Esa-Pekka Salonen Commissions Fund, to honor his commitment to the music of our time.

The New York Theater Workshop will announce two forthcoming productions this week. In September, it will offer “Aftermath,” by Jessica Blank and Erik Jensen, the collaborators behind “The Exonerated.” The new documentary play is based on interviews with Iraqi civilians about their wartime experiences. Rebecca Gilman’s “The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter,” based on the Carson McCullers novel, will follow in November. It will be directed by Doug Hughes (“Doubt”) in a co-production with the Acting Company, which presented the world premiere of the play in 2005, also directed by Mr. Hughes. … “punkplay,” by Gregory Moss, will be the first offering in Clubbed Thumb’s 14th annual Summerworks festival, to be held at the Ohio Theater in SoHo June 3-27. Davis McCallum (“Queens Boulevard”) will direct the story of a suburban teenager who teams up with a tough runaway and tries to change his life through punk rock music. Two other productions will round out the festival: “Precious Little,” by Madeleine George and “Telethon,” by Kristin Newbom. … Ellen Stewart, the founder and director of La MaMa E.T.C. is at work on a new show about Aesculapius, the ancient Greek god of healing. (He’s the guy who carried around a staff with a serpent twisting around it, now a universal symbol for medicine.) This tale of the child of the god Apollo and the mortal maiden Coronis, scheduled for May 28-June 14, will be told with actors from the Great Jones Repertory Company, puppets created by Theodora Skipitares and music by several composers including Ms. Stewart.

It’s that time of year again, when a group of “Let’s-put-on-a-show” theater folks — actors, directors, composers, lyricists, choreographers — forgoes sleep and devotes a precious Monday night off to a good cause. And no, Liza Minnelli is not playing a late set at Splash.

There's a tendency to see women's rights in developing countries as worthy but minor, as secondary in a world facing so many vast challenges of war, terrorism and environmental degradation. My wife and I, in our forthcoming book on this topic, try to argue that in fact you can't address these larger issues of poverty, environment or security unless you also address the rights and status of women in these countries, and I just finished reading a new book that makes this case particularly eloquently. The book is Michelle Goldberg's "The means of Reproduction: Sex, Power, and the Future of the World."

Roger Federer married his longtime companion, Mirka Vavrinec, in a small ceremony in his hometown, Basel, Switzerland. He announced the wedding on his Web site, saying the couple were married “surrounded by a small group of close friends and family.” They announced last month that they were expecting their first child.

Buffalo Bills defensive back Donte Whitner was shocked with a stun gun and arrested by officers trying to control a rowdy crowd outside a Cleveland nightclub, the police said. Whitner, 23, was jailed early Saturday, Lt. Thomas Stacho said. He was released, and a prosecutor will decide whether to file charges.

The teenage star Joey Logano raced to his second Nationwide Series victory, holding off his Joe Gibbs Racing teammate Kyle Busch in the Pepsi 300 at Nashville Superspeedway in Gladeville, Tenn. The 18-year-old Logano and Busch ran in the top two and traded the lead for most of the race.

The Cleveland Indians have placed starter Scott Lewis on the 15-day disabled list with an elbow strain. Lewis, a left-hander, pitched four and a third innings Friday in the Indians’ home-opening loss to the Toronto Blue Jays. With their bullpen overworked and underperforming, the Indians purchased the contract of the right-hander Vinnie Chulk from Class AAA Columbus. Chulk arrived in time for Saturday’s game against Toronto as the Indians tried to get their first win of the season after an 0-4 start.

China’s basketball administration has handed out a record fine of 330,000 yuan ($48,290) to two clubs and five players for a brawl during a playoff game last Sunday. China’s attempt to bring more contact into the domestic game has resulted in an increase in on-court violence and more fines from the governing body, officials said. The noncontact style previously prevalent in the league was criticized for producing players not tough enough for the international game.

Alberto Contador, a Spanish rider for Astana, won his second straight Tour of Basque Country title Saturday after extending his overall lead in the final stage ending in Zalla, Spain. He is using the Basque classic as part of his preparations for the Tour de France, which he won in 2007.

Jelena Jankovic will face a local favorite, the Spaniard Carla Suarez Navarro, in the Andalucia Tennis Experience final Sunday in Marbella, Spain. Jankovic defeated fourth-seeded Anabel Medina Garrigues, 7-5, 6-2, to reach her first final of the season. Suarez Navarro held off seventh-seeded Sorana Cirstea, 6-2, 6-7 (5), 6-2. ¶Lleyton Hewitt of Australia reached his first clay court final in a decade with a 7-6 (4), 6-4 win over Evgeny Korolev of Russia at the United States Men’s Clay Court Championships in Houston. He will face the American Wayne Odesnik, who beat Bjorn Phau of Germany, 6-4, 6-3. houston (AP).

KAUFMAN--Sheila Kelley, on April 8, 2009. Beloved wife of Robert M. Kaufman; devoted daughter of the late William J. Kelley and the late Jane Seymour Kelley; loving sister of the late Donald Seymour Kelley; dear friend of Otelia Nicholson. She was a public relations executive who served as a press secretary to Senator Jacob K. Javits, as a Senior Vice President of Doremus and Company and Gavin Anderson and Company and as a principal of The Dilenschneider Group. Funeral private. Contributions in her memory may be made to The New York Community Trust for the Jane and Donald Seymour Kelley Fund or the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

HITCHINGS-SHAVER--Joyce C.,M.D. Dr. Joyce C., 77, died April 3, 2009 in New York City of cancer. A graduate of Cornell University, class of 1953, and Cornell Medical School, class of 1957, Dr. Shaver-Hitchings began her career as a clinical physician and researcher in the field of endocrinology. She completed post-doctorate work in Geneva, Switzerland and conducted medical research at Bellevue and Roosevelt hospitals in New York City before moving to Chapel Hill, NC in 1974 to devote her practice to the treatment of alcoholism and drug addiction. Dr. Shaver-Hitchings was affiliated with the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Graduate and Medical School teaching programs and was co-founder of the UNC-CH Shaver-Hitchings Scholarship Fund. A native of Corning, NY, Dr. Shaver-Hitchings was the daughter of William W. Shaver, Ph.D., a senior research physicist at Corning Glass Works and a pioneer in the field of glass fiber optics, and Ruby Bower Shaver, a graduate of Elmira College, class of 1921. An intrepid traveler, accomplished pianist and eternal student, Dr. Shaver-Hitchings inspired a love of learning and adventure in all who knew her. Beloved mother of Joan Muecke Gerolmo (deceased), Anne Muecke Somlyo, and William Edward Muecke, her children with first husband Dr. Edward C. Muecke, M.D. of New York City. Cherished grandmother of Edward Liptzin, Frank, Julia, and Samantha Gerolmo, Katie and Andrew Somlyo, and Liam, Cecilia, and Theo Muecke. Dr. Shaver-Hitchings was the widow of Nobel Laureate Dr. George H. Hitchings, M.D. We will miss her warm friendship and supportive presence, her easy self-deprecating laugh and ready humor, her zest for word-play and puns, her silly songs and thoughtful prose, her love of music, art, and dramatic theater, her appreciation for the subtle natural world, her ability to find wonder to celebrate in even the smallest detail, her photos that captured every angle of the ordinary in panoramic collages that were extraordinary, her panache for Ziploc, her appreciation for inner value, her humanist ethic, her encouragement to dream, to strive, and to create happiness, her lessons in love, acceptance, and perseverance, and her acute fascination with the free, the funny, and the beautiful simplicities of life. We love you, Mom

An article on March 22 about Greg Mottola's movie ''Adventureland'' misidentified the actress who plays the stepmother of Kristen Stewart's character. She is Mary Birdsong -- not Wendie Malick, who portrays the mother of Jesse Eisenberg's character.

A Manischewitz and bourbon cocktail? Now there's some chutzpah. Meet the Drunken Pharaoh, a drink that sounds like a Sammy Davis Jr. routine served over ice. (And I haven't even mentioned yet the rim of crushed matzo on the glass.) Along with a liver-and-bacon-on-challah dish entitled ''The Conflicted Jew,'' it's on the menu at JoeDoe, a 27-seat bistro at 45 East First Street, and it was the liquid starter to the ''Progressive Passover'' seder that the restaurant held Tuesday. After all, as the comedian Jackie Mason once said, ''a seder without sweet Manischewitz would be like horseradish without tears, like a cantor without a voice, like a shul without a complaint, like a yenta without a big mouth, like Passover without Jews.''

AINSBERG--Zelda. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Dearest mother of Arthur and Richard (Suzy). Loving grandmother of Joseph (Jessica), Aliza, Zachary, and Alex. Devoted sister-in-law of Louis Ainsberg and Jeannette Ikka. A women whose greatest love and devotion were to her family.

AUSTIN--Alice Howe, 91, of Missoula, died quietly at her home on Sunday, March 29. She was born in Windsor, CT on August 6, 1917 to Arthur Howe and Margaret Armstrong. Alice grew up in Windsor, CT, Hanover, NH, and Hampton, VA, where her father was an educator and administrator at Taft School, Dartmouth College and Hampton Institute respectively. Her mother was self-employed in her later years managing the family owned resort Rockywold-Deephaven Camps on Squam Lake, NH that became the center of her family's life over the years. It was on a Vassar Outing Club trip to Mt. Moosilauke, NH that Alice met her future husband, Briggs M. Austin, who was on a similar expedition with Dartmouth's Outing Club. Throughout their life together, they continued to travel and enjoy mountain and wilderness areas on foot and by canoe, including overseas and in Montana where they retired in 1975 to Missoula. In Rochester, NY, Alice took up teaching elementary grades in the inner-city schools and working for Planned Parenthood, living out her deep commitment to social justice and equality started in the family by her grandfather, General Samuel Chapman Armstrong, who founded Hampton Institute, the first college for black students, at the end of the Civil War. In Missoula, Alice became well-known for her dedication and service to preservation of the natural environment through her extensive lobbying and volunteer efforts, and the sense of community she found in Montana derived from these efforts brought her great pleasure.

BARNETT--Dr. Marjorie C.,a leading Chicago psychoanalyst, patron of the arts, passed away peacefully on April 2 at her home in Lincoln Park, Chicago surrounded by her friends and family. She was 78 years old. Dr. Barnett loved her children, loved music, loved art, loved her profession, loved her patients, loved good food and fine wine, loved good literature, loved tennis, loved skiing and running, loved and was loved by her friends she truly loved and embraced life. Dr. Barnett founded the A.N. and Pearl G. Barnett Family Foundation in 1989 to underwrite research in medicine and psychoanalysis. For many years, she supported clinical research in Hematology. Since 1997, the Foundation has sponsored an annual competition for young talented musicians. Each year a different instrument was featured, the young competitors played a selection of classical repertoire. Under her direction, The Foundation commissioned works by young composers to be learned and performed by all contestants. Most recently, she funded the Israeli String Quartet that was suggested to her by her friend, Itzhak Perlman, who has admitted her into his Perlman Music Program. She hosted eagerly anticipated evenings for the competitions, and concert soirees featuring the finest professional musicians reminiscent of the grand salons of 19th century Europe. The invitees came from all walks of life, the established, working folk, musicians, students, photographers, career professionals, artists anyone who shared Dr. Barnett's interest in music, art, and stimulating conversation. She thrived on lively conversation, analysis, art, music and fine food. Often the chef de cuisine was a famous local chef- and more recently her brilliant chef son-Douglas. Dr. Barnett was born in Brooklyn, New York, attended Stanford University at the young age of 16, and later graduated from the University of Wisconsin-Madison. She was the first woman to attend and to graduate from the Chicago Medical School. After receiving her medical degree, she completed her internship at the University of Minnesota Hospital, and a residency in Psychiatry at Michael Reese Hospital. She continued her studies at the Institute for Psychoanalysis in Chicago, graduating in both the core analytic and child analytic programs, and later served on the faculty. She also served on the faculty of the University of Chicago, authored several seminal articles on psychoanalytic theory published in the Journal of the American Psychoanalytic Association, and the Annual of Psychoanalysis. Well-known as a person of wide ranging interests and remarkable intensity and ability, she was exceptionally dedicated to her patients and practice continuing to see patients until the very end. She played piano brilliantly, traveled extensively and was a devoted enthusiast of 20th Century modern art. She skied well enough to be selected to join the Aspen Ski Patrol, piloted an airplane, played tennis every Saturday and challenged the best players on the court. She explored the intellectual aspects of all facets of the world and was a slave to none although she remained a confirmed and convinced Freudian. As with music, she had the same keen understanding and appreciation of art and literature. Anyone who visited a museum with her, or attended a concert, or shared in a book discussion, came away amazed at the independence, and depth and subtlety of her appreciation. She will be missed by all who loved and knew her. She is survived by two adoring sons, Alexander Gordon Barnett, and Douglas George Barnett of Chicago, two sisters, Sally Barnett and Barbara Barnett Goldfarb of New York, and an extensive network of close friends that she cultivated throughout her life. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions may be made to the A.N. and Pearl G. Barnett Foundation, 300 West Adams St., Suite 424, Chicago, IL 60606, or visit www.thebarnettfoundation.org

A review of the novel ''A Fortunate Age'' on Page 12 this weekend refers incorrectly to the author, Joanna Smith Rakoff, at several points. As correctly noted elsewhere in the review, she is Rakoff -- not Smith.

THE NEWS On his way to a top-level briefing on a planned roundup of terror suspects, Bob Quick, the head of counterterrorism for the London police, got out of a car holding a secret document about the operation in the plain view of news photographers. BEHIND THE NEWS After failing to suppress photos in which the document, including names of suspects, could be clearly read, the British government rushed the planned arrests, and Mr. Quick resigned. It was the second major embarrassment in a week for the police: A video surfaced showing an unprovoked assault by an officer on an unarmed man during street protests in London on April 1; the man later died.

KIRSCH--William J.,died March 25 at age 86. He is survived by his beloved sister Mary Goldsmith and by eight nieces and nephews and their loving families and by his close friend, John Battis. Bill served his country honorably in the mechanized cavalry during WW II. He graduated from Reed College in Portland, OR in 1950 and had a distinguished career in nonprofit management, retiring after many years of service to the Foundation Center in New York where he was Vice President/Treasurer. Bill will be greatly missed by his many friends, professional colleagues, and loving family. A celebration of Bill's life will be held at Scandinavia House, New York City on April 17. Memorial contributions may be made to the American-Scandinavian Foundation. Contact Lynn Carter at 212-847-9720 for more information.

The city during Easter Week was a kaleidoscope of color and craziness: circus-themed shop windows, elephants lunching at Eighth Avenue and 33rd Street. And one could say the Easter parade has gone to the dogs -- they're wearing the hats. For many New Yorkers, spring arrives with the blooming magnolias on the lawn of the Frick Collection. Workers in Central Park were planting the urns at the Naumburg Bandshell, and an inflatable rabbit decorated a 91st Street town house. Enormous necklaces and gigantic pink shoulder bows are part of the spring explosion.

BARCELONA Not to be missed in Barcelona at the moment is an exhibition of Cildo Meireles, a Brazilian conceptual artist, on view at Macba (Museu d'Art Contemporani de Barcelona, Plaça dels Angels 1; www.macba.cat) through April 26. After all, how many art exhibitions require visitors to sign not one but two waivers releasing the museum from any responsibility for personal injury? Several of the artist's installations, which fall into the broad category of conceptual art, call on the visitor to participate in the artistic experience.

WHEN General Motors unveiled Project P.U.M.A. in New York on Tuesday (with partner Segway), it was showing not so much a vehicle as a vision for a new transportation system. And that's high risk, high reward, because as much as new concepts are needed, they're excruciatingly hard to actually put in place. The P.U.M.A. is a two-wheel, two-seat, gyroscopically balanced urban transit device with a top speed of 35 miles an hour and the potential to be remotely operated. Toyota has also shown a fanciful personal mobility option called the i-Swing, a single-seat pod on wheels with joystick controls.

KOVACIC--Jerald J.,a renowned leader in the application of algebraic techniques to differential equations theory died at his home of glioblastoma multiforme on April 1, 2009. He was 68. He died in the care of his loving partner and now husband of 32 years, Daniel J. Kiser. The famed Kovacic algorithm for solving second order linear ordinary differential equations has been implemented in commercial and open source scientific software. It is a breakthrough procedure for computing the algebraic group associated with the equation, called its differential Galois group. Dr. Kovacic received his Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1968. He was an assistant professor at Princeton University from 1968 until 1970. He taught at Lehman College, Fordham University, and Brooklyn College. From 1981 to 2001, he was computer programmer and technical director at JYACC, a computer services firm in NYC. Jerald was working on the challenging task of laying the foundations for a new geometry of differential equations, modeled on algebraic geometry. He was webmaster and defacto technical director of the Kolchin Seminar in Differential Algebra (KSDA), Graduate Center, CUNY. Memorial Service Friday, April 24, 6:30pm at his home. Contributions to City College/KSDA; c/o Dan Kiser, Inc, 307 7th Avenue 1405 New York, NY 10001.

FEEL-GOOD WIN AT BLUE GRASS For Thomas McCarthy, a 75-year-old retired principal from Louisville, it was his first victory in a stakes race. And what a dandy it was. General Quarters, owned and trained by McCarthy, edged Hold Me Back and Massone to win the $750,000 Blue Grass Stakes in Lexington, Ky., by one and a half lengths. He finished the one-and-one-eighth-mile race in 1:49.26 and paid $30.60 on a $2 bet to win.

HITCHINGS-SHAVER--Joyce C.,M.D. Dr. Joyce C., 77, died April 3, 2009 in New York City of cancer. A graduate of Cornell University, class of 1953, and Cornell Medical School, class of 1957, Dr. Shaver-Hitchings began her career as a clinical physician and researcher in the field of endocrinology. She completed post-doctorate work in Geneva, Switzerland and conducted medical research at Bellevue and Roosevelt hospitals in New York City before moving to Chapel Hill, NC in 1974 to devote her practice to the treatment of alcoholism and drug addiction. Dr. Shaver-Hitchings was affiliated with the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Graduate and Medical School teaching programs and was co-founder of the UNC-CH Shaver-Hitchings Scholarship Fund. A native of Corning, NY, Dr. Shaver-Hitchings was the daughter of William W. Shaver, Ph.D., a senior research physicist at Corning Glass Works and a pioneer in the field of glass fiber optics, and Ruby Bower Shaver, a graduate of Elmira College, class of 1921. An intrepid traveler, accomplished pianist and eternal student, Dr. Shaver-Hitchings inspired a love of learning and adventure in all who knew her. Beloved mother of Joan Muecke Gerolmo (deceased), Anne Muecke Somlyo, and William Edward Muecke, her children with first husband Dr. Edward C. Muecke, M.D. of New York City. Cherished grandmother of Edward Liptzin, Frank, Julia, and Samantha Gerolmo, Katie and Andrew Somlyo, and Liam, Cecilia, and Theo Muecke. Dr. Shaver-Hitchings was the widow of Nobel Laureate Dr. George H. Hitchings, M.D. We will miss her warm friendship and supportive presence, her easy self-deprecating laugh and ready humor, her zest for word-play and puns, her silly songs and thoughtful prose, her love of music, art, and dramatic theater, her appreciation for the subtle natural world, her ability to find wonder to celebrate in even the smallest detail, her photos that captured every angle of the ordinary in panoramic collages that were extraordinary, her panache for Ziploc, her appreciation for inner value, her humanist ethic, her encouragement to dream, to strive, and to create happiness, her lessons in love, acceptance, and perseverance, and her acute fascination with the free, the funny, and the beautiful simplicities of life. We love you, Mom

YOUNG--Jane Jaffe, Ph.D. Professor of English at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, where, for 43 years, she taught composition, literature, and film. As chapter chair of the faculty union, the Professional Staff Congress, since 2001, she advocated effectively for the rights of her colleagues and was choosen Member of the Year for Higher Education by the New York State United Teachers in 2007. A freelance writer and poet, she published articles in academic journals and in New York Magazine, the Village Voice, the Daily News, and Newsday. At the age of nineteen, she won the Mayoral Peotry Award for her poem "Kaleidescope," along with now-famous author Erica Long. Her book, D.H. Lawrence on Screen, studied the ways in which filmmakers adapted the stylistic elements of "The Rocking-Horse Winner," Sons and Lovers, and Women in Love to Lawrence's literary style. Critic John Simon wrote that "her conclusions are of equal value to Lawrence scholars, film students, and all others who care about film and fiction and their fascinating interplay." She graduated from the High School of Music and Art, received her B.A. degree Phi Beta Kappa from the City College of New York, earned a master's degree at Harvard University, and completed her Ph.D. at New York University. She died at home surrounded by loving family and friends. She is survived by her life partner, Phil Eggers, daughter Victoria Young Salganik, son-in-law Jonas Salganik, granddaughter Natasha Rose Salganik, stepson David Eggar, stepdaughter Cynthia Wendy Eggers Butler and husband Sean Butler, and stepson Michael Eggers. A service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, on Sunday, April 12 at 2:30pm. Contributions may be made in lieu of flowers to the Mesothelioma Applied research Foundation (MARF), P.O. Box 91840, Santa Barbara, CA 93190-1840.
Danny Casarella AGE 17, senior

ENGELSON--Miriam (Mim), died March 30, 2009 at age 87 with her family present in California. Beloved wife of Howard for 67 years. Devoted mother of Carol, the late Ellen, Kathy and Erik; grandmother of Alexandra, Susan and Elisabeth; and great-grandmother of Chloe, Samantha, and Luke. Mim spent short periods in Florida, Georgia, and Indiana, and lived most of her life in New York. Already a grandmother, she proudly earned her B.A. degree in English and Teaching License from Queens College in NYC at age 58, and went on to teach in Great Neck, NY. Later she became the special assistant to the Japanese Ambassador to the United Nations and worked at the NY Metropolitan Museum of Art. Howard and Mim moved to Boston, where she volunteered at the Boston Athenaeum, and then to Half Moon Bay, CA. She served for a decade as a docent at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. She will be greatly missed for her love, spunk, flair, smarts, and savvy. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Osteoporosis Foundation.

CARTER--Elizabeth Baker, 70, died quietly at home in Eastham, MA on April 5th. She was the beloved wife of Paul; loving mother to Michael, Catherine, and Stephen; adoring grandmother to Megan, Alexandra, and Julianne; and devoted sister to Brian and Diane. Teacher, editor, and perpetual student of art history, she completed the manuscript of her father, Carlos Baker, and arranged for its posthumous publication as "Emerson Among the Eccentrics: A Group Portrait." Betsy had an intellectual curiosity, a probing mind, a sympathetic concern for those in need, and a love of life. She courageously faced a number of serious health problems during her life and triumphed over them. She will be missed greatly by her loving family and her many friends. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the James H. Beck Memorial Fund, Dept. of Art History, Columbia University; or International House, 500 Riverside Drive, New York City.

PEARALL--Willard H.,Jr., died April 6, 2009 at the age of 85 inJacksonville, Florida. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he graduated from Poly Prep, Williams College and Harvard Business School. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Paula, his daughters, Marilla and Katharine (John-Fiske Smith), his son, Willard, his brother, Otis, sister-in-law Nancy, a nephew, Lt. Col. NEW York City subway cars are not exactly known as good spots for communal gatherings. But the No. 7 train that trundled out of Times Square one recent Saturday afternoon was crammed with chummy straphangers with a common purpose. The riders, who clambered over one another to snag pizza slices from a folding table while a musician strummed a guitar, were all members of CouchSurfing.com. These 80-odd people are perhaps more accustomed to unorthodox environments than your average subway rider. CouchSurfing is a social-networking Web site that lets travelers link up with like-minded people all over the world who have a couch, spare bedroom, patch of open floor or backyard to offer -- absolutely free. Charging for accommodations is forbidden, making it perfect for frugal travelers. The five-year-old site, run primarily by volunteers, fosters an atmosphere of cultural exchange and friend-making, all while fighting the impression that it's solely for the backpacker set.
