BEARD--Leo Roy, a world renowned hydrologic engineer, died in Austin, TX, on March 21 at the age of 91. Roy Beard founded the US Army Corps of Engineers Hydrologic Engineering Center in Davis, CA, and was a professor of Civil Engineering at the University of Texas. He was known for his pioneering work on the application of statistics to hydrologic engineering. He received the American Society of Civil Engineers' Lifetime Achievement Award and was elected to the National Academy of Engineering.

BENJAMIN--John Townshend, of Oxford, died Sunday, March 22, 2009, at Memorial Hospital at Easton after a brief illness. He was 87. Born June 21, 1921, in Southampton, Long Island, NY, the son of the late Henry Rogers Benjamin, a Mayflower descendant and Dorothy Rennard Benjamin. He attended the Beauvais School and the Buckley School in New York City and concluded his preparatory education at St. Paul's School in Concord, NH with the Class of 1939. After graduating, Mr. Benjamin undertook aeronautical training, both elementary and advanced, at Roosevelt Field on Long Island, NY. Upon England's entry into World War II, he attempted to enlist in the Royal Canadian Air Force but was dismissed after failing to tell the enlistment officer he had not yet reached his majority. Upon entry of the United States into the war, Mr. Benjamin joined the United States Naval Air Force and after graduation from flight school became officer in the U.S. Marine Corps. As a Marine flyer he undertook further training in the San Francisco and Seattle areas and successfully flew 59 missions in the Pacific theatre and was awarded two Distinguished Flying Crosses. Piloting B-25 Mitchell bombers from the Pacific island of Ulithi he undertook numerous long range missions in order to bomb the major Japanese military bases on the island of Truk in the Caroline Islands. Mr. Benjamin was discharged at the end of the war after a brief recovery period at Camp Pendleton hospital from an infection contracted from the jungle climate. After leaving the service with the rank of Captain, Mr. Benjamin was employed by the Boeing Corporation in Seattle, but left the company after approximately two years to participate in the family automobile dealerships in Cali, Columbia. On his return from Cali, Mr. Benjamin managed his own widespread investments in the New York area. He was also active in wildcat oil drilling in the North Texas and Oklahoma regions. In 1958, Mr. Benjamin acquired a wooden 110-foot converted World War II Canadian Sub Chaser which he kept in the Miami River in Florida and on which he and his wife, Patricia Traer Benjamin cruised extensively in the United States, the Bahamas and Central America. In 1963, they relocated to Talbot County, residing first on Old Country Club Road in Easton and then in 1969 acquiring Long Point Farm in Oxford. Mr. Benjamin's marriage to Patty ended in divorce in 1972. He was remarried in 1974 to Florence Mackay of Los Angeles, CA. Mrs. Florence Benjamin preceded Mr. Benjamin in death, dying 1989. Mr. Benjamin loved Talbot County, and especially the shorefront scenery around Long Point Farm. He was active in many community organizations and was a generous benefactor of the YMCA of Talbot County. Mr. Benjamin is survived by his sister, Anne Benjamin Barry of Palm Desert, CA and Southampton, NY; his brother, William Evarts Benjamin II of Manalapan, FL and Mount Desert, Maine; his half-brother, Thomas Hyde Clarke of Cooperstown, NY; and by many nieces and nephews whom he always treated with affection and generosity. He was preceded in death by his older brother, Henry Rogers Benjamin, who died in 2004. Funeral services will be private and limited to the close family and friends. Memorial donations may be made to the YMCA of Talbot County and/or Hyde Hall Foundation, the former family home at Cooperstown, NY.

MYERS--W. P. Laird. The Staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) notes with sadness the death of its esteemed colleague, W. P. Laird Myers, M.D. Dr. Myers served at MSKCC for 37 years (from 1952 to 1989). He was Chair of the Department of Medicine from 1967 to 1977, when he was appointed Chairman of Clinical Educational Affairs for Memorial Hospital. He also held the Eugene W. Kettering Chair of Education. In a career that encompassed patient care, research, and education, Dr. Myers was instrumental in broadening graduate and undergraduate medical school curricula to include training in oncology, and he developed a pioneering program requiring rotation to an oncology service as part of the training of doctors specializing in internal medicine. As Chair of the Department of Medicine, he expanded its services from the delivery of cancer care to include all sub-specialities of internal medicine, initiated a transition to a full-time faculty staff model, and set policy for a single physician of record for every patient. Dr. Myers was a model physician, caring for many patients, and mentoring and teaching innumerable medical students and physicians in training. We extend our condolences to his wife, Katharine, and his family. Robert E. Wittes Physician-in-Chief George J. Bosl Chair, Department of Medicine Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

Made family circle a priority and passed that down to three generations. A great friend and relative to all who know her. Her legacy lives on.

SAM ROBERTS has never gotten over a sight familiar to anyone who has crossed the Ambassador Bridge over the Detroit River: the expansive view, at the crest of the bridge, of the Detroit skyline. That image, and the events of 1967, were the inspiration for ''Detroit '67,'' a song by his eponymous Montreal-based band that was released in Canada last year. Not surprisingly, the song is getting extensive air play in the Detroit area and is about to become the group's new American single.

HONG KONG There are only a few weeks a year when the weather is perfect for outdoor eating in Hong Kong: a brief spell in the spring, before the humidity envelops the city like a wet wool blanket, and an even shorter period in the fall, before the blustery weather that passes for winter in this tropical climate really sets in. As a result, there are very few restaurants with outdoor terraces, but of the few, there are some gems. Isola, an Italian restaurant in the International Finance Center, has a spectacular view overlooking Victoria Harbor and its continual parade of ships (Level 3, IFC mall, Central; 852-2383-8765; www.isolabarandgrill.com). Another good spot is the Garden Café, in the Pacific Place complex, next to the pool at the Conrad Hotel, with a menu of European and Asian dishes (Pacific Place, 88 Queensway, Admiralty; 852-2521-3838; www.conradhotels.com).

CUMMINGS--Bruce Willard. 1936-2009. Founder and CEO of Angela Cummings Fine Jewelry, Inc. and former Vice President of Tiffany & Co., passed away at his home in Salt Lake City on January 30, 2009, after a brave battle with lymphoma. Cummings, a certified Gemologist of the American Gem Society (1972) and a Fellow of the Gemological Association of Great Britain (1973), was employed in the diamond office of Tiffany & Co. in New York City for many years before becoming Vice President of the Company, a position he held for over two decades. Mr. Cummings also held a B.A. in Business Management from Stamford University. While at Tiffany & Co., Bruce met the young jewelry designer, Angela Baeumker, and married in 1970. The Cummings left Tiffany & Co. in 1984 to found Angela Cummings, Inc., a privately held corporation. For 20 years Bruce and Angela worked side by side building the Angela Cummings brand, best known its exquisite jewelry pieces composed of 18-karat gold as well as platinum and sterling silver, highlighted with bright-colored gems. The brand later expanded into categories other than jewelry, such as tabletop, accessories and leather goods. Bruce and Angela opened the first Angela Cummings Fine Jewelry Boutique in the upscale Bergdorf Goodman on Valentine's Day 1985. The 500-square-foot space, a first for a fine jewelry designer at the Fifth Avenue retailer, enjoyed an unprecedented 20-year success. Angela Cummings Boutiques were also showcased throughout Neiman Marcus, Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdales, as well as internationally in a long-term partnership with Shiseido in Japan. In June 2003, Bruce and Angela and their business partner, Michele Ateyeh, decided to retire and close the design studio and the wholesale showroom. Over 400 retail executives, designers, clients and friends of the Cummings attended the farewell event at the Grill Room in Manhattan's Four Seasons restaurant to wish the two well-liked industry figures well in their new endeavors. Upon retirement, Bruce and Angela moved from Greenwich, Connecticut, to Salt Lake City, Utah, where Bruce had resided most of his life, prior to moving to the East Coast. He was an avid skier and tennis player who very much enjoyed the active lifestyle offered in Salt Lake City. Bruce is survived by his wife, Angela, his son, Bruce Campbell Cummings (Nicole), and his daughters, Allison McPherson, Hillary Pugh and Millicent Cummings. He is also survived by four grandchildren, by his brothers, Richard (Julie) and Robert (JoAnn) and by many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Primary Children's Medical Center of Salt Lake City.

MYERS--Dr. Warren Powers Laird, 87, of Norwich, VT and Hanover, NH, a noted medical oncologist, died at home on April 1, 2009. A graduate of Episcopal Academy, Yale University and the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, Dr. Myers was also the recipient of various honors for his post-doctoral work at the Mayo Clinic and at Trinity College of Cambridge University in Cambridge, England. For his work in medical school, he was awarded membership in Alpha Omega Alpha, the national medical honor society. Following his service as a medical officer in the United States Navy, internships at Philadelphia General Hospital and Maimonides Hospital, and fellowship at the Mayo Clinic, Dr. Myers joined the staff of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. Apart from a fellowship at Cambridge, he remained with Memorial Sloan-Kettering for 34 years until his retirement in 1986. As Chairman of the Department of Medicine, he transformed Memorial Sloan-Kettering's approach to oncology in accord with his belief that the best cancer care is delivered by physicians who are specialists in both oncology and internal medicine. Later, he served as Memorial's vice president for educational affairs, occupying the Eugene Kettering chair of education. Throughout his years at Memorial, he also taught on the faculty of Cornell University Medical College, served as its associate dean, and authored numerous articles, research studies, and a portion of a prominent medical textbook. During his years in New York, Dr. Myers was a leader in a variety of civic and professional organizations. He was a director of the Damon Runyon Cancer Fund and an active member of the Charaka Society, the Practitioners' Society of NY and the Century Association. He also served as an elder of the Rye, NY and the Fifth Avenue (NYC) Presbyterian Churches and as a deacon of the Norwich Congregational Church. Following retirement, Dr. Myers and his wife moved to Norwich, VT. There he found great pleasure in riding his 1946 Ford tractor, monitoring the progress of his corn crop, and walking with his dog. Professionally, he continued to teach physical diagnosis at nearby Dartmouth Medical School, from which he retired as Emeritus Professor of Medicine in 1996, and served on the Boards of Trustees of the Hitchcock Clinic and Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center from 1983 to 1996. Renowned both as a "patient's doctor" and as a "doctor's doctor," Myers will probably be best remembered as an educator of physicians. Scores of today's leading oncologists and internists trained under Dr. Myers at Memorial Sloan-Kettering and learned physical diagnosis under his tutelage at Cornell and Dartmouth medical schools. The other side of the student-teacher relationship was equally important to him. He always considered himself the most fortunate of physicians for having been allowed to train under and work with the very best men and women in their fields.

I DON'T keep a stocked bar. I usually have wine if I haven't forgotten to go to the liquor store. When I was in my 20s, however, I kept Scotch, bourbon, gin, vodka, vermouth and various aperitifs. I did this because my parents did it, although they had a real bar with a black marble sink. My parents lived a relatively formal life. They gave cocktail parties and dinner parties at which I sometimes helped wait table. My mother used silver every day: flat silver, silver trays, silver teapots, silver coffeepots, sugar bowls, creamers, on and on. My mother had grown up in England with impossibly high housekeeping standards maintained by servants. I can still remember meals at my grandparents', the table arrayed in crystal and silver and china, bowls of roses from the garden. Even the dog and cat were brushed every morning to prevent shedding.

SAFTCHICK--Isabel Mass, 73, passed away peacefully on April 2nd, 2009 with her children at her bedside. Born and raised in Bronx, NY, she spent her childhood summers in the Catskills at her grandfather's hotels. She raised her family in Bayside, Queens, and spent the last 23 years of her life in Sunrise Lakes, Florida. She had a flare for fashion and owned a successful boutique for many years in Bayside. Her purchases were trendsetting for the 1970s. She taught us how to live life with courage, conviction, compassion, and loyalty. She taught us the value of family and was a devoted mother, mother in-law, and a very special grandmother. She is survived by her sons Stuart and Leonard. Her daughter in-laws Denise and Melodie and her grandchildren Brandon, Carli, Ryan and Eden and many nephews and nieces. She will be missed dearly.

PICKETT--Linda, 82. Daughter of Jamaican immigrants Passmore and Agnes Lindsay. Born 1926 in Manhattan and raised in the Bronx with her siblings Edsel, John, Lloyd and Martha. Married Alfred Pickett in 1947 and became a Harlem resident while working and raising her family. As a working mom, she held several jobs highlighted by a 20 year career at the W.T. Grant Foundation primarily as a Program Officer. Linda and Al became Roosevelt Island pioneers in 1975 where they were actively involved in a variety of activities. They also began their worldwide travels together. Beginning in 1990 Linda spent her retirement years as a passionate world traveler, active volunteer for many organizations, avid reader - book club member, a loyal arts supporter and generous philanthropist while still enjoying her Roosevelt Island home. Linda passed away peacefully at home on March 24, 2009 after a courageous and heartfelt battle with pancreatic cancer. Linda is survived by her sister Martha Dunlap, brothers Edsel and Lloyed Lindsay, son Steve along with many nephews and nieces, godchildren, dear friends, associates and neighbors. Please join the family in Celebrating Linda's almost 83 years of vibrant, loving and benevolent life. In lieu of flowers or gifts, please take a moment to remember Linda's smile and spirit during her time with you.

FOR nearly 25 years, Marc J. Straus ran an oncology practice in White Plains, working 80-hour weeks. ''It's rewarding being able to help people this way,'' said Mr. Straus, a resident of Chappaqua, N.Y. ''But there wasn't a day or night that I wasn't called on a new case. No one could ever play tennis or racquetball with me because the odds were I wouldn't show up.'' Three years ago, Mr. Straus, 65, who also is a well-known art collector, closed his full-time practice (though he is still taking on cases selectively) and turned his attention toward another passion: poetry. A latecomer to writing verse, he has published more than 100 poems and three books since taking his first course in poetry writing at the 92nd Street Y in 1991. Now his first play -- ''Not God,'' a two-act, two-character piece written in verse -- makes its full-fledged debut at Luna Stage in Montclair in previews on April 16 (the official opening is April 24).
Georgia Squyres AGE 17, senior
Laura Rosenfeld AGE 18, senior

FOR high school seniors applying to college, this has been an April unlike any in recent memory, if ever. As families watch their paychecks and college savings accounts shrink, and their household expenses rise, the colleges themselves are scrambling to cut their budgets, too. Which has made the receipt of a so-called fat envelope -- brimming with the good news of college acceptance, along with details of scholarships and loans -- not necessarily the moment of joy it might have been in years past.

SCHUMAN--Jerome Bertram, 90, Chairman of the Board of Arthur Schuman Inc., died April 10th in Saddle River, New Jersey where he and his wife Bobbe resided. Mr. Schuman was born October 28th, 1918 in Passaic and graduated Passaic High School in 1937 and Northwestern University with a BSC degree in 1941. October 19, 1941 he married Bobbe Cohen of Terre Haute Indiana. He served in the United States Army Air Corps from 1941-1945, and served overseas in England in the 385th Bomb Group, receiving the Distinguished Flying Cross, three oak leaf clusters and the Distinguished Unit Citations. In 1945, he joined Arthur Schuman Inc., a family business, which imported cheeses. He was instrumental in developing the Italian, South American and Eastern European markets for cheese importation to the U.S. During his tenure, the company became the largest importer of Italian and Italian-type cheeses and the second largest domestic hard cheese company. Mr. Schuman was President of the Cheese Importers Association from 1962-1964 and this year received the prestigious NCI Laureate award. He was past Commander and County Commander of the Jewish War Veterans and past President of the Little League in Teaneck. Mr. Schuman and his wife Bobbe, who spent winters in Palm Beach, Florida, have been married for 68 years and have three children, Neal, Joan, and Martha; 11 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Mr. Schuman was an avid collector of Oceanic Tribal Art and loved sports, particularly Hockey and the New Jersey Devils. Funeral Monday 1:30pm at Gutterman and Musicant, Hackensack. For information 1-800-522-0588

Although he missed three relatively short birdie putts during his round Saturday and was making three bogeys on the back nine as others were charging, the two-time Masters champion Phil Mickelson said he was still a contender for the Masters title. ''I don't feel like I'm out of it because a lot of things happen on Sunday at the Masters,'' said Mickelson, who finished the third round at four-under 212. ''A lot of things could happen again. Yes, it's easy to get on a roll with a bunch of birdies, but it's also easy to start to go the other way, and when you do, it's easy to tumble.''

TALK SHOW In an act of gratitude after appearing on my show, the great magician Tony Slydini offered to take me on as a student, ''If-a you have time.'' I kvelled. I felt the way a young cellist might if asked by Yo-Yo Ma if he ''had time.'' (I once rudely asked the cellist if I could call him by his first Yo.) Tony lived in a tiny, old ground-floor apartment on West 46th Street: Mecca for his students, some of whom commuted from distant cities for their treasured sessions.

THE READERKate Winslet's Oscar-winning performance as an illiterate, former concentration camp guard who has an affair with a teenage boy (David Kross). Stephen Daldry directed. Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times in December that ''the film is neither about the Holocaust nor about those Germans who grappled with its legacy: it's about making the audience feel good about a historical catastrophe that grows fainter with each new tasteful interpolation.'' (The Weinstein Company, $29.95, R) THE SPIRIT Will Eisner's comic book series about a big city cop who comes back from the dead becomes a heavily digitized live action feature under the direction of Frank Miller. With Gabriel Macht, Eva Mendes and Scarlett Johansson. The movie is ''a talky, pretentious stew of film noir poses and crime-fighter clichés,'' A. O. Scott wrote in December in The Times. (Lionsgate, Blu-ray $39.99, two-disc special edition $34.98, single disc $29.95, PG-13)

FOR high school seniors applying to college, this has been an April unlike any in recent memory, if ever. As families watch their paychecks and college savings accounts shrink, and their household expenses rise, the colleges themselves are scrambling to cut their budgets, too. Which has made the receipt of a so-called fat envelope -- brimming with the good news of college acceptance, along with details of scholarships and loans -- not necessarily the moment of joy it might have been in years past.

Even with an extended spring training because of the World Baseball Classic, some competitions for starting positions were still not decided by the first week of the season. And some who had won jobs had tenuous holds on them. Jason Motte, left, had a strong spring to tag himself as the Cardinals' closer. But in his first save opportunity, he gave up four runs in the ninth inning to the Pirates and took a loss. Dennys Reyes collected a save on Thursday, and in Motte's next opportunity, on Friday, he gave up two singles while facing three batters. He was pulled in favor of Kyle McClellan -- like Motte, a right-hander -- who got the save.

Predeceased also by a daughter, Susan Brayer, Lucille will be greatly missed by Susan's twin brother, Anthony Warren, and a daughter, Ann Kanter, in addition to five grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren.

MANNING THE ROPES, COAST OF CROATIA, OCT. 10, 2008 Dimitar Shkordovski, 26, at right, a production manager from Skopje, Macedonia, sails in a race on the Adriatic Sea. ''In our crew, we're all part of a small group of power gliding pilots, and the idea for a yacht race started when one of our members, who's a skipper, suggested we organize something. We wanted to have it annually on Oct. 11, our national holiday, the day of the people's uprising. So, symbolically, we had 11 boats, and all the competitors were Macedonian. This year was our second run, with three days of training, two days of racing and two days of partying. It's great. You have the sun, the open water; sometimes you have dolphins swimming beside you. And if the wind is good and you're at full sail, the adrenaline rush is perfect. When you have a whole crew that's working toward the same goal, you become very close, like a family. You've got 10 people on a boat that's only 43 feet long, for a whole week, so you must be very open-minded.'' As told to Austin Considine

SHOWING POTENTIAL Even if this Masters winds up out of Sean O'Hair's reach, he continued to demonstrate why a major championship could be in his future. O'Hair, 26, a two-time winner on the PGA Tour who finished second to Tiger Woods at the Arnold Palmer Invitational two weeks ago, bounced back from a second-round 76 with a 68 that included seven birdies. O'Hair said he was envisioning a wild Sunday at the Masters and not counting himself out even though he was seven strokes behind the leaders, Kenny Perry and Ángel Cabrera.

At the first read-through of “Rachel Said Sorry” all that was clear about the plot was that it involves four female friends the morning after a lingerie shower for a bride-to-be. Set at a “lacy, fussy Victorian hotel,” it includes drinking Lemon Drops, debating the merits of “An Inconvenient Truth,” the documentary on global warming, and Rachel hurting the bride-to-be’s feelings by saying she gave up “a fake career for a regular life.” At least that’s what the script said at 9:15 a.m.

Richard Price and T. Coraghessan Boyle, two authors who are generally not wildly enthusiastic about honors or distinctions, are among the newest inductees of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, The Associated Press reported. On Monday, the academy was to announce that Mr. Price (whose novels include “Clockers” and “Lush Life”) and Mr. Boyle (“Drop City”) would be among the nine artists added to its 250-member roster. The new class will also include the poets Jorie Graham and Yusef Komunyakaa, the visual artist Judy Pfaff, the architect Tod Williams and the composers Stephen Hartke, Frederic Rzewski and Augusta Read Thomas. The new members will be inducted in a ceremony in May, and will be allowed to serve on academy committees that award prizes but otherwise they have no official responsibilities. Upon learning in 1999 that he had won a literary prize from the academy, Mr. Price said, “I thought maybe I get discounts at local restaurants,” according to The A.P.

Having scored an unexpected hit with his literary mashup “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies,” the writer Seth Grahame-Smith will take at least two more stabs at combining period drama and horror, Publishers Weekly reported. Mr. Grahame-Smith currently finds himself at No. 3 on the New York Times’s Paperback Trade Fiction Bestseller list with “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies” (Quirk Books), which combines Jane Austen’s classic, out-of-copyright novel with scenes of bone-chomping gore. (Opening line: “It is a truth universally acknowledged that a zombie in possession of brains must be in want of more brains.”) So of course publishers want a second and third helping: Grand Central Press signed Mr. Grahame-Smith to a two-book deal, starting with a new book called “Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter” that imagines the 16th president dedicating himself to the great task that the undead shall perish from the earth. Publishers Weekly said the two-book deal could be worth as much as $575,000, a figure that Grand Central Press declined to confirm.

An exhibition of the Dead Sea Scrolls slated to open this summer at Toronto’s Royal Ontario Museum has drawn criticism from Palestinian officials who say the coming show is a violation of international law, The Toronto Star reported. The exhibit, “Dead Sea Scrolls: Words That Changed the World,” is scheduled to open at the museum on June 27 and would display scrolls discovered in caves near the Dead Sea between 1947 and 1956. But in a letter sent to Canada’s Prime Minister Stephen Harper and to the museum, Palestinian officials say that the scrolls were obtained illegally by Israel when it annexed East Jerusalem after the war in 1967. “The exhibition would entail exhibiting or displaying artifacts removed from the Palestinian territories,” wrote Hamdan Taha, the director-general of the archaeological department in the Palestinian Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities, according to The Star. William Thorsell, the museum’s chief executive told The Star, “I’m quite certain the scrolls fall within the parameters of the law.”

A variation of meatloaf, it is denser, with more meat, and the addition of cream and spices makes it delicious and elegant enough to serve at dinners where you want to impress your guests. Meatloaf can't do that.

Hugh Hefner, the founder of Playboy, a magazine devoted to breasts and things, has created a utopian commune where the external world conforms to his weltanschauung. This week, Michelle and James Nevius, the authors of "Inside the Apple: A Streetwise History of New York City," will be answering questions about the history of Manhattan from Henry Hudson's arrival in 1609 to the present. If you have ever walked by a building in the borough and wondered about its origins, or whether a historic event really took place where you think it did, or any other little-known fact, they will know the answers. Both in their book and on their guided tours, the authors try to link the history of Manhattan to places that can still be visited today. One of their goals is to focus on the patterns that emerge as a neighborhood or street changes over time.

Monday, 7:10 p.m. Corporate sponsorship of sports stadiums is nothing new. What does seem new, however, is corporate sponsorship by potentially insolvent corporations. Take Citigroup, for instance, which promised millions in exchange for naming the new home of the New York Mets Citi Field. The stadium opens tonight when the Mets take on the San Diego Padres. Given the $45 billion in public money shoveled into Citigroup, how long until the stadium, as populists have been saying, is renamed Taxpayer Park? 126th Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Queens.

An article on Thursday about the University of Connecticut women’s basketball team referred incorrectly to Renee Montgomery, a departing senior. She is one of three seniors — not the only one. (The team is also losing Tahirah Williams and Cassie Kerns to graduation.).

An article on Friday about an agreement between Google and Universal Music Group to create a Web site for music videos described the new site’s ownership structure incorrectly. It will be owned by Universal; it will not be a separate company owned by Universal and Google.

An article on Friday about the German government’s move to nationalize a troubled mortgage lender, Hypo Real Estate Holding, misstated the value of the deal. The offer valued the 91.3 percent of the company that the government did not own at $385 million; that is not the value of the entire company.

An article on Wednesday about the effect of exercise in patients with heart failure misspelled the given name of a researcher at the Duke University School of Medicine. She is Kathryn Flynn, not Katherine.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about the Pakistani foreign minister’s public criticisms of United States policy on Pakistan during a visit there by two senior American officials referred incorrectly at several points to the rank of one of those officials, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. As the article initially noted, the chairman is Adm. Mike Mullen; he is not “General Mullen.”.

An article on Thursday about the United States’ negotiating positions at global climate talks in Bonn, Germany, described incorrectly the reductions of greenhouse gas emissions proposed by Barack Obama at the time he was running for president. He said the United States should progressively reduce emissions to 80 percent below 1990 levels by 2050 — not to 80 percent of 1990 levels.

A spate of attacks on ships off Somalia and the rescue Sunday of an American captain held hostage by pirates have reinvigorated a long-simmering debate over whether the crews of commercial vessels should be armed. While the arming of merchant vessels was commonplace for centuries, it faded in recent decades because of ship owners' concerns about liability and the safety of their sailors.

THE JUAN MACLEAN ''The Future Will Come'' (DFA) The looming future is a mere diversion on the Juan MacLean's second album, a dance-floor odyssey with subversively pensive designs. ''Left me for the great unknown/Lost you to oblivion,'' Nancy Whang sings more than four minutes into the opening track, ''The Simple Life.'' Her words, floating mournfully over a disco beat and a pulsating bass line, are among the first on the album. She goes on to voice a more direct complaint -- ''Now you're gone,'' repeated as a refrain -- that seizes on pain in the present tense.

RASCAL FLATTS ''Unstoppable'' (Lyric Street) Two songs on ''Unstoppable,'' the sixth studio album by the pop-country behemoth Rascal Flatts, prominently feature voicemail messages left undeleted as reminders of how things once were. Another involves a phone call that's never going to come. These aren't commentaries on the persistence or obsolescence of technology, only a reminder that you can be let down even from a distance, and that Rascal Flatts lives for the letdown.
SMOKIE NORFUL ''Live'' (EMI Gospel) The second track on Smokie Norful's new album, ''Live,'' seems to know how you anticipate and absorb patterns in music much better than you do.
International CULTURAL WARFARE

Kenny Perry was disappointed but not despondent after losing the lead on the last hole at the Masters, then failing to match Ángel Cabrera's par on the second playoff hole. For Perry, a seasoned and decorated PGA Tour player who has never won a major championship, Sunday's second-place finish was a setback but one that he says will not consume him. ''I'll look back on it occasionally and wonder what I might have done differently, but I won't dwell on it,'' he said. ''If this is the worst thing that happens in my life, I've got it pretty good. I won't let it dog me. There are so many other things in life that matter more, and I'm not just saying that for this situation or to make anyone else feel better.

Jelena Jankovic beat Carla Suarez Navarro, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, to win her first title of the season, at the Andalucia Tennis Experience in Marbella, Spain. The fourth-ranked Jankovic broke Suarez Navarro six times on the outdoor clay to improve to 3-0 against her. Suarez Navarro appeared to run out of steam in the third set as Jankovic raced to a 5-1 lead and her first title since October. ''I know that I have not played well during the past three months, but after this win, I have regained the confidence that I needed,'' she said. (NYT)

Shoppers clipping, er, printing coupons online are going for household staples like cereal, laundry detergent and diapers, which can be fairly costly. They are also looking to save on products like soda, dessert and toiletries. Whatever it is consumers want, more of them are looking for it online, and they're looking for it more often. According to Compete.com, which measures Internet traffic, Coupons.com had 14 million unique visitors in March, an increase of 70 percent over March 2008, as well as a 123 percent increase in visits during the same period.

While the top executives at the Cable Show last week were jockeying to cut deals to distribute major cable networks over the Web (for paying customers), the engineers in the background were talking about a completely different approach to getting cable programs onto computers. New technology will let cable companies feed programs onto your home network in the standard formats used by the Internet. That way you could simply run video software, like Windows Media Player or a special program given to you by your cable company, to watch any show on your cable system on your PC, game console or smartphone.

AROUND AUGUSTA Ángel Cabrera's victory was in keeping with a Masters trend that began with Nick Faldo's victory in 1990. Only once since then has the winner come from outside the final pairing: Zach Johnson in 2007. ... Shingo Katayama, the flashy, cowboy-hat-wearing Japanese pro, has a thing for Georgia. His two highest finishes in major championships have come in the Peach State: his fourth place in this Masters and his tie for fourth at the 2001 P.G.A. Championship at Atlanta Athletic Club. ... Todd Hamilton did not reach his goal of finishing in the top 10, but he earned a return trip by finishing among the top 15. He finished tied for 15th at 283, his best showing in his 16 major appearances since he won the British Open in 2004. LARRY DORMAN

When it comes to sudden changes, head-spinning and gut-wrenching ones, there is once again no place like Augusta National on a Sunday. The first three-man sudden-death playoff in 22 years at the Masters followed a daylong rush of adrenaline-charged roars that cascaded like Niagara Falls across the greensward. And when it was done, when the apparent victors were vanquished and the astounding winner raised his arms in the dying light, the story was etched on the faces of each. The winner, Ángel Cabrera, a former caddie from Argentina, wore an expression of pure joy. The vanquished, Kenny Perry, a 48-year-old whose life is filled with everything but a major championship, wore a look of grim acceptance. And Chad Campbell, whose Masters began with five straight birdies and ended with a 5-foot miss, simply looked perplexed.

Electronic Arts doesn't have Will Wright to parade around anymore. Mr. Wright, the creative spirit behind SimCity, the Sims and, more recently, Spore, has decided to leave Electronic Arts after 12 years with the video game maker. They will continue to have a relationship, though, as E.A. has taken an equity stake in Mr. Wright's new venture, the Stupid Fun Club.

The Showtime historical drama “The Tudors,” about a British king who dispenses with his unwanted wives through beheadings and other unpleasant means, will be cut off after its fourth season, The Hollywood Reporter said. The series, which stars Jonathan Rhys Meyers as the Tudor monarch Henry VIII, has been renewed for a fourth season but will conclude at the end of that 10-episode run. The final episodes will be written by Michael Hirst, the creator of “The Tudors,” and will chronicle Henry VIII’s last two marriages, to Catherine Howard and Catherine Parr. The announcement follows an earlier report that Showtime has rejected all four pilots it had in development, including a spinoff of its series “The L Word” and a comedy called “Ronna and Beverly,” whose creators included Jenji Kohan, the creator of “Weeds.” No premiere date for the final season of “The Tudors” was given.

A dream almost a century old moved another step closer to reality Tuesday as the Smithsonian Institution chose a team led by David Adjaye, the celebrated Tanzanian-born architect, to design the National Museum of African American History and Culture, scheduled to open on the National Mall in 2015.

Updated | 12:36 p.m. The Metropolitan Opera’s mounting of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle, which has already been hit by a flurry of casting changes, is about to weather a few more. Gerhard Siegel has withdrawn from the role of Mime, and Jill Grove has withdrawn from the roles of Erda and the First Norn in the four-opera cycle. In a statement, the Met said that both performers had left due to illness. Robert Brubaker will sing the role of Mime in “Siegfried” on Saturday, as well as April 30 and May 7; Dennis Petersen will sing the role in “Das Rheingold” on April 23 and 27 and May 4. Wendy White, who was scheduled to sing Erda in “Das Rheingold” on April 23 will also sing the role on April 27 and May 4, as well as in “Siegfried.” Additionally, the Met said, Johan Botha did not sing Siegmund in “Die Walküre” last Saturday due to illness; he was replaced by Gary Lehman, who performed the role in that work for the first time in his career.

Lawyers for Kanye West were granted an extension on Monday for the rapper’s arraignment on charges that resulted from his scuffle with a photographer at Los Angeles International Airport in September, The Associated Press reported. The arraignment was postponed until May 20 after a brief hearing in a Los Angeles court. On Sept. 11, Mr. West was videotaped by the Web site TMZ.com as the flash of a paparazzo’s camera was broken. He was arrested and charged with misdemeanor battery, grand theft and vandalism, and his road manager, Dan Crawley, was charged with six misdemeanor charges, including battery, vandalism and grand theft related to damage to the camera and TMZ’s video camera. At the hearing Monday, Mr. West’s lawyer, Blair Berk, told the court that she had not been allowed to review the police report until then and asked prosecutors to turn over any additional evidence, according to The A.P.

American Ballet Theater has promoted Veronika Part to the position of principal dancer, the company said Tuesday in a news release. Ms. Part, who joined the troupe in 2002 as a soloist, was born in St. Petersburg, Russia, where she trained at the Vaganova Ballet Academy in 1988. She joined the Kirov Ballet in 1996 and was promoted to soloist there in 1998. Her roles at Ballet Theater have included the Sugar Plum Fairy and the Snow Queen in “The Nutcracker,” Lady Capulet in “Romeo and Juliet” and Odette-Odile in “Swan Lake”; she is scheduled to make her debut in the title role of the company’s production of “La Sylphide” in the spring. The troupe said Ms. Part’s promotion would be effective on May 18.

Updated | 4:38 p.m. The Broadway revival of “West Side Story” has broken the Palace Theater box office record for two consecutive weeks, earning $1,234,652 for performances during the week ending April 5, and $1,308,787 for the week ending April 12. The Palace record was previously $1,219,488, set by the musical “Legally Blonde” during Christmas week 2007. “West Side Story” was the third-highest grossing Broadway show last week, behind the musicals “Wicked” and “The Lion King.” A national tour of this current incarnation of “West Side Story” will begin in fall 2010, producers disclosed. Tour stops and casting will be announced soon.

“The 24 Hour Musicals” ended last night with performances of four very different musicals that ranged from the touching to the outrageous. The two following photo essays provide a glimpse into the nerves, the camp and the theatrical mojo of the event.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — The auction of memorabilia from Michael Jackson’s Neverland Ranch is so big that it has been installed in a former department store here, but the crowds that turned out for its public viewing this morning were less than gigantic. A trickle of fans and passers by made their way through the 1,390-lot installation in the opening hour of the exhibition, drawn by curiosity and the possibility of owning one of Mr. Jackson’s E.T. statues or makeup-smeared stage costumes.

The motley program the YouTube Symphony Orchestra will play at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening was devised partly to ensure every section a place or two in the sun. So after full-orchestral rehearsals at the Juilliard School on Monday — led by Michael Tilson Thomas, its artistic adviser and conductor, and Tan Dun, who composed a piece for the occasion — the orchestra split up starting at mid-afternoon for smaller sessions.

A Boston Municipal Court clerk-magistrate said Monday that some charges brought against the artist Shepard Fairey for hanging his posters around the Boston area could be dropped due to lack of evidence, a lawyer for Mr. Fairey told The Boston Globe. Mr. Fairey, the Los Angeles-based graphic artist best known for the “Hope” poster of Barack Obama that was widely displayed during the 2008 presidential campaign, was facing 17 counts of vandalism for placing posters, murals and stickers in public and private spaces throughout the city. The artist was scheduled to return to court on Tuesday to answer the 10 remaining charges. Mr. Fairey is also involved in separate legal proceedings with The Associated Press, which contends that he violated its copyright on the photograph that became the basis for the “Hope” poster.

Michael Jackson fans won’t be able to pick up a spangled glove or military-style jacket after all. The planned auction of the contents of Mr. Jackson’s Neverland Valley Ranch was called off on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Jackson had sued Julien’s Auction House in an attempt to block the sale. The two parties reached an agreement, a spokesman told The AP.

It's the gimmes that make crosswords a personal experience. If you adore musicals, the singing milkman is a gimme. If you prefer a "derivative Spanish-language game show" now and then, Vas ONO Vas (Deal or No Deal) is a gimme. If you love Paris in the springtime, you've probably walked by the ELYSEE Palace. Part of the magic of crosswords is that everyone comes to each puzzle with unique personal life experiences. Everyone has their own gimmes. "Gimme!" is also my favorite clue/answer pair today in this amusing and clever puzzle nicely laid out, following all the proper etiquette rules, by Michael Vuolo.

The Jets' schedule was announced about half an hour ago. They will play the final regular-season game at Giants Stadium, on Jan. 3, in what will probably be a non-marquee matchup with the Bengals. Of course, it will be the final game only if the Jets and the Giants don't qualify for home games in the playoffs. (The new stadium opens in 2010.)A few bullet points:1) The Jets will play only two prime-time games, and one will be on the NFL Network on a Thursday night (Dec. 3).2) Rex Ryan will be tested quickly, in Week 2 against New England and a week later against Tennessee, which had a 10-game winning streak snapped by the Jets last November.3) Hmmm. It doesn't get easier in Weeks 4-5, at New Orleans and at Miami. The first month looks tough.
In music, the audience eagerly awaits the opening of a new concert hall or opera house in order to assess the acoustics.

The Giants' schedule was announced a few minutes ago on the NFL Network.A couple of bullet points:The Giants will ....1) Help open the Cowboys' new stadium with a Sunday night game in Week 22) Play three straight road games, Weeks 2-4. That's far from ideal, and something the N.F.L. tries to avoid.3) NOT play the final regular-season game at Giants Stadium (the new stadium will open in 2010). That honor will fall to the Jets, on Jan. 3 against the Bengals. But the Giants can rectify things by making the playoffs and earning home-field advantage for at least one game.

Updated, 10:53 p.m. | Officials at the Police Department told news organizations early Tuesday evening that they will have to leave the office space they have long occupied at One Police Plaza, the department's headquarters, by July 31 to make room for a new Joint Operations Center. * Donald Trump has sued the developers of the Baja California project that once bore his name. Last month the developers, Los Angeles-based Irongate, announced they would not build the Trump Ocean Resort Baja. They also refused to return $32 million (about 24.1 million euro) in deposits from buyers. The buyers sued the developers and Trump, who licensed his name to the project and actively promoted sales, though he was not directly involved in the financing or construction of the development. Now buyers hope Trump will help them get their money back.* Turmoil continues over the fate of CityCenter, the $9 billion project under construction on the Las Vegas Strip. In the latest development, Dubai World, which controls 50 percent of the project, is threatening to withhold its payments until MGM Mirage, its partner in the deal, develops a new financing plan, Reuters reports. Dubai World pulled a similar power play last month. Colony Capital LLC, a Los Angeles private equity firm, was reportedly ready to ride to the rescue, but now it appears talks have broken off.* Basketball superstar Shaquille O'Neal is struggling to sell his 19,440-square-foot (about 1,800-square-meter) mansion on Miami's Star Island, complete with indoor basketball court and Superman logo in the pool. Shaq recently cut the price again, this time to $22.5 million (16.9 million euro), the Wall Street Journal reports (second item). Mr. O'Neal priced the property at $35 million (26.4 million euro) in 2007. (The listing can be found here.)

Liverpool and Chelsea made an adventure of it. After going up 2-0 before the game was half an hour old, the Reds looked as if they could pull an Istanbul. But an opportunistic finish from Didier Drogba in the 51st minute; a screaming free kick off the outside of Alex's right boot in the 57th; and Frank Lampard's poise in the 76th saw Chelsea ease back into the aggregate lead. But Liverpool was not finished. An unbelievable goal tally was augmented by Lucas's 81st minute goal and Dirk Kuyt's narrow header two minutes later. But Lampard had had enough: he put the nail in the coffin a minute from time to see Chelsea through to the semifinals, 7-5 on aggregate.

At the same time, the Pakistani government has granted broad concessions to the militants to achieve a truce after more than a year of fighting. In news that will be bad for activists hoping to start another American Revolution with a series of protests modeled on the Boston Tea Party, a new Gallup Poll finds that a solid majority of American say the income tax they pay is "fair," and that slightly more than half classify their own tax burden as either "about right" or "too low."

Over on City Room, Glenn Collins reports on a recent tour given to restaurateurs (including Ti Adelaide Martin of Commander's Palace in New Orleans) who are interested in taking over Tavern On the Green. Among the details prospective bidders learned: The twinkling lights and beveled mirrors are not coming with the restaurant, unless the LeRoy family, which currently operates the restaurant, wins the bidding. The LeRoys also own the name "Tavern on the Green," which was recently appraised at $19 million.

Outside of adding a big receiver in Terrell Owens, the Bills haven't shaken up their roster. (Editor's note: North America can only stand so much shaking.) David Wright's fifth-inning drive last night looked good and gone when it went off the bat - didn't it? The left fielder, Chase Headley, stopped and stared. The crowd roared. But the ball? It landed two rows deep into the left-field stands, just beyond the 15-foot, 8 1/2-inch fence. The Mets said the ball traveled an estimated 390 feet, which is a long way to go for a home run that was almost a wall-banger, especially to left field. At Shea Stadium, even on a crisp night like Monday, that ball would have reached halfway up the bleachers.

Addendum at 5 p.m. This post previously said Goldman borrowed $19.5 billion with a government guarantee. That number came from Thomson Reuters, but Goldman tells me they missed one issue, and also did not include some private offerings. The actual total, they say, is $28 billion, and Goldman has the right to raise that as high as $35 billion. I have also updated the post to reflect the closing price of Goldman stock today.Goldman Sachs, as you know by now, wants to return that $10 billion in TARP money it got.

Now that my son is learning to read - happy day! - he has the same question for me that my older acquaintances often do: what books do I recommend? But being a book review editor, or a dad, doesn't make it any easier to match reader to title; and on our last family trip to the library, I fell back helplessly on the early-reader authors I knew from my own childhood. "William Steig!" I said, grabbing an unfamiliar picture book. "He wrote 'Shrek'! And 'The Amazing Bone'! And 'Sylvester and the Magic Pebble'! You'll love him!" (Against my better instincts, and the current recommendations of the American Academy of Pediatrics, I often use exclamation points when I talk to my children. Accents and funny voices too.)

Apparently we're all Barbie girls in a Barbie world. The temporary Barbie store at London's Dover Street Market has been extended by popular demand to run through April 25. Curated by Henry Holland, the store is selling limited-edition versions from the new Platinum Collection styled by the latter-day dollybirds Roksanda Ilincic and Danielle Scutt (and a hilarious goth Ken decked out by Gareth Pugh). But if you ask us, the most fantastic bits of plastic are the Tippi Hedren doll that went largely unnoticed when it was first released last year (to coincide with the DVD reissue of "The Birds") and the Shopgirl Barbie Doll from the Gold Collection that's meant to resemble a soignée Parisian sales associate but has been walking out of the store because everyone thinks it's Daphne Guinness. Like Barbie, our lips are sealed.

The grittiness of Mexico City, coupled with a cheap, overwhelming abundance of materials, is helping to create a vibrant design scene there. And surprisingly for a megalopolis, it's not all against nature. "We're trying to go down all the way to the forest where the wood comes from," says Emiliano Godoy, who with his partner, Alejandro Castro, runs PIRWI, a sustainable-furniture firm in Mexico City. "The city is huge and densely populated with a lot of environmental problems. You can feel that every day and see how things need to be negotiated."

The Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, or ICBC, said it was now the world’s largest bank by deposits after clients invested another 950 billion yuan ($140 billion) in the first quarter. Deposits rose to 8.9 trillion yuan as of March 31; including deposits from financial companies, the amount was 9.78 trillion yuan ($1.43 trillion), the bank said in a statement. ICBC overtook JPMorgan Chase and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group of Japan, according to the statement. JPMorgan had $1 trillion in deposits at the end of 2008, while the Japanese lender held $1.29 trillion as of March 31, 2008, according to Bloomberg data.

Alcoa said it would curtail production and lay off 275 workers at a smelter in Canada if workers there do not agree to a 15 percent pay cut. An exhibition of the Dead Sea Scrolls slated to open this summer at the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto has drawn criticism from Palestinian officials, who say the coming show is a violation of international law, The Toronto Star reported. The show, “Dead Sea Scrolls: Words That Changed the World,” is scheduled to open at the museum on June 27 and would display scrolls discovered in caves near the Dead Sea between 1947 and 1956. But in a letter sent to Canada’s prime minister, Stephen Harper, and to the museum, Palestinian officials say that the scrolls were obtained illegally by Israel when it annexed East Jerusalem after the war in 1967. “The exhibition would entail exhibiting or displaying artifacts removed from the Palestinian territories,” wrote Hamdan Taha, the director-general of the archaeological department in the Palestinian Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities, according to The Star. William Thorsell, the museum’s chief executive, told The Star, “I’m quite certain the scrolls fall within the parameters of the law.”.

Isiah Thomas, who was fired as the Knicks' coach and president one year ago but remains under contract, appears close to cutting his final ties to the franchise. According to multiple reports, Thomas was the leading candidate to take over the men's program at Florida International University. The university announced that it had fired Coach Sergio Rouco, who went 55-94 in five seasons. Thomas has done some scouting for the Knicks in the last year but he has no title and no specific role with the franchise. Team officials have said he is free to pursue other opportunities. The Knicks' president, Donnie Walsh, said through a team spokesman that Thomas had informed him of his discussions with Florida International. More coverage at nytimes.com/sports.

SHAW--Robert, M.D.,died comfortably at home in Bolinas, CA on March 26. He is the husband of Judith Shaw (nee Bloom). Bob's grace and wisdom is inherited by his children Elizabeth (Lizzy) Shaw, Sarah Shaw Dubois, Charles L. Shaw, and John W.M. Shaw, and through affectionate closeness by his children spouses, Lisa Bodwalk, Francesca Shaw, Pierre Dubois and his three granddaughters, Alix, Madeleine and Ellie. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate consideration of a contribution to West Marin Senior Services, Pt. Reyes, CA 94956.

As bad as the start of the season has been for the Washington Nationals -- they dropped to 0-7 with Monday's 9-8 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies and remain the only team without a victory -- they are not even in the neighborhood of the major league's worst starts. Though two of those worst starts actually happened in their neighborhood. The high-water mark for futility was set about an hour up the road by the 1988 Baltimore Orioles, who started 0-21. Those Orioles dropped their opening game, 12-0, and were outscored by 43-7 through their first six. Manager Cal Ripken Sr. was fired and Frank Robinson took over, but Baltimore had losses of 12-1 and 13-1 before it won a game, 26 days into the season.

An airstrike by NATO forces early Monday in mountainous eastern Afghanistan killed six civilians, including two children, a local Afghan official said, the latest accusation of civilian casualties leveled against NATO and American forces. NATO officials confirmed the raid but said that only insurgents suspected of planning attacks on the alliance's outposts had been killed.

In 1906, when Alois Alzheimer, a German psychiatrist, autopsied the brain of a 55-year-old woman, he saw under his microscope the characteristic amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles of dementia. These were phenomena already well known, and Alzheimer never claimed to have discovered a new disease. Rather, he was presenting an unusual case of the ailment in a younger person, and he referred to it as ''pre-senile dementia.''

PEARSALL--Willard H.,Jr., died April 6, 2009 at the age of 85 in Jacksonville, Florida. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he graduated from Poly Prep, Williams College and Harvard Business School. During WWII he served for three years in the Army Air Force Weather Service in the Pacific arena. In 1953, he began a 45 year career with Florida Machine and Foundry Co., a Jacksonville based steel foundry, as Chief Accountant and later became Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. He was a Director Emeritus of SunTrust North Florida. He was an aficionado of jazz music and a lifelong passionate Dodger fan. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Paula, his daughters, Marilla and Katharine (John-Fiske Smith), his son, Willard, his brother, Otis, sister-in-law Nancy, a nephew, Lt. Col. Gilbert, a niece, Melissa Pearsall Hirsch, and numerous great nieces and nephews. He was the son of the late Willard H. Pearsall, Sr. and Marilla Pratt Pearsall, and is predeceased by a brother, Gilbert Pearsall, Sr. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to The Mayo Clinic Florida, Neurology Research, 4500 San Pablo Road, Jacksonville, Florida, 32224.

The N.B.A. may consider using instant replay to judge shot-clock violations in response to a missed call that helped San Antonio beat Sacramento on Sunday. Under current rules, the play was not reviewable.

With Anne Hathaway already set to play Viola, the Public Theater announced additional casting on Wednesday for its Shakespeare in the Park production of “Twelfth Night,” scheduled to run June 10 to July 12 at the open-air Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Audra McDonald (a four-time Tony Award winner whose credits include “A Raisin in the Sun” and “Ragtime”) will play Olivia. Raúl Esparza (“Speed-the-Plow,” “Company”) will play Orsino. Michael Cumpsty will play Malvolio, Jay O. Sanders will play Sir Toby Belch, David Pittu will play Feste and Hamish Linklater will play Sir Andrew Aguecheek. Daniel Sullivan is directing.

If you had just 24 hours in New York, how would you spend them? Take in “Mamma Mia!” or a Yankees game, or maybe fend off some nefarious terrorists? We’re assuming that Jack Bauer, the nonstop action hero portrayed by Kiefer Sutherland, will be doing more of the latter than the former when his Fox television series “24” comes to the city. A Fox spokesperson told TV Guide that the eighth season of “24,” a spy serial whose events are supposed to take place in real time, would be set and at least partly shot in New York. The transition of the show, which has previously been filmed in Los Angeles, was first mentioned on the Web site of Entertainment Weekly, EW.com. The eighth season of “24” is scheduled to start showing on Fox in 2010.

Attention all fans of Elaine Stritch, it’s time to get better acquainted with the New Jersey Transit schedule. Paper Mill Playhouse, in Millburn, N.J., has announced that La Stritch is joining its production of the musical comedy “The Full Monty,” running June 10 to July 12.

One fewer contestant and a muzzle on the judges could not help “American Idol” finish on time Tuesday night, as the most popular show on television once again ran over its hourlong slot on Fox, this time by about four minutes. After receiving numerous complaints the previous week, when the Tuesday-night competition episode ran about eight minutes long, the “Idol” producers tried to keep the live show within bounds this week by allowing only two of the four judges to critique each of the seven contestants. Many of the complaints about last week’s overrun came from viewers who set their digital video recorders to save the broadcast for later viewing but who apparently did not avail themselves of the feature that allows the machine to keep recording beyond the scheduled finishing time. But the delay in the start of the following Fox series, “Fringe,” also potentially gave fits to Fox’s local affiliates, which were faced with either letting that program infringe on their newscasts or cutting short their own broadcast time.

The new musical “Vanities,” whose Broadway debut was indefinitely postponed earlier this year because of producers’ concerns about the economy, will have its New York premiere this summer after all: Off-Broadway at Second Stage Theater, with previews to begin June 30.

The country-pop trio Rascal Flatts called its latest album “Unstoppable,” and the title proved appropriate. Released by Lyric Street Records, Disney’s Nashville branch, “Unstoppable” sold 351,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and is the band’s fourth album in a row to open at No. 1 on the Billboard chart. The soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) rose three spots to No. 2 in its third week in stores, with 196,000 sales. The Yonkers rapper Jadakiss‘s new album, “Last Kiss” (Def Jam), reached No. 3 with 135,000, the country singer Jason Aldean‘s “Wide Open” (Broken Bow) opened at No. 4 with 109,000, and “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 30 is No. 5 with 99,000 sales. Taylor Swift‘s “Fearless” (Big Machine), which was named album of the year at the Academy of Country Music Awards on April 5, jumped four spots to No. 6 in its 22nd week in stores; it sold 82,000 copies last week, putting the album’s total sales at just over 3 million.

What we’re reading (and watching) on Wednesday morning.

George Harrison, the former Beatle who died of cancer in 2001, was honored Tuesday with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, Reuters reported. The star was placed in front of the offices of Capitol Records, which released the Beatles’ albums in the United States as well as solo works by Mr. Harrison. Among those in attendance at the ceremony were his widow, Olivia, and his son, Dhani, as well as his former bandmate Paul McCartney. Mr. McCartney did not make any public remarks, but Olivia Harrison said of her late husband, “He was a beautiful, mystical man living in a material world, and he was as funny as the day is long, and just as perplexing,” according to Reuters. Also on hand was Tom Hanks, who told the crowd, “All things must pass, sure. But George is going to live forever.”

Though Woody Allen is used to having his late-period movies criticized, even his resilient ego may be stung by the comments made by a lawyer for the clothing company American Apparel and reported by The Associated Press. Last year, Mr. Allen filed suit against American Apparel after it posted billboards in New York and Los Angeles that used an image of him in rabbinical attire, from his movie “Annie Hall,” without his authorization. In a deposition in December, Mr. Allen said the ads were “sleazy” and “infantile,” according to The A.P. Stuart Slotnick, a lawyer for American Apparel, told The A.P that at a May trial date he intends to bring up Mr. Allen’s affair with the woman he later married, Soon-Yi Previn, the adopted daughter of his then-companion, Mia Farrow. “Certainly, our belief is that after the various sex scandals that Woody Allen has been associated with, corporate America’s desire to have Woody Allen endorse their product is not what he may believe it is,” Mr. Slotnick told the A.P.

He’s already been the subject of obsessive media coverage, and now he will be the subject of a children’s book. Bo, the Portuguese water dog who recently became the first presidential pet in the Obama White House, is the star of “Bo, America’s Commander in Leash,” which is expected in stores by the end of the month. Mascot Books, a small independent publisher in Herndon, Va., that specializes in producing titles based on university and school mascots, is rushing out the book to capture the fervor surrounding the Obamas’ new dog. The book is written by Naren Aryal, a founder of Mascot Books, and illustrated by Danny Moore, an employee of the company. Mr. Aryal said he and Mr. Moore had been working on the project for about two months, leaving space for pictures of the dog once it was chosen. The 32-page book includes references to longstanding White House traditions like the Easter egg roll and the pardoning of the Thanksgiving turkey, as well as newer things introduced by the Obamas like the swing set for their daughters, and Michelle Obama’s organic garden. Mr. Aryal said neither of the Obamas’ daughters are named in the book because he wanted to protect their privacy.

My Thursday column draws on the recent scholarly work showing that I.Q. is more malleable, especially for kids lower on the socio-economic spectrum, than has been thought. The conventional wisdom among scholars and lay people alike, shaped by a series of studies of twins, had suggested that I.Q. was largely fixed and genetic and little shaped by the environment. From that evidence, people like Charles Murray argued that education could do relatively little for kids in the bottom half of the distribution.
Demonstrators attended tea party rallies from Yakima, Wash., to Washington, D.C., to vent their frustrations over the sagging economy and government bailouts.

The new Secretary of Commerce, Gary Locke of Seattle, is a former Eagle Scout, prosecutor, and popular two-term governor whose idea of a good time is to crawl under the kitchen sink with plumber's tape and a gob of grease. Just one week into the new job, he flew home to mow his lawn.

Unlike Barack Obama, Richard Nixon had planned a presidential trip to Europe even before he won the White House. Coming shortly after his inauguration, the tour was to be part of proving him "a master statesman," as he described his long-sought role. As it unfolded, the trip had its own portents, a mix of the serious and the petty, of the skill and squalor that were to epitomize Nixon's presidency.

Most days, if I'm home and trying to figure out what to do next, Toby the Lab has his chin resting on the windowsill in my office, looking out at the world he knows more intimately than I do. This particular room of the house was designed for short-legged dogs-namely, Freddy and Raggedy Ann, our Jack Russells-so they could readily observe the main events of the day: the squirrels and turkeys, the arrival of our garbage man. Fred and Raggedy Ann are both now gone, buried in a place that is framed by the view from this window so that at least for certain periods of each day they are in my sights. Some things should not change too much.

Here is something we missed two weeks ago: some snapshots of Dayana Mendoza, Miss Universe, enjoying her trip to Guantánamo Bay. When "The Hills" returned to our television screens a few weeks ago, we knew the flickering romance between Heidi and Spencer, enshrined in Mexican matrimony last season, would not last long. Call us cynics or maybe just sentient beings. Sure enough, by Episode 503 this week, things have gone off the rails. Spencer is hitting on a trashy bartender, and Heidi is about to call it quits. Who's to blame for this debacle (other than the show's script writer)? Fingers that know point to Charlie, Spencer's new wing man and the Mephistopheles of "The Hills." SOUTH ORANGE -- Village officials and leaders of the public employees' union have agreed on a proposal to avert 11 of the 14 planned layoffs. The deal calls on municipal employees to increase their contribution to health insurance payments and take 12 unpaid furlough days before the end of 2010, according to a union official.

I'm awed by the courage of those 300 Afghan women who endured stones, jeers and threats to march through Kabul today demanding a measure of equal rights. As my colleague Dexter Filkins reports, the women were chased and insulted as "whores" by a mob of men and women three times as large. The women were protesting a new law, applying only to Shiites, that obliges women to sleep with their husbands on demand and bars them from leaving the home without their husbands' permission.

Earlier this week, I was saddened to hear that Mark Fidrych, the 1976 American League Rookie of the Year, was found dead under his Mack truck after he suffocated when his clothes became entangled in a spinning shaft. Although I was too young to follow his amazing first season, I remember collecting his baseball card from the subsequent seasons until he retired in the early 1980s. Fidrych, a pitcher for the Detroit Tigers when he won the award, had one of those melancholic careers that happen so often in baseball -- a brilliant rookie season followed by injuries, forcing an early retirement.

Following is the first set of answers from Michelle and James Nevius, the authors of "Inside the Apple: A Streetwise History of New York City." This week they will be answering questions about the history of Manhattan from Henry Hudson's arrival in 1609 to the present. If you have ever walked by a building in the borough and wondered about its origins, or whether a historic event really took place where you think it did, or any other little-known fact, they will know the answers. Both in their book and on their guided tours, the authors try to link the history of Manhattan to places that can still be visited today. One of their goals is to focus on the patterns that emerge as a neighborhood or street changes over time.

Russia has always been a major source of inspiration for fashion - remember Yves Saint Laurent's 1976 Ballet Russes collection? These days, however, the country's impact on the style community is about far more than nostalgia. Russian models dominate most catwalks, designers like Denis Simachev are gaining recognition abroad, and Western luxury houses are tripping over each other to cash in on the megawealthy and clothes-obsessed Russian oligarch market.

Hasheem Thabeet of Connecticut has decided to forgo his final year of college eligibility and enter the N.B.A. draft. RAPAPORT--Stella Fuld, nee Fread, award-winning illustrator and children's book author, passed away at her home in West Palm Beach, Florida. She was 98. Stella was born August 7, 1910, in New York City to Mollie and Abraham Fread. With her sister Edith Harris (1907-1999) and brother Bernard Fread (1904-1992), she shared many wonderful memories growing up which became the basis for some of her books. She attended Hunter College and The Art Students League. Among her best known artistic endeavors were her watercolor and oil paintings, often whimsical, combining nature scenes from her global travels with her great knowledge of birds and animals. Highlights of the books she wrote and illustrated include "A Whittle Too Much," winner of the Catholic Book Club Award and one of The New York Times 100 Best Books for 1955. "Reindeer Rescue," won the William Allen White Children's Book Award for 1957-1958. Her next book, "The Bear Ship of Many Lives," received the Boys Life Dodd Mead Writing Award in 1962. To research the true story for this book, Stella traveled above the Arctic Circle. Stella also illustrated and authored "Binkley's Bottleneck" and "Philip and the Ninety-Nine Frogs." In June 1931, she married Irving S. Rapaport, Esq. (1903-1972), a name partner in a law firm. Irving was a devoted husband and father involved in Jewish causes. He was a synagogue vice president. Stella is survived by their loving sons, Myron S. Rapaport (Barbara) and Robert D. Rapaport (Cobey), their beloved grandchildren: Marc Rapaport (Allison), Elisa Rapaport (Michael), Fred Rapaport (Lori), Mason Rapaport (Amy), Peggy Goldblatt (Adam), Jeff Rapaport, Tali Rapaport, and their precious great-grandchildren: Zachary, Emily, Yael, Natan, Jared, Devin, Ilana, Talia and Zefora. In January 1976, Stella married Judge Stanley H. Fuld (1903-2002), Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals. Judge Fuld served as Chairman of the board of The Jewish Theological Seminary. She is survived by his devoted daughter Hermine Nessen. A memorial service will be held on Friday April 17 at 1pm at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, New York. Donations may be sent to: Fread Sanctuary, Temple Beth El, West Palm Beach.

FITLER-ELLIS--John A.,passed away Sunday night, March 28th in Palm Springs California. John graduated from the Parsons School of Design and worked for many years for Dorothy Draper as a designer. He was responsible for the Cherry Hill Inn in New Jersey and the Greenbrier Inn at White Sulphur Springs, WV for Ms. Draper. He also established his own interior design firm in Philadelphia, as well as a wholesale fabric and wallpaper company in San Francisco. He leaves little family and many friends behind and will be missed by all. A memorial service is planned for early summer in both New York City and San Francisco.

In the span of a couple of weeks recently, I enjoyed salads made with pears and pecorino. One was a rather delicate and refreshing assembly on a bed of sliced fennel, with a sprinkling of pine nuts, at the new Armani Ristorante on Fifth Avenue. The other was at Insieme in the theater district; it had scattered walnuts and used escarole and frisée as the bed. Both restaurants used pecorino, a firm and tangy sheep's milk cheese, from Pienza in Tuscany, which is famous for it. Despite the allure of these salads, they challenge wine. Sancerre to the rescue! Its grape, sauvignon blanc, is the default when it comes to salad. It classically yields a wine whose minerality, herbaceous notes and steely backbone are undaunted by whatever vinegar you might splash its way. And it proved the right choice for my take on the pear-pecorino combo, made with fava beans that caught my eye in the market. FLORENCE FABRICANT

A Comic Book Pioneer Tells His Story Yoshihiro Tatsumi's graphic memoir, ''A Drifting Life,'' chronicles his life in post-Hiroshima Japan, and his travails as a struggling artist. The 73-year-old is a pioneer of the manga form, but his work has dealt with decidedly darker fare than much of the genre. ''It's a big, fat, greasy tub of salty popcorn for anyone interested (as Americans increasingly are) in the theory and practice of Japanese comics,'' writes Dwight Garner.

SEDGWICK--Eve Kosofsky, age 58, died on Sunday after 18 years of living with breast cancer. She was a Distinguished Professor of English at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. She is survived by her mother Rita Kosofsky, her brother David Kosofsky, her sister Nina Kopesky, and her husband Hal Sedgwick. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her honor may be made to the Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick Memorial Fund of the National Breast Cancer Coalition Fund (stopbreastcancer.org) A memorial service is being planned at a date to be an nounced.

Reposing at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., New York City. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 9:30am, St. Anthony's RC Church. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park. NADEL--Lawrence, of Great Neck, NY died on April 13 at the age of 80 after a brief illness. Beloved father of Charles and Brian; cherished grandfather of Emily, Jamie, Graham and Peter, he was the devoted husband of Elaine. His first wife Madeline predeceased him. A dedicated public servant, he served as the mayor of Great Neck Estates. Always optimistic, strong-willed and active, his spirit will be missed by all those who knew him. Funeral service at Riverside Great Neck on Thursday at noon.

KRISTEIN--Marvin M.,Stony Brook, LI, NY, on April 11 at home, after valiant struggle against leukemia. Pioneer in calculation of smoking's societal costs, particularly to employers and economy, key evidence for national anti-smoking policies. Patron of higher education, fine and performing arts; established Kolozsvar Awards honoring New York City Opera artists performing new/unusual repertory. SUNY Stony Brook, Professor, Economics 1959-87; CUNY, Economics, 1956-59, 1987-90, retired as Professor Emeritus. Townsend Harris High School 1942. CCNY BA 1947 (interrupted by US Army service). New School Ph.D. 1955. Survived by beloved and loving wife Vera Rony. Burial private; memorial event being scheduled.

BONER--Mitchell, of White Plains, NY, 94, passed away from natural causes on April 14, 2009. He is survived by Eleanor, his loving and devoted wife of 67 years, his son Larry Bonner of Delray Beach, FL, his daughter Ethel Tankenson of Los Angeles, CA, his cherished grandson, Alex Bonner of New York NY, his daughter-in-law Stephanie Bonner and son-in-law Mike Tankenson. Mitchell was born in Riga, Latvia January 8, 1915. He emigrated to the United States at the age of 22. He was a self-made businessman and entrepreneur who founded one of the pre-eminent jewelry manufacturing companies in New York City. He dearly loved his wife, his family and his adopted country, and will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Funeral Services, 11:30 am April 16, 2009. Call Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY. 914-381-1809

When Alex Rodriguez needed hip surgery last month, it seemed to be an ominous sign for his future. Rodriguez is 33 and starting the second season of a 10-year contract. He said his mind flashed to elite athletes like Bo Jackson and Albert Belle, whose careers ended because of a bad hip. But Dr. Marc Philippon, the surgeon in Vail, Colo., who operated on Rodriguez and has supervised his rehabilitation, drew a more encouraging comparison: the golfer Greg Norman, Philippon's former patient.

GLEICK Beth Youman, 80, died April 14. She was the devoted wife of 52 years to Donen, beloved mother of James, Peter, and Elizabeth, and grandmother of Daniel, Harry, Jeremy, Margaret and Julia. A lifelong resident of New York, she was a children's book author and a designer and editor of newsletters. She was born August 29, 1928, and she graduated from Connecticut College in 1950. She returned to graduate school and received her M.A. from New York University in 1981. A social animal and a wily game player, she was deeply devoted to her family and friends. Memorial service on Friday, April 17, 3:30pm, at Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of choice.

John Phillip Hernandez, a 24-year-old unemployed machinist who lived with his parents, walked into a giant sporting goods store here in July 2006, and plunked $2,600 in cash on a glass display counter. A few minutes later, Mr. Hernandez walked out with three military-style rifles. One of those rifles was recovered seven months later in Acapulco, Mexico, where it had been used by drug cartel gunmen to attack the offices of the Guerrero State attorney general, court documents say. Four police officers and three secretaries were killed.
