On this week’s Popcast, Ben Ratliff reviews “Live,” a new album from the gospel singer Smokie Norful, and chairs a roundtable discussion on the Grateful Dead where the participants debate the eternal question: What was the best Grateful Dead performance ever captured on tape? Sia Michel is your host.

Beneath his placid, nebbishy exterior, Woody Allen may well possess a backbone: the filmmaker has fired back at the clothing maker American Apparel, which he is suing for using his image in advertisements without his permission, The Associated Press reported. In court papers filed Wednesday, lawyers for Mr. Allen said that American Apparel had “adopted a ‘scorched earth’ approach” in its defense, employing excessive subpoenas and requests for documents from the director, and engaging in a “despicable effort” to intimidate him, according to The A.P. On Tuesday, a lawyer for American Apparel said that at trial in May, he intended to bring up details of Mr. Allen’s personal history, including the director’s affair with Soon-Yi Previn. The billboards, which appeared in New York and Los Angeles, used a still image of him in character in “Annie Hall.”
Who could have possibly foreseen that these two characters would turn out to be related?

Normally we’d say that the only place you’d find Conor Oberst, Brian Stokes Mitchell and Ian Hunter is in the dictionary definition for eclecticism. But all of these artists and many others will be part of the River to River Festival, the free arts series held annually along the waterfronts of downtown Manhattan. In a news release, the event’s organizers said that this year’s festival would begin May 31 with the Bang on a Can Marathon at the World Financial Center. Other highlights include a performance by Mr. Mitchell, the Tony Award-winning Broadway performer, on June 3 at Rockefeller Park; a one-hour version of Mozart’s “Magic Flute” featuring the soloists and orchestra of New York City Opera, on June 25 at Rockefeller Park; a concert by Mr. Oberst and the Mystic Valley Band with Jenny Lewis on July 4 at State Street and Battery Place; and a site-specific event involving the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, Aug. 1 and 2 at a location to be determined. A full listing of events will be post online at RiverToRiverNYC.com.

Janet Silver, the former publisher of Houghton Mifflin’s adult trade books division and an editor at large at the Nan A. Talese/Doubleday imprint of the Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group, has joined the literary agency Zachary Shuster Harmsworth as an agent and its editorial director, the company said in a news release. During her time at Houghton Mifflin, Ms. Silver acquired and edited works by Philip Roth, Tim O’Brien, Jhumpa Lahiri and Cynthia Ozick, among others. The publisher also released bestsellers like “Fast Food Nation” by Eric Schlosser and “The God Delusion” by Richard Dawkins during her tenure. Ms. Silver was ousted from Houghton Mifflin in 2008 when it merged with Harcourt, and its publisher, Becky Saletan, was made publisher of the combined company. Ms. Saletan became the editorial director of Riverhead Books in January.
Look, we love George Lucas‘s “Star Wars” movies (the first three, anyway) as much as the next guy who ever asked his wife if he could name their first child Boba Fett. But even this may be too much.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra has canceled a planned tour of Europe that would have commenced in 2010 and included performances in Paris and Vienna, The Boston Globe reported. In a statement, the orchestra said the cancellation was a result of the economic downturn and added that it “will not resume international touring activity until a recovery is well under way,” according to The Globe. The orchestra said it would continue to focus on performances in Boston, Tanglewood and New York.

American Ballet Theater announced Thursday that it had received a gift of $5 million from Toni and Martin Sosnoff. In a release, Ballet Theater said that it was the single largest gift it has received from an individual donor, and that the money would be used to create the Toni and Martin Sosnoff New Works Fund, which will support all future works that it commissions. Ballet Theater said that its world premiere of Alexei Ratmansky’s “On the Dnieper,” scheduled for June 1, and its company premiere of James Kudelka’s “Désir” would be the first works supported by the new fund. Mr. Sosnoff is the chairman and founder of the investment management company Atalanta/Sosnoff Capital and is on the board of trustees of Ballet Theater.

The team behind the film “Slumdog Millionaire” said that it would make a donation to Plan, an international charity that focuses on children’s development in India and elsewhere. In a news release, the “Slumdog” filmmakers, including the director Danny Boyle and the producer Christian Colson, said that they had pledged about $745,000 to a five-year program intended to improve the lives of children in the slums of Mumbai, where the movie takes place. Following the release of “Slumdog Millionaire,” its creative team was criticized for exploiting the child actors they had recruited from Mumbai; the filmmakers said the actors had been tutored and paid three times the average Indian adult’s salary while working on the film.

Updated | 3:51 p.m. In response to a countersuit filed by The Associated Press, lawyers for the artist Shepard Fairey said that his use of an A.P. photograph of Barack Obama in the artist’s well-known “Hope” poster was permissible under fair-use law and the First Amendment, according to court documents filed Tuesday. Mr. Fairey’s lawyers also said that The A.P. was engaging in a similar practice by claiming ownership of and licensing photographs of copyrighted works by other artists, including Jeff Koons, Banksy and Mr. Fairey, without their permission. In February, Mr. Fairey sued The A.P., seeking a declaratory judgment that the “Hope” poster does not infringe on its copyrights. The A.P. countersued in March, saying that Mr. Fairey misappropriated its rights to the original image of Mr. Obama. In a statement, The A.P. said it was still reviewing Mr. Fairey’s response, but added that he “appears to have deliberately omitted” the newsgathering context of the news service’s photographs of artwork.

The Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle theater awards committees will not consider the musical “Next to Normal” for honors this spring, their leaders said on Thursday because nominators for the two organizations and the show’s producers could not agree on a performance schedule and on whether the show would be eligible for awards in all categories.

Charles André Joseph Marie de Gaulle - as Richard Nixon often referred to the French president, a full name he thought resonant of "grandeur, glory, greatness" - was the last of the great World War II leaders still on the world stage in 1969: former commander of the Free French, peer of Roosevelt and Churchill, and an outsized figure to a young Southern California lawyer and postwar congressman named Richard Nixon. The new president, as White House chief of staff H.R. Haldeman saw it, was simply "in awe" of the French general.

A central dispute was over how scientists can best discuss risks and responses related to inherent, and dangerous, extremes of climate in a world increasingly fixated on how to limit global warming caused by human activity. I have to admit that part of my view is laziness: it's quicker and takes less brain power to put the steamed (not boiled) potatoes through a ricer than to hand-crush them to that stage where they're still rustic but are mashed enough to absorb the requisite milk and butter.

Perched high in the upper deck, there had to still be a few seats at the corner of Stadium and No Stadium. And for the Yankees' home opener on Thursday afternoon, they belonged to Phil DiCandido and Jessica Nonnemacher on the right-field side.

WASHINGTON -- I hate to say it (and I shouldn't really, because it's just one game) but midway through Wednesday's Game 1 victory the much-maligned defense pairing of Michal Rozsival and Wade Redden was made the Rangers' shutdown unit. Coach John Tortorella and assistant Jim Schoenfeld, who runs the defense, made the switch about halfway through the game, and Rozsival and Redden ended up with about 28 minutes of ice time each, tops on the team, and the most both have played all season long.

Following is the second set of answers from Michelle and James Nevius, the authors of "Inside the Apple: A Streetwise History of New York City." This week they are answering questions about the history of Manhattan from Henry Hudson's arrival in 1609 to the present. If you have ever walked by a building in the borough and wondered about its origins, or whether a historic event really took place where you think it did, or any other little-known fact, they will know the answers. Both in their book and on their guided tours, the authors try to link the history of Manhattan to places that can still be visited today. One of their goals is to focus on the patterns that emerge as a neighborhood or street changes over time.

The Pierro Gallery's current exhibition, "At This Moment She" presents the work of four talented New Jersey artists -- Christine Gatti, Stephen Rice, Anthony Santella and Joan Goldsmith -- tackling a serious subject: women, the "She" in the exhibition's title. As interpreted by the artists in this show "She" is multifaceted, alternately alluring, despairing, industrious, confined, worshiped and restrained.

By today's standards, the cover of a fashion magazine is about as creative as baby formula. There's the requisite torso (airbrushed to a fair thee well) positioned to allow for the requisite cover lines, which more often than not contain the number 25. Now compare that to the Vogue cover of January 1950: Jean Patchett's face reduced to a beauty mark, mouth, eye, brow and nose. If ever there were a visual haiku, this is it. Woman distilled to her essence; the sum of her parts more alluring than the whole.

Many home cooks are comfortable with spinach but are intimidated by the unfamiliar variety of other cooking greens they start to see at this time of year: chard, mustard, turnips, collards, kale and more. Kale is my favorite of these greens, and this preparation is dead easy.

LONDON | When debating a big move from California to London, I agonized more about leaving behind the great burritos than saying goodbye to the California sunshine. For the past eight years - four in Los Angeles and four in San Francisco - I've consumed an unknown, but vast amount of burritos and tacos. That all stopped the day I left the Bay Area for Ol' Blighty five months ago.

Apparently, they pull up to the ship, they fire some shots, scare everyone off, then they climb up the side, then I guess they copy and distribute DVD's. Is that what they do?

The loss-making Saab Automobile unit of General Motors said on Thursday it had signed confidentiality agreements with 27 potential suitors in its efforts to find a new owner to help it survive the downturn, Reuters reported.

The Yankees went to great lengths to incorporate many features of their old stadium (bottom) into their new one (top). They replicated the original frieze and kept the field dimensions just about the same. And if the sun is out during Thursday's opener, perceptive fans and players will notice another striking similarity: the imposing stadium shadows that became part of countless famous games.

Mariah Carey's life reads like a deconstructed fairy tale. Columbia Records' Tommy Mottola discovered Carey in 1988, and her debut album generated five back-to-back No. 1 singles. Then there was her reportedly suffocating marriage to Mottola, which ended in divorce and her departure from Columbia in 2001. Carey was dropped by her next label, struggled through unsuccessful financial deals and suffered a physical and emotional breakdown. Her film project bombed. Then, in 2005, she released "Emancipation," and was back on top.

Geno Auriemma, the Connecticut women’s coach, said he would continue to coach the Huskies while also taking over the United States women’s team. Auriemma was introduced as the national team coach for the next three years, through the 2012 Olympics in London. Auriemma, 55, just guided Connecticut to its sixth national championship and third perfect season. He is the first active college coach to head a women’s Olympic team since Tara VanDerveer led the 1996 team to a gold medal in Atlanta. ¶Forward DeMarcus Cousins signed a national letter of intent to play at Kentucky, the first one secured by the new coach, John Calipari. Cousins had previously committed to play for Calipari at Memphis, but is joining the Wildcats because Calipari was hired earlier this month to replace Billy Gillispie. Along with Cousins, Kentucky announced Jon Hood of Madisonville, Ky., and Daniel Orton of Oklahoma City as members of the signing class. kentucky ¶The former U.C.L.A. and Alabama-Birmingham coach Gene Bartow has received a diagnosis of stomach cancer. Bartow, 78, the president of the company that owns the N.B.A.’s Memphis Grizzlies, will begin outpatient treatment at the Kirklin Clinic in Birmingham next week, U.A.B. said. Bartow succeeded John Wooden as U.C.L.A.’s coach in 1976 and led the Bruins to the Final Four. He left after two seasons to start Alabama-Birmingham’s program. bartow.

Cristiano Ronaldo scored on a spectacular 40-yard shot in the sixth minute, and defending champion Manchester United defeated Porto, 1-0, on Wednesday night to advance to the European Champions League semifinals with a 3-2 aggregate victory. Manchester United extended its Champions League record unbeaten streak to 23 games and will meet Arsenal in an all-English semifinal, at home April 29, with the return match May 5. Arsenal defeated Spain’s Villarreal, 3-0, on goals by Theo Walcott, Emmanuel Adebayor and Robin van Persie to advance by 4-1 on aggregate.

The former Olympic 100-meter champion Justin Gatlin has reached an out-of-court settlement with the United States Olympic Committee, the United States Anti-Doping Agency, USA Track & Field and the International Association of Athletics Federations. Gatlin had sued those groups in federal court, saying his rights were violated under the Americans with Disabilities Act. He said he was discriminated against because his first of two doping violations, in 2001, was for taking prescribed medication to treat attention deficit disorder. Because that penalty was on the books, his second violation, in 2006, triggered a suspension that kept him from defending his 2004 Olympic gold medal at the Beijing Games. Gatlin’s lawyer said the settlement documents were not final.

Brawn GP’s Jenson Button can keep his Formula One victories, and Ferrari will have to rush to redesign its car. The world motor sports governing body approved the use of a rear diffuser design that helped Button win the season’s first two races, in Australia and Malaysia. The decision by F.I.A.’s International Court of Appeals ends efforts by Ferrari, Renault, BMW Sauber and Red Bull Racing to protest the diffusers. Had they won their appeal, Button could have had his victories annulled.

The Olympic gold medalist Shawn Johnson added the Sullivan Award as the nation’s top amateur athlete to her balance beam title at the Beijing Games. Johnson beat out her teammate Nastia Liukin, the all-around champion at the 2008 Games, and several others for the 79th annual award. She is the third gymnast to win the Sullivan, joining Kurt Thomas (1979) and Paul Hamm (2004). Other finalists were the United States Olympic men’s 400-meter freestyle relay swim team; the volleyball player Cynthia Barboza of Stanford; and the North Carolina basketball player Tyler Hansbrough.

An obituary on Monday about the bandleader Manny Oquendo misstated the surname of one of his surviving sisters. She is Lydia Crespo, not Crystal.

An obituary on Wednesday about Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick, a literary critic who focused on sexual identity in fiction, misidentified the North Carolina city that is home to Duke University, where she taught. It is Durham — not Chapel Hill, which is where the University of North Carolina is located.

An article on Wednesday about the announcement that Isiah Thomas will be the new basketball coach at Florida International University misstated the name of the university he led to a national championship as a player in 1981. It is Indiana University. There is no University of Indiana.

The Shortcuts column on Saturday, about the value of sabbaticals, misstated the business of Accenture, a company that allows workers to set aside part of their pay and take up to three months’ paid leave every three years. It is a consulting company, not an accounting company.

An article on Friday about the Bank of England’s efforts to revive bank lending misstated the extent of joblessness in Britain. The ranks of the unemployed rose more than 420,000 in 2008, to 2 million; the country has not lost “millions” of jobs since the credit freeze and housing crisis undermined the economy last year.

The new musical “Vanities,” whose Broadway debut was indefinitely postponed because of producers’ concerns about the economy, will have its New York premiere this summer after all: Off Broadway at Second Stage Theater, with previews to begin on June 30. “Vanities” follows three female friends from their years as high school cheerleaders through adulthood. The musical is based on the play of the same title by Jack Heifner (who also wrote the book for the musical), which ran for more than four years Off Broadway in the 1970s. Second Stage scheduled “Vanities” as a replacement for “Mr. & Mrs. Fitch,” a new play by Douglas Carter Beane that was postponed because its director, Scott Ellis, had a scheduling conflict with his new duties on the Showtime series “Weeds.”.

The country-pop trio Rascal Flatts called its latest album “Unstoppable,” and that has proved appropriate. Released by Lyric Street Records, Disney’s Nashville branch, “Unstoppable” sold 351,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and is the band’s fourth album in a row to open at No. 1 on the Billboard chart. The soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) rose three spots to No. 2 in its third week in stores, with 196,000 sales. The Yonkers rapper Jadakiss’s new album, “Last Kiss” (Def Jam), reached No. 3 with 135,000; the country singer Jason Aldean’s “Wide Open” (Broken Bow) opened at No. 4 with 109,000; and “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 30 is No. 5 ,with 99,000 sales. Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine), which was named album of the year at the Academy of Country Music Awards on April 5, jumped four spots to No. 6 in its 22nd week in stores; it sold 82,000 copies last week, putting the album’s total sales at just over 3 million.

If you had just 24 hours in New York, how would you spend them? Take in “Mamma Mia!” or a Yankees game, or maybe fend off some nefarious villains? We’re assuming that Jack Bauer, the nonstop action hero portrayed by Kiefer Sutherland, will be more interested in terrorists than tourism when his Fox television series, “24,” comes to the city. Fox told TV Guide that the eighth season of “24,” a spy serial whose events are supposed to take place in real time, would be set and at least partly shot in New York. The move of the show was first mentioned on the Web site of Entertainment Weekly, EW.com. The eighth season is scheduled to begin on Fox in 2010.

With Anne Hathaway already set to play Viola, the Public Theater announced additional casting on Wednesday for its Shakespeare in the Park production of “Twelfth Night,” scheduled to run June 10 to July 12 at the open-air Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Audra McDonald (a four-time Tony Award-winner whose credits include “A Raisin in the Sun” and “Ragtime”) will play Olivia. Raúl Esparza (“Speed-the-Plow,” “Company”) will play Orsino. Also joining the cast are Michael Cumpsty as Malvolio, Jay O. Sanders (Sir Toby Belch), David Pittu (Feste) and Hamish Linklater (Sir Andrew Aguecheek). Daniel Sullivan is directing.

Though Woody Allen, below, is used to having his movies criticized, even his resilient ego may be stung by the comments made by a lawyer for the clothing company American Apparel and reported by The Associated Press. Last year Mr. Allen filed suit against American Apparel after it posted billboards in New York and Los Angeles that used an image of him in rabbinical attire, from his movie “Annie Hall,” without his authorization. Stuart Slotnick, a lawyer for American Apparel, told The A.P. that at a May trial date he intends to bring up Mr. Allen’s affair with the woman he later married, Soon-Yi Previn, the adopted daughter of his companion at the time, Mia Farrow. “Certainly, our belief is that after the various sex scandals that Woody Allen has been associated with, corporate America’s desire to have Woody Allen endorse their product is not what he may believe it is,” Mr. Slotnick told The A.P.

The opponents are imaginary in the samurai martial arts form known as iaido (pronounced ee-eye-doe), an unlikely combination of dancelike movements and a nasty-looking weapon. Iaido is especially appealing, perhaps, to anyone who's ever practiced tough-guy poses in the bathroom mirror. Iaido (below) can be a ''moving meditation,'' but its operative idea is deadly, explained Noboru Kataoka, one of its leading masters and a martial arts film actor. ''The moment you draw the sword, you have to kill your opponent,'' he said. Each of its swordsmanship routines, called kata, evokes a specific peril, like fighting in a low-ceilinged tunnel, sparring in the dark, or being jumped from two sides.

It can be surprising in Japanese archery to see a shooter taking aim a mere bow's length from her target. While that distance can stretch, kyudo (below) is not about the bull's-eye. ''You have to have this awareness of what you're doing but not be judging it,'' explained Vivi Spicer, a Maryland curator, as she trained in her yard. Indoors, she popped in a video profile of Kanjuro Shibata, her school's master, who looks like a Japanese Jack LaLanne but sounds like a mystic. ''A master does not try to hit the target,'' Mr. Shibata intoned, adding that ''if he has a good heart, he will hit the target even if he is blind.'' Kyudo is more stillness than action. ''Every movement of the hands, of the body, of the feet, is prescribed'' by sequences analogous to iaido's kata, Ms. Spicer said. Even releasing the arrow is less a decision than something ''that happens when the movement is right, like fruit dropping.''

FRANK--Patricia N.,passed away on April 14, 2009. For 58 years she was the beloved wife of Robert B. Frank and the adored mother of Priscilla (Leonard) Adler and Karen "Kiki" (Howard) Kelrick and their children, Leslie and Jamie Adler and Allison and Scott Kelrick. Memorial services will be at 2pm at Temple Beth El of Boca Raton, 333 SW 4th Avenue, Boca Raton, FL 33432 on April 16, 2009, with family receiving friends at the Franks' home afterward. Remembrances may be made to the Miami City Ballet, 2200 Liberty Avenue, Miami Beach, FL 33139 or www.miamicityballet.org

Of all the disciplines covered here, the arts of kali, arnis and eskrima (left), from the Philippines, are perhaps the most vigorous, employing an almost balletic violence to prepare for rough nights on the town. It's no accident that their weapons -- rattan sticks, wood daggers and the hard side of one's hand -- can be approximated by items you might have on hand, like umbrellas, bottles or even a pen, Mr. Acosta said. Classes consist of sparring and grappling drills called offensiva-defensiva, usually practiced in pairs. But instructors eschew rigid sequences. ''You have to learn the pattern, and then break the pattern,'' Mr. Acosta explained, because ''a real attack is random chaos.''

BONER--Mitchell, of White Plains, NY, 94, passed away from natural causes on April 14, 2009. He is survived by Eleanor, his loving and devoted wife of 67 years, his son Larry Bonner of Delray Beach, FL, his daughter Ethel Tankenson of Los Angeles, CA, his cherished grandson, Alex Bonner of New York NY, his daughter-in-law Stephanie Bonner and son-in-law Mike Tankenson. Mitchell was born in Riga, Latvia January 8, 1915. He emigrated to the United States at the age of 22. He was a self-made businessman and entrepreneur who founded one of the pre-eminent jewelry manufacturing companies in New York City. He dearly loved his wife, his family and his adopted country, and will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Funeral Services, 11:30 am April 16, 2009. Call Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY. 914-381-1809

A report in the City Room column on Wednesday about a new reimbursement for bicyclists who commute to work included an outdated figure for the maximum monthly reimbursement for participants in a transportation fringe benefit program who commute to work by mass transit. It is $230, no longer $120. (The $230 rate, however, is set to expire at the end of the year.)

It's not often that a phone app is better than the original program. But in this case, the free DirecTV phone app, which lets you use your iPhone to tell your digital video recorder to grab your favorite shows, beats the DVR itself.

The Taiwanese computer manufacturer Acer is surging ahead in market share, and while it's still chasing Hewlett-Packard and Dell, the company is not letting up. Acer recently unwrapped its Timeline series of notebooks, with prices starting at about $700. That's $700 for Acer's flagship product. The company claims up to eight hours of battery life with a conventional hard drive, and 10 hours with a solid-state drive. The heaviest model in the lineup is just more than five pounds; the lightest is 3.5 pounds. The Timelines promise to turn the heat down with their ''Laminar Wall Jet'' technology, which is supposed to redirect cooling air along the bottom side of the notebook. Developed with Intel, Laminar Wall Jet incorporates a design used to cool turbine blades.

With national elections next Wednesday, a campaign to ''Stop Zuma'' has been started by opposition leader Helen Zille. She said while there may be no chance of keeping Jacob Zuma, the leader of the governing African National Congress, from the presidency, she hopes to stop the A.N.C. from winning the two-thirds majority in Parliament that would allow it to make changes to the Constitution. The A.N.C. wants to shield itself ''from corruption investigations, even if it means undermining the constitution,'' she warned, adding that South Africa could well become a ''failed state.'' The governing party has held a two-thirds majority for the past five years without making such changes.

SHERMAN--William, 95, died peacefully at home in NYC on April 13. Adored and adoring husband of Annette for 58 years. Gentle, loving father of the late James Sherman, Robert Sherman and his wife Rhonda. Devoted and playful Popop of Sophia and Charlie. A pied piper to children, respected and proud attorney for 60 years, William was a dedicated Honorary Trustee of Park Avenue Synagogue. Handsome, with the most beautiful blue eyes, he lived his life with dignity, kindness and grace. Funeral services, Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street, 10am Friday.

URBAIN--John, of Block Island, RI, died peacefully on April 8, 2009, in Milford, CT at age 88. A devoted father, husband, poet, and artist-- his talent, insights, humor and warm spirit, inspired and touched the lives of many. Born in Brussels, Belgium in 1920, he immigrated with his parents to Detroit, Michigan in 1922. Drafted into the US Army in 1941, John was an infantry Corporal whose skill as an illustrator led him to create army training graphics and murals. Wounded during WWII, he later depicted the pathos of war in his own artwork. Under the G.I. Bill, John studied art at Black Mountain College, where his most influential teacher, Josef Albers, opened his eyes to new approaches to design, color, matiere, and collage, that soon became the dominant perspective from which John would create his art. In 1946, John and his new wife, fellow artist and Black Mountain student, Elaine Schmidt moved to Paris where they studied art at the Academie de la Grande Chaumiere. John worked as Art Director for Philip Morris for over 25 years, where he was instrumental in acquiring an outstanding corporate art collection. John's own work has been in the collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the National Gallery of Art, the Detroit, Houston and North Carolina Museums of Art, the Asheville Art Museum, and in numerous private collections and galleries in the US and abroad. Throughout his life, John worked pro bono for the civil rights and anti-war movements; taught neighborhood children painting and stained glass; and served as an inspiration to countless artists. John also studied poetry and was published in the New York Quarterly and Yankee Magazine. In an exhibition catalogue, he wrote: "I offer here a portrait of my life - not as a finished piece, but rather as a work in progress-- not so much about what I have produced as it is about the journey itself. I am continually struck by my indebtedness to friends and family who have helped at every juncture along the way. Art, in the end, is a reflection of existence: yearning, suffering, epiphany and love." John is survived by his son, Michael, of Peekskill, NY, and his daughter, Catherine, and granddaughter, Carina, of Milford, Connecticut. A memorial service will be held on April 18th in Scarborough, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to the Block Island Nature Conservancy. The family is in the process of establishing the John Urbain Memorial Scholarship to support the study of art for students at the Block Island School. For details, contact Catherine Urbain at: 203-260-1449.

Developed a thousand years ago as warriors' pole-arms, naginata (above) later passed to samurai wives for defense. Eventually, ''a fine naginata became a requisite item in the dowry of a samurai bride,'' said Ray Sosnowski, a Maryland engineer, Zen lay priest and instructor of weapons arts. In 1912, naginata was introduced in Japanese high schools, where it remains a staple of girls' physical education. Though Japanese men disdain it, perhaps half the roughly 200 United States naginata practitioners are male, Mr. Sosnowski estimated. Today's naginata are slender and lightweight, up to seven and a half feet long, with curved tips of wood or bamboo. Their use -- to batter, stab or hook an opponent -- makes sense for women, as it relies on ''the centripetal force of rotating hips, of swinging arms, and of the long, rotating weapon'' rather than upper-body strength, Mr. Sosnowski explained.

An article on Wednesday about the flow of guns from the United States to Mexico misidentified, in some editions, the professional affiliation of Tom Diaz, who said that the system to regulate gun sales facilitates gun trafficking. He is a researcher with the Violence Policy Center, not the Violence Project.

8:30 P.M. (TV5Monde) THE TRILOGY The director Lucas Belvaux used three editors (each of whom won a César Award) to create three films -- a romantic comedy, a thriller and a melodrama -- all shot at the same time in southwestern France using the same cast. In this first installment, ''The Amazing Couple'' (2002), a man finds out that he has to undergo minor surgery but decides not to tell his wife so as not to worry her. She knows he's keeping a secret and suspects he's cheating, so she asks her best friend's husband, a police inspector, to track him. The film ''is, for the most part, pretty funny,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''It helps enormously that the protagonist, a fussy, hypochondriacal lawyer named Alain, is played by François Morel, whose rubbery, hangdog face and slumping posture take some pressure off Mr. Belvaux, who as a farceur is more competent than dazzling.'' Ornella Muti and Gilbert Melki, above, also star. Part 2, ''On the Run,'' will be shown on April 23; Part 3, ''After the Life'' on April 30. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYBen Affleck promotes his new film, ''State of Play,'' before moving on to ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' at 9 on ABC.

No photo montage of China is complete without a sunrise shot of elderly people tracing the deliberate gestures of tai chi in a public park. It would be easy to imagine tai chi's sister art, xing yi (pronounced shing-ee), as similarly pacific, but it's not. More than 1,000 years ago in northern China's hinterlands, there were no police, so xing yi (left) emerged for self-defense, said Mr. Henning, the martial arts historian.

BOREK--Gene. The members of Metropolis Country Club in White Plains, NY, mourn the passing of a consummate gentleman, their long time Head Golf Professional and friend, Gene Borek, who died on April 15, 2009 at his home in Hartsdale after a more than seven year battle with cancer. Mr. Borek, who was 72, joined Metropolis as Head Golf Professional in 1980 and remained in that position for 25 years. Following his retirement, Gene became an honorary member of Metropolis and continued to be at the Club on a regular basis maintaining the many friendships and student-teacher relationships he had established over the years. Gene Borek is widely regarded as one of the best club pro players of the modern era. He gathered national attention when he shot a course-record 65 in the 1973 U.S. Open at Oakmont, a record that was broken two days later by the Championship winner, Johnny Miller. Additional national honors included Mr. Borek winning the PGA National Stroke Play championship twice and the PGA National Match Play Championship once. He competed in 11 PGA Championships and 10 US Opens, for a total of 21 PGA Tour majors. On the local level Mr. Borek had a truly successful career. He won the Met PGA Championship three times, was twice Met Player of the Year, won three Long Island PGA Championships, two Long Island Open titles and two Westchester PGA titles. Gene is a member of four Halls of Fame (Metropolitan PGA, Westchester Sports, Yonkers and Metropolis). In addition to being a great player, Mr. Borek was a great teacher, mentor and all-around professional. His list of non-playing honors and awards is legendary and includes being named Met PGA Professional of the year in 1972, Met PGA Teacher of the Year in 1996, and the 2003 recipient of the Met PGA Bill Strausbaugh Award for Club Relations and Mentoring, to name a few. While Mr. Borek was a gifted player and Teaching Professional, he was also a dignified and gentle man and a good friend to many of the club's members. A private person himself, he never failed to show genuine interest in the personal lives of his friends at Metropolis. Numerous Metropolis members have said that the best decision made in the Club's long history was inviting Gene Borek to join the Metropolis family. Mr. Borek is survived by his daughter, Coleen, sons Robert and Wesley and by his wife, Joan.

DeGEORGE--Lawrence J.,88, of Jupiter, Florida died Monday, April 13, 2009 of complications arising from congestive heart failure. Born in New York City, NY, Mr. DeGeorge served in the Navy during World War II. He began his business career in New York City during the early growth of cable television and rose to be CEO of Times Wire and Cable, a major supplier of cable to that industry. His career took him to Insilco Corporation in Meriden, Connecticut until he retired in 1980 Vice Chairman. From 1980 until 1997 Mr. DeGeorge successfully managed his own venture capital company which purchased troubled companies and restructured them to profitability. Since 1997 he lived in Jupiter, Florida and invested in commercial real estate. Over the past 30 years he received awards in recognition by his peers for his philanthropic work thru his charitable trust with children's charities. He was an avid boater and lifelong "ham" radio operator cultivating long-term friendships with other "ham" advocates many of which he never met in person... Survivors include his wife, Florence A., two sons Lawrence F. and Peter R., all of Palm Beach County, Florida; three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A funeral mass will be held at 10:00am Saturday at St. Patrick's Catholic Church, Prosperity Road, Palm Beach Gardens, Florida with Father Brian Flannigan saying mass. Mr. DeGeorge will be cremated. The family will receive friends after the service time at the church. A private memorial service will held later on Saturday.The family requests that expressions of sympathy take the form of contributions to: The Boys & Girls Clubs of Palm Beach County, Inc. 800 Northpoint Parkway - Suite 204, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407-1946 or Camp Boggy Creek, 30500 Brantley Branch Road, Eustis, Florida 32736. Services entrusted to: Aycock Funeral Home, 1112 Military Trail, Jupiter, Florida 33458.

LIESEM--Hermann dide April 14, 2009 in Medina, Ohio at the age of 94. He was born in Hamburg, Germany, immigrated to the US at the age of five and previously lived in Rego Park, New York, where he was a house painting contractor. During WWII, he was a Ninth Army Air Force engine mechanic, serving in England and France. He was an active member of the Masons and the Painting and Decorating Corporation of America, receiving lifetime achievement awards from both. He had a passion for working with his hands, in stone, in wood and in the garden. He spent many happy days at his cabin in Upstate New York. His wife of 62 years, Gloria, preceded him in death last July. He is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Paul and Linda Liesem, graddaughters and spouses Beth and Marty Harrington, Robin and Rob Byrne, Laura Liesem and two great-grandsons, Tyler and Jacob Harrington. Services will be held at Fairlawn Lutheran Church, 3415 West Market Street, Fairlawn on Friday at 11 am. Visitation will be on Thursday from 5-7 pm at Waite & Son Funeral Home, 765 North Court Street, Medina. Donations in his name can be made to Lutheran World Relief, 700 Light Street, Baltimore, Maryland 21230 or www.lwr@lwr.org

With Anne Hathaway already set to play Viola, the Public Theater announced additional casting on Wednesday for its Shakespeare in the Park production of ''Twelfth Night,'' scheduled to run June 10 to July 12 at the open-air Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Audra McDonald (a four-time Tony Award-winner whose credits include ''A Raisin in the Sun'' and ''Ragtime'') will play Olivia. Raúl Esparza (''Speed-the-Plow,'' ''Company'') will play Orsino. Also joining the cast are Michael Cumpsty as Malvolio, Jay O. Sanders (Sir Toby Belch), David Pittu (Feste) and Hamish Linklater (Sir Andrew Aguecheek). Daniel Sullivan is directing.

When news like the rampaging Conficker virus hits, Mac users often feel a sense of comfort, if not superiority, knowing it does not affect them. The Yankees went to great lengths to incorporate many features of their old stadium (bottom) into their new one. They replicated the original frieze and kept the field dimensions just about the same. And if the sun is out during Thursday's opener, perceptive fans and players will notice another striking similarity: the imposing stadium shadows that became part of countless famous games. This satellite image, taken in the late morning on Feb. 21, shows that the Yankees' quest to orient the new stadium in the same way as the old one was a success. Now all the Yankees need to do is extend those shadows into October.

A suicide bomber detonated a car laden with explosives at a police checkpoint on Wednesday, killing 16 people, in a village not far from Swat, the Taliban stronghold where the government agreed to Islamic law this week, the police and residents of the area said. Ten of the dead were police officials, including a deputy police chief and another officer who a week ago shot and killed a would-be suicide bomber who tried to strike a political rally, news reports and a police official said.

FULD--Stella Rapaport, nee Fread, award-winning illustrator and children's book author, passed away at her home in West Palm Beach, Florida. She was 98. Stella was born August 7, 1910, in New York City to Mollie and Abraham Fread. With her sister Edith Harris (1907-1999) and brother Bernard Fread (1904-1992), she shared many wonderful memories growing up which became the basis for some of her books. She attended Hunter College and The Art Students League. Among her best known artistic endeavors were her watercolor and oil paintings, often whimsical, combining nature scenes from her global travels with her great knowledge of birds and animals. Highlights of the books she wrote and illustrated include "A Whittle Too Much," winner of the Catholic Book Club Award and one of The New York Times 100 Best Books for 1955. "Reindeer Rescue," won the William Allen White Children's Book Award for 1957-1958. Her next book, "The Bear Ship of Many Lives," received the Boys Life Dodd Mead Writing Award in 1962. To research the true story for this book, Stella traveled above the Arctic Circle. Stella also illustrated and authored "Binkley's Bottleneck" and "Philip and the Ninety-Nine Frogs." In June 1931, she married Irving S. Rapaport, Esq. (1903-1972), a name partner in a law firm. Irving was a devoted husband and father involved in Jewish causes. He was a synagogue vice president. Stella is survived by their loving sons, Myron S. Rapaport (Barbara) and Robert D. Rapaport (Cobey), their beloved grandchildren: Marc Rapaport (Allison), Elisa Rapaport (Michael), Fred Rapaport (Lori), Mason Rapaport (Amy), Peggy Goldblatt (Adam), Jeff Rapaport, Tali Rapaport, and their precious great-grandchildren: Zachary, Emily, Yael, Natan, Jared, Devin, Ilana, Talia and Zefora. In January 1976, Stella married Judge Stanley H. Fuld (1903-2003), Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals. Judge Fuld served as Chairman of the board of The Jewish Theological Seminary. She is survived by his devoted daughter Hermine Nessen. A memorial service will be held on Friday April 17 at 1pm at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, New York. Donations may be sent to: Fread Sanctuary, Temple Beth El, West Palm Beach.

There will be a service of thanksgiving in South Africa on Friday, April 17th. Arrangements are pending for the funeral in Bermuda and a memorial service in New York.

Game 1 was a battle between two stars, the Capitals' Alex Ovechkin and the Rangers' Henrik Lundqvist, exactly as everyone expected. But the outcome was decided by a highlight-reel goal from someone entirely unexpected. Brandon Dubinsky scored the winning goal with 8 minutes 17 seconds to play on a beautiful inside-outside move along the left boards that victimized Washington defenseman Jeff Schultz, leaving him sprawled on the ice as Dubinsky glided past and beat Washington goalie Jose Theodore.

The Brooklyn Philharmonic, running a deficit and facing declining revenues, has canceled its final program this season, on May 9, and all of next season’s subscription concerts, the orchestra said Friday. The orchestra said it would continue its teaching projects and school concerts, which still have funding, mainly from government sources. The orchestra, which is led by Michael Christie, usually presents about four programs a year at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. J. Barclay Collins II, the orchestra’s board chairman, said the philharmonic was in talks with the Brooklyn Academy about paying some of the concert costs for future seasons. Separately, Mr. Collins said a recent lawsuit filed against the orchestra by a composer was “totally without merit.” The composer, Nathan Currier, accused the Brooklyn Philharmonic of truncating his two-hour work during a performance in 2004 to avoid paying overtime to the musicians.

In an effort to avoid layoffs, the Brooklyn Museum said Friday it is planning to implement a one-week unpaid furlough this summer for its entire staff and to reduce the pay of employees who earn more than $60,000 a year. The museum is also offering voluntary buyout packages — a week’s salary for every year worked, up to 26 years — to each of its 281 full-time staff members. “The buyout plan might be able to eliminate or significantly reduce layoffs,” said Arnold L. Lehman, the museum’s director. The museum would not disclose how many employees earn more than $60,000 annually.

Tessa B. Dick, the fifth wife and widow of the science-fiction writer Philip K. Dick, has filed suit against a production company run by two of her husband’s daughters, saying she is owed money for projects adapted from his novels “Ubik” and “A Scanner Darkly,” Variety reported. In Los Angeles Superior Court on Tuesday, Ms. Dick sued Electric Shepherd Prods., the company run by Dick’s daughters Laura Leslie and Isa Dick-Hackett, saying she is entitled to proceeds from those two novels under the terms of her 1976 divorce agreement with the author, who died in 1982. In her suit, Tessa B. Dick seeks money she says she is due as well as compensatory damages; also named in the suit were the Halcyon Company, which has a deal with Electric Shepherd to produce adaptations of Dick’s novels, and Celluloid Dreams, which optioned “Ubik” in 2008. Ms. Leslie is the daughter of Dick’s third wife, Anne Williams Rubinstein; Ms. Dick-Hackett is the daughter of his fourth wife, Nancy Hackett.

A collaboration between the dance group Pilobolus and Steven Banks, a writer for the animated series “SpongeBob SquarePants,” is among the highlights of the Joyce Theater‘s summer season. In a release, the Joyce announced that its summer schedule would begin on June 2 with the New York debut of the Trey McIntyre Project, a Boise, Idaho, troupe whose artistic director, Mr. McIntyre, has created works for American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet. Other events include the 35th anniversary season of Jennifer Muller/The Works, from June 9 through 14; Keigwin + Company’s “Bolero/NYC,” with a 50-person cast, which runs on June 23, 25 and 27; the theatrical comedy duo the Umbilical Brothers, from June 29 through July 11; and Pilobolus, which runs from July 13 through Aug. 8. A full schedule can be found online at joyce.org.

George Wein, the music impresario and longtime producer of the JVC Jazz Festival and the Newport Folk and Jazz Festivals, has announced the initial lineups for two new eponymous festivals that will run this summer in Newport, R.I. In a release, New Festival Productions said that George Wein’s Folk Festival 50 would run from July 31 through Aug. 2, and feature such performers as Pete Seeger, The Decemberists, Arlo Guthrie, Fleet Foxes, Joan Baez, Neko Case and Judy Collins; George Wein’s Jazz Festival 55 would run from Aug. 7 through 9 and include Tony Bennett, Branford Marsalis, Etta James, Esperanza Spalding and the Dave Brubeck Quartet. In 2007 Mr. Wein, 83, sold his company, Festival Productions to Festival Network. Rhode Island authorities said that they canceled Festival Network’s contract to present events at Fort Adams State Park because of late payments.

Brandeis University said on Friday that it would allow its Rose Art Museum to remain open while its fate is being decided. University trustees voted in January to close the museum with the goal of selling artworks to raise money to aid Brandeis’s ailing endowment. After the vote, the university backtracked, saying that no works would be sold in the immediate future and that the building would remain open as an art-study center. The Massachusetts Attorney General’s office is reviewing Brandeis’s plans.In a letter to the university Friday, Marty Wyngaarden Krauss, Brandeis’s provost, said that the museum’s current exhibitions would be extended through May 17 and the Rose would reopen to the public on July 22, displaying works from the permanent collection under the direction of a three-member professional staff. The decision was seen as a minor victory by opponents of the university’s plans, because it means the Rose will continue, for the time being, to remain subject to the laws and ethical codes that govern public museums and that place restrictions on the sale of works.

Carbon dioxide is ruled to be a pollutant, but will that lead to action or litigation?.

It's nearly official. Carbon dioxide, the bubbles in beer, is a pollutant in the context of the Clean Air Act, the Environmental Protection Agency proposed on Friday. The long-lived heat-trapping gas, while benign in a brew pub, is deemed a threat to public health and welfare through its growing impact on climate and, in the long run, sea levels.

Twitter - the microblogging service that lets you post and read fragmentary communications at high speed - is fun, but it's embarrassing. You subscribe to the yawps of a bunch of people; they subscribe to your yawps; and you produce and consume yawps for the rest of your days. The me-me-me clamor brings to mind Emily Dickinson's poem about the disgrace of fame, "I'm Nobody! Who are you?": "How public - like a Frog - / To tell one's name - the livelong June - / To an admiring Bog!"

Though Rome may be the Eternal City, each year she never misses a birthday celebration. According to legend - and the calculations of Lucius Taruntius Firmanus, a Roman astrologer and mathematician who lived in the 1st century B.C. - Romulus founded the city on April 21, 753 B.C. For about 2,000 years, Romans marked their city's birth, known as the Natale di Roma, with raucous popular festivals involving large quantities of eating, drinking, joke playing and other forms of merrymaking.

Rem Koolhaas's Office for Metropolitan Architecture has never shied away from head-turning design. Its concept sales office for 23E22, O.M.A.'s slanted residential tower that appears to step up the sides of One Madison Park, literally asks you to cock your head 90 degrees. The narrow space on Mercer Street holds a room-size reproduction of 23E22 - toppled horizontally on one side to fit. Overturned and hollowed, the building's miniature setbacks serve as steps. Floor-to-ceiling windows have become either long shelves (showcasing O.M.A.'s working models) or translucent light boxes that checker the walls. The flipped facsimile lacks floor slabs, offering the potential buyer a glimpse straight through all 18 stories, into a dazzling nightscape turned outside-in.

Following is the third and final set of answers from Michelle and James Nevius, the authors of "Inside the Apple: A Streetwise History of New York City." This week they will be answering questions about the history of Manhattan from Henry Hudson's arrival in 1609 to the present. If you have ever walked by a building in the borough and wondered about its origins, or whether a historic event really took place where you think it did, or any other little-known fact, they will know the answers. Both in their book and on their guided tours, the authors try to link the history of Manhattan to places that can still be visited today. One of their goals is to focus on the patterns that emerge as a neighborhood or street changes over time.

The Yankees are not the first team to open a new park with the same name as its predecessor. The Cardinals replaced Busch Stadium with Busch Stadium in 2006. The White Sox kept the name Comiskey Park on their new home until U.S. Cellular bought the rights before the 2003 All-Star Game. There are other examples through baseball history, too.

Lamb stew is a quintessential spring dish that can be a real celebration -- or unbearably heavy. The difference has little to do with the lamb and much to do with the vegetables. If the stew has color and lots of flavors, it is lovely, almost light. But the flavorings that make the difference between a tired stew and one that sings come at the end of the cooking time.

I have owned a condominium for four years and have been on the waiting list for a basement storage locker. Some lockers have opened up, but I am told that I am ineligible for one because I am renting my apartment to a tenant. I have asked to see a copy of the house rules, but am being told that a house rule like this one may not be in writing. Instead, it might just be a "spoken rule." Can the managing agent make up new rules as it goes along? What rights do I have in this case?

Quarterback Tim Tebow takes a shotgun snap and fakes an inside handoff to Emmanuel Moody. Tebow then rolls to his right. Just when it seems as if the big quarterback is going to tuck and run, he floats a pass into the middle of the field, where Percy Harvin is completely uncovered on a shallow crossing route. Harvin catches the soft pass, makes a few cuts, and races for a touchdown.

I guess we shouldn't be too surprised that stores are starting to put spring clothes on sale, since nobody's shopping. In the course of preparing for a fashion shoot next week, I've been spending a lot of time in stores with several different stylists. Sort of an extended girls' shopping trip. And each day, somewhere, a new rack of sale merch appears. On Tuesday, we were at the Michael Kors shop on Prince Street, and we noticed a cute mini trench coat-well-made (in China, I believe) and at $200, a much better value and fit than a $400 version at nearby Topshop. We wondered what the original price of the Kors trench was.

Spring is finally in the air and with it, baseball season. For fans wanting to keep it all close by, the Baseball Toolbar and Theme add-on for Firefox converts the browser window into a baseball news portal, complete with a shortcut button to a favorite team's Web site, streaming headlines in the toolbar and video clips in the side panel. The Baseball Toolbar and Theme is available here and can always be uninstalled from the Add-ons box in the Firefox Tools menu when the season is over.

Watching the first practice sessions of the Chinese Grand Prix this morning I began having doubts about what I have been thinking for weeks and wrote in my own story this morning: That despite the final decision by the FIA that the double diffusers are legal, the top teams of the past will have the time to catch up to the Brawns, Toyotas and Williams cars with those diffusers. For as I watched the sessions, it was clear that these teams are still the best so far this year.

The spring design issue of T Magazine will put you ahead of the curve -- in more ways than one. Our cover star is Greg Lynn, champion of "blob" architecture, whose first house was photographed by Raymond Meier. We also take a tour of an artful Manhattan town house that looks as contemporary now as it did the day the owner -- who also designed it -- first moved in back in 1973. William Shaw profiles Richard Woods, whose faux wood facades have the art world floored. Ambra Medda, the founder of Design Miami Basel, shows why she's the fairest of them all; Frank Gehry takes us out on his sailboat, Foggy; and Alice Rawsthorn explains how a quirky, seaweed-like room divider became a runaway design hit. And there's a lot more where that came from. Dive in!

The Jets, upset about being scheduled for home games on consecutive Sundays in direct conflict with Jewish holidays, sent N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell a letter Thursday asking that one of the game times be changed. The Jets’ home opener is Week 2 against New England at 1 p.m. on Sept. 20, which falls during Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year. The Jets then play Tennessee at 4:15 p.m. the next Sunday, with Yom Kippur, the Jewish day of atonement, beginning at sundown.

The trainer Kiaran McLaughlin said the colt Mafaaz would not run in the Kentucky Derby despite clinching a spot in the field. McLaughlin said the horse’s owner, Sheik Hamdan, had decided to keep Mafaaz at Shadwell Farm in Lexington for a week or two, then move him to New York. Mafaaz moved into McLaughlin’s barn this week after finishing eighth in the Blue Grass Stakes on Saturday. He was previously trained by John Gosden. He had clinched a Derby berth by winning the Kentucky Derby Challenge at Kempton Park.

KORNREICH--Matthew. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Matthew Kornreich and extends sincere sympathy to his children and other mem- bers of his family. Ira Eichner, President Milton Fine, Secretary

It is a story whose outlines are already well-known. Last week, the 20-member crew of an American cargo ship foiled a pirate hijacking attempt hundreds of miles off the coast of Somalia. Their captain, in the process, became a hostage in a lifeboat, floating at sea for four days until Navy sharpshooters killed his pirate captors. But just how the unarmed crew regained control of their ship -- and how the captain ended up in an enclosed orange lifeboat -- have remained murky. On Thursday, the 19 crew members sketched a fuller picture of what took place. No doubt the captain, Richard Phillips, who left Mombasa, Kenya, and is expected back in the United States on Friday, will be able to fill in many of the details.

Should the Most Valuable Player award go to the N.B.A.'s leading scorer and the only player in league history to have recorded at least 2,000 points, 500 assists, 150 steals and 100 blocks in a season? China just reported that it has had the lowest quarterly increase in its economy since 1992. That's not good news -- but it's not as bad as it sounds. Certainly, the 6.1 percent rise still shames the rest of the world -- Singapore's economy has just shrunk twice as fast as China's grew. More important, there are signs that Premier Wen Jiabao's $585 billion stimulus is taking effect. The problem now isn't the efficacy of the medicine but the severity of the side effects. On their own, gross domestic product figures don't mean much. They reflect what was, not what will be, and in China their reliability is always questionable.

WHILE on a bike ride in the hills behind Stanford University, I was helping a fellow cyclist fix a flat tire when a rental car full of lost Italian tourists pulled over. Clutching a map in his hands, the driver beseeched us, ''Can you tell us where we can go to see Silicon Valley?'' The cyclist, Tony Fadell, an Apple engineer who led the iPod and iPhone design teams, and I grinned at each other, but we had to sympathize with the driver's plight. Perhaps more than any region, Silicon Valley has transformed the world in the last half century. Yet exploring -- or even finding -- this patchwork quilt of high-tech research and development centers, factories and California suburbia can be baffling. That's because the valley is as much a state of mind as it is a physical place.

When George Steinbrenner was introduced before the first game at the new Yankee Stadium, he received a nice ovation. Steinbrenner, who was sitting in an owner's suite with his wife, Joan, was emotional after receiving the applause. His shoulders shook and he started to cry. Steinbrenner became famous as the blustery owner of the Yankees, but he is mostly silent now. Before the game, Derek Jeter called him ''the greatest owner'' in sports history.

In the main, Picasso only got better. That's the take-away from the staggering exhibition of Picasso's late paintings and prints at the Gagosian Gallery. One of the best shows to be seen in New York since the turn of the century, it proves that contrary to decades of received opinion, Picasso didn't skitter irretrievably into an abyss of kitsch, incoherence or irrelevance after this or that high-water mark. For some, his decline began as early as 1914, when he and Braque went their separate ways after inventing Cubism. Others deferred until the arrival of the bourgeois Olga Khokhlova in 1917, or the pliant Marie-Thérèse Walter in 1927, or the end of World War II. But the mid-1950s have been generally accepted as the point of no return.

REYCRAFT--Pamela C.,81, of Manhattan died on April 8, 2009 surrounded by her family. Born in Ireland and raised in New Haven, Pamela spent her last 30 years in Pelham Manor, NY, Surfside, FL, and Manhattan where she pursued many interests including her greatest passion: bringing together her family. She will be missed dearly by all she touched, including her seven children: George, Tom, Thaddeus, Anna, Nancy, Pamela and Sheilah; and her 13 grandchildren. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st St.) until Saturday, 9:45 am. Funeral Mass St. Thomas More R.C. Church, 10:30 am. Visiting hours Friday 2-4 and 6-8. Donations may be made to Bartow-Pell Landmark Fund or Central Park Conservancy.

His teammates were long gone when Dwyane Wade emerged fully dressed from the Heat training room smelling of wintergreen liniment. Wade, a 6-foot-4 guard, was hurting more than usual on this night last month, though no one would have guessed it by the way he played. He had 27 points in 32 minutes in a victory against Memphis, including a dunk over the Grizzlies' 7-foot center Darko Milicic. After a rubdown came a rundown of his performance with reporters, which Wade conducted while wearing a conspicuous symbol of his pain.

LUCCHESI--Rose, passed away early Thursday morning, April 16, 2009, of natural causes. She was born in New York City on August 1, 1913 where she lived her entire life. She graced our presence for 95 years. Rose was the daughter of the late Joseph and Domenica Barossi Ianelli. Rose was married to the late Alibrando Lucchesi for sixty-four years. Her brother, Aldo Ianelli and her sister Pierina Rodnicki predeceased her. Rose worked in the garment district for over 50 years and retired as a buyer of children's clothes for Genesco, Inc. After retirement, she worked with her husband at an antique business known as Eugene Lucchesi, Inc. located at 859 Lexington Avenue in New York City. She was a parishioner of Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church. She is survived by her nephews, nieces, great-nieces and great-nephews. Family will receive Friday 2-4 pm and 7-9pm from Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 10am, Our Lady of Peace RC Church. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting donations be made to: Pax Christi Hospice, St. Vincent Catholic Medical Center Foundation, 130 W. 12th Street, Suite 6J, New York, NY 10011. The American Cancer Society, PO Box 22718, Oklahoma City, OK 73123-1718.

WE'VE never really gotten over Lincoln's assassination, 144 years ago this week. The news came quickly, but the full import of the deed -- a sordid attack upon democracy at a most vulnerable moment in our history -- took longer to settle in. Early in the morning on April 15, the first reports flashed with lightning speed along telegraph lines and railroad tracks throughout the newly united states. Twenty years earlier, it would have taken New Yorkers more than a day to know. Now the facts were instantaneous and overwhelming. By 3 a.m. Northern cities had heard of the shooting; by 8 a.m. they knew the result.

WHO Susan Alfieri, 72, an artist and retired teacher, and her husband, Donal, 75, a retired port director of Panama City Beach. WHAT 3-bedroom house WHERE Inlet Beach, Fla. Susan: When Donal was working in Baton Rouge, we used to come to this area to vacation. In the 1970s, we were able to buy this piece of property, which is Gulf-front on the dunes. It was just a lot. There was no house here. But that was exciting for me because I wanted to design the house myself. I pictured it snuggled into the dunes, protected from the water. It would sit on the land diagonally, its front pointing toward the water like a ship's prow. And it would be a perfect square.

PART Deadwood and part Reno, the Rocky Mountain town of Black Hawk, Colo., is a surreal combination of Old West authenticity and the neon pizazz of casino gambling. Just 40 miles from Denver -- and with little more than 100 full-time residents -- Black Hawk unfolds along a ravine dotted with tumbledown mines and colorful gingerbread-style homes. Its dusty main drag, often crammed with tour buses, passes through Victorian-era general stores and hotels refashioned into casinos with names like Bullwhackers and Bull Durham.

The house has juniper tongue-in-groove ceilings and walls throughout, and there is a stone-surround gas fireplace in the living area. There are four bathrooms. Broker: Barry Breit, ReMax Broker in Charge, (252) 202-1043; www.obxbrokers.com.

When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton traveled to Mexico last month, she caused a stir by acknowledging the obvious, that the United States bears a share of responsibility for the drug wars ravaging its southern neighbor. ''Our insatiable demand for illegal drugs,'' she said, ''fuels the drug trade.'' The remarks were interpreted as a departure from the previous administration, another sign of a new day in foreign policy under Mr. Obama. Forgotten in the discussion was the fact that President George W. Bush said virtually the same thing in Mexico two years ago. ''The United States has a responsibility in the fight against drugs,'' he said, because ''when there is demand, there is supply.''

There probably is not a person in this little mountain town who has mentally deleted the images of 2007, when angry orange flames, followed by giant plumes of smoke, licked at the trees and roared across the freeway near here, killing neighbors in communities close by and engulfing hundreds of homes. Eager to avoid a repeat of that horrific year, and the ensuing lawsuits, officials of San Diego County's chief power utility have hatched a disputed plan to deal with one potential fire source: downed power lines. If electrical wires can cause fires when winds and temperatures are high, the officials say, then electricity itself will have to go.

SEAMAN--Carl, 73, on April 11, 2009. Beloved husband of Linda, father of Dana and Jordan, father-in-law of Hal and Rebecca, Papa of grandsons Hank, Slade, Ben, and granddaughter Jessie. Graduated Wharton in 1957: Joined older brother Morton in Seaman's Furniture and grew to second largest retail furniture chain in US before sold in 1987. Carl went on to develop ETI Financial Corp., and Seminole Casualty Insurance Co. in Florida. He always loved the people who worked for and with him. A devout gold investor since 1979, he wanted you to invest in gold (or oil and gas) for your own good. A sports fan from birth-to-death he enthralled in the Brooklyn Dodgers as a boy, and was often seen inside Ebbets Field before pre-game practice had begun. Duke Snider was the greatest. The Dodgers' move? Unforgivable! But not Mr. O'Malley's fault (see Robert Moses). Later, devotee of the football Giants, Knicks, Islanders, Mets, and Tar Heels, he could be seen dressing like Walt Frazier and working quietly at home with the game on the radio and a cigar in his mouth. He loved lifting weights. Also propped up candy industry in good times and bad, he once considered malted milk balls a healthy snack (milk), and did not believe it necessary to eat at any restaurant fancier than Wendy's (maybe a diner). Really, why do you have to be so "fancy"? He did love his cats. Linus was a mensch; Butch and Sunny great, too. A philanthropist as well, Carl Seaman and family were instrumental in the development of carrier testing for familial dysautonomia, and virtually eliminating new cases of this terrible (primarily Jewish) disease. He supported many other important causes as well through his Julius Ada Foundation, including North Shore Child and Family Guidance, in Roslyn, Long Island. Success did not spoil Carl Seaman, and he would never be a member of any club that would have someone like him as a member. Now, at the great Ebbets Field in the sky, he is ordering a "smaller piece" of cake for each of his many childhood heroes that are already there. Yes, Clem Labine would have struck out Bobby Thompson, and if you think that some of today's games are not "fixed", you don't watch sports. "This was a man." Memorial Service to be announced. Donations to North Shore Child and Family Guidance, please.

The first Iraq war insurgent to be prosecuted in an American court was sentenced Thursday to 25 years in prison by a judge worried that the defendant would not serve nearly that much time. After video recordings of his plots were played in court, Wesam al-Delaema, 36, an Iraqi-born Dutch citizen, was sentenced by Judge Paul L. Friedman in United States District Court in Washington for conspiring to kill Americans in Iraq. But because the sentence will be served in the Netherlands, Mr. Delaema may spend much less than a quarter-century behind bars. Under an agreement between the United States and the Netherlands, Mr. Delaema was extradited to the United States two years ago on condition that he be tried in a civilian court and that he be returned to the Netherlands to serve his sentence. ''I didn't agree to that,'' Judge Friedman said Wednesday. ''The executive branch did.'' Mr. Delaema pleaded guilty in federal court in February to conspiracy to murder American citizens outside the United States, one of six counts in an indictment returned in September 2005.

BEGINNING WITH BERRA The Yankees announced Wednesday that Yogi Berra would throw the ceremonial first pitch at the opener of their new ballpark. But less than two hours before the start of the game, Berra said he did not even know about it. ''I've done it before,'' said Berra, who has done it seven times at the home opener, two shy of Joe DiMaggio's club record. ''I hope I can get it there. Let's see what happens.''

Britain and France criticized the Tamil Tiger rebels on Thursday, saying they were preventing civilians from leaving the small conflict zone in the northeast of Sri Lanka. ''We deplore their determination to use civilians as a human shield,'' the British foreign secretary, David Miliband, and his French counterpart, Bernard Kouchner, said in a joint statement. Sri Lanka imposed a two-day cease-fire Monday for the Sri Lankan New Year. But Britain and France said they were ''deeply concerned that there was no large-scale movement of civilians away from the conflict area to safety.'' Pressure is also increasing on the government to stop shelling in the conflict zone.

Fifty-five years ago, Martin and Matthew Bucksbaum built one of the nation's first shopping centers, in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Soon they built another, and another, and another -- transforming their family company, now known as General Growth Properties, into a colossus of the American mall. But early Thursday morning, after months of increasingly dire warnings, this giant on the retail landscape toppled. General Growth, whose malls include Ala Moana Center in Honolulu, Water Tower Place in Chicago and the Westlake Center in Seattle, filed for bankruptcy.

The Justice Department on Thursday made public detailed memos describing brutal interrogation techniques used by the Central Intelligence Agency, as President Obama sought to reassure the agency that the C.I.A. operatives involved would not be prosecuted. In dozens of pages of dispassionate legal prose, the methods approved by the Bush administration for extracting information from senior operatives of Al Qaeda are spelled out in careful detail -- like keeping detainees awake for up to 11 straight days, placing them in a dark, cramped box or putting insects into the box to exploit their fears.

Deborah Digges, a renowned poet and memoirist whose work often sprang from private adversity, died on April 10 near Amherst, Mass., apparently in a suicide. She was 59 and lived in Amherst. Ms. Digges apparently jumped from an upper level of the Warren P. McGuirk Alumni Stadium, on the campus of the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, a university spokesman said on Tuesday. She was found on the ground outside the stadium and taken to Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass., where she was pronounced dead.

The Coachella Valley Music & Arts Festival began in 1999, and it built its reputation with smart, cutting-edge rock taste, booking Bjork, Radiohead, Nine Inch Nails and the reunions of the Pixies and the Stooges. But its most daring lineups have come in the last couple of years, as it has looked beyond fashionable alt-rock circles to bring in mainstream, old-line stars like Prince and Roger Waters of Pink Floyd. And on Friday, the opening night of its 10th year, Coachella got about as close to rock orthodoxy as possible with a headlining performance by Paul McCartney. At 66, he is old enough to be the grandfather of most members of the festival’s target demographic.

WASHINGTON--The Capitals are a successful, easygoing organization on and off the ice. But what will become of them if they can't recover from the 0-games-to-2 hole they find themselves in against the Rangers in this opening round? Will they still be the relaxed crew they have been until now, and will their soft-spoken coach with the Dutch-uncle demeanor have to suddenly force himself to start hollering?
Henrik Lundqvist made 35 saves in the Rangers' 1-0 victory in Game 2 - his third career playoff shutout - but he gave plenty of credit to his teammates.

My Sunday column is about my visit to Dominican Republic to visit Yuneiris, a child I have sponsored for five years now through Plan USA. I was initially reluctant to write the column because I didn't want to suggest that this is THE WAY to help others -- there are thousands of ways, and thousands of organizations, and this is just indicative of the many easy ways to do so.

The Yankees get a huge break in the schedule Thursday with a scheduled day off before a three-game series at Fenway Park. They could very easily skip Chien-Ming Wang the next time through the rotation and keep everyone on regular rest. That would line up A.J. Burnett, Andy Pettitte and C.C. Sabathia for the Red Sox.

One of the outrages that I periodically fulminate against is maternal mortality: It's a disgrace that half a million women die annually in childbirth, the same number that were dying a quarter-century ago. Today at the Unite for Sight conference at Yale, I met a doctor who has started an NGO that takes an interesting approach to address the problem. Laura Stachel realized that women were dying on the operating table in Africa in part because lights would go out. Or a woman would show up urgently needing surgery, and no doctor could be found.

When a fellow journalist somewhere is killed or kidnapped or imprisoned, we all stagger a little bit under the blow. Today Roxana Saberi, an Iranian-American from North Dakota working as a journalist in Iran, was sentenced to eight years in prison by the Iranian government. My heart aches for her and her family.

The fans at Yankee Stadium today can say they saw history: According to the Yankees, the 14 runs scored by Cleveland in the top of the second are the most the Yankees have ever allowed in an inning. The old Yankee Stadium hosted baseball for 84 seasons, and the most runs the Yankees ever allowed in an inning there was 13, back on June 17, 1925 against Detroit.

Tyler Kepner of The Times crawled out on a limb this month when he picked the Royals to win the A.L. Central. That limb may be sturdier than others thought. Kyle Davies has made two strong starts this season, and he finished 2008 by going 4-1 with a 2.27 earned run average in September. With Davies following Gil Meche and Zack Greinke, the Royals could match three starters with virtually anyone.

Once close friends and training partners, Gary Sheffield and Barry Bonds are now linked by less ignominious circumstances. That night in San Francisco, in 2001, Sheffield was playing left field for the Dodgers and Livan Hernandez, who started for the Mets on Friday, was in the Giants' dugout.

In the cluster of cubicles that comprise the Automobiles department of The Times, I'm the Camaro cheerleader. I've earned the right: I own a '67 SS350, a restored matching-numbers coupe that has been in my family for 30 years.

In the cluster of cubicles that make up the Automobiles department of The Times, I'm the Camaro cheerleader. Oakland holds the seventh pick, a nice improvement from its fourth overall pick in 2008 and the first selection in 2007. Following the logical progression, you can start penciling in Oakland for the 10th pick in 2010. (editor's note: Logical and Al Davis haven't gone together lately). So who will Davis and the Raiders take next weekend? Will it be the sub-4.3 skill player who wowed them at the combine? Or the troubled lineman who fits the old-school Raider outlaw image? How about a better question: Will the Raiders finally be competitive again?

Someone asked me the other day why they had seen so many artichoke recipes and blog posts lately, far more words than any other spring ingredient receives. Delicious by default and mysterious by design, with layers of leaves forming a shield around the heart, artichokes do have a certain status to them. Or maybe it's just mystique: what you eat at a restaurant, unless it's a whole steamed artichoke, generally bears no resemblance to the awkward, rough, spiny blossom you pick up the market.

Sebastian Vettel's second career pole position, scored during qualifying for the Chinese Grand Prix outside Shanghai today, was an even more impressive show than was his first pole at the Italian Grand Prix in Monza last September. The young German driver waited until the final minutes of the second qualifying round before going onto the track and setting the fastest time of that session on a single flying lap. He then did exactly the same thing in the third qualifying session - he waited until the very last minute, took to the track and did a single flying lap (excluding the out lap, of course) and took the pole position.

As the remembrances of Mark Fidrych poured in after his death last week, one game in particular seemed to stand out for fans. On June 28, 1976, Fidrych pitched a complete-game victory over the Yankees in less than two hours. He talked to the ball, got down on his knees to manicure the mound, congratulated his teammates and took a postgame curtain call as the cheers rained down at Tiger Stadium.It's no surprise that game is so well remembered. It was shown on ABC's "Monday Night Baseball," which at the time was one of only a few nationally televised games that fans could watch. For Fidrych, the timing was perfect.Although he had a 7-1 record going into the game, even Warner Wolf, who called the game for ABC, was relatively unfamiliar with Fidrych, a 21-year-old rookie. His broadcast partner, Bob Uecker, had seen Fidrych pitch an 11-inning complete game against the Milwaukee Brewers earlier in the season and told Wolf that he was in for a treat."Uecker told me: 'Warner, you got to see this kid. He's incredible,' " Wolf said in a telephone interview last week. "No one knew what he was talking about. Most of the country hadn't even seen Fidrych yet."
