KURMAN--Sandra, on April 14, 2009, in Shanghai, China. Loving and devoted daughter of Beverly and the late Martin Kahn. Mother of Stephanie and Serena. Mother-in-law of Greg Clement. Grandmother of Samantha, Mia and Jessica. Sister of Andrew and sister-in-law of Peggy Kahn. Aunt of Howard, Michael and Emily Kahn. An avid reader, member of the Mystery Writers Association, member of the Dorothy L. Group and Judge of the Nero Wolfe Awards. Accomplished mentor and executive at Kahn Lucas. A great friend who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Sunday April 19, 1:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

BOSCARELLI--Patricia Cryan, 87, died peacefully on Easter Sunday in Vero Beach, FL, where she had recently moved from New York City. Pat was born and raised in the Bronx, New York. Soon after graduation from Hunter College, Pat married Ignazio Frank Boscarelli (1920-1995) on October 2, 1943, in Our Lady's Chapel in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Pat is survived by her daughter Eileen, son Thomas and wife Robin, daughter Maureen and husband Peter, and her devoted grandchildren, Paul and wife Leanne, Carolyn, Kate and Nicholas. Throughout her life, Pat was a dedicated volunteer and fundraiser for innumerable New York City institutions ranging from the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, to Mary Manning Walsh Home, to the Catholic Big Sisters. Her love of life was infectious and she shared warm friendships with princesses and porters alike. A daily communicant, she was always ready for a game of bridge or a theatre outing, as long as she could attend Mass on the way. A celebration of Pat's life will be held in New York City at a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, a gift in Pat's memory can be sent to: Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10022, Attention: Rachel Russell.
HOLLENDER--Selma. Today is 15 years. Our love is forever. Alex , Jane, Beth, Herb, Jeanette, and Sussal family.

Grace will always be remembered for her wisdom, countless acts of kindness, and love of family and friends. Funeral service to be held at 12:15pm, Young Israel of Woodmere, 859 Peninsula Blvd., Woodmere, NY.

ROSENZWEIG--Irving, 88, of Great Neck, NY, passed away on Friday April 17 having lived a full and joyous life. Born in New York City, NY, he was a decorated World War II veteran and esteemed tax attorney in the City for over 50 years. He left behind his beloved wife, Bobbie Rosenzweig, his sons Paul Rosenzweig and James Rosenzweig, grandchildren, Jordana, Olivia and Dustin Rosenzweig, and many step grandchildren, step-great grandchildren, nieces and nephews, all of whom will miss him dearly. He will be remembered as a learned, loving, wise, warm-hearted man of great intellectual curiosity. The funeral will be held at 1pm on Sunday April 19 at the Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in Irving's memory to the Schneider Children's Hospital, part of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, or a charity of your choice.

Many of Con Edison's challenges are well known -- blackouts and steam pipe explosions included -- but a lesser-known problem has proved no less nagging: how to protect equipment from the thousands of monk parakeets that nest in the utility poles of Queens and Brooklyn. These birds -- also called monk parrots or Quaker parrots -- are attracted to the heat given off by the transformers and other equipment high up on the utility poles. Their nests often wreck the electrical equipment by engulfing the electrical devices, blocking ventilation.

It has become a recurring theme of Hillary Rodham Clinton's early travels as the chief diplomat of the United States: she says that American policy on a given issue has failed, and her foreign listeners fall all over themselves in gratitude. On Friday, Mrs. Clinton said here that the uncompromising policy of the Bush administration toward Cuba had not worked. That, she said, is why President Obamadecided earlier this week to lift restrictions on travel and financial transfers for United States residents with relatives in Cuba.

TREAT--Doris L.,(nee Gerding), of Rutherford, New Jersey passed away peacefully Thursday, April 16, 2009 in Hackensack Hospice after suffering a stroke. Born in Hackensack, New Jersey, December 9, 1929, to Heinrich (Henry) and Lillian Gerding, Doris was a graduate of Rutherford High School - Class of 1948 and went on to graduate Berkeley Secretarial School. She was retired from the Borough of Rutherford after 30 years of service as the Administrative Secretary to the Chief of Police. She was a member of St. John's Lutheran Church. She was predeceased by her husband of 34 years, Robert G. Treat. She is survived by her son Robert J. Treat, his wife Meg Ann, her daughter June Cheval and her husband Eugene. She is also survived by two grandchildren, Krystle and Kyle Cheval. Friends will be received on Monday April 20, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Collins-Calhoun Funeral Home, 19 Lincoln Ave., Rutherford. Memorial Service will be held on Monday at 8pm. Cremation Private. Memorial Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Rutherford PBA Local 300, PO Box 228, Rutherford, NJ 07070 "Good & Welfare Account".

Dodd of Connecticut whom the senator mainly held to blame -- calling him ''a liar and a forger and a thief'' -- in a case that ultimately led the Senate to censure Mr. Dodd in 1967, died March 15 in Chapel Hill, N.C. Simon Channing Williams, a film producer whose partnership with the director Mike Leigh resulted in a string of quirky, critically praised films, including ''Secrets and Lies'' and last year's ''Happy-Go-Lucky,'' died last Saturday in the county of Cornwall, England. He was 63. The cause was cancer, Mr. Leigh told the BBC.

For many years, cars loaded with skis and snowboards sped past the turnoff to Hot Creek in the eastern Sierra on their way to the Mammoth Mountain Ski Area. Now, some winter visitors are stopping to fly fish at one of California's most fabled trout streams, although not everyone seems pleased. Hot Creek is in a valley framed by the Sierra to the west and the Glass and Inyo Mountains to the east. This is volcano country, formed by a huge eruption 760,000 years ago. Earthquakes still rattle ski condominiums, and geothermal springs provide water to Hot Creek that is mixed with mountain snowmelt from Mammoth Creek. The result is mineral-rich water with stable year-round water temperatures ideal for trout.

AUSTIN--Alice Howe, 91, of Missoula, Montana died quietly at her home on Sunday, March 29. She was born in Windsor, CT on August 6, 1917 to Arthur Howe and Margaret Armstrong Howe. Alice grew up in Windsor, CT, Hanover, NH, and Hampton, VA, where her father was an educator and administrator at Taft School, Dartmouth College and Hampton Institute. Her mother was self-employed in her later years managing the family-owned resort Rockywold-Deephaven Camps on Squam Lake, NH, that became the center of her family's life over the years. It was on a Vassar Outing Club trip to Mt. Moosilauke, NH that Alice met her husband, Briggs M. Austin, who was on a similar climb with Dartmouth's Outing Club. Throughout their life together, they traveled and enjoyed mountain and wilderness areas on foot and by canoe, both overseas and in Missoula where they retired in 1975. In Rochester, NY, Alice taught elementary grades in the inner-city schools and worked for Planned Parenthood, living out her deep commitment to social justice and equality started in the family by her grandfather, General Samuel Chapman Armstrong, who, at the end of the Civil War, founded Hampton Institute, the first college for black students. Through her volunteer efforts in preserving the natural environment, Alice became well known in Missoula and derived great pleasure in serving the community.

With her fearsome nickname, unpredictable style of play and two pairs of custom-fit, rubber-soled shoes, the athlete known as Timebomb thundered onto the court at Mountain View Middle School. But even as the crowd whooped and the loudspeakers shook to the strains of ''Who Let the Dogs Out?'' before a recent game, other details made it clear that Timebomb -- along with her teammates Reckless, Ginger and April Surprise -- was no ordinary athlete. She plays for carrots. She has hairy ears. She is not potty-trained.

Houston, who captured the promise, the harshness and the sheer beauty of California in novels like ''Continental Drift'' and ''Snow Mountain Passage'' and in nonfiction works like ''Farewell to Manzanar,'' about a World War II internment camp for the Japanese, died on Thursday at his home in Santa Cruz, Calif. Sheik Abdullah Humedi Ajeel al-Yawar says there is no hidden reason why he still flies the three-starred flag of the old Iraqi government from the towers and guard posts of his ranch near the Syrian border. It is a practical matter, he explained. The Iraqi government has yet to come up with a permanent new design, so why change the flags until they do?

Greeted by his jubilant family and flag-waving supporters, the ship captain held hostage for five days by Somali pirates returned home on Friday, thanking the military for his rescue and saying he was just doing his job. ''I'm not a hero, the military is,'' the cargo-ship skipper, Richard Phillips, told reporters and a small group of well-wishers who greeted him here at Burlington International Airport. ''I'm just a bit part in this story. I'm a small part. I'm a seaman doing the best he can, like all the other seamen out there.''

Over the years, New York courts have handled almost every kind of villain the world could cough up: mass murderers, mob kingpins, hell-bent terrorists, greedy politicians and Ponzi schemers. But it has been a long time, if ever, that a pirate has gone on trial.

MORIARTY--Donald P.,on April 15, 2009, age 78, from a Hemorrhagic Stroke, Overlook Hospital, Summit, NJ. Investor and General Partner of Twin Oaks Partners, an investment management firm. A wake will he held at Burroughs, Kohl & Dangler funeral home located at 309 Springfield Ave, Summit, NJ on Sunday evening from 6-8pm and on Monday from 2-4pm and 6-8pm. The funeral Mass will be held at St. Teresa of Avila Church in Summit at 11am on Tuesday, April 21. Mr. Moriarty attended St. Peter's Preparatory school in Jersey City where he excelled in athletics earning varsity letters in football, basketball and track. He went on to attend the College of The Holy Cross in Worcester, MA where he received a football scholarship. After graduating from Holy Cross with an AB degree in English, he served in the U.S. Army from 1953 through 1956 attaining the rank of Sergeant, First Class. Following military service, he attended Law School and Business School at New York University. He began his career as a securities analyst at Bankers Trust and went on to become managing partner of William A.M. Burden & Company where he managed investments for the Burden family and the Florence V. Burden Foundation. In 1991, he founded the investment management firm Twin Oaks Partners and served as its general partner until his death. In addition to his business career, Mr. Moriarty devoted himself both to public and private service. In 1970, he joined the Summit Board of Education serving as President in 1975. Continuing his civic involvement, he became a trustee of the Overlook Hospital Foundation and also served as a trustee of the Summit Area YMCA. He was a board member of the Pingry School in Martinsville, New Jersey and Chairman of the Board at his alma mater, St. Peter's Prep. He was a charter member of the St. Peter's Donne Society and in 1999 he was inducted into the school's Legends of Prep. He served on the Board of Trustees at Holy Cross for three decades and provided leadership as its Chairman. As longtime head of Holy Cross's Investment Committee, he took primary responsibility for the financial health of the College. At Holy Cross, he was a member of the College's Cornerstone Society, its Lifetime Benefactor's Circle and a charter member of its President's Council. In 2008, he was awarded an Honorary Degree by the College of the Holy Cross for his many years of leadership, support and devotion. Mr. Moriarty served as a trustee of the Florence V. Burden Foundation and as the Chairman of the Carnegie Council on Ethics and International Affairs where he was an honorary trustee. He was a member of the Smithsonian Institute Investment Policy Committee and he was a director and Investment Committee Chair of The Summit Trust Company. He is survived by his wife, Mary Eileen, his seven children, his twenty-four grandchildren, and his sisters Veronica Fleming and Patricia O'Neil. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Donald Patrick Moriarty '48 Scholarship Fund in care of St. Peter's Preparatory School, 144 Grand St., Jersey City, NJ, 07302.

Still Calling It Shea The Yankees are not the first team to open a new park with the same name as its predecessor. There are other examples through baseball history, too. Most recently, the Cardinals replaced Busch Stadium with Busch Stadium in 2006. The White Sox kept the name Comiskey Park on their new home until U.S. Cellular bought the naming rights before the 2003 All-Star Game.

The Yankees' announced attendance Friday was 45,101, or 93.4 percent of the sold-out crowd for the Yankee Stadium opener Thursday. Considering the usual drop-off for early-season games, the Yankees were encouraged. ''We're actually very pleased, based on the history of reduced attendance for the second game of the year,'' the Yankees' president, Randy Levine, said. ''We significantly exceeded even the last year of Yankee Stadium.''

Investigators here are exploring whether a single assailant is responsible for three late-night attacks, all in hotel rooms, on women who had advertised massage services on Craigslist, the classified advertising Web site. The latest incident took place Thursday in Warwick, R.I., where a woman told the police that a man had come to her room at the Holiday Inn Express, held her at gunpoint and demanded money.

After Duncan Birmingham, a comedy screenwriter in Los Angeles, got one too many holiday cards featuring miserable-looking pets wearing fake reindeer antlers, he realized the photos were great material for a blog. Mr. Birmingham started Pets Who Want to Kill Themselves in early January, uploaded the first entry and asked readers to contribute. Within days, visitors were supplying him with snapshots of bulldogs in bunny costumes and cats wearing wigs. The blogosphere noticed -- and so did the publishing world. Within a week, he was contacted by editors and literary agents. By the second month, he said, he had sold a book based on the photos to Three Rivers Press, an imprint at Crown Publishing Group, for ''enough money to buy a Lincoln Town Car'' -- with change left over.

The former Jets coach Eric Mangini has already put his stamp on the Cleveland franchise. Is this a good thing? Gone are many of the veterans from the old regime, replaced by a handful of his former Jets and free agents from around the league. Mangini inherited a 4-12 team with the Jets in 2006, leading them to a 10-win season and a playoff berth. Any chance for a repeat in his first year in Cleveland?

Ever since my first book, "John Skelton's Poetry," was misclassified by Books in Print as an edition, I have tried to come up with titles that announced (sometimes in words that were too clever by half) that the content between the covers was original and even outlandish. I think I got pretty good at it - "There's No Such Thing As Free Speech and It's a Good Thing Too," "Self-Consuming Artifacts," "Professional Correctness," "Is There a Text in This Class?" - but I can't hold a candle to the headline writers of the New York Post. I am not thinking only about the famously attention-grabbing headlines like "Headless Body in Topless Bar" (the title of a compilation put into book form by Post staffers), but of headlines that demand interpretive work of a kind usually associated with modern poetry.

As private sector professionals lose their jobs or suffer cutbacks in pay and benefits, more and more of them are thinking about second careers. Public service is suddenly popular with all generations. Teaching may not pay a lot, but it comes with relatively good benefits and, in public schools, job security in the form of tenure after three years. But this fallback fantasy may be unrealistic, despite reports of a possible teacher shortage in the next several years. Does such a shortfall really exist? What does it take to become a teacher, let alone a good one?

Before I do some economics posts, I think I ought to say something about the torture memos -- namely, that there is now no way to view the people who ruled us these past 8 years as anything but monsters. We had all these rationalizations of torture over the "ticking clock" and all that -- then we learn, for example, that Khalid Sheikh Mohammed was waterboarded 183 times in one month.

Making his first career start at second base today is Fernando Tatis, who was out early this morning working with Jose Reyes on starting the double play. Over and over, Tatis would field the grounder and shovel the ball to Reyes. Relatively speaking, that is an easy play for a second baseman. Much harder is actually turning a double play because the second baseman is blind to the runner steaming toward him, and he must corral the throw, pivot and fire to first in a smooth motion. Tatis has played six positions, but has played only two innings at second base, Aug. 19, 2006, for Baltimore against Toronto.

The Kelowna Rockets used a strong second period to take command, then held off the Vancouver Giants, winning their opening game in the Western Hockey League's Western Conference final, 4-2, on Saturday night. The Rockets outworked the Giants.

My article last week looked at how replacing primitive stoves with cleaner alternatives in the developing world could have big benefits for climate as well as local health and welfare. Because traditional cookstoves burn their fuel (wood and dung) incompletely. they produce a large amount of black carbon - a k a. soot. Soot cuts short the lives of more than 1.5 million people (mainly women and children) each year. Fuel gathering requires hours of sometimes hazardous work, also mainly by women and children.

Sebastian Vettel's victory at the Chinese Grand Prix today was a beautiful way to ensure yet another unexpected race finish, and a clear demonstration that this championship is wide, wide open. He drove a dream race, a dream weekend, in fact, just like when he handed Toro Rosso its maiden victory last September at Monza. Just no doubt about this extraordinary result.

Weird creatures trapped in a sunless, frigid, briny dungeon deep beneath the ice at Blood Falls -- has a nice horror-movie ring to it, doesn't it? And for microbes, they have quite the exotic back story. They've been living in dark pockets of an ancient saltwater lake trapped under the advancing Taylor Glacier in Antarctica between 2 million and 4 million years ago.

Thousands of fans filed into Citizens Bank Park to bid farewell to the legendary broadcaster Harry Kalas, the voice of the Philadelphia Phillies. Kalas, the Hall of Fame announcer known for his signature “Outta here!” home run call, died Monday in Washington. He collapsed in the broadcast booth before a game against the Nationals. He was 73.

Chicago Cubs outfielder Milton Bradley has been suspended for two games and fined an undisclosed amount after he “aggressively argued balls and strikes and made contact with umpire Larry Vanover,” during the Cubs’ 7-4 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals on Thursday, Bob Watson, baseball’s vice president for on-field operations, said in a statement.

Boston Bruins defenseman Matt Hunwick was taken to a hospital to be checked for a spleen injury. Bruins Coach Claude Julien said Hunwick was not feeling well after a team meeting Saturday, ahead of Game 2 of the Eastern Conference playoff series against Montreal. Hunwick was involved in a fight in Game 1 with Montreal’s Mike Komisarek.

Didier Drogba scored with six minutes left to give Chelsea a 2-1 win over Arsenal and a place in the F.A. Cup final on May 30. Chelsea advanced to its second final in three years and will play for the title against the winner of Sunday’s semifinal between Manchester United and Everton. It was Chelsea’s first F.A. Cup win over Arsenal since 1947.

The Louisville men’s coach Rick Pitino said he was the victim of an extortion attempt and had reported it to the F.B.I. The university said in a statement that Pitino reported the threats last month, and that the F.B.I. was investigating. Pitino said, “I am hopeful the media and public will recognize the slanderous nature of this direct and malicious attack.”.

Advice spoiled Square Eddie’s first start in three months, roaring from last place to take the $300,000 Lexington Stakes at Keeneland in Kentucky. Advice, trained by Todd Pletcher and owned by WinStar Farm, overtook Square Eddie with a spectacular move in the stretch, then held off Conservative to win by a length. It was his first win as a 3-year-old in the last major prep race for next month’s Kentucky Derby. Advice covered the one and one-sixteenth mile over Keeneland’s Polytrack in 1 minute 43.33 seconds. Square Eddie finished third.

Rafael Nadal defeated fourth-seeded Andy Murray, 6-2, 7-6 (4), to reach the final of the Monte Carlo Masters in Monaco. Nadal extended his winning streak at Monte Carlo to 26 matches and stayed on course for a fifth straight title. Nadal will play third-seeded Novak Djokovic in Sunday’s final. Djokovic beat Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland, 4-6, 6-1, 6-3. ¶Caroline Wozniacki advanced to the final of the Family Circle Cup in Charleston, S.C., by holding on to beat top-seeded Elena Dementieva, 6-4, 5-7, 7-5. Wozniacki will face 16th-seeded Sabine Lisicki, who defeated sixth-seeded Marion Bartoli, 6-3, 6-1. family (AP).

The free-agent running back Dominic Rhodes agreed to a two-year contact with the Bills, giving Buffalo an established starter while Marshawn Lynch opens next season serving a three-game suspension. Rhodes is an eight-year veteran who played last season with the Indianapolis Colts. In 15 games last season, Rhodes had 538 yards rushing and a team-leading 6 rushing touchdowns.

Brian Gay shot a four-under-par 67 in the third round Saturday to take a three-shot lead over Tim Wilkinson at the Verizon Heritage on Hilton Head Island, S.C. Gay, who has one career PGA Tour victory, has made only one bogey at Harbour Town Golf Links. Wilkinson, a left-hander from New Zealand seeking his first PGA victory, shot a 65. Lee Janzen, who has not won on the tour since 1998, shot a 69 that kept him in third, four shots behind.

Will Power won the pole for the Indy Racing League’s Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach. Power was replaced in one Team Penske car when Hélio Castroneves returned after being acquitted of five of six tax-evasion charges. But he jumped into another and outdueled the former IndyCar Series champion Dario Franchitti. The rookie Raphael Matos was third. Castroneves, who had not driven a racecar since October, qualified eighth for Sunday’s 23-car field.

An article last Sunday about the track star Usain Bolt misstated the number of Olympic gold medals Carl Lewis won during his career. He won nine gold medals and one silver; he was not a 10-time Olympic gold medalist.

An article last Sunday about the veteran golfers who set the pace at the Masters through three rounds referred incorrectly, in some editions, to Kenny Perry, the 48-year-old who was tied for the lead. Greg Norman was 53 when he held the lead of the 2008 British Open at the same point; Perry was not the oldest man with at least a piece of the lead after 54 holes of a major championship.

An article last Sunday about immigration policies that are hindering efforts by technology companies to hire foreign-born engineers misstated the birthplace of Jerry Yang, co-founder of Yahoo. He was born in Taiwan, not China. The article also misstated the Hungarian-born Andrew S. Grove’s role in the start-up of the Intel Corporation. He was brought in by Robert N. Noyce and Gordon E. Moore to operate the company at its founding in 1968; he was not a co-founder.

An article last Sunday about state budget deficits referred incorrectly to Arizona’s cuts for fiscal 2009. In closing a $1.6 billion budget gap, the state is cutting $580 million in general-fund spending, has taken more than $500 million from agencies financed with fees or other sources, and is using $500 million in federal stimulus money; the entire $1.6 billion deficit is not being covered entirely through direct spending cuts.

An article last Sunday about the director Mike Nichols misstated the name of the character who sings the aria “Vesti la Giubba,” which Mr. Nichols mentioned in talking about his appreciation of classical music. The character Canio sings the aria, not Pagliacci. (“Pagliacci” is the name of the opera in which the aria appears.) The article also misidentified the director of the 1977 Broadway production of “Annie.” It was directed by Martin Charnin — not by Mr. Nichols, who produced the show. And the article misstated the timing of the Museum of Modern Art’s retrospective of films by the director Bernardo Bertolucci. The retrospective is scheduled to take place next year; it has not already been presented.

Woodsy / (wood ze) / adj. / Characteristic of wood or of the work of the artist Richard Woods, both of which are enjoying a moment in the contemporary design spotlight, as in, “We considered recladding our cabin in cedar shingles, but in the end we thought Richard Woods’s faux-grain planks felt, well, more woodsy.”.

When this striking, art-filled town house appeared on the cover of a special issue of The New York Times Magazine in September 1973, the art critic Katharine Kuh, writing in Saturday Review magazine, was appalled. Such a cold and sterile interior, she argued, had to echo a similarly bloodless nature in the owners.
Greg Lynn champions “blob” architecture, but his first house is straighter than you’d think.

By the time you read this, Tropicana orange juice’s new image — the sans-serif typeface, the oddly generic packaging, the picture of a glass filled with orange juice — will be a thing of the past, a relic of the grocery-store imagination, an Edsel of the breakfast aisle. In the world of commercial design, Tropicana’s overly bland, overly simplified redesign, introduced in January, will go down in history for annoying consumers so mightily that they agitated for a return to the original packaging: a white carton with a picture of a juicy orange, Venetian-stripe straw piercing its skin.
What is the deal with architects and their love of boats?

In 1985, a brash new pop star named Madonna, channeling Marilyn Monroe and surrounded by a chorus of men proffering diamonds, declared that we were “living in a material world” — a proposition that at the time seemed provocative and even a little crass. By today’s standards, the song’s music video, a campy anthem to ’80s excess, looks unbelievably quaint: the party was just getting started. And now it’s over. We woke up one morning to discover that we had too many toys and no retirement. Somewhere along the way, our entire economy came to be based on consuming stuff. Waving the flag for those who persist in the belief that shopping will be our salvation, Louis Vuitton’s ad campaign this season features the Material Girl herself.
Richard Woods has the art world floored.

Every so often a designer comes up with something so appealing to so many people that it becomes a best seller. Jasper Morrison’s pearly glass Glo-Ball light, in the shape of a beach ball, was one. Philippe Starck’s Juicy Salif lemon squeezer, which looked as if it had landed from another planet, was another. Never mind that it squirted lemon juice over anyone rash enough to actually use it.

The Samurai Shopper says unto you: prepare to meet thy maker. Your coffee maker, that is, the one kitchen appliance worth hugging for its cherished function: delivering caffeine to your sleep-ridden self. Odds are you wake up each morning needing some means to shift gears into performance mode. This can be done without coffee, but that would be like getting dressed and not brushing your teeth.

Maybe it’s the chill that has descended over the world’s economy, but the warmth of wood — especially plywood — is looking mighty inviting. Mind you, this isn’t a sudden development: wood has been making a comeback in the furniture world for some time. Still, there’s something about the simplicity of plywood, and its throwback to Modernist idealism, that suits our craving for plain but honest and elegant furnishings right now.
The Plywood Era . . . Supermarket Modernism . . . Suited for Space . . . Glorious Excess . . . The News From Milan.

In Italy, a peculiar thing happens when you add an “s” to the beginning of the word “kitsch.” The meaning flips, so tasteless or jokey becomes refined, even glamorous. That’s the idea behind the new luxury design brand Skitsch, which opens its flagship store in Milan this month during the furniture fair — to elevate things like candles and Ping-Pong tables to design objects. Think Ikea meets Moss, with almost everything made in Italy. There will be a catalog and, if all goes well, eight more stores throughout Europe by 2012.

Gary Hustwit, a Brooklyn filmmaker, spent years on movie projects about bands like Wilco and Death Cab for Cutie, but a documentary about a font made him a rock star in his own right: Hustwit’s direction of “Helvetica” in 2007 earned him the adoration of graphic-design geeks worldwide. His latest, “Objectified,” had its premiere at last month’s South by Southwest festival. This film looks at industrial design, mixing interviews with assembly-line factory shots and B-roll footage of people shopping. Sustainability, consumerism, robots — “Objectified” covers all the bases and catches the design world’s hotshots off guard. There’s Dieter Rams, pruning a bonsai tree in his Japanese garden; the IDEO co-founder Bill Moggridge firing up his 1955 GMC Jimmy; and Jonathan Ive, deep inside Apple’s top-secret facilities, wiping the screen of his iPhone with his T-shirt. [?][?][?] JILL SINGER.

More Serpentine Gallery than Safeway, the supermarket chain Mpreis is the unlikely patron of some of Austria’s best architecture. Founded in 1920 in Innsbruck, the family-owned company started taking architecture seriously in the early 1980s. Now most of the chain’s 156 locations are light-filled pavilions that are made out of such gourmet materials as structural glass, perforated steel, poured concrete and raw birch timbers. The chain is based in the Tyrolean Alps, and the most striking stores take full advantage of the dramatic mountain backdrops. Every Mpreis is different — no cookie-cutter here — designed by architects who range from international stars like Dominique Perrault to regional talents like Peter Lorenz. No wonder Mpreis was selected in 2004 to represent Austria for the architecture Biennale di Venezia. A new store is scheduled to open this summer in Wildschönau-Oberau, a secluded village with good skiing. There, Helmut Seelos of Seelos Architekten will turn a 40-year-old stucco market into a sleek wood-shingled box, the 21st collaboration between Mpreis and the architect. “Those clients who care about architecture are the ones we like,” Seelos said. “We like Mpreis.” [?][?][?] OLIVER SCHWANER-ALBRIGHT.

Depending on how you look at it, “Baroque 16201800: Style in the Age of Magnificence” is either a glorious romp through the original age of excess or a cautionary tale about making a sensible decorating budget and sticking to it. The exhibition, which is at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London through July 19, traces the proliferation of the Baroque style through all manner of things gilded and grandiose — from paintings by Peter Paul Rubens and this Bavarian monstrance (below) to the Duchess of Devonshire’s silver-gilt toilet service and a rare Louis XIV cabinet. Such opulent objects were expressions not so much of contemporary good taste but rather of wealth and power at a time when those who had them were not in the least afraid to flaunt them. [?][?][?] ALIX BROWNE.

It’s difficult to imagine that the wisdom of the Italian design maestro Bruno Munari once seemed unfashionable. And yet his about-to-be-reissued 1971 manifesto, “Design as Art” — in which he urges his peers to create everyday objects rather than elitist masterpieces — spent more than two decades out of print. In the excess-happy 1980s, Munari’s suggestions — that expensive utensils be tossed in favor of chopsticks or that a lamp should actually look like a lamp — seemed curmudgeonly. Now his preoccupations look a lot like our own: furniture must be constructed so that “out of a flat box comes a three-dimensional object” (the flatpack); a designer should study “the structures of nature, observing the evolution of forms” (biomimicry); the designer should always be prepared to “step down from his pedestal” and “make a sign for a butcher’s shop” (recession). Penguin Press UK’s art director, Jim Stoddart, who spearheaded the book’s revival, says, “You can’t pretend its ideas are groundbreaking now, but they have fed what’s groundbreaking now.” [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV.

When Russel Wright’s American Modern dinnerware first appeared in 1939, it brought unfussy elegance straight to the table. Each piece, designed with the eye and hand in mind, presented a wonderfully refined silhouette — a creamer as stout as a Disney dwarf, a water pitcher as sleek as a heron in flight. Manufactured until 1959 by Steubenville Pottery in Ohio, American Modern became one of the best-selling tableware lines in history. After a lackluster attempt by Oneida to bring American Modern to the masses via Bed Bath and Beyond in 2002 (curves were deleted, sizes amped up, and the 16 new, uninflected colors were reminiscent of Necco Wafers), Russel Wright Studios — under the direction of the designer’s daughter, Annie Wright, and the industrial designer Patrick Dickson — is taking American Modern back into its own hands. A collaboration with Bauer Pottery of Los Angeles, the new version captures the delicate forms and luminous palette of the originals, including radiant chartreuse and sea-foam blue in newly formulated glazes. “We also thought it was important to include Russel’s perfect tea tumbler,” Dickson says. “Because sustainable design isn’t just about recyclables. It’s about good design that can go on forever.” This time around, let’s hope so. [?][?][?] SUSAN MORGAN.

Of all the otherworldly concerns raised by space travel, fashion is chief among them. Even spacesuits aren’t immune to the changing winds of style — one minute it’s gold-visored helmets, the next it’s all about blue silicone soles. “Spacesuits: Within the Collections of the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum” (Powerhouse Books), written and compiled by the museum’s resident space historian Amanda Young, showcases the most interesting of the 3,000 intergalactic artifacts from the Smithsonian vaults, many of which have not been shown to the public until now. Highlights include the campy, custom-made aluminized suits worn by the “Mercury Seven” for their first mission (the filmmaker Michel Gondry would be over the moon) and a pair of astro gloves from 1967 that feature sharkskin pads and pressure-resistant stainless steel “fingernails.” While NASA no longer offers bespoke suits for its astronauts, it recently hired a new company, Oceaneering International, to revamp its look. Apparently John Galliano was unavailable. [?][?][?] ALEX HAWGOOD.

Tuyomyo, Frank Gehry’s nine-foot-long aluminum bench for Emeco, is based on a sketch that he drew for the company’s Superlight chair (2004), which can be lifted with one hand. The one-off bench, which cost around $250,000 to produce, takes its name from a creative spelling of the Spanish for “yours and mine,” signifying Gehry’s realization that the design is better suited to two people than to one. For now, Tuyomyo is a charitable venture; after its debut this month at the Milan Furniture Fair, the bench will be sold at auction in New York later this year to support the Hereditary Disease Foundation, Gehry’s favorite charity. But Emeco hopes to produce pieces like this in quantity, so that they may really be both tuyo y mío. [?][?][?] ALISON S. COHN.

On May 16, when the Art Institute of Chicago opens its 264,000-square-foot, Renzo Piano-designed addition, it will become the second-largest art museum in the country, after the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The new limestone and glass wing, with its innovative “flying carpet” sunscreen canopy and its bladelike pedestrian bridge that connects the museum to Millennium Park, will house (among other things) the Art Institute’s architecture and design department, which is growing in scope as well as in size. Joseph Rosa, the department’s chief curator, said its mission has expanded from that of a regional, archival repository to one of actively collecting drawings, models, objects and video by an international roster of architects and designers. Its opening exhibition, “Selections From the Architecture and Design Collection,” will include items ranging from a Ron Arad Rover chair to a video by the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister, and will speak, Rosa said, “to the culture of making and of progressive thinking.” Go to artic.edu. [?][?][?] PILAR VILADAS.

Paper or plastic? The Japanese industrial designer and artist Tokujin Yoshioka couldn’t possibly choose. His Honey-Pop chair from 2001 is made entirely of paper; “Powder Snow,” a sculpture from 2006, is a three-dimensional plastic puppy complete with pliable hair.
An art collector's radical reworking of a Manhattan town house is still contemporary after all these years.

STYLE MAP / ISTANBUL It is the only city in the world to straddle two continents, zipped up smartly by the Bosporus. And with a booming art and design scene, Istanbul is continuing to live up to its reputation as a cultural crossroads. The metropolis – as choked up with traffic as it is with mosques – offers a lush, gritty synthesis of East and West, ancient and modern.

1. GREGORY KRUM likes to mix it up. As director of retail for the Shop at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, he stocks its grass-green vitrines (adapted from a 1962 Fritz Haller design) with objects he singles out for their craftsmanship, quirkiness, contextual relevance or just plain beauty. “I try to keep the shop focused yet full of the unexpected,” he says. “I particularly like things that are made by individuals for individuals, things that could never withstand the rigors of mass production.” (Go to cooperhewittshop.org.).
STASH YOUR GUESTS IN STYLE.

The prolific design powerhouse Tom Dixon keeps churning out instant classics. For the coffee table, there’s his new book from Rizzoli, “Tom Dixon Interior Worlds,” a catalog of the visual inspirations — from Maori tattoos to stock cars — that populate his brain. And to add inspiration to your own interior world, there is the Tom Dixon for George Smith Collection of handmade upholstered furniture, like this Wingback Chair. [?][?][?] ANDREAS KOKKINO.

The boxy, contemporary architecture of Barry Bergdoll and William Ryall’s Long Island house is no surprise. Bergdoll, after all, is the chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art and freely admits to being “an old-fashioned cliché modernist.” Still, even modernists need light. The two men (Ryall, a New York architect, designed the house) had searched in vain for the perfect light fixture for the kitchen, a double-height room that is the focal point of the house. And the focus of the focus had to be special. Then they saw the Zettel’z Hanging Lamp by Ingo Maurer. On sale. Bergdoll was familiar with it — it’s in MoMA’s collection — and thought it might work. A sprightly nimbus of wires with small clips clasping little paper notes, it could stand for the kind of jotted informality of kitchen communiqués (messages, lists, recipes) and not be confused with “decoration.” At first, they used the notes that came with the chandelier. “We were unbelievably respectful of it,” Bergdoll said.

RAZE--Priscilla Bishins, on April 10. Wife and best friend of the late Dr. Louis Raze. Loving mother of daughters Shayne Raze (and son-in-law Daniel Shapiro) and Betsy Raze. Devoted grandmother and more to grandson Leigh Raze.

DREIFUSS--Curt Julius, died peacefully on April 13, 2009 at the age of 87. Born in Hamburg, Germany, he is survived by his loving and devoted wife of 57 years, Elaine Dreifuss (nee Jackson) and his adoring son, Rodney Dreifuss of St. Louis, MO. Curt was also the loved grandfather of Elizabeth and Peter Dreifuss and father-in-law to Carol DiSanza-Dreifuss. He is predeceased by his brother, Dr. Richard Dreifuss and sister, Ms. Margreth Dreifuss.

After their show they let us take a few pieces from past seasons. The boots are old Miu Miu. The Chanel purse I just bought as a present to myself -- I've always wanted it. And the feather clip I wore in the Lanvin show. Doing the collections, it's kind of like shopping.

SEAMAN--Carl, 73, on April 11, 2009. Beloved husband of Linda, father of Dana and Jordan, father-in-law of Hal and Rebecca, Papa of grandsons Hank, Slade, Ben, and granddaughter Jessie. Graduated Wharton in 1957: Joined older brother Morton in Seaman's Furniture and grew to second largest retail furniture chain in US before sold in 1987. Carl went on to develop ETI Financial Corp., and Seminole Casualty Insurance Co. in Florida. He always loved the people who worked for and with him. A devout gold investor since 1979, he wanted you to invest in gold (or oil and gas) for your own good. A sports fan from birth-to-death he enthralled in the Brooklyn Dodgers as a boy, and was often seen inside Ebbets Field before pre-game practice had begun. Duke Snider was the greatest. The Dodgers' move? Unforgivable! But not Mr. O'Malley's fault (see Robert Moses). Later, devotee of the football Giants, Knicks, Islanders, Mets, and Tar Heels, he could be seen dressing like Walt Frazier and working quietly at home with the game on the radio and a cigar in his mouth. He loved lifting weights. Also propped up candy industry in good times and bad, he once considered malted milk balls a healthy snack (milk), and did not believe it necessary to eat at any restaurant fancier than Wendy's (maybe a diner). Really, why do you have to be so "fancy"? He did love his cats. Linus was a mensch; Butch and Sunny great, too. A philanthropist as well, Carl Seaman and family were instrumental in the development of carrier testing for familial dysautonomia, and virtually eliminating new cases of this terrible (primarily Jewish) disease. He supported many other important causes as well through his Julius Ada Foundation, including North Shore Child and Family Guidance, in Roslyn, Long Island. Success did not spoil Carl Seaman, and he would never be a member of any club that would have someone like him as a member. Now, at the great Ebbets Field in the sky, he is ordering a "smaller piece" of cake for each of his many childhood heroes that are already there. Yes, Clem Labine would have struck out Bobby Thompson, and if you think that some of today's games are not "fixed", you don't watch sports. "This was a man." Memorial Service to be announced. Donations to North Shore Child and Family Guidance, please.

WU--Pei-Yi, a specialist in the study of premodern Chinese culture and literature, died on April 6th, at the age of 81. Long affiliated with Queens College and Columbia University, Wu was the author of The Confucian's Progress, a book on the origins and history of autobiography in China. Professor Wu was born in Nanking in 1927, the son of Ou Tsin-Chen, Vice-Minister of Education in the Nationalist government and Ni Lian, Professor of Psychology and Statistics at National Taiwan University. After receiving an undergraduate degree in Foreign Literature from Nanking University in 1948, he emigrated to the United States where he received various degrees. Among them were an MA in Mathematics and a doctorate in East Asian Languages and Culture. Both these degrees were from Columbia. In 1967 Professor Wu became a full time member of the Queens College faculty, retiring in 1996 with the rank of full professor. During the last thirty years of his life, Pei-Yi Wu was an adjunct professor at Columbia University. His signature course was Directed Readings. It examined classical and modern Chinese texts. He gained recognition for his work on Confucian guilt, self-examination, autobiography, the history of childhood, Chinese women warriors and the literature of pilgrimage. The work on autobiography culminated in The Confucian's Progress (Princeton, 1990). To quote, Philip Kuhn, a close friend, "PY's diverse circle of friends will continue to revere his invincible skepticism, his inter-cultural curiosity and his belief that the human condition is grave but not serious". Pei-Yi Wu is survived by his sisters, Helen Pei-Ping Chang and Pei-Ching Chen, his nephews, Julius Chang and Raymond Chen, and his long time companion, Mary Jo Robertiello.

Frank and the adored mother of Priscilla (Leonard) Adler and Karen "Kiki" (Howard) Kelrick and their children, Leslie and Jamie Adler and Allison and Scott Kelrick. She was raised in New Rochelle, NY, and graduated from the University of Wisconsin. Remembrances may be made to the Miami City Ballet, 2200 Liberty Avenue, Miami Beach, FL 33139 or www.miamicityballet.org

MILLER--Lawrence A.,64, of Los Angeles (formerly of Yonkers) passed peacefully on April 11th after a long illness. A noted stage & motion picture designer, stage credits included a Tony Award nomination for "Nine The Musical" as well designs for the NYC Opera & NYC Ballet. Motion picture credits included "Overboard," "The Flamingo Kid," "Doc Hollywood" and "L.A. Story" among others. He is survived by his beloved spouse, Gerry Turnbull, his brother Bob (Sherry) Miller of White Plains, nephew Bill Miller & nieces Nina Young & Alison Miller. There will be a memorial gathering at his home on May 3rd.

LEFKOWITZ--Estelle Ruth, MD, 74, passed on March 31, 2009 due to complications of cancer. Daughter of Anne and William Rosenburg of Brooklyn NY. She was born September 22, 1934. She attended Brooklyn College, graduated from the University of Geneva School of Medicine in 1960, interned at Newton Wellesley Hospital, and was a fellow in Oncology at Yale New Haven Hospital. She established her own practice in Oncology in Mount Kisco, NY 1972, and was a physician with old-world values, who dedicated over 30 years to her patients and her profession. She always gave of herself and cared for those in need, continuing to make house calls until she retired. During college she was a competitive swimmer. As an adult she became an enthusiastic collector of antiques, glassware, and jewelry, and a true lover of the theatre, arts, world travel, animals, and beautiful vistas. She was well known for her storytelling, infectious laughter, world class cuisine, and entertaining. She was a loving and dedicated wife of over 50 years, a mother, role model and mentor to her three children and five grandchildren. She is survived by her husband, Marty; children, Bill, Mia and Mark; grandchildren, Samantha, Molly, Joseph, Jacob and Isabella, and brother Herman. She was one of those special people in this world, who had a joie de vivre that was unforgettable. She had a big heart and would have liked to have cared for the whole world. She gave more to us than she'll ever know, and she will be remembered, celebrated and deeply missed. We love you.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Ballpark Statistics Follow a New Count, the Toilet Ratio'' (April 13): The obvious solution for potty parity is having 20 percent of toilets that can be pushed male or female, depending on the audience. For football games, that middle group of toilets becomes male territory. For a grade school teachers conference, the middle group of toilets becomes female territory. No firm rules for potty parity will ever work for all groups.Dennie Van Tassel

LANES--Selma G. Children's book author, editor, critic, essayist, lecturer died early on April 8th of complications due to Parkinson's disease. She was 80 years old. Ms. Lanes was born in Dorchester, MA, 1929; the daughter of Jacob and Lily Gordon. After graduating from the Dorchester High School for Girls she attended Smith College ('50) and later the Columbia School of Journalism. Ms. Lanes career included several years as editor of Parents Magazine, editor in chief of Parents Magazine Press and managing editor of Western Publishing children's book division. Ms. Lanes authored several books most notably The Art of Maurice Sendak, Down The Rabbit Hole and An Actors Life for Me. She wrote dozens of reviews on childrens books many of which appeared in this paper as well as an article on the author Tomi Ungerer which appeared in the Times Magazine. A long time resident of New York City and East Quogue, Long Island, Ms. Lanes, died in Honesdale Pa. at the Ellen Memorial Health Center. She is survived by two sons, Andrew Lanes of Vail Co., Matthew Lanes of Damascus Pa. and her brother Sheldon Gordon of Brooklyn NY, their spouses, nieces, nephews, grand children and loyal dear friends. Donations in Selma's name can be made to the Parkinson's Foundation of America.

In the sprawling city of Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, where contemporary architecture tends toward the straight and angular -- blue glass high-rises, narrow makeshift shops constructed from repurposed shipping containers -- the house that Elias Sime has spent the past decade hand-building from mud and straw is an anachronism. Round shelters known as tukuls, made from unbaked earth, thatched straw and green timber poles, have been part of the region's architectural heritage since before the Queen of Sheba. Still, this is an artist's house. Its organic, circular structure, intricately carved walls and woven roof appear like a voluptuous dream, a swirl of ancient techniques and ecstatic imagination. Born in 1968, Sime grew up in Addis Ababa during the Derg era, Ethiopia's 12-year period of Communist military rule. As a child, he taught himself to sew, embroider and repair furniture. His widower father, a road construction foreman, recognized his son's gift and supported his desire to become an artist. ''In Ethiopia, most families do not encourage their children to become artists unless they are descended from traditional ceramicists, carvers, painters, blacksmiths or weavers,'' observes Meskerem Assegued, a curator and the director of the Zoma Center for Contemporary Art in Addis Ababa. ''In many parts of the country, artists and craftspeople are considered almost subhuman, with the power to use their 'evil eye' to harm the public.''

The emphasis by Lisa Belkin on the lower intelligence of children born to older fathers (April 5) is potentially intimidating and misleading. In several of my texts, I cite studies to the contrary from different cultures (France; Scotland; Israeli students of Asian-African origin) wherein achievement actually may increase as a function of birth order in large families. Indeed, the extensive study of historically famous persons by Ivor Aleksachin and Andrei Tkatschenk concluded that the fathers of 2,000 men of genius were predominantly older than 30 years, whereas the age of their mothers played no significant role. H. J. ROBERTS Palm Beach Institute for Medical Research West Palm Beach, Fla.

The Easter Parade has always been a promenade, although it has changed a lot from its start after the Civil War, when churchgoers arrayed in robber-baron splendor took to strolling along Fifth Avenue. Today, dandies excepted, contemporary fashion is a rarity among the costumes and carnival headdresses. Among the eye-catchers this year were a homemade tribute to the heroic landing in the Hudson, a plane with rabbits on the wings; and three creations with a nest-egg theme ornamented with grim financial headlines and a photo of Bernard Madoff. A live swing band provided music for dancing.

The leading indexes closed just slightly higher on Friday, but that was enough for each to end the week with a net gain. Early in the week, the markets fell on news of disappointing retail sales and wholesale prices. But investors turned hopeful on signs that the overall economy might be stabilizing. One of those signs came from the beleaguered banking sector. Citigroup and JPMorgan, for example, posted quarterly earnings that beat analysts' expectations.

DOMESTIC DISTURBANCES It's weird, isn't it, that in an age in which the definition of acceptable girlhood has expanded, so that desirable femininity now encompasses school success and athleticism, the bounds of boyhood have remained so tightly constrained? And so staunchly defended: Boys avail themselves most frequently of epithets like ''fag'' to ''police'' one another's behavior and bring it back to being sufficiently masculine when someone steps out of line, found Barbara J. Risman, a sociologist at the University of Illinois at Chicago, while conducting extensive interviews in a Southeastern urban middle school in 2003 and 2004. ''Boys were showing each other they were tough. They were afraid to do anything that might be called girlie,'' she told me this week. ''It was just like what I would have found if I had done this research 50 years ago. They were frozen in time.'' -- JUDITH WARNER,

BOSCARELLI--Patricia Cryan, 87, died peacefully on Easter Sunday in Vero Beach, FL, where she had recently moved from New York City. Pat was born and raised in the Bronx, New York. Soon after graduation from Hunter College, Pat married Ignazio Frank Boscarelli (1920-1995) on October 2, 1943, in Our Lady's Chapel in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Pat is survived by her daughter Eileen, son Thomas and wife Robin, daughter Maureen and husband Peter, and her devoted grandchildren, Paul and wife Leanne, Carolyn, Kate and Nicholas. Throughout her life, Pat was a dedicated volunteer and fundraiser for innumerable New York City institutions ranging from the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, to Mary Manning Walsh Home, to the Catholic Big Sisters. Her love of life was infectious and she shared warm friendships with princesses and porters alike. A daily communicant, she was always ready for a game of bridge or a theatre outing, as long as she could attend Mass on the way. A celebration of Pat's life will be held in New York City at a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, a gift in Pat's memory can be sent to: Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10022, Attention: Rachel Russell.

SNORKELING IN THE GRAN CENOTE, TULUM, MEXICO, DEC. 29, 2008 Mark Moldenhauer, 39, a businessman from El Paso, Texas, and his son Nick, 7. ''I was on vacation with my family -- we are Germans but currently are living in El Paso, where I work in the automotive business. We decided to rent a car and drive around a little bit, and we went to Tulum to see the pyramids. We wanted to snorkel a little bit in a cenote. I jumped in the water with my oldest son. We had already snorkeled around in salt water before, in Hawaii, and he told me he liked the fishes in the sea more. He was not very amazed by the fishes in the cenote. But he still enjoyed it -- it was amazing to see those underwater caves. The cenote goes pretty deep and the water is clear, and then you see those stalactites inside the caves. We clasped our hands and snorkeled around -- a little adventure for my son at the famous pyramids. He especially appreciated this daddy-son experience.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

THE NEWS On a visit to Mexico City, President Obama called on the Senate to ratify a treaty to curb the flow of guns and ammunition to drug cartels in the Western Hemisphere that has been pending for more than a decade. BEHIND THE NEWS Gun violence and the crossborder drug trade have taken center stage in American relations with Mexico, which has been struggling to contain criminal gangs. Administration officials have been saying publicly that lax gun laws and insatiable demand for illegal drugs in the United States are big contributors to Mexico's problem. The treaty has already been ratified by 29 of the 34 members of the Organization of American States.

Excerpts from recent posts on the Globespotters blog, a guide to cities around the world. Full entries can be found at globespotters.blogs.nytimes.com. MUMBAI As Mumbai's classical architecture gives way to skyscrapers, the curious traveler needs to be quick to see the fading parts of old Bombay. There were once Iranian cafes at nearly every corner in south Mumbai. Originated by Iranian immigrants in the 19th century, they provided cheap food and good company in a leisurely -- though often rather grimy -- setting. Many have vanished, but those that have survived have kept prices low and their ambience intact. You can eat a full meal for less than 40 rupees (about 80 cents at 51 rupees to the dollar), or nurse a single cup of tea for hours without being disturbed. (Be warned: there is no air-conditioning.)

ON the heels of its first anniversary, Dossier, the biannual fashion and arts journal, has opened a bricks-and-mortar shop in Brooklyn. ''People told us to do an online magazine and an online store,'' said Katherine Krause, a founder of the publication. ''In both cases, we wanted something real.'' Housed in the garden apartment of a landmark brownstone just a block from the Brooklyn Flea Market, the store, which is opening this weekend, is billed as an extension of the magazine, combining fashion, art, literature and design, much of it produced by friends and contributors. Among the offerings: clothing from Bless, Bodkin and Electric Feathers; jewelry by Pamela Love and Black Sheep & Prodigal Sons; artist editions by David Armstrong; art books from small-run presses; assorted curios like handmade stationery and Victorian corkscrews; and a selection of high-end vintage pulled from the closets of stylists, musicians and models. The store will also host parties, designer pop-up shops and art shows, curated by various individuals.

MORIARTY--Donald P.,on April 15, 2009, age 78, from a Hemorrhagic Stroke, Overlook Hospital, Summit, NJ. Investor and General Partner of Twin Oaks Partners, an investment management firm. A wake will he held at Burroughs, Kohl & Dangler funeral home located at 309 Springfield Ave, Summit, NJ on Sunday evening from 6-8pm and on Monday from 2-4pm and 6-8pm. The funeral Mass will be held at St. Teresa of Avila Church in Summit at 11am on Tuesday, April 21. Mr. Moriarty attended St. Peter's Preparatory school in Jersey City where he excelled in athletics earning varsity letters in football, basketball and track. He went on to attend the College of The Holy Cross in Worcester, MA where he received a football scholarship. After graduating from Holy Cross with an AB degree in English, he served in the U.S. Army from 1953 through 1956 attaining the rank of Sergeant, First Class. Following military service, he attended Law School and Business School at New York University. He began his career as a securities analyst at Bankers Trust and went on to become managing partner of William A.M. Burden & Company where he managed investments for the Burden family and the Florence V. Burden Foundation. In 1991, he founded the investment management firm Twin Oaks Partners and served as its general partner until his death. In addition to his business career, Mr. Moriarty devoted himself both to public and private service. In 1970, he joined the Summit Board of Education serving as President in 1975. Continuing his civic involvement, he became a trustee of the Overlook Hospital Foundation and also served as a trustee of the Summit Area YMCA. He was a board member of the Pingry School in Martinsville, New Jersey and Chairman of the Board at his alma mater, St. Peter's Prep. He was a charter member of the St. Peter's Donne Society and in 1999 he was inducted into the school's Legends of Prep. He served on the Board of Trustees at Holy Cross for three decades and provided leadership as its Chairman. As longtime head of Holy Cross's Investment Committee, he took primary responsibility for the financial health of the College. At Holy Cross, he was a member of the College's Cornerstone Society, its Lifetime Benefactor's Circle and a charter member of its President's Council. In 2008, he was awarded an Honorary Degree by the College of the Holy Cross for his many years of leadership, support and devotion. Mr. Moriarty served as a trustee of the Florence V. Burden Foundation and as the Chairman of the Carnegie Council on Ethics and International Affairs where he was an honorary trustee. He was a member of the Smithsonian Institute Investment Policy Committee and he was a director and Investment Committee Chair of The Summit Trust Company. He is survived by his wife, Mary Eileen, his seven children, his twenty-four grandchildren, and his sisters Veronica Fleming and Patricia O'Neil. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Donald Patrick Moriarty '48 Scholarship Fund in care of St. Peter's Preparatory School, 144 Grand St., Jersey City, NJ, 07302.

GOUSE--Charles F. Passed away March 11, 2009, at 78 years old. Charles was born to Frederick Jacob Gouse and Frieda Van de Water on February 16, 1931 in Mineola, NY. He most recently lived in Sag Harbor, NY with his wife, Audrey. He is survived by his devoted wife, Audrey and his children Andrea (and John Sullivan), Stephanie (and Christopher Vyce) and Rick (Sherri); his step-children Alison (and Greg Gore) and Matthew as well as six grandchildren; Taylor and Ethan Sullivan, Lily and Brady Gouse, Hadyn and Alexander Gore. Charles had one great-grandchild, Logan Sullivan. Charlie's professional life was centered on his love of music; playing, arranging, conducting and teaching. After earning Bachelor's and Master's degrees at Hofstra College he received a Doctorate in Music at Boston University. He studied trumpet with Harry Glantz of Toscanini's NBC Symphony and Armando Ghitalla of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, conducting with Tibor Serly and composition with Elie Siegmeister. Charles played with the Boston "Pops" Orchestra under Arthur Fiedler and was the principal trumpeter with the original (NYC) Bach Aria Group. He also worked with many studio and free-lance groups. He was founder and conductor of the North Shore Symphony (formerly Hicksville Community Orchestra), Music Director and conductor of the Orchestra da Camera and the conductor of the Merrick Symphony from 1977 to 1994. Charles also conducted the New Amsterdam Symphony Orchestra (NYC) for its Alice Tully Hall concerts. In addition to his musical arrangements for the Eglevsky Ballet, Mr. Gouse's works have been performed by the Batsheva Dance Co. (Isreal), the David Parsons Dance Foundation (NYC), the Ballet Met (Ohio) and the Spoleto Festival (Melbourne, Australia). His educational materials are published by Alfred Publishers, Van Nuys, California. Charlie retired from the North Shore School District in 1986 as the Coordinator of Fine Arts. Previously, he spent over 25 years as Director of Music for Hicksville School District. His students and colleagues were a source of joy over the years. Before returning to Long Island, Charlie spent many happy years splitting his time between Lake Sunapee, New Hampshire and Flagler Beach, FL where he enjoyed the lake and beach equally with family, friends and his beagle (Bella) over the years. Charlie's love for people, music and life will be missed.

BELA BORSODI Even in these dour economic times, the Austrian photographer Bela Borsodi remains a commodity devotee with a sense of humor. His still-life portraits, which have appeared in publications like Another Magazine and Italian Glamour, often play up the eroticism that lurks below the surface of, say, a B&B Italia armchair. He once placed a fur hat on the tip of a phallic pink balloon sculpture (far right) and enjoys creating female forms out of luxury accessories. (Another example of his work is at center.) ''Our society is very conscious of the body,'' he says. ''In a way, it is our big fetish.'' Inspired by the idea of ''a nice sunny day at the pool,'' Borsodi shot the best new outdoor furniture for ''Sunny Side Up'' on Page 84. ''Many of the products in my images relate very much to our psyche -- our society, our vanities, our insecurities.'' If that sounds like some armchair philosophizing, Borsodi's aim is actually quite succinct: ''What can an object tell us about a person?''
Classical Allan Kozinn
