There are two words that should give every N.F.L. team hope when the draft starts next Saturday: Matt Ryan. Two more? Joe Flacco. At this time last year, Ryan and Flacco were quarterback prospects generating considerable questions, and Atlanta and Baltimore were losing teams embarking on rebuilding. Then the Falcons chose Ryan, the Ravens maneuvered for Flacco and the rest is playoff history. As rookies, Ryan and Flacco proved that adept drafting really can instantly reverse a franchise's fortunes. Is Matthew Stafford, out of Georgia, the next Ryan or Flacco? And who will have the nerve to find out Saturday if Stafford or Southern California's Mark Sanchez can make the transition as smoothly? Quarterbacks are always the draft-day stars, but this draft is loaded with offensive linemen and receivers. With not much delineation between players who could go in the first few picks and the middle of the first round - the draft analyst Gil Brandt said he believed there were 23 players who could be taken in the top 10 - and so much money due players who go in the first few spots, expect the teams near the top of the draft list to try to trade down to get more bang for their buck. Here is a look at each team's needs going into the draft. (Position of first-round picks in parentheses.) AMERICAN CONFERENCE East Buffalo Bills (11, 28) No draft pick is going to change the Bills more than Terrell Owens will, but getting a tight end and shoring up the offensive line would help Owens, too. And the Bills have to upgrade in the pass rush, which was awful last year. Jets (17) At least one of the top three quarterbacks could still be on the board when the Jets pick in the first round. Moving on from the messy Brett Favre experiment is the Jets' greatest need. But if they stick with a training-camp battle between Kellen Clemens and Brett Ratliff, they have to get a big-time wide receiver to ease their quarterback's path. New England Patriots (23) With 4 of the first 58 picks - and with holes in the secondary and at running back filled in free agency - Coach Bill Belichick can add more youth and speed to his defense. Miami Dolphins (25) Their needs do not seem quite as desperate as last year's, but to keep the progress going, the Dolphins need upgrades at receiver and across the board on defense, especially at cornerback. North Cleveland Browns (5) Whoever becomes their starting quarterback will find major issues at receiver, including Donté Stallworth's legal situation. But with Eric Mangini in charge, they will try to rebuild the pass rush, too. If linebacker Aaron Curry is on the board when Cleveland picks at No. 5, he will be tempting. Cincinnati Bengals (6) The Bengals have spent their last four first-round picks on defense. Now it is time to shore up the offense again. Carson Palmer's elbow should be healthy again, but to keep it that way, the Bengals need reinforcements on the offensive line. If they really want to make Palmer feel good, they will get him a pass-catching tight end or another receiver. Baltimore Ravens (26) Now that the Ravens have solved a decade-long quarterback problem with Flacco, they could use a top-notch receiver from a deep class to pair with him. Pittsburgh Steelers (32) The Super Bowl champions are some of the best drafters around, so expect them to go for a cornerback to replace Bryant McFadden and perhaps another offensive lineman. South Jacksonville Jaguars (8) The Jaguars should get one of the top players in the draft. They can use it -- at wide receiver, on both lines, and at linebacker and in the secondary. Houston Texans (15) With the dynamic offense in great shape, it will be all defense, all the time for the Texans. Look for them to go for linebackers and defensive backs. Indianapolis Colts (27) There has been a lot of change with the Colts -- farewell, Tony Dungy, and good luck finding another job, Marvin Harrison -- but as in recent years, the defense needs a few upgrades, particularly at linebacker and on the interior defensive line. Any offensive picks are for depth only. Tennessee Titans (30) The Titans do not need much to remain competitive. They have already replaced the departed Albert Haynesworth, but could use quality pickups at wide receiver and at linebacker to fill out a strong roster. West Kansas City Chiefs (3) Almost everybody expects that General Manager Scott Pioli will take Wake Forest linebacker Aaron Curry, perhaps the best player in the draft, with the third pick to address the Chiefs' woeful pass rush and begin building a defense in the Patriots' image. Oakland Raiders (7) If JaMarcus Russell is ever going to become a real force, he is going to have to have a go-to receiver. The Raiders don't have anything close right now. Denver Broncos (12, 18) The Broncos have a boatload of picks from the Jay Cutler trade, 2 in the first 18 over all. Despite an active free agency, they need a lot of help in shifting their defense to a 3-4. But the questions remain: Is Kyle Orton really their quarterback, or will they take one this year? San Diego Chargers (16) The biggest addition will be getting Shawne Merriman back, but the Chargers lost Igor Olshansky this off-season, and finding a defensive end to replace him is a priority. NATIONAL CONFERENCE East Washington Redskins (13) From Dan Snyder's off-season activity, you might think the Redskins need a quarterback. Not so much. They do need an offensive tackle and help on the defensive line and at linebacker. But Snyder likes to ''win'' free agency and the draft with splashy acquisitions, so don't rule anything out. Philadelphia Eagles (21) For a conference finalist, the Eagles need plenty: a running back to take some heat off Brian Westbrook, a go-to receiver for Donovan McNabb and reinforcements for both lines and the secondary. Oh, yes, and somebody who can possibly replace Brian Dawkins's leadership. Giants (29) Even before they sent Plaxico Burress packing, the Giants needed a receiver. Now the need for a tall, red-zone threat is more acute than ever. Maybe a Braylon Edwards trade will finally come together, but if it doesn't, the Giants have to find Burress's replacement. Dallas Cowboys (none) You cannot draft peace and quiet, which is what the Cowboys need most of all. In lieu of that, the Cowboys need depth on the offensive line and on defense. But this is still a talented team and the departures of Adam Jones, safety Roy Williams and Terrell Owens can only help. North Detroit Lions (1, 20) When you're 0-16, what don't you need? The new coach, Jim Schwartz, comes from the defensive side, and the Lions need help front to back on defense. But if they're going to pay the big money that the first overall pick commands, they need a quarterback - and a franchise face - who can lead the long rebuilding slog. Plus, Matthew Stafford actually wants to play for Detroit. Green Bay Packers (9) Don't blame Aaron Rodgers for the Packers' downfall last year. He got little help from the running game and an ineffective offensive line, and the defense was dreadful. Green Bay is switching to the 3-4 defense, which means it needs a nose tackle. Minnesota Vikings (22) Let's assume they are going to choose between Tarvaris Jackson and Sage Rosenfels at quarterback. The Vikings had better protect whomever they choose - last year they gave up 43 sacks, making the drafting of a tackle a near necessity. Chicago Bears (none) The Bears have already made their biggest acquisition of this off-season, when they traded for quarterback Jay Cutler. They don't have a pick until the 49th over all, but they'll need a No. 1 receiver to keep Cutler happy and a cornerback so that Cutler doesn't find himself in too many shootouts. South New Orleans Saints (14) Drew Brees and his offensive teammates can set all the records they like, but if the Saints don't upgrade their defense, it will be for nothing. Jonathan Vilma could use some help at linebacker. Tampa Bay Buccaneers (19) The Buccaneers still don't have a franchise quarterback and they could draft one. But they also need a lot of parts for their gutted defense, particularly in the front seven. Atlanta Falcons (24) They got the offense straightened out faster than anybody imagined. Now it's time for help on defense, especially on the defensive line. Carolina Panthers (none) On paper, the Panthers don't need much to contend again. But if they wind up trading the disgruntled defensive end Julius Peppers, it will leave an enormous hole in the pass rush that they will have to fill immediately. West St. Louis Rams (2) Their fingers are probably crossed that the Lions don't take tackle Jason Smith, who could replace Orlando Pace. They also need a receiver to take over for Torry Holt. Lucky for the Rams, this draft is flush at both positions. Seattle Seahawks (4) Their passing defense was abysmal last season, so they could use the fourth overall pick on a pass rusher. San Francisco 49ers (10) Maybe it's time to finally give up on Alex Smith and draft a quarterback. The Niners could move down and still get Mark Sanchez or Josh Freeman if Matthew Stafford doesn't somehow fall to them. Arizona Cardinals (31) That passing game sure is exciting, but how about another running back to bring some balance, and to relieve some pressure on the not-getting-any-younger Kurt Warner?

Iran has sentenced an Iranian-American journalist, Roxana Saberi, to eight years in prison after convicting her of spying for the United States, her lawyer said Saturday. The State Department has called the charges against Ms. Saberi, 31, baseless and has asked for her release.

AUSTIN--Alice Howe, 91, of Missoula, Montana died quietly at her home on Sunday, March 29. She was born in Windsor, CT on August 6, 1917 to Arthur Howe and Margaret Armstrong Howe. Alice grew up in Windsor, CT, Hanover, NH, and Hampton, VA, where her father was an educator and administrator at Taft School, Dartmouth College and Hampton Institute. Her mother was self-employed in her later years managing the family-owned resort Rockywold-Deephaven Camps on Squam Lake, NH, that became the center of her family's life over the years. It was on a Vassar Outing Club trip to Mt. Moosilauke, NH that Alice met her husband, Briggs M. Austin, who was on a similar climb with Dartmouth's Outing Club. Throughout their life together, they traveled and enjoyed mountain and wilderness areas on foot and by canoe, both overseas and in Missoula where they retired in 1975. In Rochester, NY, Alice taught elementary grades in the inner-city schools and worked for Planned Parenthood, living out her deep commitment to social justice and equality started in the family by her grandfather, General Samuel Chapman Armstrong, who, at the end of the Civil War, founded Hampton Institute, the first college for black students. Through her volunteer efforts in preserving the natural environment, Alice became well known in Missoula and derived great pleasure in serving the community.

ANDREOLI--Thomas E.,M.D., passed away on April 14, 2009 due to a cerebrovascular accident. A devoted husband, father, grandfather, physician, mentor and friend, Dr. Andreoli was born on January 9, 1935 in The Bronx, New York. He received his B.S., cum laude, from St. Vincent College in 1956 and his M.D., magna cum laude, from Georgetown University in 1960. It was as a resident in Internal Medicine and fellowship at Duke University, where under the mentorship of Eugene Stead he crystallized his vision for academic internal medicine departments. After solidifying his training in basic science at the Laboratory of Intermediary Metabolism at the NIH, he was appointed to the faculty at Duke University where he trained with Roscoe R. (Ike) Robinson and Daniel C. Tosteson. He made seminal observations on ion and water transport in epithelia. On the basis of these discoveries he rose to national prominence and was appointed as the Founding Director of Nephrology at the University of Alabama in Birmingham School of Medicine (UAB). He created one of the premier academic Divisions of Nephrology in the world, establishing the model of nephrologic training centers with his creation of the UAB Nephrology Research and Training Center. He was appointed the Chair of the Department of Internal Medicine at the University of Texas Medical School in Houston in 1979. In 1988, he came to the University of Arkansas College of Medicine (UAMS) and was appointed Professor and Chair of the Department of Internal Medicine, where he lead the Department to national prominence attracting talented academic scientists from throughout the country. At the time of his death, Dr. Andreoli was a Distinguished Professor and Chair Emeritus of Internal Medicine at UAMS. During his distinguished career he held many leadership positions in national and international medical societies, including Secretary-Treasurer of the American Society for Clinical Investigation, President of the American Society of Nephrology, and President of the International Society of Nephrology. He served as Editor of the American Journal of Physiology: Renal Physiology; Editor-in-Chief of Kidney International; and Editor-in-Chief of Andreoli and Carpenter's Cecil Essentials of Medicine. He was a member of the Board of Directors, National Space Biomedical Research Institute, Board of Directors, KDIGO (Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcomes), and served on the Visiting Committee of Harvard/MIT Division of Health Sciences Technology. But his most cherished role was as a mentor and teacher to generations of students and colleagues in the medical sciences. His legendary bedside rounds were noted fondly by many of the practicing physicians both in Arkansas and throughout the world. For these prodigious talents, he has been richly recognized and rewarded. He received the Distinguished Faculty Scholar Award of the University of Arkansas, the Distinguished Faculty Award from the Caduceus Club at UAMS, the George L. Ackerman Outstanding Faculty Award at UAMS, the Distinguished Teacher Award from the American College of Physicians, a Mastership from the American College of Physicians, the Homer W. Smith Award for Renal Physiology from the American Society of Nephrology, the David M. Hume Memorial Award of the National Kidney Foundation, the Robert W. Berliner Award for Excellence in Renal Physiology from the American Physiological Society, and the Robert H. Williams Distinguished Chair of Medicine Award from the Association of Professors of Medicine. His teaching has been recognized internationally in his receipt of the Louis Pasteur Medal from the University Louis Pasteur, the Silver Plate Award from the Hungarian Kidney Foundation, and his election as a Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians (Edinburgh) and of the Royal College of Physicians (London). Endowed Chairs in his name were established at the University of Alabama School of Medicine and at the University of Arkansas College of Medicine. He holds a Sc.D., honoris causa, from St. Vincent College, Docteur, honoris causa, University Paris VII, a Sc.D. honoris causa from the Aristotelian University in Thessaloniki, and a M.D. honoris causa from Semmelweis University in Budapest. Dr. Andreoli read voraciously and was passionate about art and music. He loved opera and would often regale his visitors in the original Italian to glorious arias. He loved the Yankees, Frank Sinatra and his dogs. He saw himself often as the elderly man in "Moonstruck" pulled at night walking his six dogs. In 1987, Dr. Andreoli married his loving wife, Elizabeth Berglund Andreoli, who is a partner at the Hardin Law Firm in Little Rock, Arkansas. Dr. Andreoli is survived by Dr. Kathleen Gainor Andreoli, mother of his three children, his daughters Paula Andreoli North of Dallas, and Karen Andreoli Roberts of Carlsbad, California, both devoted mothers, and his son, Thomas Anthony Andreoli, a partner at the Chicago law firm of Sonnenschein, Nath & Rosenthal. Dr. Andreoli is also survived by his beloved 10 grandchildren: Stephen, Sarafina, Claire, Mia, Mark, Charlotte, Gigi, Danny, Penelope and Anthony. The family wishes to gratefully acknowledge a virtual member of the Andreoli family Ms. Clementine Whitman, his lifelong academic partner for nearly 40 years. The family requests memorial gifts sent to: The Thomas E. Andreoli Education Fund, University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, 4301 W. Markham, Slot 716, Little Rock, AR 72205. Checks should be made payable to the University of Arkansas Foundation Fund, Inc.; The Humane Society of Pulaski County, 14600 Colonel Glenn Road, Little Rock, Arkansas 72210; and The Thomas E. Andreoli, M.D. Endowed Chair in Nephrology at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, care of Virginia Loftin, University of Alabama at Birmingham, BDB 485, 1530 Third Avenue South, Birmingham, AL 35294-0012; vgloftin@uab.edu; (205) 975-5602. Online guestbook: rollerfuneralhomes.com/chenal

Claggett and Sheffield, Linked Again On Nov. 10, 2006, Anthony Claggett joined the Yankees as one of three pitching prospects acquired from Detroit for Gary Sheffield. Ever since, he has felt linked to Sheffield and followed his career.

Excerpts from recent posts on the Globespotters blog, a guide to cities around the world. Full entries can be found at globespotters.blogs.nytimes.com. LONDON On April 22, it will be 500 years since Henry VIII acceded to the throne. To mark this anniversary, several major exhibitions will examine his life. ''Henry VIII: Man and Monarch'' runs from April 23 to Sept. 6 at the British Library (96 Euston Road, NW1; 44-870-444-1500; www.bl.uk/henry). Among the 250 items on exhibit are official documents, maps and books from the king's personal library, as well as loans from other collections. A highlight will be a love letter, Henry VIII's declaration of his ''unchangeable intention'' to marry Anne Boleyn, which has been concealed in the Vatican for almost five centuries -- a letter that changed the nation. -- PAM KENT

KORNREICH--Matthew. The Officers, Board of Directors, and the entire staff of The NIA Group and Kornreich NIA are deeply saddened by the passing of Matt Kornreich, Co-Chairman of the Kornreich Organization, on Wednesday April 15th. Matt and his twin brother Mort joined their father Saul, and helped build S. Kornreich & Sons Inc. into one of the largest privately held insurance brokerage firms in the United States. The firm was a pioneer in offering multi-lines of insurance services and products to its clients. Matt was a Chartered Life Underwriter and a member of the Million Dollar Round Table. In addition to his many honors, Matt, along with his brother, were named Mass Mutual Men of the Year in 1975. Matt was a dynamic mentor and coach, a talented professional, a compassionate human being, and a real gentleman. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his sister, Norma Weinstein; his children, Kathy and Sam Weinberg, William and Eileen Kornreich and their children, Lisa, Andrew and Sarah. We also extend our condolences to our partners Jim and Tom Kornreich. Funeral services will be held at 1:00pm, Friday, April 17th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Ira Lipson, Director of Institutional Advancement at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave., Mazer 725, Bronx, NY 10461.

ROSENZWEIG--Irving. The Partners, Counsel, Associates and Staff of Troutman Sanders deeply mourn the passing of our beloved and esteemed colleague, Irving Rosenzweig. As a trusted confidante, Irving's wise counsel was sought by clients and colleagues alike, and he will be sorely missed. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Bobbi, and his entire family.

YOUNG--Jane Jaffe, Ph.D. Professor of English at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, where, for 43 years, she taught composition, literature, and film. As chapter chair of the faculty union, the Professional Staff Congress, since 2001, she advocated effectively for the rights of her colleagues and was chosen Member of the Year for Higher Education by the New York State United Teachers in 2007. A freelance writer and poet, she published articles in academic journals and in New York Magazine, the Village Voice, the Daily News, and Newsday. At the age of nineteen, she won the Mayoral Poetry Award for her poem "Kaleidescope," along with now-famous author Erica Jong. Her book, D.H. Lawrence on Screen, studied the ways in which filmmakers adapted the stylistic elements of "The Rocking-Horse Winner," Sons and Lovers, and Women in Love to Lawrence's literary style. Critic John Simon wrote that "her conclusions are of equal value to Lawrence scholars, film students, and all others who care about film and fiction and their fascinating interplay." She graduated from the High School of Music and Art, received her B.A. degree Phi Beta Kappa from the City College of New York, earned a master's degree at Harvard University, and completed her Ph.D. at New York University. She died at home surrounded by loving family and friends. She is survived by her life partner, Phil Eggers, sister, Paula Kopelman, daughter Victoria Young Salganik, son-in-law Jonas Salganik, granddaughter Natasha Rose Salganik, stepson David Eggar, stepdaughter Cynthia Wendy Eggers Butler and husband Sean Butler, and stepson Michael Eggers. A service was held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, on Sunday, April 12 at 2:30pm. Contributions may be made in lieu of flowers to the Mesothelioma Applied Research Foundation (MARF), P.O. Box 91840, Santa Barbara, CA 93190-1840.

PICKETT--Linda, 82. Daughter of Jamaican immigrants Passmore and Agnes Lindsay. Born 1926 in Manhattan and raised in the Bronx with her siblings Edsel, John, Lloyd and Martha. Married Alfred Pickett in 1947 and became a Harlem resident while working and raising her family. As a working mom, she held several jobs highlighted by a 20 year career at the W.T. Grant Foundation primarily as a Program Officer. Linda and Al became Roosevelt Island pioneers in 1975 where they were actively involved in a variety of activities. They also began their worldwide travels together. Beginning in 1990 Linda spent her retirement years as a passionate world traveler, active volunteer for many organizations, avid reader - book club member, a loyal arts supporter and generous philanthropist while still enjoying her Roosevelt Island home. Linda passed away peacefully at home on March 24, 2009 after a courageous and heartfelt battle with pancreatic cancer. Linda is survived by her sister Martha Dunlap, brothers Edsel and Lloyed Lindsay, son Steve along with many nephews and nieces, godchildren, dear friends, associates and neighbors. Please join the family in Celebrating Linda's almost 83 years of vibrant, loving and benevolent life. In lieu of flowers or gifts, please take a moment to remember Linda's smile and spirit during her time with you.

Although central Essex County has remained an oasis from the worst of the nation's real estate meltdown, there is still the occasional housing horror story -- like the sorry tale of 572 Prospect Street in Maplewood. A gracious six-bedroom brick Tudor -- with wood floors, high ceilings, a one-bedroom carriage house and nanny's suite -- the house was put up for sale in the heady days of March 2007 at an asking price of $899,000. Within a month, the owners received an offer within $40,000 below the asking price. A deal never materialized, but in an era of bidding wars and easy credit -- when Maplewood homes routinely sold for 99 percent of asking price -- it was completely reasonable to expect that another buyer might come along to snatch it up soon.

Tyler Kepner of The Times crawled out on a limb this month when he picked the Royals to win the A.L. Central. That limb may be sturdier than others thought. Kyle Davies, below, has made two strong starts this season, and he finished 2008 by going 4-1 with a 2.27 earned run average in September. With Davies following Gil Meche and Zack Greinke, the Royals could match three starters with virtually anyone. Carlos Marmol has not displaced Kevin Gregg as the Cubs' closer -- yet. He got his second save Friday because he was already warming up to pitch the ninth inning with Chicago trailing when the Cubs took a one-run lead in the eighth. But how long can Lou Piniella's blood pressure handle Gregg in the biggest spots? Gregg has already blown a save; he has a 9.00 E.R.A. and has yielded six hits and five walks in four innings. In six appearances, Marmol has allowed two hits, three walks and no runs.

Prospects: M.B.A.'s You don't need an M.B.A. to know times are tough. Michelle Antonio,director of M.B.A. career management at the University ofPennsylvania Wharton School, shares what she's seen so far: ''Base salaries are the same no growth and no decline but signing bonuses are coming in a bit lower, about $3,000 to $5,000 less.''National surveys show campus recruiting and job postings down about 10 percent, and financial service jobs are gone. Reality check,says David Wilson, president of the Graduate Management AdmissionCouncil, makers of the GMAT: ''Only a handful of M.B.A.'s go into financial services. Graduates may have to refocus their search, but there are going to be jobs out there.'' Meanwhile, his business is good:the number taking the GMAT is up 8 percent. Below, how grads of full-time, two-year programs fared last year.
GREENWICH COLONIAL $1,650,000

EARTH DAY is this Wednesday, and all things ''green'' will be celebrated. But it's worth asking: how environmentally friendly are ''green'' products, really? Consider, for example, this paragon of eco-virtue: the stainless steel water bottle that lets us hydrate without discarding endless plastic bottles. Using a method called life cycle assessment, we have evaluated the environmental and health impact of a stainless steel thermos -- from the extraction and processing of its ingredients, to its manufacture, distribution, use and final disposal. There were some surprises. What we think of as ''green'' turns out to be less so (and, yes, sometimes more so) than we assume.

As the remembrances of Mark Fidrych poured in after his death last week, one game in particular seemed to stand out for fans. On June 28, 1976, Fidrych pitched a complete-game victory over the Yankees in less than two hours. He talked to the ball, got down on his knees to manicure the mound, congratulated his teammates and took a postgame curtain call as the cheers rained down at Tiger Stadium. It's no surprise that game is so well remembered. It was shown on ABC's ''Monday Night Baseball,'' which at the time was one of only a few nationally televised games that fans could watch. For Fidrych, the timing was perfect.

Businesses that disappear, empty storefronts, boardedup construction sites the artist Joan Chiverton has seen evidence of the recession along the streets of Manhattan. These illustrations, most of them drawn from her neighborhood on the Upper West Side, show a city that has been bruised by the downturn but hardly beaten. Some residents may be forgoing their $4 lattes, or at least trading them for 99-cent ones, but others are still opening their wallets for inexpensive luxuries like bananas, a pedicure or a bouquet of daffodils.

WACHS--Bernice, 84, for over 47 years the devoted wife of Irving, beloved and dedicated mother of Dahlia and Michael, mother-in-law to Rachel and Keith and adored grandmother of Amelia, Elizabeth, Emily, Ethan, Jeremy, Sabrina and Samantha. The youngest of five siblings, Bernice put herself through school, earned a Bachelor's and Master's Degree from Columbia University. She became a teacher, selflessly giving to others, as she did throughout her life for family and friends. Her courage in fighting and beating ovarian cancer 14 years ago was an inspiration. The graceful but determined manner she fought a second cancer more than ten years later was an example to all. Her passion for family, from doting over her children growing up to nursing Irving back to health after he suffered a stroke, will remain part of her legacy. Funeral services will be held today at 1pm at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th St. Contributions to: www.caringforcarcinoid.org.

April 15: A preview party opened SOFA New York, an exhibition of sculpture, objects and functional art, at the Park Avenue Armory. The Museum of Arts and Design held another party in the armory's Tiffany Room. The event continues through today. 1. GAEL MENDELSOHN.

It has been 2,000 years since the Romans built their aqueducts, and 200 years since Philadelphia began using cast-iron water mains. But the 6-inch-wide city pipe that still delivers drinking water to a block on Nixon Street here uses an even more primitive technology: wood. Its wooden planks are lashed together with a coil of metal as if each section of pipe were a long, narrow barrel. And while the small stretch beneath the ground here may seem more Swiss Family Robinson than 21st century, it is not unique to Chelan.

STUDENT PHOTOGRAPHERS roving their campuses for The Times: Jason Wang at Harvey Mudd College, Larry Ash at the University of Arkansas, Benjamin Innes at Minneapolis College of Art and Design. D.I.Y. ''It's pretty bare bones,'' says Emily Kay Atchison (center) about the sandblasted Raleigh frame she assembled from discarded parts found at bicycle shops around town. ''I don't have brakes on it or anything.'' Ms. Atchison, a senior at Minneapolis College of Art and Design, is one of dozens of students who count themselves among a community of technical artists who build bikes from new and leftover parts, not only to save money but to create something of pride. ''You've specialized and personalized the very thing that's getting you from A to B,'' explains Allegra Lockstadt (left). Jennifer Hedrich is at right.

THE Anglo-Brazilian It girl Charlotte Dellal had originally wanted to design corsets. She found that footwear satisfied the same creative urge. ''They're both these very detailed little sculptures that make a woman feel more feminine,'' she said. No surprise, her shoes, introduced in London three years ago under the label Charlotte Olympia, are showstoppers: sky-high (the fall collection includes her first flats, which she refers to as ''vertically challenged''), leopard-print and lipstick-hued platforms, inspired by 1940s pinups. And they have acquired a cult following among the kind of women who get noticed, Kate Moss and Daphne Guinness included. ''My customer is someone who dresses from the feet up,'' Ms. Dellal says. ''Everything else comes after.''

BEARD--Leo Roy, a world renowned hydrologic engineer, died in Austin, TX, on March 21 at the age of 91. Roy Beard founded the US Army Corps of Engineers Hydrologic Engineering Center in Davis, CA, and was a professor of Civil Engineering at the University of Texas. He was known for his pioneering work on the application of statistics to hydrologic engineering. He received the American Society of Civil Engineers' Lifetime Achievement Award and was elected to the National Academy of Engineering.

GORDON--Irving Herbert (Herb), 92, died peacefully at home on April 13th. Poet, writer, photographer, orator and outdoor enthusiast: he and his passion for life will be missed profoundly. He is survived by his loving family; wife, Gail, daughters, Debbie, Hilary and Rebecca, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on April 20th at 2pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Amsterdam/91st St., New York.

Michael Cox, an authority on the Victorian ghost story who, five years ago, spurred by the threat of blindness, sat down and wrote the vast Gothic novel that had been haunting him for three decades, ''The Meaning of Night,'' a widely praised narrative of intrigue and murder, died on March 31 in Kettering, England. He was 60 and lived in the Northamptonshire region of England. The cause was hemangiopericytoma, a rare vascular cancer, said his wife, Dizzy Cox.

DOMNITCH--Henrietta, passed away suddenly on April 16, 2009. She was the cherished wife of Irving Domnitch for 62 years; mother to Marilyn Metz and Karen Domnitch; grandmother of Justin Metz, Devon Metz, Jonathan Marmon, and Eryn Marmon Dolan; and great-grandmother to Luc Ryder Metz. She lived her life with strength, courage and humor, surrounded by her family and friends. Her kindness, generosity, and spirit will be profoundly missed. The family requests donations be sent to Lenox Hill Hospital or the charity of your choice.

HERE IS a map every captain heading for the Horn of Africa might want to study: dots show the region's recent pirate attacks. Banditry has long flourished near Somalia, but 2008 set a record for incidents and 2009 is on course to far exceed that, according to a United Nations analysis. Ship traffic off Somalia's Indian Ocean coast plunged as piracy surged there. So swarms of pirates, nimble in their small craft, moved to the Gulf of Aden, already a dangerous zone for merchant fleets.

I WAS saddened to hear last week that Mark Fidrych, the 1976 American League Rookie of the Year, was found dead under his Mack truck on Monday after he suffocated when his clothes became entangled in a spinning shaft on the truck. Although I was too young to follow his amazing first season, I remember collecting his baseball card from the subsequent seasons until he retired in the early 1980s.

BURKE--David J.,a decorated veteran of the Vietnam War, passed away on April 13, 2009 at Stanford University Medical Center in Palo Alto, California after a long battle with esophageal cancer. He was 75 and had been a resident of Portsmouth, RI. David is survived by his wife of 44 years, Anne S. Burke, his three children, David C. Burke of Atherton, CA, Thomas C. Burke of San Francisco, CA, and Elizabeth A. Burke of New York, NY, three grandchildren, Aidan, Caroline, and Charlie, and his brother Michael Burke of Saratoga Springs, NY and sister Mary Fitzsimmons of Tequesta, Florida. Born and raised in Saratoga Springs, New York, David was a graduate of Saratoga Springs High School (1951) and The College of Holy Cross (1955). He later received his MS in Business Administration from George Washington University (1967) and was a distinguished graduate of the US Naval War College (1974) in Newport, RI. He served as an officer in the US Air Force from 1955 to 1981 and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross for an aerial mission over North Vietnam in July, 1968 and the Legion of Merit upon his retirement as a Colonel in 1981. He served with the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the Pentagon from 1974-77 and at Andrews Air Force Base from 1977-81. Following his Air Force career, David was the Director of Federal Government Policy and Procurement for Digital Equipment Corporation in Washington, DC from 1981 to 1991.

LAPTOPS on airplanes are hardly an unusual sight these days, but when Heather Poole pulled out her computer on a recent flight from New York to Los Angeles, she got a surprising reaction from the flight attendants serving drinks. ''They stopped service -- they wanted to hold it, look at it,'' said Ms. Poole, 38, a flight attendant herself, who also writes for the travel Web site Gadling.com.

TREAT--Doris L.,(nee Gerding), of Rutherford, New Jersey passed away peacefully Thursday, April 16, 2009 in Hackensack Hospice after suffering a stroke. Born in Hackensack, New Jersey, December 9, 1929, to Heinrich (Henry) and Lillian Gerding, Doris was a graduate of Rutherford High School - Class of 1948 and went on to graduate Berkeley Secretarial School. She was retired from the Borough of Rutherford after 30 years of service as the Administrative Secretary to the Chief of Police. She was a member of St. John's Lutheran Church. She was predeceased by her husband of 34 years, Robert G. Treat. She is survived by her son Robert J. Treat, his wife Meg Ann, her daughter June Cheval and her husband Eugene. She is also survived by two grandchildren, Krystle and Kyle Cheval. Friends will be received on Monday April 20, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Collins-Calhoun Funeral Home, 19 Lincoln Ave., Rutherford. Memorial Service will be held on Monday at 8pm. Cremation Private. Memorial Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Rutherford PBA Local 300, PO Box 228, Rutherford, NJ 07070 "Good & Welfare Account".

ROSENTHAL--Renee. Three Arrows mourns the passing of Renee Rosenthal, beloved wife of Dr. Leslie Rosenthal, mother of Regina, David and Alice, grandmother of Jesse, Alex and Joy. She died April 10, 2009, at age 85, after cardiac surgery. A gifted artist, she won the prestigious Gradiva Award for Art in 2007. In her 25 years as a master teacher and years of community activism, she combined a passion for enhancing the lives of others with a genius for innovative programs, always bringing people together. Contributions may be made to her favorite charity, the Alzheimer's Association.

A FEW days before the scheduled unveiling of Porsche's four-door Panamera at the Shanghai auto show, Aston Martin released an image of the Rapide, its entry in the four-door grand tourer sweepstakes. The Rapide, the company announced, will make its debut later this year and arrive in showrooms in 2010. The Rapide concept, designed by Marek Reichman, Aston's design director, was unveiled to general acclaim at the 2006 Detroit auto show. The car will be built on a version of the DB9 platform and is about a foot longer. Mr. Reichman likened it to ''a lithe long-distance runner, beside the sprinterlike V-8 Vantage or muscular DBS.''

WHEN Robert and Patty Mittleman shopped for a new home 11 years ago, what they saw, before settling on their five-bedroom three-bath center-hall colonial on an acre in Woodbury, N.Y., was ''whatever the agent took you to,'' recalled Mr. Mittleman, the owner of a personal training studio. These days, they are doing preliminary house shopping online, viewing slide shows and virtual 360-degree tours of homes that fit their criteria not far from Woodbury in the Syosset school district on Long Island.

GLUCK--Eleanor, of Great Neck, NY on April 17th, at age 87. Widow of Irvin, mother of Kathy Berkman (Andrew) and the late David, grandmother of Emily (David), Ben (Boji) and Sofi. Survived as well by three great-grandchildren, Ella, Rosie and Lily. Services Sunday, April 19, at Riverside Memorial Chapel (Amsterdam Ave and 76th St at 1pm). Eleanor will be remembered for her devotion to her family, her friends and to the many students she touched over the years as an English teacher, as well as for her undiminished intellect, curiosity and love of culture and the arts.

Questions are on Page 28. Add the number of correct answers and subtract a quarter point for each wrong one. Loosely extrapolating from the annals of Advanced Placement scoring and using its 5-point scale, 14 to 18 correct answers approximately equates to a 5 (extremely well qualified); 12 to 13, a 4 (well qualified); 9 to 11, a 3 (qualified); 6 to 8, a 2 (possibly qualified); and 0 to 5, a 1 (no recommendation). Different colleges grant credits for different scores. And keep in mind, these selected questions would account for only a tenth of a test, and you haven't even seen the essay questions yet.

TUCHMAN--Gloria, born in the Bronx, worked as a teacher at Drexel and Park Avenue and as principal of George Jackson Elementary. She later became an attorney. Her passion was her family. An eternal optimist she approached the world with hope and inspired everyone to be the best that they could be. Her smile brightened our lives. She will be forever missed by her husband and soulmate Chet Tuchman, Alan and Donna Tuchman, Terri and Russell Meyers, and grandchildren Matthew, Megan, Madison and Taylor Tuchman and Sarah, Michael, Jack and Casey Meyers. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

NOTORIOUS Not the Hitchcock classic, but an authorized biography of the Brooklyn rapper Biggie Smalls, also known as the Notorious B.I.G. (played by Jamal Woolard). With Angela Bassett, Derek Luke and Aunjanue Ellis; George Tillman Jr. directed. Writing in The New York Times in January A. O. Scott called the movie ''a messy, lively melodrama, reasonably faithful to the facts of Biggie's life and wholeheartedly devoted to burnishing his myth.'' (Fox, Blu-ray $39.99, three-disc standard definition edition $34.98, single-disc $29.98, R) THE WRESTLERDarren Aronofsky's ruthlessly naturalistic look at an aging professional wrestler who can't admit his time is up earned an Oscar nomination for its no less battered star, Mickey Rourke. With Marisa Tomei and Evan Rachel Wood. ''It's a bit phony, perhaps,'' Mr. Scott wrote in The Times in December, ''but to refuse to embrace the movie's deep hokiness would be to cheat yourself of some of the profound pleasure it offers.'' (Fox, Blu-ray $39.99, standard definition $29.98, R)

ROSENZWEIG--Irving, 88, of Great Neck, NY, passed away on Friday April 17 having lived a full and joyous life. Born in New York City, NY, he was a decorated World War II veteran and esteemed tax attorney in the City for over 50 years. He left behind his beloved wife, Bobbie Rosenzweig, his sons Paul Rosenzweig and James Rosenzweig, grandchildren, Jordana, Olivia and Dustin Rosenzweig, and many step grandchildren, step-great grandchildren, nieces and nephews, all of whom will miss him dearly. He will be remembered as a learned, loving, wise, warm-hearted man of great intellectual curiosity. The funeral will be held at 1pm on Sunday April 19 at the Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in Irving's memory to the Schneider Children's Hospital, part of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, or a charity of your choice.

Forgive the self-reference for a moment: Holland Cotter, an art critic for The New York Times, won the 2009 Pulitzer Prize for criticism, it was announced Monday afternoon. In its citation, the Pulitzer committee said it was honoring Mr. Cotter, who has been a staff critic at The Times since 1998, for “his wide ranging reviews of art, from Manhattan to China, marked by acute observation, luminous writing and dramatic storytelling.” In a speech to Times staffers this afternoon, Mr. Cotter said, “Esoteric is something I just haven’t explored yet; weird is what makes me want to get up in the morning.”

You know it’s spring when the temperature goes up, the flowers bloom and bloggers begin their campaigns to save their favorite shows in danger of being cancelled. With just a few weeks before the networks announce their fall schedules, the Web seems to have coalesced around “Chuck,” NBC’s action satire about a computer geek (played by Zachary Levi) turned unlikely secret agent. Fan sites like Give Me My Remote as well as online columnists like Michael Ausiello of Entertainment Weekly and Alan Sepinwall of The Star-Ledger have encouraged viewers to call upon NBC to give the show a third season.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Monday morning.

The police in Mumbai said they were investigating accusations that the father of a child actor from the movie “Slumdog Millionaire” tried to offer her for adoption in exchange for money, Reuters reported. On Sunday, Britain’s News of the World published the results of a sting operation in which it said Rafiq Qureshi, the father of 9-year-old Rubina Ali Qureshi, offered her for adoption for around $290,000 to a wealthy Dubai family – who were actually reporters for the newspaper. Rubina Ali portrayed the young incarnation of the “Slumdog Millionaire” heroine played by Freida Pinto, and attended the Academy Awards in February when it won the award for best picture. Moinuddin Qureshi, an uncle of Rubina Ali, denied that her father had tried to sell her, telling Reuters: “This is just an attempt to malign her name. After all she has become world famous now, hasn’t she?”

Despite periodic cell phone brownouts as 50,000 people reached for their phones every time they wanted to rejoice in a great set (or complain about sound bleed and the lines for the bathrooms), Twitter was the premier method of disseminating news and opinion at the 10th annual Coachella Valley Music & Arts Festival. I sent more than 100 tweets, squinting in the glare of the scorching desert sun. Here are some samples:

The comedian Kathy Griffin and the clergyman V. Gene Robinson were among the top honorees of the GLAAD Media Awards, which were presented Saturday night in Los Angeles by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. In a news release, GLAAD said that it had given Ms. Griffin, star of “Kathy Griffin: My Life on the D-List,” its Vanguard Award, presented to individuals whose work has “increased the visibility and understanding of the LGBT community in the media.” Bishop Robinson, the openly gay Episcopal bishop who delivered the invocation at a presidential inaugural event in January, received the Stephen F. Kolzak Award, which GLAAD said is given to “an openly lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender person who has made a significant difference in promoting equal rights.” The Showtime series “The L Word” received special recognition, as did the viral video “Prop 8 — The Musical.” “Desperate Housewives” was named outstanding comedy series and “Milk” was named outstanding wide-release film.

A court in Malawi will hear on May 4 an appeal of a ruling that denied Madonna‘s petition to adopt a 3-year-old girl there, a court official told The Associated Press on Monday. Earlier this month, Malawi’s High Court ruled that Madonna could not adopt the girl, Chifundo James, because she had not been a resident of the African nation for the last 18 months. In 2008, the pop singer completed the adoption of her son, David Banda, from Malawi, and has a daughter, Lourdes, 12, from a previous relationship, and a son, Rocco, 8, from her marriage to Guy Ritchie, whom she divorced in January. The A.P. said that Madonna’s appeal would be heard by Malawi’s Supreme Court of Appeal and that she need not be present.
INDIO, CALIF. — Five highlights from the three-day Coachella festival, which ended late Sunday night:

Oprah Winfrey abruptly canceled on Monday a broadcast of her talk show that was to focus on the 10th anniversary of the Columbine shootings, The Associated Press reported. The episode, called “10 Years Later: The Truth About Columbine,” was timed to the anniversary of the incident at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., in which 12 students and a teacher were shot to death by two students, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, who then killed themselves. In a message on her show’s Facebook Web page, Ms. Winfrey wrote: “I decided to pull the Columbine show today. After reviewing it, I thought it focused too much on the killers.” In its place on Monday, “The Oprah Winfrey Show” was scheduled to run an episode about a mother who had been released from prison.

Updated | 2:25 p.m. Dan Brown, the author of the mega-bestselling novel “The Da Vinci Code,” has finally delivered his long-awaited new novel, “The Lost Symbol,” and it will be published Sept. 15. The Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group said on Monday that it was planning a first print run of 5 million copies, a number that dwarfs most other books. “The Da Vinci Code,” which was made into a movie starring Tom Hanks, was a worldwide publishing phenomenon, with 81 million hardcover copies in print. Fans and the publisher have been waiting a long time for Mr. Brown to finish the new book. It was originally scheduled for a 2005 delivery. “The Lost Symbol” will again feature Robert Langdon, the protagonist of “The Da Vinci Code.” According to Jason Kaufman, executive editor at Doubleday, the novel takes place over the course of 12 hours and will “follow Robert Langdon through a masterful and unexpected new landscape.” In a statement, Mr. Brown said he had spent five years on research for the book. “Robert Langdon’s life clearly moves a lot faster than mine,” he said.

The Broadway musicals “Billy Elliot” and “Shrek” each received 10 nominations for Outer Critics Circle awards on Monday, while no one play emerged as the dominant contender in the nominations — a reflection of this season’s unusually robust offering of plays that laid claim to various categories.

In my Findings column, I explain how researchers have discovered that, over the long term, being richer often translates into being greener. Many environmental problems get worse as a country first industrializes, but once it reaches a certain level of income, the trend often reverses, producing a curve shaped like an upside-down U. It's called a Kuznets curve (in honor of the economist Simon Kuznets, who detected this pattern in trends of income inequality).

When Roxana Saberi, a 31-year-old Iranian-American journalist, was arrested in Tehran in January, her parents were told it was because she tried to buy alcohol. Details about her detention in the notorious Evin prison near Tehran were sketchy. But her case was speeded up this month when she was charged with spying, then convicted and sentenced in a short trial.

The New York Times Magazine cooking videos, formerly known as 'Tiny Kitchen,' are back! I am in the kitchen again (of course, I never really left), and Jenny is behind the camera. We're now operating under the name Kitchen 4B, in honor of my New York City digs. (That's my apartment door on the logo.) Better yet, we will now be posting two webisodes a month, one every other weekend. Stay tuned for more webisodes, including one on how to stock your kitchen and pantry (a direct response to your comments), and check us out at 35,000 feet; Kitchen 4B now airs on the New York Times channel on JetBlue.

It was 20 years ago today that passers-by found an unconscious 28-year-old woman who came to be known as the Central Park jogger, a victim of a rape and beating during a regular nighttime run. Although she remained anonymous for years, the woman, Trisha Meili, revealed herself publicly with her 2003 memoir, "I Am the Central Park Jogger: A Story of Hope and Possibility." Today, Ms. Meili is a motivational speaker and advocate for victims of sexual assault and brain injury, and helps organize the "Hope and Possibility" run in Central Park. On Well, the personal health blog of The Times, Tara Parker-Pope spoke with Ms. Meili about her life, running and finding purpose in adversity.

For those of you who think that silk flowers are too granny - or those of you who love them but think that convincing examples are too expensive - Carlos Mota has news for you. A stylist, writer and editor at large for Elle Décor magazine, he is also the designer of Casa Carlos Mota, a collection of six polyester-silk flower arrangements with recession-friendly prices that are making their television debut (along with Mota himself) tonight on HSN. Mota has always loved silk flowers, but he didn't love their fusty reputation, or the daunting price tags of the better arrangements. As fate would have it, he was styling a photo shoot at the home of Mindy Grossman, the chief executive of HSN, and when she complimented Mota on his (fresh) flower-arranging skills, he promptly pitched the idea of a silk collection. The most expensive arrangement, of hydrangeas, is $49.95; the least expensive, a small bouquet of roses, is $29.95. All six are in white ceramic vases. A few months ago, Mota sent a sample arrangement of peonies and ranunculus ($39.95) to my office. At first, I felt a little sheepish with a bouquet of fake flowers on my desk and wondered whether people at work would see it as some kind of ironic, anti-design statement -- or whether they would just consider me deeply uncool. Instead, all they saw was a bunch of pretty blossoms, and soon, so did I. I've lost count of the number of colleagues, style mavens all, who walk by my workstation and exclaim, "What beautiful flowers. Wait - are those real?" And, as Mota points out, faux flowers just keep on giving: "They offer unconditional love."

Nascar: Not bad for an old-timer. Mark Martin started from pole position and led nearly half of the 312 laps at Phoenix International Raceway in Arizona on his way to becoming the first 50-year-old winner in the Sprint Cup since 1993. Martin held a healthy lead until an accident by Dale Earnhardt Jr. brought out a caution with 11 laps to go. Martin went to the pits and emerged in second behind Ryan Newman. But when the green flag dropped, he stormed past Newman and cruised to an easy win, his first since 2005.

Monday, 10 a.m. The Department of Environmental Protection's police force - 125 strong - is up there with pet detectives and postal inspectors in terms of recognition and respect. But the department's officers are responsible for protecting New York's water supply, a chain of reservoirs and aqueducts that - as the officers point out - stretches over 2,100 square miles. For this task, the officers receive no "line of duty" injury benefits and don't even have a nickname, à la New York's Finest. Today, they rally on the streets, seeking those benefits. Brian Gay, helped by an eagle putt at the second hole, charged to a 10-shot victory at the Heritage Classic on Hilton Head Island, S.C. Three ahead of the field overnight, Gay clinched his second PGA Tour title after closing with a sparkling seven-under-par 64 at Harbour Town Golf Links.

Meredith Michaels-Beerbaum of Germany and her 16-year-old gelding Shutterfly won the World Cup title for show jumpers with two fault-free rounds in Las Vegas. The score of zero penalties was two better than the total posted by McLain Ward of Brewster, N.Y., and his mare Sapphire. Michaels-Beerbaum became only the second rider to score a triple in the World Cup final.

At least 14 polo horses, worth as much as $1.5 million, collapsed and died before competition at the U.S. Open polo championships in Wellington, Fla., The South Florida Sun-Sentinel reported. The horses were part of the Venezuelan-based Lechuza Caracas team. The cause of death was not confirmed. Veterinarians tried to save the ponies as fans looked on.

Rafael Nadal became the first player to win five straight Monte Carlo Masters titles by beating Novak Djokovic, 6-3, 2-6, 6-1, on Sunday. Nadal extended his winning streak at Monte Carlo to 27 matches and won his 21st straight victory on clay since losing to Juan Carlos Ferrero in the second round of the Rome Masters in May 2008.

Dario Franchitti, returning to the IndyCar Series this season after spending 2008 trying to transition to Nascar, won the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach in California. Franchitti dominated the 85-lap event on the temporary street circuit, finishing far ahead of the runner-up Will Power, the pole winner. It is his ninth IndyCar win and first since the 2008 season finale at Chicagoland.

In a step toward musical diplomacy, the Israeli conductor Daniel Barenboim, above, led the Cairo Symphony Orchestra on Thursday in his first performance in Egypt. Mr. Barenboim, who has long tried to use music to bring people from Israel and the Arab world together, conducted the orchestra in Beethoven's Fifth Symphony and played Beethoven's ''Pathétique'' piano sonata, BBC News reported. During a rehearsal Mr. Barenboim, who has been critical of Israeli policy toward Palestinians and holds an honorary Palestinian Authority passport, said, ''I hope very much that this, my first visit to Egypt, will maybe allow another way of thinking to come.'' In 1999 Mr. Barenboim and the writer Edward Said founded the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, made up of Arab and Israeli musicians. In January two concerts planned in Qatar and Egypt were canceled because of safety concerns for the Divan Orchestra musicians. Mr. Barenboim's visit was a result of an invitation from the Austrian embassy in Cairo.

The popularity of photo Web sites has shifted away from sites that organize, share and, most notably, print a set of snapshots, to sites where users simply share. Older Web sites like Shutterfly let users print only those pictures they wanted, and sites like Picasa offered the convenience of ordering prints from the neighborhood drugstore. Facebook's photo Web site, which has grown along with its parent site (Facebook has grown 72 percent from last March), does away with printing and adds tagging. Photos are just another part of the ''look at me now'' experience. SHELLY FREIERMAN

If the ruling generals holed up in Naypyidaw, their garrison capital in central Myanmar, wanted to know what riotous fun young Burmese were capable of, they should have come down to watch how the people celebrated the traditional New Year's water festival in this former capital. A similar festival is celebrated in neighboring Thailand and Laos. But the one here has a certain poignancy. This is the one time of year when the junta looks the other way as masses of young people let loose, dancing and drinking in this otherwise repressive city, where gatherings of more than 10 people are usually banned.

Abu Zubaydah has been described as a Qaeda operative.

LOWENSTEIN--Louis. We mourn the death of the firm's co-founder Louis Lowenstein, who practiced law with us from 1968 until 1978 when the firm was known as Kramer Lowenstein Nessen & Kamin. As a young man of 43 with energy and noble ambition, Lou led a group of departing lawyers from Hays, Aklar & Hertzberg to join Kramer, Nessen & Hochman in forming an upstart firm that was guided by a vision: creating an egalitarian, first class group of lawyers that would compete with the major firms of the day. Forty-one years later, the firm is one of the country's largest first-tier law firms. Lou was a brilliant legal strategist, deep thinker and a consummate professional who created and led the firm's corporate department and provided sage advice to diverse clients. Lou left private practice to accept the challenge of running a NYSE company and thereafter joined the faculty at Columbia Law School, from which he had graduated after serving as editor-in-chief of the Columbia Law Review. As an academic, Lou used his business saavy and practical experience to write and lecture on corporate governance, markets and finance; to direct the law school's institutional investor project; and to teach students as the Simon H. Rifkind professor emeritus of finance and law. Lou generously dedicated his extraordinary talents to a variety of philanthropic efforts, including unstinting service on behalf of the Coalition for the Homeless. He was a noble character and inspirational figure whose legacy continues to guide our law firm. To his beloved Helen and Roger, Jane, and Barbara we extend heartfelt sympathy. The partners, attorneys and staff of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel LLP

LOWENSTEIN--Lou. From cheering for our beleaguered sports teams to intense discussions about finance, we have been fortunate to have you as a fixture in our lives. You and Dick have taught us so much about what is truly important in life. We will miss you, Michael and Carol, Wendy and Neil

Here's a tip about playing in the rain from Jerry Mowlds, a leading golf instructor who grew up weathering the occasionally soggy conditions of Oregon: ''For approach shots with your irons, you want to keep your weight on your left foot as much as you can,'' Mowlds said, referring to right-handed golfers. ''If you get any weight on your right foot at impact, it's going to be easy to hit it fat or behind the ball. And hitting the wet grass behind the ball in the rain can lead to a pretty ugly shot -- lots of flying wet turf but the ball goes nowhere.''

After 97 years in the education business, Georgia State has come around to football. Calendars are marked for Sept. 2, 2010: the planned grand opening at the Georgia Dome. Leading this unlikely team will be an equally unlikely coach -- Bill Curry, a 66-year-old veteran of the N.F.L. and the major college coaching ranks, who is 13 years removed from his previous clipboard-toting gig. Georgia State has joined a small wave of colleges beginning football teams with far grander goals in mind than adding another set of uniforms to launder.

ELLIS--Lilli, of Queens, 96, died peacefully April 17, 2009. Wife of the late Robert Ellis, brother of Erwin Herrnstadt. Born in Germany, she escaped in 1939 to Shanghai, and later came to New York. Lilli, a surgical nurse, read the Times daily and could discuss anything from genetics to Google. She enjoyed conversations with friends of all ages. Her memory was faultless. We will greatly miss this woman of extraordinary strength and character, whose loving, warm-hearted nature, wisdom, and keen intelligence we will remember always. Service on Sunday May 3, 3pm, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. Donations can be made to UJA Federation of New York, 130 E. 59th St., New York, NY 10022.

BERGMANN--Peter George, of New York City, on Saturday, April 18, at age 59, after a brief illness. A loving husband to Kay, father to Caroline and Joseph, brother to Steven and Ronald, and son to his late parents, Paul and Therese, and beloved uncle of Rachel, David, Margarette and Paul. For 25 years, Peter was a litigation partner at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, where he built and led the health care/not-for-profit practice group. A tenacious advocate and masterful negotiator, and an advisor of uncommon insight, Peter had more fun practicing law than most people have doing things that actually are fun. Peter was honored to receive the Robert Ray Parks Award from Trinity Church for contributions to the field of gerontology, and the Lillian D. Wald Award from the Visiting Nurse Service of New York for significant contributions to the well-being, health and welfare of New Yorkers. Peter will be remembered for his broad shoulders, joy, generosity and humor, and his unstinting readiness to stand with a client, friend, family or stranger in their most difficult times. We have lost a great soul. Services will be held at 10:30am on Wednesday, April 22, at The Hebrew Tabernacle, 551 Fort Washington Avenue (at 185th Street), in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Fort Tryon Jewish Center, 524 Fort Washington Ave, New York, NY 10033.

The two Army lieutenants crouched against boulders beside the Korangal River. Taliban gunfire poured down from villages and cliffs above, hitting tree branches and rocks and snapping as the bullets passed over the officers' helmets. An American platoon was pinned in the riverbed, which had blossomed into a kill zone. One squad and the radio operator were trapped in a wheat field on the far side. An improvised bomb had just exploded in their midst. The blast wave had blown the soldiers down, and, though the platoon did not yet know it, killed a soldier on the trail.

He will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York, NY, Monday, April 20, 2:30pm. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Coalition for the Homeless, 129 Fulton St. New York, NY 10038.

Tyna Carter, burdened with $25,000 in credit card debt, did not want to be a deadbeat. After looking for help on the Internet, Mrs. Carter, a West Virginia homemaker, wound up in the hands of a sweet-talking ''credit specialist'' from Texas. He claimed his company, Credit Solutions of America, could set her on the road to a debt-free life. But what really happened, Mrs. Carter says, is that Credit Solutions pocketed nearly $4,000 of the couple's income, a little bit each month. Now they are in a deeper hole than ever.

Easter services were celebrated Saturday night and Sunday morning at the Holy Trinity Ethiopian Orthodox Church in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx. The denomination, like some other Eastern churches, observed Easter a week later than the Western Christian churches. The Ethiopian Orthodox Church was part of the Coptic Church of Egypt until it became independent in 1959.

President Obama is running into stiff Congressional resistance to his plans to raise money for his ambitious agenda, and the resulting hole in the budget is threatening a major health care overhaul and other policy initiatives. The administration's central revenue proposal -- limiting the value of affluent Americans' itemized deductions, including the one for charitable giving -- fell flat in Congress, leaving the White House, at least for now, without $318 billion that it wants to set aside to help cover uninsured Americans. At the same time, lawmakers of both parties have warned against moving too quickly on a plan to auction carbon emission permits to produce more than $600 billion.

CRYPTACIZE ''Mythomania'' (Asthmatic Kitty) Nedelle Torrisi, the lead singer of Cryptacize, has a guileless voice, an instrument of earnest pleasure and petition. ''If I could find my way back to you,'' she cries one minute into the band's second album, ''Mythomania,'' leaving the thought wistfully unfinished. She sounds rueful and sweet, though the song, ''Tail & Mane,'' has already made it clear she's pursuing her love on a stolen horse.

A relative of a victim of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing paused at a downtown memorial, the Field of Empty Chairs, on Sunday, the anniversary of the blast at the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building that killed 168 people and injured hundreds.

ALLEN TOUSSAINT ''The Bright Mississippi'' (Nonesuch) From a distance Allen Toussaint might look like a jazz musician: he's a sophisticated gray eminence of New Orleans. In fact he's a pop musician and producer, a great one. He has nothing to apologize for. It's just that jazz as we know it is not part of his working life.

10 P.M. (Science) BUILD IT BIGGER The architect and acrophobe Danny Forster climbs to extreme heights to analyze some of the world's largest and most complex construction and architecture projects and demonstrate how they came together. Season 3 begins with a look at the new Dallas Cowboys stadium; Mr. Forster, above, is atop the stadium's dome. At 3 million square feet, with 80,000 seats, the world's longest retractable roof, largest operable glass door and two 180-foot-long high-definition video screens, the stadium is setting records even before the first ball is passed on its field. Jerry Jones, the Cowboys' owner, talks about the new toast of Texas. 7 A.M. SHAPIRO--Robert E.,passed away peacefully at home April 19, 2009. He is survived by his beloved and cherished wife, Rita, loving family, daughters Ellen, Carol, Roberta and Patti, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. His kindness, charm, and wisdom touched all whom he met, adding to a legacy of leadership and guidance as the longtime chairman of Presidential Realty Corp. We all loved him very much. Memorial service Wednesday 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment private.
Aug. 6, 2010, 3:30 p.m. | Updated
What we’re reading (and watching) on Tuesday morning.

That’s some enchanted catalog: Rights to the songs and musicals written by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II, a body of work that includes “South Pacific,” “The Sound of Music,” “The King and I” and “Oklahoma!”, were sold to the publisher Imagem Music Group, the company announced in a news release. Imagem, which is owned by the Dutch pension fund ABP and the European media company CP Masters BV, said it had acquired the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization, which handles licensing for the works of many composers including Irving Berlin, Andrew Lloyd Webber and Kurt Weill. Imagem said it would retain the current management of the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization, including its president and executive director, Theodore S. Chapin. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The organization also said it was in discussions with Mr. Webber’s Really Useful Group about continuing to represent the rights for his musicals including “Cats” and “Evita.”

Hope they saved some money in the budget for soundproofing: Variety reported that the actor Christian Bale and the director David O. Russell, two Hollywood stars who are not exactly known for their verbal restraint, will soon be working together on a new film called, of all things, “The Fighter.” The movie, to be directed by Mr. Russell, is to star Mark Wahlberg as the boxer “Irish” Mickey Ward and Mr. Bale as his troubled half-brother Dicky Eklund. In 2007, Mr. Russell became the punch line to countless jokes when an outtake from his movie “I Heart Huckabees,” in which he was seen berating the actress Lily Tomlin, was leaked to the Internet. Earlier this year, it was Mr. Bale’s turn, when audio from his movie “Terminator Salvation” in which the actor unleashed an obscene tirade on the film’s director of photography was also released on the Web.

Like a bear rousing from hibernation, the summer rock-music circuit is slowly returning to life. The band Green Day announced that it would commence its first North American tour in three years on July 3 in Seattle. In a release the band said that it would perform shows in more than 30 American and Canadian cities, including dates in Hartford, Conn., on July 24 and New York on July 27, with its final tour stop scheduled for Aug. 25 in Los Angeles. Locations for the concert have not yet announced. Also, the annual Lollapalooza festival, scheduled to take place this year Aug. 7 through 9 at Grant Park in Chicago, announced its complete lineup. Performers include Depeche Mode, Beastie Boys, Tool, Lou Reed, Kings of Leon, Snoop Dogg, Andrew Bird, TV on the Radio, Vampire Weekend and the Decemberists, as well as the reunited Jane’s Addiction, the band led by the Lollapalooza founder Perry Farrell. A complete lineup can be found online at lollapalooza.com.

Three American authors have been named to the short list of the Orange Prize for Fiction, the annual British award given to the best novel of the year by a woman. In a news release, the prize committee said that its six finalists included the Americans Marilynne Robinson for her novel “Home,” Ellen Feldman for “Scottsboro” and Samantha Hunt for “The Invention of Everything Else.” The other finalists are the British writer Samantha Harvey for her first novel, “The Wilderness,” Kamila Shamsie, who is British and Pakistani, for “Burnt Shadows” and the Irish writer Deirdre Madden, an Orange Prize finalist in 1997, for “Molly Fox’s Birthday.” The Orange Prize will be presented in London on June 3; it includes a prize of about $43,000 and a bronze statue known as the Bessie.

The 2009 Tribeca Film Festival, which begins on Wednesday evening with the premiere of Woody Allen‘s “Whatever Works,” has announced its juries, and let’s just say they’re a diverse bunch of decision makers. The full lineups are below:

Two men pleaded guilty Tuesday to charges stemming from the firebomb attack on the home of a London publisher who had announced plans to release a novel about the life of A’isha, a wife of the Prophet Muhammad, Reuters reported. The men, Ali Beheshti, 41, and Abrar Mirza, 23, admitted that they had been involved in the attack on the north London home and office of Martin Rynja, whose publishing company, Gibson Square, delayed publication of the novel, “The Jewel of Medina,” by Sherry Jones after the bombing. Gibson Square acquired the British publication rights to the novel after it was dropped by Random House; in the United States, the book was released by Beaufort Books. A third man arrested in connection with the arson attack, Abbas Taj, 30, was scheduled to go on trial on Tuesday.

What recession? The Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif., just had the second-best turnout in its 10-year history, with 160,000 fans drawn to the Southern California desert to see Paul McCartney, the Cure, the Killers, M.I.A., Leonard Cohen, My Bloody Valentine and more than 100 others, according to the promoter, Goldenvoice. (Its best year was 2007, with Rage Against the Machine, Red Hot Chili Peppers and Bjork, drawing 186,000.) Tickets to Coachella this year cost $269 for a three-day pass, or $99 each day, plus fees.

Updated | 5:11 p.m. In an announcement that will both delight and perplex fans of the fashion reality show “Project Runway,” the Lifetime Channel said Tuesday that it had set a premiere date for the new season, but not until Aug. 20. The debut of the sixth season of “Project Runway” has been delayed for months by litigation between the Weinstein Company, which produces the show, and NBC Universal, the parent company of Bravo, which broadcast its first five seasons. Earlier this month, the Weinstein Company paid an undisclosed settlement to NBC Universal. A spokeswoman for the Weinstein Company, Emily Feingold, said on Tuesday that despite the settlement, the company did not concede that it had acted improperly in selling the show to Lifetime. Much of the taping for the sixth season of “Project Runway” took place in 2008, and episodes were at one point scheduled to air on Lifetime in November.

With the release of his latest mockumentary “Bruno” just a few months away, the comic provocateur and litigation magnet Sacha Baron Cohen was handed an encouraging decision on Tuesday by a Los Angeles court. Judge Terry Friedman of Los Angeles County Superior Court dismissed a libel lawsuit brought against Mr. Cohen, HBO and the British broadcaster Channel 4 by a woman who said Mr. Cohen had used her name in a comedy routine.

Around this time last year, I was preparing for a daunting trip: the Frugal Grand Tour, a three-month jaunt around Europe in which I would follow in the footsteps of the great travelers of the 18th and 19th centuries. From classic destinations (Paris, Rome) to off-the-beaten-track locales (northern Cyprus, Malta) to up-and-coming hot spots (Bucharest, Gdansk), I planned to seek out the roots of Western civilization, have a few good meals and, somehow, not spend a fortune.

Last November, David J. Kahn used circles to paint a picture of a sailboat (Across Lite, Solution, blog.) Today, Daniel A. Finan has us connect the dots in order to see another one. Then, he goes a step further by describing the component parts according to their associated letter names, and finally, he crams the clues with nautical references. Well done.

ST. LOUIS - J.J. Putz loved pitching to Omir Santos in spring training, so count him as someone who was "impressed but not surprised" at how Santos secured the Mets' 1-0 victory Saturday against Milwaukee. With one out in the ninth inning, Santos signaled to Francisco Rodriguez to throw a full-count changeup to J.J. Hardy. As Ryan Braun broke for second, Santos stayed back to frame the pitch - strike three - then, with a quick release, fired to second to catch Braun stealing to end the game.

One small thrill of the editor's sedentary life is improving a sentence by shortening it. Your eye fastens on a word or phrase that is not doing much work. You ask, "Do we need this?" And then you strike. Kill the right words and the rest of the sentence vibrates like a guitar string.

Will the airlines be the next troubled industry to ask for a government bailout? The industry reported major losses this week for the first quarter, eating away at their cash cushions. Further losses are expected for the year. And with most carriers having junk-bond credit ratings, cash won't be that easy to raise in the skittish debt markets.

So the market was greatly reassured when Tim Geithner declared that the "vast majority" of banks are well capitalized. Count me as baffled. I mean, maybe he was actually giving us a hint about the stress tests -- but I took it as a remark that was uninformative at best, ominous at worst.

Updated, 7:48 p.m. | State regulators on Tuesday approved a $523.4 million, one-year increase in Consolidated Edison's rates for delivering electric service. Typical residential customers will see an increase in their monthly bill of about $6 in New York or about $8 in Westchester County. Critics of the utility immediately criticized the decision, saying it would harm economically vulnerable customers as the region struggles through a recession. Con Edison itself said it was "disappointed" by the decision, saying there was not enough money for essential maintenance of the energy infrastructure.In addition to the delivery rate increase, the New York State Public Service Commission also authorized the raising of an additional $198 million through a temporary surcharge on bills to pay for state-mandated assessments, for a total increase of $721 million. In all, the increase on electricity bills will be 6.1 percent across the Con Edison system.

The Chiefs might have hit rock bottom in 2008, but the future looks brighter in the hands of the former Patriots executive Scott Pioli, who takes over for Carl Peterson as the face of the organization (editor's note: some Chiefs fans might say that that face was The Scream.) His next step is to rebuild one of the thinnest rosters in the league. It all starts with the third pick.

In 2007, the conceptual artist Charles Ray installed an 18-ton machined-steel sculpture of a toy tractor at Matthew Marks Gallery in New York. Ray's favorite plaything, however, is his 44-foot sailboat, C-Squared, which he solo-sails out of Marina del Rey, Calif. Ari Marcopoulos, who photographed "Love for Sail," a story about artists and architects and their affinity for the material culture of boats for the spring issue of T Design, went sailing with Ray and the architect Frank Gehry (who sails a Benetau First 44.7 called Foggy), and made a short film (above). Whose boat is faster? Tune in and see.

Rozsival, who had earned high praise along with Wade Redden for their veteran savvy in keeping the Caps' powerful top scorers in check so far in this series, crumbled to the ice, small pools of blood collecting beneath his head. He went off for repairs and it is suspected the stick broke his nose.

With the looming May 15 release of "Angels & Demons," the Tom Hanks and Ron Howard sequel to "The Da Vinci Code," and the news that author Dan Brown will unveil his latest thriller on Sept. 15, Columbia Pictures said it will move as quickly as it can to fast-track the film version of this newest book, "The Lost Symbol."

The city of Miami said Monday it was seeking $200 million in stimulus money to speed up installation in homes and businesses of one million "smart meters" -- devices that permit electricity customers to get much more detailed information about their energy use. Florida Power & Light, the electric company in the area, already has 100,000 in service in Broward County, north of Miami.
