Savannah is one of those places you never want to leave. Maybe it has to do with the easy and well-mannered way locals treat out-of-towners. Or maybe it's because it's a place that strikes a perfect balance: one moment you're munching on barbecue in a backyard rib shack, the next you're at a private dining club surrounded by ladies with pearls and men in coat and tie. On a recent visit - I was speaking at Savannah College of Art and Design's SCAD Style, a six-week-long series of lectures, workshops and exhibitions - I ate and drank my way from one end of the culinary spectrum to the other.

LONDON | The Whitechapel Art Gallery has been exhibiting exciting and influential art in London's East End, for over 100 years, long before the current crop of contemporary artists set up shop in the area. Partially closed since 2007 to undergo a £13.5 million expansion, or $19.7 million at $1.46 to the dollar, the gallery reopened on April 5.

Congress is back from the Easter recess and the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, used his opening speech this morning to voice concerns about the Obama administration's plans to close the detention camp at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

Each year during the run-up to the Derby, turf writers worth their salt submit a weekly Derby top 10 for consideration and debate. Since we are a frenetic society, the American public loves its lists. But we decided there could be more to this ritual. That's why the Paulick Report put together a list of 32 top writers, handicappers and bloggers to create the Paulick Derby Index with a points system styled after the Associated Press and coaches polls of college sports. (10 for a first place vote, 9 for a second place vote, etc.)

In his second full day back from his Latin American travels, President Obama takes on a full Washington schedule -- meeting with King Abdullah of Jordan, receiving his daily economic briefing and, for the second time in two days, greeting prominent athletes (Monday it was Tiger Woods and the president's hometown Chicago White Sox; today he meets the United States Naval Academy football team.)

Today's article about Major League Baseball's authentication program, designed to combat fakes and forgeries in the memorabilia market, explains how and why certain pieces of game-used equipment - baseballs, bats, bases, jerseys, even dirt and sod - are authenticated at each stadium. A ball is used, it is brought to a specially trained (and vetted) authenticator who witnessed its use, and it is marked with a tamper-proof hologram and scanned into a computer system. Decades from now, the idea goes, there will be no debate about the ball's place in baseball history.
BlackRock, the big money manager, said on Tuesday that its first-quarter profit tumbled 56 percent, as the firm suffered from market pressure across a wide variety of its investments.

As the number of charter schools in New York City and elsewhere swells, unions have become increasingly aggressive in trying to organize their teachers. These two major forces in education politics, having long faced off in ideological opposition, have begun in some places to enter tentative and cautious partnerships, and in others to engage in fierce combat. New York City's teachers' union now runs two charter schools in Brooklyn, and workers have organized at many more, including more than a dozen across New York State.

General Motors, at its press conferences at the Shanghai auto show, is trying to prepare its Chinese customers for what a possible bankruptcy in the United States might mean to its ambitious Asian expansion plans. "It is very important to understand that if there is a court-ordered restructuring, it is different from in some other countries," Kevin Wale, president of G.M.'s China Group, told a media gathering. "A company continues to trade and continues its business and can come out of it stronger than before."

The Treasury Department's most ambitious plans to rescue troubled banks - partnerships between the government and private investors, backed by the Federal Reserve - are inherently vulnerable to fraud and should not be started without stronger safeguards, a top government investigator warned in a report to be released Tuesday.

Congressman John Boehner, the Ohio Republican who leads his party in the House, is no fan of the Environmental Protection Agency. Last week, the agency declared that carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases pose a danger to public health, paving the way for regulation of their emission.

New York City's penchant for symbolically renaming streets in honor of beloved community figures is well known. Rarely, however, is a street renamed twice -- for the same person.That is what happened on Monday, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill symbolically renaming 129th Avenue between Merrick Boulevard and 174th Street in St. Albans, Queens, "Poor Freddie's Avenue." That stretch of 129th Avenue was already renamed "Freddie Dill Sr. Avenue" in August 2007, but as Councilman Leroy G. Comrie, who represents the area, notes, "Everyone called him Poor Freddie." The family requested the (latest) renaming as the best way to honor Mr. Dill's legacy, Mr. Comrie said.

Mississippi Coach Andy Kennedy avoided jail time for an altercation with a Cincinnati cab driver by pleading guilty to a reduced charge of disorderly conduct in Hamilton County Municipal Court. Kennedy was sentenced to 40 hours of community service and probation.

The L.P.G.A. Corning Classic, the longest-running event on the women’s tour with the same title sponsor and played at the same venue, in Corning, N.Y., since its inception in 1979, will end in May. Jack Benjamin, the tournament president, said Monday that the board of directors came to the conclusion after six months of discussion. The tournament had an option for 2010, but Benjamin said the loss of more than $500,000 in sponsorship revenue made it unfeasible to sustain it beyond this year in the economic climate.

The Detroit Lions introduced a fiercer-looking logo as they rebrand themselves after an N.F.L.-first 0-16 record last season. With sharper teeth, the Lions’ logo has undergone the most significant change since it was first placed on the team’s helmet in 1961, according to a news release.

A court hearing in Greene County, N.Y., was postponed for Ernie Paragallo, a prominent thoroughbred breeder charged with cruelty after scores of malnourished horses were found on his farm. Paragallo was to appear in Coxsackie Town Court, but a clerk said the hearing was postponed at the request of his lawyer. A new date had not been set.

The comedian Kathy Griffin and the Episcopal bishop of New Hampshire, V. Gene Robinson, were among the top honorees of the Glaad Media Awards, which were presented Saturday night in Los Angeles by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. In a news release Glaad said it had given Ms. Griffin (above, dressed to receive her award), the star of “Kathy Griffin: My Life on the D-List,” its Vanguard Award for work that has “increased the visibility and understanding” of gay people in the media. Mr. Robinson, the openly gay bishop, received the Stephen F. Kolzak Award for “an openly lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender person who has made a significant difference in promoting equal rights.” The Showtime series “The L Word” received special recognition, as did the viral video “Prop 8 — The Musical.” “Desperate Housewives” was named outstanding comedy series and “Milk” was named outstanding wide-release film.
Oprah Winfrey abruptly canceled a Monday broadcast of her talk show that was to focus on the 10th anniversary of the Columbine shootings, The Associated Press reported.
HarperCollins announced that it had acquired worldwide rights to the book, “Harmony,” which will encourage readers “to restore the lost balance between Man and Nature.”

A court in Malawi will hear on May 4 an appeal of a ruling that denied Madonna’s petition to adopt a 3-year-old girl there, a court official told The Associated Press. This month Malawi’s High Court ruled that Madonna could not adopt the girl, Chifundo James, because she had not been a resident of the country for the last 18 months. In 2008 Madonna completed the adoption of her son, David Banda, from Malawi; she also has a daughter, Lourdes, 12, from a previous relationship, and a son, Rocco, 8, from her marriage to Guy Ritchie, whom she divorced in January. The news agency said that her presence would not be required in court. The A.P. also reported that a photographer who took pictures Saturday of Madonna after she fell from a horse in the Hamptons is disputing accounts of the incident. A publicist for Madonna has said she fell when her horse was startled by paparazzi. One photographer, Thomas Hinton, said no photographers startled her horse; he took his own pictures from a public road before and after the incident.

The police in Mumbai said they were investigating accusations that the father of a child actor from the movie “Slumdog Millionaire” tried to offer her for adoption in exchange for money, Reuters reported. On Sunday, News of the World in Britain published the results of a sting operation in which it said Rafiq Qureshi, the father of 9-year-old Rubina Ali Qureshi, right, offered her for adoption for around $290,000 to a member of a wealthy Dubai family — who was actually a reporter for the newspaper. The girl portrayed the young incarnation of the “Slumdog Millionaire” heroine played by Freida Pinto and attended the Academy Awards in February when it won the award for best picture. Moinuddin Qureshi, an uncle of Rubina Ali, denied that her father had tried to sell her, telling Reuters, “This is just an attempt to malign her name.”.

KAPLAN--Arthur S.,M.D., 85, of Norfolk, VA passed away April 14, 2009. He was an outstanding and highly respected physician and community leader for many years in Norfolk and the Tidewater area. He was born March 4, 1924 in Raleigh, NC to Sara and Harry Kaplan. The family moved to High Point, NC where he spent his younger days. Dr. Kaplan was a graduate of the University of North Carolina and New York Medical College. He served as a naval doctor during the Korean Conflict. He began his medical career in Norfolk, VA where he married his wife, Phyllis Berman, 50 years ago. He served as Chairman of the Department of Internal Medicine as well as president of the medical staff at Sentara Norfolk General Hospital. Kaplan was well regarded in philanthropic pursuits in the Jewish and general community of Norfolk. He was a unique individual who found time to maintain a large medical practice while doing great philanthropic work. He was awarded the Humanitarian Award in 1995 by the National Conference of Christians & Jews as well as the distinguished Service Award from the United Jewish Federation of Tidewater. As a physician and philanthropist his life seemed to revolve around a "30 hour day". In past years he became an avid horticulturalist specializing in orchids. Dr. Kaplan lectured widely on orchids and served as president of the Tidewater Orchid Society as well as the Eastern Orchid Congress. His passion culminated in his founding a conservatory for orchids at Old Dominion University where he not only donated his vast orchid collection but led the fundraising efforts and construction for this lasting memorial. Dr. Kaplan is survived by his wife, Phyllis, daughter, Nancy Kaplan and husband George Peabody, son Harvey, brother, Leonard J. Kaplan and wife Tobee, and four grandchildren, Leah, Avi, Katie, and Anna. His son Roger is deceased.

BERGMANN--Peter George, of New York City, on Saturday, April 18, at age 59, after a brief illness. A loving husband to Kay, father to Caroline and Joseph, brother to Steven and Ronald, and son to his late parents, Paul and Therese, and beloved uncle of Rachel, David, Margarette and Paul. For 25 years, Peter was a litigation partner at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, where he built and led the health care/not-for-profit practice group. A tenacious advocate and masterful negotiator, and an advisor of uncommon insight, Peter had more fun practicing law than most people have doing things that actually are fun. Peter was honored to receive the Robert Ray Parks Award from Trinity Church for contributions to the field of gerontology, and the Lillian D. Wald Award from the Visiting Nurse Service of New York for significant contributions to the well-being, health and welfare of New Yorkers. Peter will be remembered for his broad shoulders, joy, generosity and humor, and his unstinting readiness to stand with a client, friend, family or stranger in their most difficult times. We have lost a great soul. Services will be held at 10:30am on Wednesday, April 22, at The Hebrew Tabernacle, 551 Fort Washington Avenue (at 185th Street), in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Fort Tryon Jewish Center, 524 Fort Washington Ave, New York, NY 10033.

A few nights ago Steven Bevacqua, a postproduction supervisor for the television series ''Life,'' was flipping through the May issue of Wired magazine when he thought he started seeing secret messages. Yes, he'd just come home from a long day at work, but then again, the issue was guest-edited by J. J. Abrams, a creator of enigmatic television shows like ''Lost'' and ''Fringe.'' So, as Mr. Bevacqua wrote on his blog, he spent the next several days following the hidden clues he believed he'd found, using Morse code, alternative computer keyboard layouts and even electrician's wiring codes to solve the covert brainteasers. Finally he was directed to a hidden Web site, from which he sent an e-mail message to a secret account. A short while later he learned that he was the first Wired reader to solve an extensive hidden puzzle embedded throughout the magazine.

The Orioles sustained a painful fourth straight loss to the Red Sox, 12-1, on Patriot's Day at Fenway Park, but a scary moment in the third inning left one Oriole with a lump far more real. Diving back into second base on a pickoff attempt, Baltimore's Ryan Freel was hit in the back of the head and neck by a low bullet from Red Sox pitcher Justin Masterson. Freel lay facedown and motionless for two or three long minutes, his legs sprawled as team trainers tended to him.

Even though he is still not officially seated as the new junior senator from Minnesota, Al Franken has begun hiring staff. Mr. Franken, a Democrat who has been locked in an endless recount battle with Norm Coleman, the Republican who held the seat until January, said on Monday that he would hire Alana Petersen, who had been working for Representative James L. Oberstar, as his Minnesota state director. Mr. Franken said the move was needed for whenever (Republicans would say if) his election was certified, so that he could ''hit the ground running.''

Fund-raisers for President Obama's inaugural committee brought in over $53 million, $8 million more than their budget of $45 million, according to a report filed Monday. That total was $11 million more than the previous record of $42.3 million for President George W. Bush's 2005 inauguration. Mr. Obama had already raised a record $750 million for his campaign before soliciting inaugural donations.

A human barricade had been set for Ray Allen, and he maneuvered around it as if he were a sports car on a curving road. By the time a helpless Joakim Noah flailed his arms, Allen knew it was too late. Soon after, a raucous crowd at TD Banknorth Garden did too. Even in a slump, Allen is among the surest of shooters. His 3-pointer with 2.0 seconds remaining Monday night propelled the Celtics to a 118-115 victory over the Chicago Bulls and reignited Boston's hopes of a successful championship defense. Their first-round playoff series is tied at 1-1, and it shifts to Chicago on Thursday for Game 3 of the best-of-seven series.

HABERMANN-Edward T.,M.D. Dr. Edward Townsend Habermann passed away at his home in Chappaqua on April 19, 2009. The cause of death was colon cancer. Dr. Habermann graduated Johns Hopkins University, where he was awarded the Barton's Cup Award for outstanding student. He earned his medical degree from the State University of New York at Syracuse and did an internship at the University of California Medical Center in San Francisco. He later joined the U.S. Navy for two years as a medical officer. Upon discharge, Dr. Habermann did a residency in general and orthopaedic surgery at the Hospital for Joint Diseases in NYC. He became a full time staff member in orthopaedic surgery at Montefiore Medical Center and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in 1966, where he rose to the rank of Chairman and University Professor of Orthopaedic Surgery. During his professional career, Dr. Habermann was a visiting professor at 122 universities and medical centers in the United States and abroad. He retired in 1998 and was given the rank of Chairman Emeritus of the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery and Professor Emeritus of both Orthopaedic Surgery and Radiology at Albert Einstein Medical College. In 1967, Dr. Habermann did a fellowship in hip surgery with Sir John Charnley, the pioneer of hip replacement surgery, at the Wrightington Hospital in England, and became one of the first orthopaedic surgeons in New York to introduce total joint replacement surgery. He also helped design and develop hip and knee replacement prostheses that are now implanted in over two million patients. Dr. Habermann volunteered for medical service in Israel during the 1967 and 1972 Arab-Israeli conflicts and, between 1968 and 1980, spent many weeks each year teaching in Israel, primarily at Hadassah Hospital. Dr. Habermann always loved working with young people, from graduate medical students and residents to students at the grade school and high school levels. He was active in his local community of Chappaqua, serving on the Parks and Recreation Commission and on the New Castle Community Television Board. He volunteered as assistant coach of Horace Greeley's varsity lacrosse and soccer teams. He also was an unofficial "beach doctor" at his summer home in Bridgehampton. Dr. Habermann was a man who loved the sun and he radiated that energy and warmth in every endeavor he chose. His tireless interest in improving lives through medicine, research, teaching, coaching, mentoring and simply living is a lasting lesson he has passed on to the many who were touched by him. Dr. Habermann is survived by his wife, Susan Koehn Habermann, and four children Joshua, Robert, Lauren and Matthew, and a brother, Norman. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Orthopaedic Research and Education Foundation or Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. A memorial service is planned for 5:00pm on Thursday, April 21st at the Whippoorwill Club in Armonk, New York.

FIORE--Frank J.,born in Brooklyn, NY on November 14, 1903, one of nine children born to Antoinette Ingoglia and Vincent James Fiore. Mr. Fiore attended the public schools in New York and began work at 12 years of age delivering newspapers to help support his family. He began his professional career working for various ship lines in the NY area which led to his being assigned to the Port of New Orleans during World War II supervising the loading and shipping of war material from the U.S. to Great Britain. After World War II, Mr. Fiore joined the Textron Corporation as the manager of all overseas shipping operations and later became vice president and general manager of Textron's international sales program and remained with Textron until his retirement in 1960. Thereafter, he engaged in the breeding and racing of thoroughbreds who competed in the New York and Florida circuits. Mr. Fiore was married to Carol Corsi for over 30 years, who predeceased him in 1958. His surviving relatives include his nephew Frank J. Fiore, Jr., niece Ann Gianocci and other nieces and nephews living throughout the U.S. The family would welcome donations in his memory to Queen of Apostles Convent, 98 Harriman Heights Road, Monroe, NY 10950, Attention Sister M. Leonore.

Barack Obama split Bill Clinton and Ted Kennedy apart. Now he is bringing them back together. The current president, the former president and the ailing senator from Massachusetts will meet in the Oval Office on Tuesday and then go to the Seed School in Washington, where Mr. Obama is scheduled to sign the Edward M. Kennedy National Service Act, which creates volunteer opportunities for millions of Americans.

WELLS--Beatrice Chuckrow, of Miami Beach, died on Monday, April 13, 2009 at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. Formerly a teacher in Troy, NY, she received her BS degree from Cornell University and her MA degree from Teachers College, Columbia University. Beatrice was predeceased by her daughters Judith Chuckrow Goetzl and Joyce Chuckrow Nadel. She is survived by grandchildren Aron, Manlio and David Goetzl, and Jennifer Wilson; and great-grandchildren Judith Eve Goetzl, and Benjamin and Kayla Wilson. Memorial contributions may be made to the Beatrice Chuckrow Wells Memorial Fund, c/o Cornell University, P.O. Box 223623, Pittsburgh, PA, 15251.

SHAPIRO--Robert E.,passed away peacefully at home April 19, 2009. He is survived by his beloved and cherished wife, Rita, loving family, daughters Ellen, Carol, Roberta and Patti, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. His kindness, charm, and wisdom touched all whom he met, adding to a legacy of leadership and guidance as the longtime chairman of Presidential Realty Corp. We all loved him very much. Memorial service Wednesday 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment private.

Each day this week in the “Guidance Office,” Ron Lieber, who writes the “Your Money” column for The Times’s business section, is answering selected reader questions related to long-term savings for college (and short-term, too.) You can put a question to him by using the comment box on our original post. The questions below may have been edited for style, and length.

The architect Frank Gehry said he would not create a park to accompany a new performance hall he is designing for the New World Symphony in Miami Beach, and has threatened to withdraw from the project entirely, The Miami Herald reported. Mr. Gehry said that the $10 million construction budget that the city has set aside for the public park, which is to include lighting effects and seating to watch events on a giant screen outside the concert hall, was insufficient, and that city officials have repeatedly overstated his fees for the project. “I’m offended,” Mr. Gehry told The Herald. “If they keep messing with me, if I get insulted enough, I will withdraw completely.” Though Miami city commissioners had said Mr. Gehry’s firm would be paid $4.6 million for the park design, Mr. Gehry said he was receiving $1.9 million. “I’m good and I deserve it,” he said, according to The Herald.

The National Children’s Museum on Wednesday unveiled plans for its building, to be designed by the architectural firm Pelli Clarke Pelli. In a news release, the museum said that the 150,000-square-foot space, at National Harbor in Prince George’s County, Md., would offer several environmentally friendly features including a wind turbine that will supply the building with energy, a sun reflector on the roof to reduce the use of artificial light and a roof system that will absorb rainwater and improve insulation. The museum said that its exhibits, which will highlight the environment, health, play and other subjects, would be created by the design firms Amaze Design, Roto Studio and AldrichPears. The museum is expected to open in 2013 and anticipates 600,000 visitors annually.

The police in Mumbai said they had not found evidence that the father of a child actor from the movie “Slumdog Millionaire” tried to offer her for adoption in exchange for money, Reuters reported. Indian authorities had been investigating whether Rafiq Qureshi, the father of 9-year-old Rubina Ali Qureshi, had tried to offer his daughter for adoption for around $290,000 to reporters from Britain’s News of the World who were posing as a wealthy family from Dubai. The mother of Rubina Ali, who played the young version of the “Slumdog Millionaire” character portrayed by Freida Pinto, had called for the investigation of Mr. Qureshi when News of the World published the results of its sting operation on Sunday. Mr. Qureshi, who lives with his daughter and her stepmother in a Mumbai slum, was questioned by the police and released.

In its fourth week out, the soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) finally reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart. It sold 133,000 copies last week, a 32 percent drop from the week before, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Day26, the group formed on MTV’s “Making the Band 4″ reality show, opened at No. 2 with its second album, “Forever in a Day” (Bad Boy), and last week’s best-seller, Rascal Flatts’s “Unstoppable” (Lyric Street), lost 69 percent of its sales, dropping to No. 3 with 107,000. The “Twilight” soundtrack (Atlantic) rose four spots to No. 4 with 49,000 sales, and “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 30 holds at No. 5, with 45,000. The Los Angeles indie-rock band Silversun Pickups reached No. 7 with their second album, “Swoon” (Dangerbird), with 43,000 sales.

Peter Kaplan, the editor of The New York Observer, announced his resignation on Wednesday and said he would be leaving the weekly in June. For the past 15 years, Mr. Kaplan has used tart headlines and a broad mix of news articles to create a kind of contemporary municipal history of New York demimondes high and sometimes low. The newspaper let those in the know know what else they should know about.

Ten years after it became a television phenomenon — and a few months after a movie that used it as a theme won the Academy Award for best picture — the game show “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” will return to ABC this summer for a two-week tournament, with Regis Philbin again as host. ABC announced Wednesday that “Millionaire” will return on Aug. 9, at 8 p.m. and will play on five consecutive nights that week and the following week. The finale will be broadcast on Aug. 23. “Millionaire” emerged as a hit show after its premiere in August 1999 and for the next three years various weeknight versions of it show ranked as the top-rated prime-time shows on television. “Millionaire” led ABC to the top of the network ratings that season. At its height, “Millionaire” was attracting about 29 million viewers. But ABC became heavily reliant on the show, running it as many as four times a week. By the end of 2001 its audience had dropped to 10 million viewers and ABC removed it from its schedule a year later. But the show has continued in syndication, and has been successful in other countries, especially where it has played as a once or twice a year tournament. Interest was also revived by the success of the film “Slumdog Millionaire,” which depicted the Indian version of the game show.

Marc F. Wilson, the director of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., announced Wednesday that he planned to retire from the position. In a release, the museum said that Mr. Wilson would end his tenure as director on June 1, 2010, and that its trustees had begun seeking his successor. Mr. Wilson, who came to the museum as its director in 1982 (after having studied there from 1967 to 1969 on a grant from the Ford Foundation), oversaw numerous acquisitions and expansions. In 2005, the museum opened its Ford Learning Center, followed in 2006 by the renovation of its Kansas City Sculpture Park. In 2007, the museum opened the Bloch Building, a crystalline counterpart to its main Beaux-Arts building, which was designed by the architect Steven Holl and which Nicolai Ouroussoff wrote was “breathtaking” and “a work of haunting power” in a review for The New York Times.

The Tribeca Film Festival starts Wednesday with the opening-night screening of Woody Allen’s “Whatever Works,” starring Larry David and Evan Rachel Wood. Below is a look at that film and some of the other offerings of the festival, which runs through May 2.

The New School acknowledged on Wednesday that the university had poorly handled the faculty changes for its Parsons fine-arts program. “We should have personally engaged the faculty about these pending changes,” said Tim Marshall, the Provost of The New School, in a public statement. “I want to offer my sincere apologies for these shortcomings and the discord it has caused.”
What we’re reading (and watching) on Wednesday morning.

Paavo Järvi, the conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, pleaded no contest on Tuesday to a charge of operating a vehicle while intoxicated, the Web site of The Kentucky Post, kypost.com, reported. Mr. Jarvi was arrested on the morning of March 19 when the police found him asleep at the wheel of his car at an intersection in Fairfax, Ohio. The police said that classical music was blaring from his car stereo and that he refused to take a breath test and failed a sobriety test. Mr. Jarvi was sentenced to six months probation and ordered to spend three days in a driver’s intervention program, and his driver’s license was suspended for six months. In a statement the orchestra said that it was satisfied that the matter had been resolved, and that its concert schedule has not been affected.

The Dutch bank ABN Amro has sued a financier who used a 17th-century painting as collateral for a loan from the bank, despite having offered the work as collateral for a separate loan from JPMorgan Chase, Agence France-Presse reported. A spokesman for ABN Amro said it would ask a district court in Amsterdam to determine the ownership of the work, “The Bend in the Herengracht,” by the Dutch painter Gerrit Berckheyde, which the financier Louis Reijtenbagh used to secure an undisclosed loan from the bank. Earlier this month, JPMorgan filed a claim on the work, saying that Mr. Reijtenbagh owed it more than $23 million in unpaid loans. The painting was acquired from Mr. Reijtenbagh by the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam in September, and is currently on loan to the National Gallery of Art in Washington until May 3.

In Britain, the Independent Police Complaints Commission, or I.P.C.C., which is investigating the death of a man during a protest against the Group of 20 summit earlier this month in London, has failed to prevent the broadcast of a video report by Channel 4 News, which shows him standing placidly, with his hands in his pockets, moments before he was struck and thrown to the ground by a police officer.

Sorry if my upbeat headline offends. I know this is normally a day for bemoaning our species' effect on the planet. But I want to follow up my Findings column on Kuznets curves with an upbeat illustration of the "decarbonization" trend measured by Jesse Ausubel and Paul Waggoner. This chart show the steady decline since 1850 in the amount of carbon emitted per unit of energy used as people around the world switch have switched to more efficient and less carbon-intensive sources of energy -- from wood to coal and oil, and then to natural gas and nuclear.
A bidding war has erupted for the remnants of Bernard L. Madoff's trading operation, once one of the largest market makers on the Nasdaq Stock Market.
On Tuesday, Google announced that it had started displaying Google profile results on name queries to help give users more control over their Google identity.

The observance of Earth Day in New York City included all sorts of ceremonies and events, many of them symbolic. At the Wildlife Conservation Society, local artists used recycled materials to create large-scale sculptures of endangered animals. The Empire State Building prepared to turn off its historic exterior lights to save energy.In Times Square, the actor Matthew Modine was on hand as an "Earth Ball" was lighted and dropped. In Greenwich Village, New York University celebrated Earth Day with a street fair featuring "eco-vendors" and performers.

BERLIN | More than a decade ago, Berlin launched what would become a cultural sensation: the Long Night of Museums, in which the city's museums stay open late twice a year. The nights have been such a rousing success that the plan has been copied in 120 cities.

The current exhibition at San Francisco's Fraenkel Gallery, "Edward Hopper & Company," examines the celebrated American painter's work and its influence on photography. Although the curator Jeffrey Fraenkel writes in the show's catalog that Hopper had an impact on a wide range of photographers, in the show he selects just eight: Robert Adams, Diane Arbus, Harry Callahan, William Eggleston, Walker Evans, Robert Frank, Lee Friedlander and Stephen Shore. Displayed alongside their work is a small but diverse selection of Hopper's paintings and drawings that cover many of the artist's central themes of isolation and contemplation. The architectural cityscapes and rural landscapes are unadorned and unpretentious, perfect complements and, in most cases, antecedents to the matter-of-fact photography on view. Shore's near-dusk view of a movie theater and Adams's austere house on Interstate 25 are quite possibly the photographic equivalents of the painter's "New York Corner" and "Lombard's House." And in the work of Arbus, Frank and Friedlander, you can see the another frequent Hopper subject: the solitary, forlorn figure. On display until May 2.Scott Hall is the photography editor of T: The New York Times Style Magazine.

Mike Smith takes us along for a ride aboard Zenyatta. Thanks to Rhonda L at the Horsey Set Net for posting on her blog, which was tipped by a tweet from @raceday360. The video is seven minutes, but the last couple are the best.

Update | 6:37 p.m. General Motors will very likely forgo making a $1 billion bond payment due June 1, opting instead to begin a debt-exchange offer by then, a spokesman for the carmaker said in a statement on Wednesday.

Lung cancer is the biggest cancer killer in the country, killing more than 160,000 people a year. Yet the disease remains low on the list of cancer funding priorities. In 2006, the National Cancer Institute spent $1,518 for each new case of lung cancer and $1,630 for each lung cancer death. By comparison, the agency spent $13,452 per death on breast cancer, which takes 41,000 lives annually.
Afshin Ghotbi is a man of the world in the world's game.

The medium has never been more the message than it is now, with all of those digital billboards turning street corners around Los Angeles into miniature Times Squares. In new twist to be unveiled on Friday, Clear Channel will use time on 86 of its L.A. billboards not to advertise entertainment, but to be the entertainment.
Helen Davis Chaitman, a lawyer and an investor with Bernard L. Madoff, offers this view of the Securities and Exchange Commission's handling of the Madoff case.

Growing up in Kew Gardens, Queens, in the 1940s and '50s, the children of Jewish refugees from Central Europe did not always feel distinctive. Attending summer camps and public schools, and going on in many cases to remarkably successful careers, they quickly assimilated into the postwar American ideal. Yet they shared, in many instances, a certain sense of unease, or even guilt -- a legacy of their identity as children of Holocaust survivors.

A Hong Kong appeals court blocked a plan Wednesday to privatize the territory's biggest phone company, PCCW, dealing a stunning setback to the company's chairman, Richard Li, and handing a major victory to Hong Kong's increasingly assertive regulatory authorities, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener reported.
The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that police officers may not search a suspect's vehicle after an arrest is made unless it is to protect the officer or evidence.

Yes, Twitter is overhyped. Just today, The New York Times had articles in the Dining section, on the Op-Ed page, and on our sister Bits blog. BAGHDAD-- This is Mohammed Ashah Jalal. He is 36 years old and from Rajshahi in Bangladesh. He left his family behind in order to work in a bakery in Baghdad. He earns about $250 per month, roughly twice as much as he would earn doing the same kind of work in his home country. He shares a cramped room with five companions and the men never venture far from their place.

The Pixar Blog, considered the definitive unofficial chronicler of the animation powerhouse, reports that work is finally under way on a studio expansion. Citing documents filed with Emeryville, Calif., the East Bay community that is the studio's home, the Pixar Blog says the four-level building will carry an initial price tag of $15 million for "preliminary material and equipment." That figure doesn't include labor costs, typically the largest part of construction projects of this nature.

With "The Biggest Loser" garnering its best ratings in almost three months, NBC earned a strong second place finish on Tuesday night, at least in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen's estimates. The audience for the NBC weight loss show grew by more than 2.5 million viewers over the course of its two-hour broadcast, averaging 9.3 million total viewers from 8 to 10 p.m.

The nation's 19 largest banks are anxiously awaiting the results of the government's "stress tests." Many of the assumptions underlying the tests remain secret, but some figures reported Wednesday in The Wall Street Journal are sounding alarm bells for at least a few bank watchers.

Early this week most of the Derby contenders put in their second-to-last workout before the Derby. With the possible exception of Friesan Fire, these horses are all fit at this stage, coming off recent outings. And Friesan Fire's workout was longer to help add more base to his conditioning. This Sunday's Keeping Score column on Jackie Robinson's attempted steals of home prompted a flood of reader responses, most of them taking the piece to task for failing to incorporate three key factors into its analysis: the identity of the batter at the plate, the game situation (inning and score), and the potential disruptive effect that Robinson's threat to steal home may have had on opposing pitchers. I'm a big fan of mezcal, a relative of tequila that is even more underrated than its more-famous agave cousin. So I was delighted not only to read Dan Saltzstein's excellent article in today's Dining section on the uptick in mezcal awareness, but also to learn that a mezcal and tequila bar has just opened in the East Village.

MILAN - Tuesday was the press-preview day for Milan's design week: all the exhibitors who show outside the actual fairgrounds give journalists a sneak peek at their new products. And we covered a lot of ground: from A (Armani Casa, which is unveiling its new kitchen with Dada) to Z (Nika Zupanc, a young Slovenian designer who is showing at Superstudio). There was everything from high-tech (Established & Sons' Flatliner L.E.D. light by Jason Bruges Studio) to crafty (Patricia Urquiola's Crinoline outdoor chair with a draped cover of crocheted natural rope for B&B Italia), but some of the day's standouts also exhibited a spirit of play.

The producers of "The Hills" are in negotiations for another season, The Associated Press reports. The fifth season of the series -- one of MTV's most popular -- made its debut earlier this month. Lauren Conrad, the heart of the show, has indicated that the current season will be her last. She is busy designing a new clothing line for Kohl's.

When a Texas internal medicine physician began a consensual romantic relationship with one of his patients, the state medical board meted out a $10,000 fine and 10 hours of ethics education as a punishment for professional misconduct.

BEIJING | There are few places in Beijing that epitomize China's new wealth more than the Lan Club. Opened by Zhang Lan, a restaurant chain owner, the enormous club/bar/restaurant is an emblem of the opulence, wealth and decadence of China's nouveau riche - and I mean that in the broadest terms; regulars at this restaurant include non-Chinese expatriates who have made their fortunes in China, as well as local Chinese.

Amid a widening investigation into possible kickbacks involving New York's pension fund, Thomas P. DiNapoli, the state's comptroller, has announced a ban on placement agents being involved in the fund's investments.

Rod R. Blagojevich, ousted governor of Illinois, wanted to travel to a Costa Rican jungle to take part in the taping of the forthcoming NBC reality show "I'm a Celebrity ... Get Me Out of Here!" But a federal judge rejected Mr. Blagojevich's request to leave the country, Monica Davey reports. Mr. Blagojevich is awaiting trial in a corruption case.

In the middle of this market chaos, several high-profile lawyers who became bankers during the boom years have gone back to Big Law. Investment Dealers' Digest looks at some prominent examples, but suggests they probably aren't a sign of a mass migration.

Lance Bouma's goal late in the third period gave the Vancouver Giants a 3-2 victory over the Kelowna Rockets in Game 3 of their Western Hockey League Western Conference final but it was the goaltending of the Giants' Tyson Sexsmith that provided the opportunity for Bouma's heroics. Sexsmith was a target for much of the game, with the Rockets' Ryley Grantham knocking him to the ice behind the Vancouver net late in the second period.

There is bread, there is quickbread, and then there is flatbread, the subject of this week's Minimalist column. It's simpler than its relatives and, if no quicker than quickbread, way more interesting. At its most basic, it's somewhere between cracker and pizza, crisp and thin, and, when made with whole wheat, interesting.
What we're looking at on the Web today ...

Tom Cruise has almost single-handedly propped up the script-doctoring business, Variety writes, as he has circled a half-dozen potential projects in search of his next starring role. Writers like Scott Frank, Richard Curtis and Paul Attanasio have been making as much as $250,000 a week, for anywhere from two to six weeks, to rewrite existing scripts to the persnickety star's specifications, all in the hopes that Mr. Cruise will choose that project over the others. At the moment, Variety says, the leading contenders are "Motorcade," a thriller involving a presidential procession, "The Tourist," another thriller about an American abroad who gets mixed up with Interpol agents (including Charlize Theron) and "Wichita," a romantic comedy about an undercover agent and a woman (Cameron Diaz) who has trouble with the men in her life. Also in the mix is "The Matarese Circle," based on the Robert Ludlum novel, about a pair of spies, a project that would team Mr. Cruise with Denzel Washington. An older post here on Slashfilm includes more details about the competing projects.

I'm sure some of you have seen the profile in May Vogue of Steven Meisel. If not, I encourage everyone to read it. Jonathan Van Meter, the writer of the piece, spends too much time at the start discussing Meisel's reclusive nature. Ultimately it doesn't matter if he is shy or mysterious or a chameleon; he has become an influential photographer with specific ideas about the work. I've done a couple of interviews with Meisel over the past decade and a half, and, as Van Meter notes, he is actually very forthcoming. What I like most about this profile are the details about Meisel's family, especially his parents, and how he started his career. Already a fashion illustrator at Women's Wear, he met Valerie Cates, the sister of Phoebe Cates, while she was shopping, and began taking pictures of the sisters on weekends. Then he was asked by Elite to take test shots of new models. He did the hair, makeup and styling himself, he told Van Meter. "I didn't know any different," he said. Anyway, there's a lot of fascinating stuff here-about Meisel, New York, and of course the supers. The profile features a self-portrait taken in a barber shop in the West Village, with Meisel surrounded by the models whose careers he helped launch. The issue, timed for the opening of the Costume Institute's "The Model as Muse" exhibit in early May, also includes an interesting piece (by Hamish Bowles) about Marc Jacobs.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Remember those Somali pirates, those crazy guys that are hijacking boats and stuff? They got one of them here in New York City standing trial. And I want to tell you something, this guy thinks he's a pirate. Well, wait until he gets the bill for his New York legal team. Then we'll see who the pirate is. That's what I say.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: A journalist from Playboy magazine attempted to withstand 15 seconds of waterboarding. And he's going to write all about it in an article that no one will ever read.

Here's a quick post to direct you to a couple of my stories today. One is on Afghanistan, where -- after decades of false starts -- officials have announced the formal establishment of the country's first national park, Band-e-Amir, which encompasses a series of spectacular lakes. I've written before about how areas depopulated by conflict sometimes shield environmental assets from damage. But it seems rare to see a country focus on environmental conservation when it's still dealing with violence and instability. Do you know of other examples?

Each side gets to pick a topic, so the first hour will be centered on the international banking crisis. The second hour will be dedicated to Nascar trivia.

Public television may be nonprofit and government-sponsored, but it has many of the same problems as commercial broadcasters when it comes to the Web. More and more viewers want to watch "Nova," "Frontline" and "Antiques Roadshow" online, but the public broadcasters worry that that if everything were available on the Internet, they could lose some of their traditional sources of financing: corporate sponsors, viewer donations and DVD sales.

It's hard to get cynical about the simple act of cleaning up. That's particularly true when you see what this little vest-pocket beach on the upriver side of Little Stony Point, just north of Cold Spring, N.Y., along the Hudson River, looked like before and after volunteers scoured for flotsam on Sunday. The Hudson, vastly cleaner than it was three decades ago, is still a conduit for trash washing down storm drains. The preservation of the point itself -- once a depot for a gravel mine -- grew out of a lot of little acts. Now the point is a great place to find the latest addition to the National Toy Hall of Fame.

Julie Foudy played 271 times for the United States women's national team from 1987-2004. She appeared in four World Cups (as the U.S. won in 1991 and 1999) and three Olympics (winning a gold medals in 1996 and 2004, and a silver medal in 2000). Now married (to Ian Sawyers, coach of Sky Blue F.C. of Women's Professional Soccer), Foudy is the mother of two. Here she selects the best of the best female soccer players, some she has played with, some against.

Though it came as no surprise to investors, the collapse of General Growth Properties, the nation's second-largest mall owner, has stirred new fears about a coming debacle in commercial real estate, The New York Times's Terry Pristin writes. The company, which owns 200 shopping centers encompassing 200 million square feet and 24,000 tenants, filed for bankruptcy protection last week.

While the necropsies on the 21 polo horses that died this week continued, the Florida authorities opened a criminal probe to determine whether the deaths were intentional, a result of negligence or simply a terrible accident. State officials have said they believe the horses died from an adverse drug reaction, toxins in their food or supplements, or some combination. Two days after the horses’ deaths, the authorities said they had not uncovered any crime but would continue to investigate. The necropsies were completed Tuesday and revealed some bleeding but offered no definitive clues. The veterinary investigators said the results from the testing of blood and tissue for toxins would be more important in pinpointing a cause of death, but those could take weeks.

The American Kara Goucher felt so good after finishing third in the Boston Marathon that she wanted to run in the London Marathon this Sunday. But her coach, Alberto Salazar, has rejected those plans. The races on back-to-back weekends would have been unprecedented for a top runner after a top finish. But the slow pace in Boston, along with the expectation of a long layoff — Goucher is going to try to start a family — left Goucher wanting a quick turnaround. She was serious enough that Salazar called in other top coaches to see if it was possible to run a second marathon six days after the first and still have a chance to win.

Dale Earnhardt Jr. and Casey Mears were penalized for intentionally bumping cars after a race Saturday at Phoenix International Raceway. Nascar put the two on probation for six races; neither was fined or lost points. Contact between the two caused Earnhardt to crash with 11 laps to go in the race. He led for 63 laps and appeared headed for a top-10 finish, but the accident dropped him to 31st. After the race, Earnhardt spun Mears on the cool-down lap. Mears retaliated by passing several cars on pit road to find Earnhardt, then bumping into the back of his car.

Ricky Rubio, an 18-year-old from Spain, has decided to enter the N.B.A. draft. Rubio, a 6-foot-2 point guard, has been rated as one of the top picks. He was under contract with the Spanish club DKV Joventut through 2011, but has a $7.8 million buyout clause. Rubio was part of the Spanish team that won the silver medal at the Beijing Olympics. He is averaging 9.9 points and 5.7 assists for Joventut. Rubio turns 19 in October, meeting the N.B.A.’s minimum age requirement.

The United States lost to Switzerland, 5-2, in its final warm-up before the World Championships in Kloten, Switzerland. The 16-nation tournament begins Friday. The United States opens play Saturday against Latvia in Group C, which also includes Sweden and Austria. The Americans adapted well in the first period to the larger rink used in international play, taking a 2-0 lead on a two-man advantage and while short-handed. But the undermanned American team, which has practiced once since landing in Europe, dressed only 18 players compared with 23 for the Swiss.

Commissioner Roger Goodell said Michael Vick had paid a significant price for his “egregious mistake” and would have to show genuine remorse and that the experience had changed him to have a chance to resume his career in the league. Goodell appeared at Washington & Lee University, engaging in a panel discussion about leadership in sports and taking questions from the audience. Vick is serving a 23-month prison term after his conviction in a federal dogfighting case and has a team of lawyers trying to settle his finances in bankruptcy court. ¶Southern California Coach Pete Carroll said on his Web site that the sophomore Aaron Corp would be the Trojans’ starting quarterback through the summer and into fall camp. Corp will start Saturday’s scrimmage, with the freshman Matt Barkley as his backup and the junior Mitch Mustain as the No. 3. Carroll said Corp’s starting status was not final. trojans.

Gone are Torry Holt and Orlando Pace, the last ties to the Super Bowl champions of 1999, closing the book on those successful and entertaining teams under former coaches Dick Vermeil and Mike Martz. So what now? Offensive line is one place to start, but there is a lot of work to be done. The former Giants defensive coordinator Steve Spagnuolo has inherited a difficult task.

An obituary on April 14 about Mark Fidrych, an eccentric pitcher who was known as the Bird and who starred briefly for the Detroit Tigers in the 1970s, misstated the timing of the diagnosis of an injury to his rotator cuff. He had surgery in 1985; the injury did not remain undiagnosed until 1986.

A picture caption on Tuesday with a dance review of “The Great Mass,” performed by the Rioult company at the Joyce Theater, misidentified one dancer shown and misspelled the surname of another. The dancer in the middle is Robert Robinson — not Michael Spencer Phillips, another member of the company. The dancer on the left is Jane Sato, not Soto.

The DealBook column on Tuesday, about accounting changes at large banks that had the effect of improving their quarterly earnings reports, misidentified a professor who was critical of the accounting moves. He is Sydney Finkelstein, the Steven Roth professor of management at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth — not Steven Roth.
President Obama left open the door to creating a commission to investigate the Bush administration’s use of harsh interrogation techniques.

An article on Tuesday about Clear Channel Communications’ efforts to restructure its debt misstated the purpose of an exchange of $2.3 billion of its bonds. That action, announced in a regulatory filing, is a routine bond exchange; it is not related to the debt restructuring.

An article on Tuesday about a speech that disparaged Israel, made by the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, at a United Nations conference on racism in Geneva, quoted incorrectly in some editions from his comment about the creation of Israel. He said, “Following World War II they resorted to military aggressions to make an entire nation homeless under the pretext of Jewish suffering.” He did not say “under the pretext of Nazi suffering.”.

An article on April 1 about Patricia Jinich, who taught a class in Washington, D.C., on cooking a Mexican Seder, referred incorrectly to Polanco, her grandparents’ neighborhood in Mexico City. The name Polanco has been associated with the area since at least the late 18th century; it was not derived from the Polish Jews (“Polaco” is Spanish for “Polish”) who settled there in the 20th century.

Lincoln Center has announced the lineup for its annual Midsummer Night Swing events, which will take place on Tuesday through Saturday evenings from July 7 through 25 at Damrosch Park, at West 62nd Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues. Highlights include performances by Chubby Checker, above (scheduled for July 8); the Argentine electro-tango group Otros Aires (July 15) and the New Orleans music revue Ponderosa Stomp (July 16 and 17). More details can be found at MidsummerNightSwing.org. ...Carnegie Hall said that the mezzo-soprano Angelika Kirchschlager had canceled her recital scheduled for Thursday in Zankel Hall because of illness. Like a bear rousing from hibernation, the summer rock-music circuit is slowly returning to life. Green Day announced that it would start its first North American tour in three years on July 3 in Seattle. The band, whose lead vocalist is Billie Joe Amstrong, right, said it would perform shows in more than 30 American and Canadian cities, including dates in Hartford on July 24 and in New York on July 27, with its final stop scheduled for Aug. 25 in Los Angeles. Sites for the concerts have not been announced. ... Also, the annual Lollapalooza festival, scheduled to take place this year Aug. 7 through 9 at Grant Park in Chicago, announced its complete lineup. Performers include Depeche Mode, Beastie Boys, Tool, Lou Reed, Kings of Leon, Snoop Dogg, Andrew Bird, TV on the Radio, and the Decemberists, as well as the reunited Jane’s Addiction, the band led by the Lollapalooza founder Perry Farrell. A complete lineup can be found at lollapalooza.com.

FLATBREAD often involves no leavening, no waiting, barely any mixing -- hardly, for that matter, any ingredients. In its purest form, flatbread is ground grain mixed with water and, usually, salt. The next most popular addition is fat: oil or butter. For a simple flatbread, for example, take one part whole wheat flour (let's say a cup), combine it with just a bit more water (about 1 1/4 cups, usually, though it varies with the moisture content of the air and therefore the flour) and a large pinch of salt. Place enough olive oil (say, a couple of tablespoons) in a large skillet, then pour the batter in and bake it in a hot oven until firm and lightly browned.

8 P.M. (13, 49) BLACKBEARD'S LOST SHIP At the height of his reign of terror over colonial American waters, Edward Teach, a k a Blackbeard, commanded a fleet of four ships and 400 men. (Above, a portrait of him from ''The General History of the Pyrates'' by Capt. Charles Johnson.) In 1717 he even blockaded the city of Charleston, S.C., crippling its economy. A posse from the Royal Navy eventually captured and beheaded him. This season premiere of ''Secrets of the Dead'' follows marine archaeologists as they analyze the remains of Blackbeard's flagship, Queen Anne's Revenge, which sank off the North Carolina coast in 1718 with the treasure of at least 18 other vessels. Was the sinking an accident, or had Blackbeard plotted to cheat his men of their share of the plunder? 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Jennifer Lopez and Brooke Shields are guests; contortionists from Cirque du Soleil perform.

STELZER--Jay Joseph, age 62 of Boca Raton died on April 20, 2009 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Jay was a true fighter and was loved by so many. He showed us all how to do this and will be greatly missed. He is survived by his loving wife of 38 years, Bonnie, his wonderful sons Howard (Ashley) and Craig, his brother Ronald (Elaine), his sister Rosalind (Brett), his Uncle Isadore, sister-in-law Marcia (Marty), brother-in-law Stu, his nieces, nephews, cousins and countless friends and relatives. He will be remembered by the many people who knew and respected him in the travel and advertising industry. He was one of a kind!! Donations can be made in his honor to the American Cancer Society.

If we lost many at once by moving to a far-off location, it would just be devastating.'' Left, pieces are being readied for plating. Right, brass shavings are kept in a barrel for recycling. WACHS--Bernice, 84, for over 47 years the devoted wife of Irving, beloved and dedicated mother of Dahlia and Michael, mother-in-law to Rachel and Keith and adored grandmother of Amelia, Elizabeth, Emily, Ethan, Jeremy, Sabrina and Samantha. The youngest of five siblings, Bernice put herself through school, earned a Bachelor's and Master's Degree from Columbia University. She became a teacher, selflessly giving to others, as she did throughout her life for family and friends. Her courage in fighting and beating ovarian cancer 14 years ago was an inspiration. The graceful but determined manner she fought a second cancer more than ten years later was an example to all. Her passion for family, from doting over her children growing up to nursing Irving back to health after he suffered a stroke, will remain part of her legacy. Funeral services were held Sunday, April 19th at 1pm at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th St. Contributions to: www.caringforcarcinoid.org.

HABERMANN--Edward T.,M.D. The members and board of the Einstein-Montefiore Orthopaedic Alumni Association mourn the passing of Edward T. Habermann, Chairman Emeritus of the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery of the Montefiore Medical Center. A devoted teacher, clinician, and innovator, he was interested in joint replacement, arthritis, and treatment of bone tumors. He was also a social innovator, removing the barrier for women entering into orthopaedic training programs. Teacher, colleague, and friend of the many Residents whom he trained, he was an important influence in their lives and will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathies and condolences to his wife, Susan, and entire family. David M. Hirsh M.D., President
BALL--Jerome E. Dear Jerry, One year has passed since you left us. You will always be in our hearts and souls. Love, Renee, Michelle, Steven, Randi, Samantha, Isabella, Jonah and Theo

ZAGNI--Tosca, aged 94, died peacefully at home on March 21, 2009. Tosca excelled at many professions during her lifetime. Finally, in 1960 she became the Associate Chief Painting Conservator at the Museum of Modern Art in NYC, where she shared her creative skills and expertise with colleagues and student interns. In 1982, Tosca retired and moved to New Hartford, CT, to enjoy the studio home where she and conservator partner J. Volkmer lived. In their kitchen Tosca's culinary masterpieces nourished family and friends. Tosca's loving personality endeared her to all, including the compassionate nurses and aids from the Foothills Hospice, who cared for her at the end. She was aware of their concern for her, and appreciated it. Tosca wanted no formal memorial. However, those close to her know that any donation made in her name to the Foothills Hospice would please her: Foothills Visiting Nurse and Home Care, Inc., 32 Union Street, Winsted, CT 06098. Montano-Shea Funeral Home, 5 Steele Road, New Hartford, CT has care of the arrangements. Visit an online guestbook at www.montano-shea.com.

SHAPIRO--Jacob Aron (October 24, 1982), of Leonia, NJ, died in a tragic automobile accident Friday, April 17th in St. Helena, CA. He was the beloved son of Catherine and Jonathan Shapiro, the younger brother of Joshua and Jeremy, sister-in-law of Amy, uncle to Benjamin, grandson of Samuel L. Shapiro, nephew to many aunts and uncles and cousin to Nicholas, Matthew and Rachel. He was also beloved by a worldwide network of close, enduring and extraordinary friends. He was a graduate of the Fieldston School, Class of 2001 and Hamilton College, Class of 2005, where he was an economics major and an All-Conference soccer player. Since January 2009, he was a student at the Culinary Institute of America at Greystone. Jacob had an insatiable appetite and gusto for life. He traveled the world with an almost unimaginable enthusiasm and joy. He was an accomplished and skilled athlete and voracious dancer. He had a smile with wattage. He loved and was loved. A star who shown brightly, Jacob's memory will be carried in many, many hearts. Contributions to the Following Your Dream Scholarship made payable the CIA Scholarship Fund in memory of Jacob Shapiro can be sent to the Culinary Institute of America at Greystone, 2555 Main Street, St. Helena, CA 94574.

PICKETT--Linda, 82. Daughter of Jamaican immigrants Passmore and Agnes Lindsay. Born 1926 in Manhattan and raised in the Bronx with her siblings Edsel, John, Lloyd and Martha. Married Alfred Pickett in 1947 and became a Harlem resident while working and raising her family. As a working mom, she held several jobs highlighted by a 20 year career at the W.T. Grant Foundation primarily as a Program Officer. Linda and Al became Roosevelt Island pioneers in 1975 where they were actively involved in a variety of activities. They also began their worldwide travels together. Beginning in 1990 Linda spent her retirement years as a passionate world traveler, active volunteer for many organizations, avid reader - book club member, a loyal arts supporter and generous philanthropist while still enjoying her Roosevelt Island home. Linda passed away peacefully at home on March 24, 2009 after a courageous and heartfelt battle with pancreatic cancer. Linda is survived by her sister Martha Dunlap, brothers Edsel and Lloyed Lindsay, son Steve along with many nephews and nieces, godchildren, dear friends, associates and neighbors. Please join the family in Celebrating Linda's almost 83 years of vibrant, loving and benevolent life. In lieu of flowers or gifts, please take a moment to remember Linda's smile and spirit during her time with you.

The program began with Central Intelligence Agency leaders in the grip of an alluring idea: They could get tough in terrorist interrogations without risking legal trouble by adopting a set of methods used on Americans during military training. How could that be torture? In a series of high-level meetings in 2002, without a single dissent from cabinet members or lawmakers, the United States for the first time officially embraced the brutal methods of interrogation it had always condemned.

REID--Whitelaw. The Fresh Air Fund and its Board of Directors are saddened by the passing of Whitelaw Reid, Life Director of The Fresh Air Fund, cherished friend and long-time supporter. For many years, Mr. Reid had been president of The Herald Tribune's Fresh Air Fund. Since 1877, The Fresh Air Fund has provided over 1.7 million inner-city children with summer experiences in the country. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Whitey's entire family, who has a long-standing tradition of support for The Fresh Air Fund. His son, Brandon Reid, is a valued member of our Board of Directors. Whitey's deep commitment to The Fresh Air Fund has made a lasting impact on the lives of countless young New Yorkers. He will be remembered as a warm-hearted man of great intellect and will be deeply missed by all. Mrs. Susan Newhouse, Chair of The Fresh Air Fund Jenny Morgenthau, Executive Dir. of The Fresh Air Fund

PAUL LIEBRANDT wants the world to know that he is not leaving New York. Ever. Mr. Liebrandt, hulking yet baby-faced, is the chef at Corton in TriBeCa, one of the most gastronomically ambitious and pleasurable new restaurants to open in the city in years. Ten years ago, he arrived to begin an on-and-off relationship with New York's diners, filled with misunderstandings, reunions and provocations. At Corton, Mr. Liebrandt has found a refined, reformed cooking style and made a mutually nourishing commitment to his adopted city.

TAYLOR--Mark, 70, Professor of English at Manhattan College and leading Shakespearean scholar, died April 14th of a brain aneurysm. He grew up in North Tarrytown, graduated from Yale, and earned a Ph.D. from the Graduate Center, CUNY. Mourned by his wife of 46 years, Professor Anya Taylor; sons, Andrew (Kristin) and Nicholas; and five grandchildren. Remembered by generations of students from Manhattan College, where he was known for 40 years as a fiercely intelligent, witty, and dedicated teacher. Author of The Soul in Paraphrase (1974), a study of the poet George Herbert; Shakespeare's Darker Purpose: A Question of Incest (1982); and Shakespeare's Imitations (2002), a Choice Outstanding Academic Title (2003). Memorial service May 9th, 3pm, Manhattan College. Contributions may be sent to the Mark Taylor Memorial Fund, Office of Planned Giving, Manhattan College, Bronx, NY 10471.

ABC dominated the ratings on Monday night, as 20.3 million viewers tuned in to ''Dancing With the Stars,'' according to Nielsen's estimates. The reality competition easily earned the largest audience in prime time. Fox edged past CBS for second place with ''Bones'' (8.4 million) and ''24'' (10.3 million). CBS was a close third despite a lineup of mostly repeats, while NBC finished a distant fourth with ''Chuck'' (6 million), ''Heroes'' (6.4 million) and ''Medium'' (7.4 million). On Friday the cable channel Nickelodeon came within striking distance of the broadcast networks with a ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' episode guest starring Johnny Depp. The show delivered 5.8 million viewers.

BERGMANN--Peter. The Board of Trustees, Trustees Emeritus, Management, Staff and Residents of The Osborn Retirement Community in Rye, NY extend their deepest condolences to the family of our dear friend Peter G. Bergmann. As our counsel for the past two decades, Peter was a trusted adviser and tireless advocate for our residents, working to ensure that they and their quality of life were well-served and secure. We will miss Peter's intelligence and legal acumen as we mourn the loss of his warmth, generosity, and uncommon spirit.

Even as they watch their endowments dwindle and financial aid applications surge, private colleges and universities are deciding whether they can afford to participate in a new G.I. Bill plan that splits the cost of private tuition with the government, allowing veterans to study at private colleges for free.

Each day this week in the “Guidance Office,” Ron Lieber, who writes the “Your Money” column for The Times’s business section, is answering selected reader questions related to long-term savings for college (and short-term, too.) You can put a question to him by using the comment box on our original post. The questions below may have been edited for style, and length.
On this week’s Popcast, Ben Sisario offers his recap of this year’s Coachella festival and the Irish rock band Bell X1 performs in our studio. Sia Michel is your host.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Thursday morning.

A roster of veteran directors that includes previous Palme d’Or winners Quentin Tarantino, Lars Von Trier and Jane Campion will have their latest films at the Cannes Film Festival in May, The Hollywood Reporter said. At a press conference on Thursday, the festival officially announced its lineup, including Mr. Tarantino’s World War II action movie “Inglourious Basterds,” Mr. Von Trier’s horror film “Antichrist,” which stars Willem Dafoe and Charlotte Gainsbourg and Ms. Campion’s “Bright Star,” a biographical film starring Ben Wishaw as John Keats. Also on this year’s festival bill are Ang Lee’s “Taking Woodstock,” which stars Demetri Martin as the Woodstock concert organizer Elliot Tiber, and Terry Gilliam’s “The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus,” a fantasy movie that includes the last film performance by Heath Ledger. The festival is scheduled to begin on May 13 with the Disney-Pixar animated film “Up,” and close on May 24 with the biographical film “Coco Chanel & Igor Stravinsky.”

Is a lit candelabrum atop a grand piano still compliant with New York fire prevention and building codes? Someone had better find out, as a musical about Liberace, the pianist and entertainer who put the flame in flamboyant, is planned for Broadway this fall. In a news release, the producers Edmund Gaynes and Nancy Bianconi announced their plans for a new show, called “Liberace: The Man, The Music & The Memories,” which they said would recreate the experience of a Liberace concert in a Las Vegas show room. The musician and comedian Wayland Pickard has been cast as Liberace and Pamela Hall (Off Broadway’s “Danny and Sylvia: The Danny Kaye Musical”) will direct. A theater and starting date have not been announced.

A professor from the University of California, San Diego, who was researching Benjamin Franklin at the British Library made an unexpected discovery on the last day of his trip to Britain: copies of 47 letters by, to and about Franklin that were written in the spring and summer of 1755 and not seen since. In a news release, the university said that the letters, which were found by Alan Houston, a professor of political science, were copied by Thomas Birch, a Franklin contemporary who was a prodigious transcriber and compiler of historical documents and later became secretary of the Royal Society. They were written to and from Franklin’s son William and his wife, Deborah, as well as the British general Edward Braddock, cover a period during the French and Indian War, when Franklin helped organize a Pennsylvania militia against the French and Native American forces that threatened the colonies. The letters are being published in the April issue of The William and Mary Quarterly.

Touchstone Fireside, an imprint of Simon & Schuster that publishes authors including the novelist Philippa Gregory and the psychic Sylvia Browne, has appointed Stacy Creamer, currently editor in-chief of Broadway Books, as publisher. She replaces Mark Gompertz, who was named to the new post of executive vice president in charge of digital publishing at Simon & Schuster on Wednesday.

When you’ve spent your life residing in a swamp, Chicago should be sumptuous by comparison: The producers of the Broadway show “Shrek: The Musical” said it would start a national tour in Chicago next year. DreamWorks Theatricals and Neal Street Productions said that the tour of the musical, about the green ogre of the animated movies and William Steig‘s fairy tale, would start at the Ford Center for the Performing Arts/Oriental Theater in June 2010. No cast was announced.

Debt and family disputes continue to whittle away at a tribal art collection, assembled by John and Marcia Friede, that the de Young Museum in San Francisco once expected to own in its entirety. The Friedes promised their 4,000-piece collection to the de Young in a series of agreements completed in 2007. But a battle over the estate of Mr. Friede’s mother, Evelyn A.J. Hall, and a roughly $25 million debt owed by the Friedes to Sotheby’s, have threatened to break up the collection, considered one of the best in the world.

Movie premieres often have a curious mix of spectacle and intimacy, a chance to see celebrities try to keep their composure as they weave their way through bossy photographers and overeager fans. But as Woody Allen is no fan of fanfare, I was curious to see how things would turn out at the opening-night Tribeca Film Festival premiere of his latest film, “Whatever Works.” I brought my Flip video camera to see if I could document a few moments of a premiere from both the perspective of a fan and a journalist.

For the New York Philharmonic, evidently, the Park Avenue Armory is a place only a maestro could love. Kurt Masur opened the more or less annual Kurt Masur Conducting Seminar on Wednesday morning — his fifth in conjunction with the Manhattan School of Music and his first at the armory — by describing his thwarted romance with the building.

In the absence of anything to say about Wednesday’s “Lost” clip show, here’s a photograph of cast members celebrating the coming 100th episode of the show with a special cake from Food Network’s “Ace of Cakes”:

Quite possibly, the finest Mendelssohn band in the city this week is the Manhattan School of Music Symphony Orchestra. Partly this excellence derives from the intensive work the dean of Mendelssohn conductors, Kurt Masur, has been doing with the players, directly and indirectly, in the Kurt Masur Conducting Seminar at the Park Avenue Armory. Whether he is addressing the players themselves or the young seminar conductors who are mostly leading the orchestra in those sessions, the players are absorbing the wisdom of a master.

James Carville and Mary Matalin will soon be sparring about politics in public more often. Ms. Matalin, the longtime Republican strategist, is joining CNN as a contributor, where her husband Mr. Carville, the Democratic operative, has worked for many years, the network announced Thursday. The couple hosted the now-defunct CNN debate show “Crossfire” at different times in the past decade, and now they’ll be appearing together twice a month on the Sunday morning public affairs program “State of the Union.” Ms. Matalin, who worked for the Bush administration from 2001 to the end of 2002, will also contribute political commentary on other CNN programs, the network said.

Jay Leno, the “Tonight” show host, was hospitalized on Thursday and a taping of the show planned for that afternoon was canceled, the Web site of the Los Angeles television station KTLA reported. An NBC spokeswoman told KTLA that Mr. Leno had checked himself into the hospital because he wasn’t feeling well, but would not elaborate on his condition. Mr. Leno will be stepping down from the “Tonight” show this summer and is scheduled to host a nightly prime-time variety series on NBC in the fall.

Mike Sager is a former Washington Post staff writer and Rolling Stone contributing editor. He is also the bestselling author of three collections and a novel, and has been a writer at large at Esquire for nearly a dozen years. His recent profile of Todd Marinovich in Esquire is a must read for college football fans. It's a compelling portrait of a superior athlete whose training methods at the hands of his father made him a curiosity and whose talent made him a star. Then he lost it all to drug addiction, a battle he is still fighting. Mike Sager was nice enough to answer some questions over e-mail and give us some further insight into the world of Todd Marinovich.

Motorcycles and all-terrain vehicles for children 12 and younger were banned from sale two months ago as part of the Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act, which imposes stricter limits on lead content in products intended for children. For three days during Milan's design week, Spazio Fendi was filled not with models parading down the runway but with young designers cutting, pleating, weaving and generally transforming materials and processes in live demonstrations, in "Craft Punk," organized by Design Miami. Garden hoses were turned into chairs, ceramic vases were decorated by means of an old-fashioned photographic printing technique, and scraps of leather discarded from Fendi's factories became tabletops, to name of few of the freewheeling projects on display.

The biggest thing in mergers and acquisitions this month is Oracle's $7.4 billion deal for Sun Microsystems. So, I was happy to see that Sun filed its agreement to be acquired by Oracle on Monday evening rather than waiting the full four business days allowed under the Securities and Exchange Commission's Form 8-K rules. I would like to think they did so out of solicitude for Sun shareholders, but more likely it was done in order to notify any other third-party bidders of the deal protection devices that were included.

The full details of the roster of films in next month's Cannes International Film Festival is up on our sister blog, ArtsBeat. As has been widely reporters, Pixar and Disney will open the festival with "Up," which will become the first animated film and the first 3D film to hold that slot, and Cannes-favorite Quentin Tarantino will offer his WWII gorefest "Inglourious Basterds." Also on the list are films from Lars von Trier ("Antichrist," starring Willem Dafoe) and Ang Lee ("Taking Woodstock," starring Demetri Martin as the legendary festival's organizer). Overall, the festival is noticeably light on American films this year.

BAGHDAD-- With relatively little fanfare and a good dollop of skepticism, the Green Zone was handed over to Iraqi control on January 1, 2009, when the Status of Forces Agreement came into effect. There are still American troops in the zone, which houses contractors, diplomats, and Iraqi government officials, but they no longer control the entry points. Technically, Iraqis do; in practice, that is mostly done by a gaggle of Peruvian soldiers working for Triple Canopy, a private security company.

MADRID | One of France's most radical 19th-century artists is currently riling up this city in an exhibition at the CaixaForum (Paseo del Prado 36; 34-902-223-040), "Maurice de Vlaminck: A Fauve Instinct, Paintings From 1900-1915," on view through June 6. With some 80 canvases, as well as a selection of ceramics, the exhibition offers the first retrospective ever held in Spain of the work of Maurice de Vlaminck (1876-1958), the painter who once compared his career in painting to "throwing a bomb." He continued: "That way I have satisfied my desire to destroy, to disobey, and to recreate a sensitive, living, free world."
