A Fulton County (Ga.) Superior Court judge ruled that Turner Broadcasting System must pay the Texas businessman David McDavid $281 million, as a jury said last year. Judge Tom Campbell denied Turner Broadcasting’s request to overturn a verdict that favored McDavid, who accused the company of cheating him out of buying the Atlanta Hawks, Atlanta Thrashers and the Philips Arena operating rights in 2003. TBS has 30 days to appeal Campbell’s ruling.

An article on April 15 about the seizure of an Aston Martin DB2/4 purchased by the financier Bernard L. Madoff, using information from court documents in Mr. Madoff’s fraud case, referred incorrectly to the model year of the car. Production of the DB2/4 ended in 1959; Mr. Madoff did not buy a 1964 model. (A lawyer in the case said that 1964 is thought to be the year the car was first registered in Britain.).

Hevesi, referred incorrectly to the status of the charges against him. As the article correctly noted, Mr. Harding was charged in a criminal complaint filed by the office of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo; Mr. Harding has not been indicted. The headline and the article also referred incorrectly to Mr. Harding’s former position with New York’s Liberal Party. He was vice chairman, not chairman. The architect Frank Gehry, below, said he would not create a park to accompany a new performance hall that he is designing for the New World Symphony in Miami Beach and has threatened to withdraw from the project entirely, The Miami Herald reported. Mr. Gehry said that the $10 million construction budget that the city has set aside for the public park, which is to include lighting effects and seating to watch events on a giant screen outside the concert hall, was insufficient, and that city officials had repeatedly overstated his fees for the project. “I’m offended,” Mr. Gehry told The Herald. “If they keep messing with me, if I get insulted enough, I will withdraw completely.” Though city commissioners said Mr. Gehry’s firm would be paid $4.6 million for the park design, Mr. Gehry said he was receiving $1.9 million. “I’m good, and I deserve it,” he said, according to The Herald.
Ten years after it became a television phenomenon, the game show “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” will return to ABC this summer for a two-week tournament, with Regis Philbin again as host.

In its fourth week out, the soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) finally reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart. It sold 133,000 copies last week, a 32 percent drop from the week before, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Day26, the group formed on MTV’s “Making the Band 4” reality show, opened at No. 2 with its second album, “Forever in a Day” (Bad Boy), and last week’s best seller, Rascal Flatts’s “Unstoppable” (Lyric Street), lost 69 percent of its sales, dropping to No. 3 with 107,000. The “Twilight” soundtrack (Atlantic) rose four spots to No. 4 with 49,000 sales, and “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 30 holds at No. 5, with 45,000. The Los Angeles indie-rock band Silversun Pickups reached No. 7 with its second album, “Swoon” (Dangerbird), with 43,000 sales.

A performance by the singer-songwriter Josh Ritter, below, and the New York Pops on June 12 will kick off the 2009 season of Central Park SummerStage, whose full lineup is expected to be released on Thursday. Other highlights include a gospel concert on June 13 featuring Smokie Norful, Tye Tribbett and Ruben Studdard; the Metropolitan Opera Summer Recital on July 13; a world music concert on Aug. 3 with Béla Fleck and Toumani Diabaté; and a new dance work by the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon on Aug. 14 and 15. All performances will take place at Rumsey Playfield in Central Park; more information can be found online at summerstage.org.

The National Children’s Museum on Wednesday unveiled plans for its building, left, to be designed by the architectural firm Pelli Clarke Pelli. In a news release the museum said a 150,000-square-foot space, at National Harbor in Prince Georges County, Md., would offer several environmentally friendly features, including a wind turbine that will supply the building with energy, a sun reflector on the roof to reduce the use of artificial light, and a roof system that will absorb rainwater and improve insulation. The museum said its exhibits, which will highlight the environment, health, play and other subjects, would be created by Amaze Design, Roto Studio and AldrichPears. The museum is expected to open in 2013 and attract 600,000 visitors annually.

After replacing its summer parks series last year with one free mega-concert in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday announced a new plan for this summer: a series of six free recitals from July 13 through Aug. 14 in all five boroughs, starting at SummerStage in Central Park, with Paulo Szot, Lisette Oropesa, Alek Shrader and Vlad Iftinca. After the opening recital, at 8 p.m. on July 13, a Monday, the rest will take place on Friday evenings at 7 p.m.: July 17 at Crotona Park in the Bronx; July 24 at Queensbridge Park in Queens; July 31 at East River Park in Manhattan; Aug. 7 at Tappan Park in Staten Island; and Aug. 14 at Coffey Park in Brooklyn. The Met will also offer, starting on Aug 29, a 10-day festival of high-definition broadcasts of Met productions in Lincoln Center Plaza, ending with Anthony Minghella’s staging of “Madama Butterfly” on Labor Day.

RECALCITRANT roots and no time to apply hair color? A temporary touch-up that shampoos out can take the glare off gray and get you through the day (or longer). The basic principle is similar to using magic marker to fill in a nick on a shoe heel; you spot the gray and color over it. Hair care companies like Irene Gari offer touch-up products that look like wax crayons, lipsticks, mascaras and even combs and are priced from $4.99.

LALLY--Franca Pironti, the founder of Parliamo Italiano Italian Language School, died at home on the evening of Tuesday, April 21st at the age of 81, surrounded by family. She was the loving mother of Kevin, Alexandra, Cherida, Brendan, and Fiona, the mother in law of Frederick Peters, Stuart Shultz, Linda Lally, and Joseph Ogilvie, and the beloved grandmother of Justin, Clelia, Jack, Bart, Max, Oliver, Simon, Francesca, Jude, Liam and Josephine. Born in Spoleto, Italy in 1927, Franca was the daughter of Professor Francesco Pironti and his wife Teresa. She met and married Captain John Lally, a British officer stationed in Naples, in 1946. They moved intrepidly through life, creating opportunity in each of the many countries in which they lived before settling in 1966 at 132 East 65th Street, where they created a salon of family, friends, artists, educators, and students which influenced everyone who was drawn in by its magnetic pull. Franca and John opened Parliamo Italiano in 1978, and Franca designed and implemented the curriculum which made it one of the most successful language programs in the city. She continued to teach classes until a few months ago. We will remember with love and admiration her courage, her enormous intellect, her commitment to high moral principles, and her generous and loving heart which drew so many to her. May she be reunited now with her beloved John. The family will receive friends at an Open House at Parliamo Italiano Italian Language School, 132 East 65th Street, between 4 and 7pm on Sunday, April 26th. There will be a memorial service at a later date.

An incident on Tuesday night in which Umpire Kerwin Danley sustained a concussion after he was hit in the head with a broken bat raised questions about the changes Major League Baseball implemented before this season to reduce the number of broken bats. Baseball officials said Wednesday that they were still compiling statistics on the number of broken bats this season and did not know how the number compared to last season. The officials said they would likely to have an answer by the end of the week.

FARBER--Morton H.,89, died peacefully of natural causes on April 22, 2009 in New York City. Morton was born July 11, 1920 to Abraham and Cecelia Farber in Weedsport, New York. He received his undergraduate degree from Cornell in 1941 and his law degree from Yale University where he later served as an adjunct professor. During World War II he was a lieutenant in the Navy serving as an intelligence officer. During the war he was trained at the University of Colorado at Boulder in the Navy's Japanese Language School and attended the Naval Intelligence School in New York. He was involved in the "breaking the code project" during the war and the United States Strategic Bombing Survey. Morton later founded the law firm of Farber, Cohen and Diamond, a leading entertainment and theatrical law firm based in New York City. He was the lawyer and/ or manager to many well known entertainers including Tony Bennett, Johnny Mathis, Jerry Vale and the Copa Cabana. Later in life, he became involved in numerous entrepreneurial activities and investments, often connected to the entertainment industry. He was a long time member of the board of the Friars Club and honored as their "man of the year" in 1988. He was active in numerous philanthropic activities. In 1956 he married Marilyn Siegel, a sculptor. They lived in Manhattan and Beverly Hills for most of their married lives. His loving sisters, Reloris Wickman and Helen Spears both predeceased him. Mort will be missed by his devoted wife of 53 years, Marilyn, his loving daughter, Harley Farber-Raiff and his adoring grandchildren Charley, Clay and Sydney Raiff. The family is receiving visitors at Frank E. Campbell located at 1076 Madison Avenue on April 23 between 7 and 9. A graveside service is planned for Friday April 24 at 10:30 at the Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, New York.

An American soldier, above, slipped in and out of consciousness on Wednesday after being injured by a falling boulder on a mountain ridge in eastern Afghanistan's Korangal Valley. The soldiers with Company B of the First Battalion, 26th Infantry had dropped by helicopter into the rarely patrolled area, which is a Taliban sanctuary. They climbed to an altitude of more than 9,000 feet to search for weapons caches, but amid freezing conditions, tough terrain and high altitude, five soldiers were evacuated for injuries or fatigue. Other soldiers helped the injured one above make the final push to return to their outpost.

8:30 P.M. (HBO) TROUBLE THE WATER (2008) Kimberly Rivers Roberts (above, with her husband, Scott Roberts), a resident of the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans, documented Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath with her video camera; the filmmakers Tia Lessin and Carl Deal met Ms. Roberts at a Red Cross shelter and made her the centerpiece of this movie, which was nominated for an Academy Award for best documentary feature. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said the filmmakers ''have created an ingeniously fluid narrative structure that, when combined with Ms. Roberts's visuals, news material and their own original 16-millimeter film footage, ebbs and flows like great drama.'' 7 A.M. SHAPIRO--Jacob Aron (October 24, 1982), of Leonia, NJ, died in a tragic automobile accident Friday, April 17th in St. Helena, CA. He was the beloved son of Catherine and Jonathan Shapiro, the younger brother of Joshua and Jeremy, brother-in-law of Amy, uncle to Benjamin, grandson of Samuel L. Shapiro, nephew to many aunts and uncles and cousin to Nicholas, Matthew and Rachael. He was also beloved by a worldwide network of close, enduring and extraordinary friends. He was a graduate of the Fieldston School, Class of 2001 and Hamilton College, Class of 2005, where he was an economics major and an All-Conference soccer player. Since January 2009, he was a student at the Culinary Institute of America at Greystone. Jacob had an insatiable appetite and gusto for life. He traveled the world with an almost unimaginable enthusiasm and joy. He was an accomplished and skilled athlete and voracious dancer. He had a smile with wattage. He loved and was loved. A star who shone brightly, Jacob's memory will be carried in many, many hearts. Contributions to the "Following Your Dream" Scholarship made payable to the CIA Scholarship Fund in memory of Jacob Shapiro can be sent to the Culinary Institute of America at Greystone, 2555 Main St., St. Helena, CA 94574.

An article on Tuesday about the arrest of a man charged in the killing of a masseuse in Boston whom he found through Craigslist misstated his age. The error was repeated on Wednesday in a follow-up article about the case. The man, Philip Markoff, is 23, not 22.

One of the coolest features of the old Palm organizers was that you could beam business cards to other Palms. The iPhone will soon add a similar feature, but in the meantime there's SnapDat, a free application that lets iPhone users send virtual business cards to other people. SnapDat has roughly 40 card designs as templates. Users can maintain any number of designs, making sure there are different cards for different occasions. To send a card to another SnapDat user, simply look up their username on the app. Cards sent between SnapDat members are automatically transcribed into your iPhone's address book. People who aren't members can also receive cards, which are e-mailed as a standard vCard attachment.

FOR most of the Caribbean, Florida Keys and the Northeast, saltwater fly-fishing season starts in March or April and lasts through the end of June, as bonefish, permit and tarpon gather in warmer waters south of the contiguous United States and striped bass migrate up the East Coast. ''Saltwater is sort of like the last frontier in fly-fishing,'' said Richard Farino, manager of the Urban Angler Fly Shop, with stores in Manhattan and Arlington, Va. ''It's becoming more popular every day, and people want new outlets to try it. It's definitely more of an adrenaline rush than freshwater since the fish are bigger, faster and fight harder.''

A headline last Thursday with an article about Raymond B. Harding's being accused by prosecutors of taking more than $800,000 in exchange for doing favors for the former state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, referred incorrectly to the status of the charges against him. As the article correctly noted, Mr. Harding was charged in a criminal complaint filed by the office of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo; Mr. Harding has not been indicted. The headline and the article also referred incorrectly to Mr. Harding's former position with New York's Liberal Party. He was vice chairman, not chairman. (The error about his title was repeated in an editorial on Wednesday and also appeared in a Political Memo article on March 8, 2007.)

Twitter fans face a hurdle: Can you use it at work without being caught? A British Web developer, Elliott Kember, has solved the problem with Spreadtweet, an easy-to-use Twitter client that looks like a boring Excel spreadsheet. Each version of the program displays a fake Excel toolbar atop its window. But those buttons don't work. The real controls are hiding just below as fake column headers: Home, Replies, Direct Messages, etc. On my Apple desktop, Spreadtweet mimics Excel to the point of placing an Excel icon into my iMac's Dock, so anyone watching from farther away than a cubicle wall will be fooled.

Voters began showing up soon after midnight in this sprawling settlement of tiny brick houses and slapdash hovels north of Johannesburg. By 4:30 a.m. on Wednesday, the lines were a thousand people long, the rooted bodies shivering in the predawn chill. At one polling place, the row of humanity stretched 200 yards down one street -- past Minguni's Butchery and the bar named Momi's Place and the Gang Star Hair Salon and Shoe Repair -- and then it turned east at the office of Dr. Dungu, the traditional herbalist healer, and finally came back north past the piles of broken-up concrete on Parks Mankahlana Street.

How important is the development of 3-D television? As far as Panasonic is concerned, it's critical. According to Eisuke Tsuyuzaki, Panasonic's general manager for its Blu-ray Disc Group, 3-D television ''could be as significant as the transformation from standard- to high-definition TV.''

DE REINECK--Marie Buford, died April 18, 2009 in New York City at the age of 100. She is survived by her son-in-law Ranga Sreenivasan (Calgary, AB), her grandchildren Gopal (Durham, NC), Govind (Newton, MA), Gauri (Ottawa, ON), Gayatri (Vancouver, BC) and Aravind (New York, NY) Sreenivasan, and seven great-grandchildren. Marie was born on July 15, 1908 in Ellington, MO, to Thomas Otto Buford (1883-1956) and Mary Lessie Deen (1886-1918). She came to New York City in about 1930 where she married (1933) Baron Radu de Reineck (1903-1970), with whom she had her only child, Claire de Reineck Sreenivasan (1935-1997). Marie worked in New York for fifty years as an interior decorator, running the Claymar School of Design. She graduated from Fordham University and for some years taught Catholic parochial school. She was remarried to Charles Romanesco (1901-1982). A mass will be held at 10:15am on Thursday, April 23, 2009 in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral (460 Madison Ave., New York City).

Please send contributions to The American Heart Association. He was deeply loved and he is sorely missed.

Sudden substitutions often befall opera casts, and they sometimes occur on the conductor’s podium, too. Just before the Metropolitan Opera’s presentation of “Das Rheingold” on Thursday night, the conductor James Levine became ill and withdrew from the performance. The assistant conductor John Keenan went on in Mr. Levine’s place. Lee Abrahamian, the Met’s director of communications, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Levine had come down with “some sort of stomach bug” but was expected to return for the Saturday matinee performance of “Götterdämmerung,” which will be broadcast live online and on the Toll Brothers–Metropolitan Opera International Radio Network and Sirius XM satellite radio.

NBC canceled a second “Tonight Show” Friday because of the illness of Jay Leno, but the network said the show’s host was feeling better and would return on Monday. It said he probably had a stomach virus.

In a new round of cost-cutting, National Public Radio said it would lay off 13 employees, eliminate contributions to employee retirement accounts for the rest of fiscal 2009 and impose five days of furloughs for all employees before the fiscal year ends on Sept. 30. The cuts, which were reported Friday in The Washington Post, also include reductions in medical benefit contributions and the addition of unpaid holidays. They follow layoffs of 64 people, or 7% of the staff, in December, because of a revenue shortfall. Employees at the vice presidential level and above will absorb additional cuts. Merit pay increases scheduled for January 2010 are being eliminated, and 18 unfilled positions are either being eliminated or temporarily frozen. Corporate underwriting has continued to drop since December, Anna Christopher, a spokeswoman for NPR, said. The new cuts add up to savings of about $17 million over the two fiscal years, which is more than the $15 million deficit that NPR has forecast. Most of the staff cuts are in the areas of information technology, legal services and communications and won’t affect programming, NPR said.

Trekkers and/or Trekkies who are looking forward to “Star Trek,” the reboot of the television and film series that hits theaters on May 8, can get a taste of what’s to come in “Star Trek: Countdown.” The story serves as a prequel to the movie and its collected edition, published by IDW, hits our paperback list at No. 2. “This particular book has captured the imagination of both the comic buying public and the Star Trek fans out there,” said Scott Dunbier, the special projects editor at IDW. The comic book has proven popular in all its formats: individual issues, collected editions and on iPhones. It seems “only appropriate,” Mr. Dunbier said, “that people are responding to them on communicators.”

Thirteen paintings said to have been made by Hitler were sold Thursday for a total of about $143,000 at an auction in Shropshire in Britain, Reuters reported. The works, which are believed to date from the early 1900s, when Hitler was still a struggling artist with unfulfilled aspirations of entering Vienna’s Academy of Arts, included an oil painting of an Alpine landscape (which sold for about $19,700) and a possible self-portrait (which sold for about $14,600). Richard Westwood-Brookes, a historical documents specialist who ran the sale for the British auction house Mullock’s, told Reuters that “people do not want to acquire these for their artistic merit; they just want to have something that belonged to someone famous from history.” Though the artworks were signed “A. Hitler” or “A.H.” and certified by an Austrian expert, Mr. Westwood-Brookes said no one could be completely certain they were painted by Hitler.

A new film by Francis Ford Coppola will open Directors’ Fortnight, the annual French film series held independently from but parallel to the Cannes Film Festival, Variety reported. Mr. Coppola’s new film, “Tetro,” stars Vincent Gallo as a writer living in exile in Buenos Aires and is scheduled to be shown at the Directors’ Fortnight series on May 14. Other films in the lineup include Cherien Dabis’s debut, “Amreeka,” which opened the New Directors/New Films series in New York in March; Lynn Shelton’s comedy “Humpday,” which was sold for distribution at the Sundance Film Festival in January; and Glenn Ficarra and John Requa’s “I Love You Phillip Morris,” starring Ewan McGregor and Jim Carrey, which also played at Sundance. The directors’ series will conclude on May 24 with “Ajami,” a drama by Yaron Shani and Scandar Copti about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

MILAN - After four solid days (and nights) of seeing, talking, and breathing design here, I'm happy to report that I am leaving for home inspired and refreshed. The fair itself was predictably conservative -- companies are trying to appeal to the greatest possible number of consumers -- but outside the fair, hand craft, imagination and optimism ruled. Zanotta's Trans-Forma exhibition, under the direction of Fabrica, offered witty re-imaginings of the company's classics, like Tak Cheung and Jade Folawiyo's transformation of the iconic 1970 Quaderna console table by Superstudio, with its distinctive grid pattern, into Dining Table Doccia (Italian for shower).

The Prada Transformer, fashion's latest starchitect-designed metamorphic space, opens in Seoul, South Korea, this month. Putting a new spin on the idea of ''mobile art,'' the Rem Koolhaas/AMO-designed structure will be flipped by cranes to reveal four different configurations. The Transformer's programming, which runs through July - and which coincides with the Korean release of the second-generation Prada Phone - will showcase works from the Fondazione Prada, curated by Germano Celant, as well as Korean film and student design. But lest anyone forget who wears the pants in this operation, the series will open with ''Waist Down,'' a retrospective of Miuccia Prada's skirts, and close with a show of her fall-winter 2009 collection.

As a travel editor, I've never been very interested in breaking down travel into "markets." Girlfriend Getaways, Guys' Golf Weekends, Nakations for Nudists - um, no thank you. But lately it's been hard to dismiss the deluge on my e-mail inbox of subject lines like "first gay couples-only retreat" and "New York's rainbow pilgrimage." If nothing else, GLBT travel is a faintly flickering bright spot on the horizon these days: according to a recent survey by Harris Interactive, 38 percent of gays and lesbians in the United States plan to stick to their vacations this year, compared to 34 percent of their straight counterparts. And 25 percent of the respondents said they'd be traveling by air, versus 19 percent of heterosexuals. Not that gays and lesbians haven't been gallivanting in earnest for some time - Rosie's Family Cruise, anyone? - but now that four states recognize the right to marriage of a group whose collective buying power is approaching $835 billion, the business better brace itself for a lucrative little something called the Gay Honeymoon.

(Here, Ed speaks about so many personal favorites of mine -- my mother loves onions and eggs too -- that it's hard to keep up. --MB)Scrambled eggs over rice -- with something added -- can be a delicious, quick home-style Chinese dinner. When tomatoes are in season and the hens raised by our bucolic friends Alberto and Jerry are producing their richest, yellowest-yolked eggs, Jackie and I will softly scramble half a dozen of those eggs ( with white pepper and sesame oil), set them aside, then briefly cook some tomatoes with garlic and ginger -- using peanut oil throughout -- and fold in the eggs. A real favorite, with plenty of plain jasmine rice. A similar thing with shrimp is very good too.

The summer movie season - which never really waits for Memorial Day anymore - is set to kick off on May 1 with the release of "X-Men Origins: Wolverine," the first of the big seasonal blockbusters. What that means is that this will be the last spring weekend at the box office, and it pits four new films against one another that could not be more different - "Obsessed," a Beyonce Knowles thriller about an office temp who stalks her boss, "The Soloist," an inspirational drama about the relationship between a newspaper columnist (Robert Downey Jr.) and a bi-polar street musician (Jamie Foxx), "Fighting," a bareknuckles actioner and "Earth," a nature documentary from Disney. Entertainment Weekly picks the finish this way: $15 million for "Obsessed," $13 million for "The Soloist," $12 million for the second weekend of "17 Again" and $10 million for "Earth." Box Office Guru, meanwhile, agrees that "Obsessed" will win (with $17 million), but expects "17 Again" to tie for second place at $12 million with "Fighting," and "The Soloist" trailing at a distant $8 million. The Los Angeles Times' Company Town blog says that "Fighting" has the best chance of ending the weekend on top.

Anne Applebaum is an American political journalist living in Poland whose columns appear weekly in The Washington Post and on Slate. Her views are pro-free-trade and generally hawkish. A Thatcherite in the 1980s, and a supporter of Obama for president in 2008, Applebaum is stoutly pro-immigration, pro-intellectual and anti-torture. Last year Foreign Policy magazine declared her one of "the world's most sophisticated thinkers." In awarding the 2004 prize for general nonfiction to her book "Gulag: A History," the Pulitzer committee called it a "landmark work of historical scholarship and an indelible contribution to the complex, ongoing, necessary quest for truth."

Generally speaking, lamb is more flavorful than beef, which means that a lamb burger is more flavorful than a hamburger. If you can't find ground lamb, it can be easily produced from part of a boned lamb shoulder -- you can also make it from a package of shoulder lamb chops - in a food processor. Just cut the meat into one-inch pieces, discard any hard fat and gristle, and process until it is ground but not smooth.

Watchdog groups have asked for an investigation of the release of private information about Caroline Kennedy by the governor's office after she withdrew her name as a Senate candidate. In an eight-page letter, the groups argue that the state's ethics panel needs to determine whether the Paterson administration violated state laws by leaking confidential information as part of a political strategy aimed at deflecting blame for her withdrawal. Members of the governor's administration called reporters with claims about problems concerning Ms. Kennedy's candidacy that are now acknowledged to have been highly exaggerated.

Traditional signs of spring in Washington always include the cherry blossoms (now faded), and the bursts of color from daffodil and tulip beds planted all around the district. But the season also carries other annual rituals, like the gathering of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank this weekend.

As a nature photographer, I very much look forward to spring. After a long, dark, very cold winter, I am just itching to get out and shoot all the spring colors. To see the electric purple crocuses, the sunshine yellow daffodils and all the new bright green growth just makes me come alive. Longer days mean more time to shoot. Warmer days mean less cumbersome layers of clothing. All this is my reward for surviving the winter doldrums.

For a decade now, the International Fashion and Photography Festival (April 24 to 27) in Hyères, France, has featured the work of 10 emerging photographers, with an international jury picking one winner. But winning is not necessarily what the festival is all about: for the participants, it's more about those few days when the artists and jurors have all the time in the world (well, almost) to talk about photography, under the warm Mediterranean sun; for everyone else, it's a chance to consider work - showing in Hyères through June 7 - that reflects how far contemporary photography has come, and how far some artists are willing to go.

A roster of veteran directors that includes Quentin Tarantino, below, Lars von Trier and Jane Campion, all previous winners of the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival, will have their latest films shown at the festival next month, The Hollywood Reporter said. At a news conference on Thursday, festival officials announced the lineup, including Mr. Tarantino’s World War II action movie “Inglourious Basterds”; Mr. von Trier’s horror film “Antichrist,” which stars Willem Dafoe and Charlotte Gainsbourg; and Ms. Campion’s “Bright Star,” a biographical film about John Keats, starring Ben Wishaw. Also on the bill are Ang Lee’s “Taking Woodstock,” which stars Demetri Martin as the Woodstock concert organizer Elliot Tiber, and “The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus,” a fantasy by Terry Gilliam that includes the last film appearance by Heath Ledger. The festival is scheduled to begin on May 13 with the Disney-Pixar animated film “Up” and close on May 24 with the biographical film “Coco Chanel & Igor Stravinsky,” directed by Jan Kounen.

A professor from the University of California, San Diego, who was researching Benjamin Franklin at the British Library made a discovery on the last day of his trip in 2007: copies of 47 letters by, to and about Franklin that were written in the spring and summer of 1755 and not seen since. The university said that the letters, which were found by Alan Houston, a professor of political science, had been copied by Thomas Birch, a Franklin contemporary who was a prodigious transcriber and compiler of historical documents and later became secretary of the Royal Society. They were written to and from Franklin’s son William and his wife, Deborah, as well as the British general Edward Braddock, and cover a period during the French and Indian War when Franklin helped organize a Pennsylvania militia against the forces that threatened the colonies. The letters are being published in the April issue of The William and Mary Quarterly.

Scientists have achieved what they describe as a milestone in animal genetics: decoding the genome of the cow. The findings provide ''tantalizing clues to explain 'the essence of bovinity,' '' according to an essay in the journal Science, which is publishing several articles on the work. ''The cows have not disappointed us,'' wrote Harris A. Lewin, an animal sciences professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, noting that the research had fulfilled its promise to provide ''exciting new information'' about the evolution of mammals and the workings of their genes. The cow whose genome was sequenced was a Hereford named L1 Dominette 01449, above, one of the 94 million cows in the United States, where cattle are a $49 billion industry. The project was a six-year effort that involved more than 300 scientists from 25 countries and cost $53 million. Cows have about 22,000 genes. Scientists say the new information may help them find ways to improve meat and milk production and resistance to disease, and to reduce the amount of heat-trapping gases released by herds of cows.

WYNN--Rev. Dr. John Charles. JC Wynn died on March 31, 2009 at 88 years of age in Catonsville, Maryland where he lived with his wife Rachel at the Charlestown Retirement Community. He grew up in Johnstown, PA, where he graduated from high school. After completing his major in philosophy at The College of Wooster and graduate work at Yale Divinity School, Rev. Wynn was ordained in 1944 and served as associate pastor at the First Presbyterian Church in Evanston, Illinois, and subsequently as pastor of the Presbyterian Church of El Dorado, Kansas. He developed a specialty in the field of marriage, family and sexuality, and was appointed in 1950 as Director of Family Education for the Presbyterian Board of Christian Education in Philadelphia. This led to Wynn's pioneering work in the field for the denomination through numerous articles, books, lecturing, and conferences. He became the chairman on the Commission on Sexuality in the Human Community, served on the Committee on the Family for the National Council of Churches and the Family Council at the World Council of Churches, and helped to write the Vatican-Protestant report on inter-faith marriage. Dr. Wynn was a fellow of the American Association of Marriage and Family Counseling, and a member of the national clergy committee for Planned Parenthood, among others. He wrote or edited nine books on marriage therapy and family issues. Dr. Wynn received his MA and Doctor of Education degrees from Columbia University, as well as a Doctor of Divinity degree from Davis and Elkins College. He joined the inter-denominational faculty of Colgate Rochester Divinity School in Rochester, New York in 1960, where he developed and administered an innovative doctoral (Doctor of Ministry) program in family therapy that graduated many ministers, priests, rabbis, and nuns over a period of 28 years until his retirement. During those years, he was a frequent guest lecturer at Wesley Theological Seminary in Washington, Union Theological Seminary, San Francisco Theological Seminary and at colleges throughout the US, Canada, South Africa, Lesotho, and Korea. In retirement, Dr. Wynn lectured and served on various committees as a member of the Presbytery of Baltimore, Maryland, ministered locally to residents of Charlestown, and taught seminars there on philosophy, especially on Plato. A memorial service was held on April 13 at Charlestown Retirement Community, Catonsville, MD. Memorial gifts may be sent to The Wynn Fund for Family Ministries, Colgate Rochester Divinity School, 1100 S. Goodman St., Rochester, NY 14620. JC Wynn leaves behind his beloved wife Rachel, whom he married 65 years ago in 1943; their three married children, Mark Wynn of Arnold, MD, Martha Borland of West Sunbury, PA, and Maryan Ainsworth of Old Greenwich, CT; five grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren.

The White House, which had been resisting self-examination to mark President Obama's first 100 days, has given up. Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, who had repeatedly derided the 100-day marker as an artificial and arbitrary construct for measuring the president's performance -- ''a Hallmark holiday,'' as he and other officials have described it -- said in his briefing Thursday that Mr. Obama would hold his third prime-time news conference on Wednesday, his 100th day in office, after returning from a trip to Missouri. ''There will be a whole lot of cards for you to pick up,'' Mr. Gibbs said, provoking laughter in the room, ''where you can inform your loved ones what you've been doing for the last 100 days.'' SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

DILLON--Thomas E. April 18, 1946 April 15, 2009. Thomas Edward Dillon was the first of six children born to Shirley and Thomas J. Dillon of San Francisco. Even from childhood, he had a keen sense of wonder and a hunger for knowledge, spending hours reading through encyclopedias. Tom was immensely grateful for his loving family, and had tremendous gratitude for his parents' love and example. He cherished many fond memories of growing up with his siblings, Nancy, Tim, John, Mary, and Robert. He was deeply saddened by the loss of his own father, whom he described as his hero, only a few years ago. Tom married the love of his life, Theresa Ann Corkery, on March 4, 1967. They were not only husband and wife, but also best friends. Tom had a great sense of humor and he could always make Terri laugh. They complemented one another perfectly. The Dillons were blessed with 42 years of marriage, four children, and 15 grandchildren. One of Tom's greatest joys was spending time with Terri and their children. He delighted in playing ping-pong with his youngest son, Danny, and loved to chronicle his family members' lives through his passion for photography. Tom had a true appreciation for beauty, and nowhere did he treasure it more than in his own family. A graduate of St. Mary's College of California, with masters and doctoral degrees in philosophy from the University of Notre Dame, Dr. Dillon devoted the last 38 years of his life to advancing and sustaining Catholic liberal education at Thomas Aquinas College in Santa Paula. Appointed to the college's teaching faculty in 1972, he served as assistant dean for student affairs from 1976 to 1981; he then served as academic dean from 1981 until his appointment as president in 1991. Throughout that time, he took great pride in the college's growing reputation for excellence, as well as in its alumni, which include 45 priests and more than 20 fully professed religious brothers and sisters. Widely recognized as a national leader in the reform of accreditation in higher education, Dr. Dillon was active in the early 1990s in organizing a new national accrediting agency, the American Academy for Liberal Education. In 2003, he was appointed to a three-year term by the United States Secretary of Education to the 15-member National Advisory Committee on Institutional Quality and Integrity, a group that, in effect, accredits the accreditors. Dr. Dillon was a member of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta and chairman of the Western Association's Defense of the Faith Committee. He served on the Board of Directors of a number of organizations, including the Institute on Religious Life, and was a member of Legatus for the past 11 years. On April 15, Dr. Dillon was killed in an automobile accident in Ireland, where he was traveling on behalf of Thomas Aquinas College. He is survived by his mother and five siblings, his beloved wife, Terri, and their four children and their spouses: Elizabeth and Thomas J. Dillon, Maria and Domiane Forte, Christine and Thomas Ellis, and Danny Dillon. He also leaves behind 15 grandchildren: Cecilia, Maggie, Sean, Frances, and Jane Dillon; Emma, Giuseppe, Enzo, Francesco, and Bella Forte; and Andrew, Liam, Seth, Caitriona, and Joey Ellis. He will be deeply mourned by his family and by the entire community of Thomas Aquinas College, to which he gave his life. The Funeral Mass for Dr. Dillon will be held in Our Lady of the Most Holy Trinity Chapel at Thomas Aquinas College on Friday, April 24, 2009, at 10:00am. Interment will be at Santa Paula Cemetery. A rosary was held Thursday evening, April 23, 2009 at 7:30pm, also in the college chapel. An all-night vigil followed. The Dillon family asks that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Thomas Aquinas College or, more specifically, to Our Lady of the Most Holy Trinity Chapel. Funeral services are under the direction of the family owned and operated Robert Rey Garcia Jr., Funeral Services, Santa Paula, CA. 93060. For further information, please call (805)229-7054.

DUBLIRER--Simon, beloved husband of Frieda Dublirer, passed away peacefully in his sleep on April 22, 2009. He was 98 years old. In addition to his wife, left to grieve his memory are his daughter, Marlene Besen and her husband, Stan, his sons Eric Dublirer and his wife, Ellen, and Brian Dublirer and his wife, Ann. He also leaves behind six granddaughters: Roberta and Elizabeth Besen, Danielle Dublirer, Jennifer Titton, Caitlin Dublirer and Sara McCauley; and three great granddaughters, Reese Titton and Marley and Emma McCauley. As a young man on the lower east side, Simon joined The Educational Alliance. He and his friends formed a group called the Rockets. The Rockets continued to meet for many years, supporting The Educational Alliance. Simon served as President of The Educational Alliance and continued to support its goal of helping families on the lower east side until his death. Simon attended City College of New York where he played on the basketball team. He worked for the Social Security Administration for 52 years, starting at its inception in 1935. He was a dedicated public servant who loved his work and the people that he helped during his long career. Most important to Simon was his family whom he loved and supported unconditionally. He and Frieda were married for 72 happy years. A graveside service is planned for Friday, April 24, 2009 at 10:30am at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made in the name of Simon Dublirer to The Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, New York, New York, 10002.

LALLY--Franca Pironti, the founder of Parliamo Italiano Italian Language School, died at home on the evening of Tuesday, April 21st at the age of 81, surrounded by family. She was the loving mother of Kevin, Alexandra, Cherida, Brendan, and Fiona, the mother in law of Frederick Peters, Stuart Shultz, Linda Lally, and Joseph Ogilvie, and the beloved grandmother of Justin, Clelia, Jack, Bart, Max, Oliver, Simon, Francesca, Jude, Liam and Josephine. Born in Spoleto, Italy in 1927, Franca was the daughter of Professor Francesco Pironti and his wife Teresa. She met and married Captain John Lally, a British officer stationed in Naples, in 1946. They moved intrepidly through life, creating opportunity in each of the many countries in which they lived before settling in 1966 at 132 East 65th Street, where they created a salon of family, friends, artists, educators, and students which influenced everyone who was drawn in by its magnetic pull. Franca and John opened Parliamo Italiano in 1978, and Franca designed and implemented the curriculum which made it one of the most successful language programs in the city. She continued to teach classes until a few months ago. We will remember with love and admiration her courage, her enormous intellect, her commitment to high moral principles, and her generous and loving heart which drew so many to her. May she be reunited now with her beloved John. The family will receive friends at an Open House at Parliamo Italiano Italian Language School, 132 East 65th Street, between 4 and 7pm on Sunday, April 26th. There will be a memorial service at a later date.

Personally, he was the devoted husband of the late Claire (Schechter) Weil and the beloved father to his daughters, Deborah and Ruth and father-in-law to Garrett Brodeur and Thomas Kosman and the revered grandfather to Alexander and Gabriel Brodeur, Phoebe and Max Kosman and proud uncle to many nieces and nephews. Family to gather for graveside services on Friday, April 24, 2009 at 11:00am at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Anti-Defamation League, www.adl.org or to Penn Smiles Program at the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine, 215-898-8951, or to a charity of your choice.

GORDON--Marjorie Grossman, April 3, 2009, Portland, OR. Born in New York City in 1915, graduate of Columbia University. For 65 years the loving spouse of Eugene, died 2003. Devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Marjorie was an ardent volunteer who supported education, public housing, mental health, court reform and the elderly, serving on numerous executive boards.

OUTSIDE the Middle of the Road antiques store on Highway 14 in Sprott, Ala., there is a well-worn patch of dusty gravel and matted weeds where curious travelers park to view what was once the local post office. ''This is one of the most photographed buildings in the county,'' said Donna Hale, pointing at the structure where, until the 1990s, farmers picked up their mail and bought locally grown corn and beans, much as their parents and grandparents had done in the Depression. The post office was built in 1842, she said, and served as a general store where children fished penny candy out of glass jars while their parents sipped cold Coca-Colas under the covered porch, sheltered from the searing sun.

WEEKES--Arthur D.,III. Hamilton, MA. Died at home in Hamilton on April 20, 2009. He is survived by his wife Margery, his brother John M. of Buhl, Idaho and James T. of Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida and seven nieces and nephews. Originally from Oyster Bay, NY, Mr. Weekes had lived in Hamilton, MA. for the past 30 years. He graduated from Groton School in 1957 and Harvard College in 1962. He was much loved and will be deeply missed. Contributions may be made to MSPCA Angell or Pine Street Inn, Boston.

SLATTERY--Rev. Kenneth F.,C.M., the 19th president of Niagara University, died April 21, 2009. Since 1976, he resided at St. John's University, Jamaica, NY. He is survived by his brother Harold and sisters Audrey Mulholland, Mary Louise Schroeder and Rosemary Stark. The pistol team won the Division III national championships in 2005 and 2007.

The estranged wife of an equipment manager was charged with trying to extort Louisville Coach Rick Pitino. According to a federal complaint, Karen Sypher first demanded cars and tuition for her children, then asked for $10 million, according a federal complaint. She is also accused of lying to the F.B.I. She appeared in court but did not enter a plea and was released on her own recognizance. It was not clear why she was demanding the money. Court documents say only that Pitino said he believed it was related to an encounter in 2003.

Steve Stamkos and Dany Heatley each scored twice for Canada, the silver medalists last year, in a 6-1 win over Belarus in Zurich.

Quality Road, considered a favorite in the Kentucky Derby, has developed more hoof problems that jeopardize his chances of competing May 2 in the 135th running of the Derby. Quality Road, a son of Elusive Quality, sustained a slight quarter crack, or a split in the hoof wall, in his right hind foot after looking superb March 28 in winning the Florida Derby. He has won three of four starts. His trainer, Jimmy Jerkens, noticed a second quarter crack on the inside of his right front hoof on Thursday morning after Quality Road returned from a gallop at Belmont Park. Jerkens called in the hoof specialist Ian McKinlay, who patched the first injury. McKinlay treated the tender feet of Big Brown, who won the Derby and the Preakness last year. The injury was repaired Friday; Jerkens said he hoped to send out Quality Road for a gallop on Saturday.

When Vladimir Guerrero went on the disabled list, the popular thinking was that the power-hitting top prospect Brandon Wood would get his chance in what has been a weak Los Angeles Angels lineup. Wood had a strong spring and had four home runs in six Class AAA games. But Manager Mike Scioscia said Wood's stay may be short as the team fiddles with its pitching. Wood was first available on Wednesday, but Scioscia started the light-hitting Maicer Izturis at designated hitter and batted him third. On Friday, Robb Quinlan was the D.H. Go figure.

Sudden substitutions often befall opera casts, and they sometimes occur on the conductor’s podium, too. Just before the Metropolitan Opera’s presentation of “Das Rheingold” on Thursday, the conductor James Levine, above, became ill. The assistant conductor John Keenan went on in Mr. Levine’s place. Lee Abrahamian, the Met’s director of communications, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Levine had come down with “some sort of stomach bug” but was expected to return for the Saturday matinee performance of “Götterdämmerung,” which will be broadcast live online and on the Toll Brothers-Metropolitan Opera International Radio Network and Sirius XM satellite radio.
On Thursday, CBS edged past ABC for first place in prime time. CBS earned its largest audiences for “Survivor” (11.4 million viewers) and “CSI” (14.5 million), according to Nielsen’s estimates.

Zack Greinke is not perfect anymore, but he is still undefeated and still one of the best stories in baseball. Although Greinke's scoreless streak to begin the season stopped at 24 innings, he pitched brilliantly in guiding the Kansas City Royals to a 6-1 victory against the Detroit Tigers at Kauffman Stadium. Greinke was dominant in pitching a three-hitter for his second consecutive complete game. He used a 97-mile-per-hour fastball, a vicious slider and a curveball that almost bounced to collect some of his 10 strikeouts. Although Greinke (4-0) was nicked for a run, it was unearned, so he maintained his 0.00 earned run average.

Devils forward Zach Parise, who had his most productive season, was named one of the three finalists for the Lady Byng Trophy, along with Detroit's Pavel Datsyuk, who has won the award the last three seasons, and Tampa Bay's Martin St. Louis, a four-time finalist. The Lady Byng Trophy is awarded to the player who excels while displaying ''the best type of sportsmanship.'' Parise played in all 82 games, scoring a career-high 45 goals, but he received only 12 minor penalties. byng DAVE CALDWELL

President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. were hustled from the White House to a secure location on Friday when a single-engine airplane veered into restricted airspace around the capital, the White House disclosed. KORCHIN--Mortimer, age 86, died April 21, 2009. Born and raised in Brooklyn, he was known to his family and friends as Morty. He was the long-time owner and President of Marshall Smoked Fish Co., Inc., of Brooklyn, New York, until the sale of the company in 1998. Morty traveled extensively in the United States and abroad to find the best quality products for the American market. He served in the U.S. Army infantry in the European theatre during World War II. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Rosalia; his brother Leo and sister-in-law Norma; his son William and daughter-in-law Sonia; his daughter Catherine and son-in-law William; and three grandchildren, Paige (age eight), William (age five), and Dylan (age four). A devoted family man, he had a generous spirit, a warm heart and a keen sense of humor. The wake will be held at the John J. Fox Funeral Home (2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY) on Sunday, April 26th, from 1-5pm and 7-9pm, and Monday, April 27th, from 9-10am, followed by the service. Morty, you are deeply loved and sorely missed.

The business leaders in this town astride the Polish-German border can't wait for Poland to adopt the euro. Twenty years after the fall of Communism, the region's economy has been rebuilt in a Western image by entrepreneurs who mastered all sorts of challenges, like getting their early shipments past border guards and engineering products that their European neighbors actually wanted to buy.

Leaders of Jamaat-e-Islami, a Pakistani religious party, behind party flags during a rally in Peshawar on Friday. Those at the rally spoke against American drone attacks near the Afghanistan border, in the northwestern tribal areas where militants, including the Taliban, have been largely beyond the reach of the Pakistan government. Pakistani and Afghan officials have criticized many of the attacks aimed at the militants, saying that civilians have been killed.

BRESLIN--Kelly. Everything said about Kelly was so. No one else was like her. She was effervescent and always smiled. A wonderful child of nature and high spirited. And we will miss her. Toni Schulman & family

LALLY--Franca Pironti, the founder of Parliamo Italiano Italian Language School, died at home on the evening of Tuesday, April 21st at the age of 81, surrounded by family. She was the loving mother of Kevin, Alexandra, Cherida, Brendan, and Fiona, the mother in law of Frederick Peters, Stuart Shultz, Linda Lally, and Joseph Ogilvie, and the beloved grandmother of Justin, Clelia, Jack, Bart, Max, Oliver, Simon, Francesca, Jude, Liam and Josephine. Born in Spoleto, Italy in 1927, Franca was the daughter of Professor Francesco Pironti and his wife Teresa. She met and married Captain John Lally, a British officer stationed in Naples, in 1946. They moved intrepidly through life, creating opportunity in each of the many countries in which they lived before settling in 1966 at 132 East 65th Street, where they created a salon of family, friends, artists, educators, and students which influenced everyone who was drawn in by its magnetic pull. Franca and John opened Parliamo Italiano in 1978, and Franca designed and implemented the curriculum which made it one of the most successful language programs in the city. She continued to teach classes until a few months ago. We will remember with love and admiration her courage, her enormous intellect, her commitment to high moral principles, and her generous and loving heart which drew so many to her. May she be reunited now with her beloved John. The family will receive friends at an Open House at Parliamo Italiano Italian Language School, 132 East 65th Street, between 4 and 7pm on Sunday, April 26th. There will be a memorial service at a later date.

di MONTEZEMOLO--Catherine Murray, of Southampton, New York died on Wednesday, April 22nd. She was 83. "Cathy" was predeceased in 2003 by her husband of 45 years, Alessandro di Montezemolo, a charming Italian nobleman who was an equestrian Champion and later CEO of Marsh & Mclennan Companies. She is survived by three sisters, Patricia Wood, Jeanne Vanderbilt and Elizabeth Conniff. She is also survived by many nephews and nieces including Robin Pickett and Hilary Geary Ross. Catherine graduated from the Convent of the Holy Child and spent the next 35 years at Vogue Magazine where she became Fashion Editor. She was instrumental in developing a young market which included names such as Ann Fogarty, Judy and Jill, Junior League. Later she developed a rising market: Sportswear--including designers such as Clare Mcardell, Caroline Schnurer, Sydney Wragge. After another 12 years as Senior V.P. and Fashion Director at Lord & Taylor she retired to her beloved Southampton to devote more time to her two favorite charities -- The Southampton Fresh Air Home and the Southampton Hospital. She served actively on each board, chairing many of their more important fund raisers. Honors given her during this period were numerous. Born into the well known Murray family of Southampton, She more than held her own with her famous sisters in the fields of charity, fashion and sports. For many years she lead all leagues in beauty and style. Contributions may be made to Southampton Hospital (240 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968) or the Southampton Fresh Air Home (36 Barkers Island Road, Southampton, NY 11968). A Memorial service will be held on Saturday, May 23rd, 2009 at 5pm at the Dune Church, Southampton, New York.

We will love her always. Shelby, Leslie, Shawn and the entire Modell family

A new film by Francis Ford Coppola will open Directors' Fortnight, the annual French film series held independently from but parallel to the Cannes Film Festival, Variety reported. Mr. Coppola's film, ''Tetro,'' about a young man who travels to Buenos Aires in search of his older brother, played by Vincent Gallo, is scheduled to be shown on May 14. Other films in the lineup include Cherien Dabis's first feature, ''Amreeka,'' which opened the New Directors/New Films series in New York in March; Lynn Shelton's comedy ''Humpday,'' which was sold for distribution at the Sundance Film Festival in January; and Glenn Ficarra and John Requa's ''I Love You Phillip Morris,'' starring Ewan McGregor and Jim Carrey, which also played at Sundance. The series will conclude on May 24 with ''Ajami,'' a drama by Yaron Shani and Scandar Copti about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

COMRAS--Joseph, 75. Real estate developer and financier passed April 23. He was a loving husband, father, brother and grandfather. He was a legend in his time and a pillar of strength and courage. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. He is survived by his devoted wife, Libby, his loving sons David, Richard and Michael, daughters-in-law Randi, Susan and Jamie, adoring sister and brother-in-law Bobbi and Herbie, grandchildren Ashley, Bryan, Jared, Jordyn, Dylan and Mikayla, and extended family the Baldors and Walkers. Over the past 49 years, Joe, has been one of the most prolific commercial and residential developers in New York City and Miami Beach. Joe began his career as Vice President and partner at one of the country's largest mortgage banking firms, Sonnenblick- Goldman New York. Joe was a member of the Real Estate Board of New York, the Urban Land Institute, and the International Council of Shopping Centers, as well as serving as Trustee of the National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine and a Founder of Mt. Sinai MedicalCenter. Joe was the co-founder of The Comras Company, which today, is at the forefront of retail development and leasing on Miami Beach and Dade County. The Company has been instrumental in bringing many of the world's leading retailers to the area. Joseph Comras aka "Papa Joe" had an unbridled passion for classic cars and boats and lived life to the fullest. He will be greatly missed by all! Donations can be made to Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Miami Beach, 4302 Alton Road, Miami Beach, Fl 33140 (305-674-2959), or The National Jewish Center, 1400 JacksonStreet, Denver, Col- orado 80206 (303-388-4461).

SCALA--Anthony J. Sr.,of Vero Beach, Florida, and long time resident of Harrison, NY, passed away on April 22nd at the age of 85. Mr. Scala was born in New York City on August 24th 1923. He graduated from Manhattan College and was a lieutenant in the US Navy serving in the Pacific during World War II. Mr. Scala retired from Lowy & Donnath, an electrical construction firm in New York City, in 2002 and served as president for over 40 years. He was a registered Professional Engineer in New York, New Jersey, and Idaho. He is survived by his four sons: Anthony Jr. (Mary Ellen) of Port Chester, James (Deborah) of Harrison, Peter (Joyce) of Massachusetts and Christopher (Kerry) of Harrison, his 13 grandchildren and his wife Jadwiga. He was predeceased by his wife Helen and son William. Visiting hours will be at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY, on Sunday from 2-4, 7-9, with the funeral mass on Monday at 11am at St. Gregory the Great Church in Harrison.

It is hard to believe, perhaps, but six decades ago there was an N.F.L. team called the Boston Yanks. Yes, the Boston Yanks. The team played most of its home games in Fenway Park and lasted as a franchise from 1944 to 1948. The team, in short, was awful. Its best record in a season was the 4-7-1 mark it compiled in 1947 under Coach Clipper Smith.

New works by Duncan Sheik, the Tony Award-winning composer of ''Spring Awakening,'' and the comedian Lewis Black will be presented this summer at the Powerhouse Theater of Vassar and New York Stage and Film. The theater announced its 2009 season, which includes ''Whisper House,'' a musical ghost story featuring music and lyrics by Mr. Sheik and book and lyrics by Kyle Jarrow and directed by Keith Powell (of television's ''30 Rock''). Also on the bill is ''One Slight Hitch,'' a play by Mr. Black (of ''The Daily Show'' fame) and directed by Joe Grifasi, as well as ''The Burnt Part Boys,'' a new musical that Playwrights Horizons and the Vineyard Theater are jointly producing for Playwrights' 2010 season. More information can be found at powerhouse.vassar.edu.

The Ford Motor Company unleashed a torrent of dismal financial numbers Friday, saying that it lost $1.4 billion, sales fell 43 percent and it spent $3.7 billion of its cash during the first quarter. But in the new math of the Detroit auto industry, this was good news.

LOWENSTEIN--Louis. The Faculty, Administration, Advisory Council, Alumni Association, and students of the Columbia University School of Social Work note with sadness the death of Louis Lowenstein, LL.B on April 18th in New York at the age of 93. He will be long remembered as a scholar, professor, and philanthropist who made public service an integral part of his career. In 2000, Helen, his wife, and he founded and endowed the Lowenstein Loan Repayment Assistance Fellowship, a fellowship program at the School of Social Work to assist mature students committed to full-time, not-for-profit social work pay prior loans and reduce the need for additional student loans. Sincerest condolences are extended to Helen Lowenstein, his son Roger, his daughters Jane Mairs and Barbara Pearl, and the entire Lowenstein family. Dr. Jeanette C. Takamura, Dean

President Obama did some not-so-subtle jawboning of colleges on the tuition front on Friday, challenging college and university officials ''to put affordability front and center as they chart a path forward.'' The president's message was cast as a pep talk for higher education to cut waste and inefficiency, just as he has urged the federal government to do. But the impetus was to counter spiraling tuition costs at a time when many students and their parents are having difficulty coming up with payments, because of lost income as well as tight credit.

NBC canceled a second ''Tonight Show'' on Friday because of the illness of Jay Leno, right, but the network said he was feeling better and would return on Monday. Mr. Leno told staff members when he arrived at his office on Thursday that he was not feeling well. After some conversation with producers he decided to go to a hospital, and NBC, which said he probably had a stomach virus, showed a repeat on Thursday night. Except for scheduled time off, Mr. Leno had never missed a ''Tonight Show'' in his 17 years as host. The only other time he did not appear during a week when the show was in production was on May 12, 2003, when he exchanged roles with Katie Couric, who was then a ''Today'' show host. For NBC, Mr. Leno's health is more important than ever because he will start a new show in prime time five nights a week this fall. Mr. Leno was expected to return home from the hospital on Friday afternoon.

The Quotation of the Day on Friday, taken from an article about the Pakistani government's paralysis in the face of Taliban advances, misstated the given name of a senior research associate for the RAND Corporation who said, ''I don't know what the Taliban's game plan is, but what seems apparent is the state has no game plan.'' As the article correctly noted, she is Christine Fair, not Christina.

Sudden substitutions often befall opera casts, and they sometimes occur on the conductor's podium, too. Just before the Metropolitan Opera's presentation of ''Das Rheingold'' on Thursday, the conductor James Levine, above, became ill. The assistant conductor John Keenan went on in Mr. Levine's place. Lee Abrahamian, the Met's director of communications, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Levine had come down with ''some sort of stomach bug'' but was expected to return for the Saturday matinee performance of ''Götterdämmerung,'' which will be broadcast live online and on the Toll Brothers-Metropolitan Opera International Radio Network and Sirius XM satellite radio.

WALBRIDGE--Cope B.,95, died peacefully in Blue Bell, PA on April 19th. Born in Chestnut Hill, PA, he graduated from St. Paul's School in 1931, Yale University in 1935 and Yale School of Architecture in 1939. He served in the U.S. Navy during WWII. In 1947 he married Elizabeth Mason and worked for the architecture firm of O'Connor & Kilham. He was an active amateur actor and singer for the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd., with leads in many Gilbert and Sullivan operettas. He also performed with the Amateur Comedy Club and the York Players. He is survived by his wife and three children. A memorial service is on Wednesday, April 29th at 11:30am at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Fort Washington, PA. A gathering in New York City is planned for a later date.
LOOKING AHEAD With PlaNYC

GERBER--Jordan. Our condolences to the entire Gerber family. We will always remember the days with Jordan in the pool, fishing excursions, and feeding the fish in the pond. He was a good friend to many, a great father and husband. Jordan will be missed by everyone with whom he came in contact. Jeffrey, Jesse, Jordan Lichtenberg

DeMaurice Smith, the new chief of the N.F.L. Players Association, will get plenty of experience negotiating a new labor contract with owners later this year. But first, he has to get his own contract situation worked out. Smith, who was chosen by players six weeks ago to fill the position after Gene Upshaw died in August, said Friday that he had no intention of walking away from his new job, even though he has been working without a contract and he and the union are believed to be far apart on salary and length-of-contract demands. Smith was chosen from four finalists, but parameters for a contract were not ironed out before the election.

BRESLIN--Kelly, August 3, 1964 - April 21, 2009. Always and forever in our hearts and prayers - We will think of you every day with love eternally. Aunt Phyllis, Dr. Party Sean, The Noonan Family, Daniel and Patricia Sherman
SIEGENFELD--Saul, Bus, 99, husband of Charlotte, died April 22, 2009 in Laguna Beach, CA. He is survived by his children Jane, Andy and Billy, four grandchildren, and eight great-grandchildren.

LAUREN--Rena. Dear Sweet Rene, my loving wife, cherished mother, adoring grandmother, charming mother-in-law, devoted sister. Loved by all who knew her. She was an elegant woman of style and grace. She lit up everyone's life. Love, Lenny

LAUREN--Rena. Services: Tuesday, April 28 at noon. Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd. 914.235.1800. In lieu of flowers donations to Morse Geriatric Center, West Palm Beach are welcome.

Leslie Ayvazian (“Nine Armenians”) and Kia Corthron (“Force Continuum”) are among 10 playwrights the Ensemble Studio Theater has gathered together for “Marathon 2009,” the company’s 31st annual marathon, scheduled for May 22 through June 27 at the Midtown theater. Divided into two evenings, the ten plays – nine of them premieres – range in theme from issues surrounding Iraq to family dramas. … “Jimmy,” a gender bending solo performance by Marie Brassard about a gay hairdresser born inside the dream of another man, will be presented May 27 through June 14 at Performance Space 122 in the East Village. … The Potomac Theater Project, which presented Jan Maxwell in Howard Barker’s “Scenes From an Execution” last year, will return to the Atlantic Stage 2 theater for its latest repertory season. Coming up in the June 30-July 26 run are another play by Mr. Barker, “The Europeans,” and “Therese Raquin,” an adaptation of the Zola novel by Neal Bell, who was also represented by a play in last year’s rep: “Somewhere in the Pacific.” Like last year, the season will also include an “After Dark” series of new plays in progress.

With the unusually large number of new shows opening on Broadway this spring, the run had to come to an end at some point: The Joan Allen–Jeremy Irons play “Impressionism,” which opened March 24 to largely negative reviews, will close on May 10, the publicist for the production announced Sunday evening.

Today The Times released the full schedules of Timothy F. Geithner from January 2007 to January 2009, when he was president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. We obtained the calendar through a Freedom of Information Act request. An examination of his schedules - backed by dozens of interviews - offers a rich account of the people and forces that shaped Mr. Geithner's thinking and actions during one of the greatest financial crises in U.S. history.

An urbanizing planet knitted by transportation is an extraordinarily welcoming world for infectious disease, particularly easily transmitted viruses like the flu. That's why it wasn't surprising Saturday when the World Health Organization concluded that the outbreaks of swine flu focused in central Mexico as well as a school in New York City and several other places around the United States officially constituted "a public health emergency of international concern." Here's a W.H.O. video describing their surveillance efforts. Will the safety net hold?

Toronto FC Coach John Carver resigned Saturday for personal reasons from a team with a 2-2-2 record. The assistant coaches Chris Cummins and Nick Dasovic will handle the coaching duties until a replacement is selected next week, the team said in a statement. Toronto FC will host Kansas City on Sunday.

The two-time Daytona 500 winner Michael Waltrip says it is too early to decide if he will retire at the end of this season or return in 2010. Waltrip has not won a race since 2003 and enters Sunday’s race at Talladega Superspeedway 25th in the Sprint Cup standings. He could retire and devote his full energy to running Michael Waltrip Racing. Waltrip opened the season with a seventh-place finish in the Daytona 500, but has finished 24th or worse in five other Cup races.

The veterinarian who injected 21 elite polo horses with a supplement before a championship match in Florida and then watched them die says the grief is unbearable. The Argentine veterinarian Felix Crespo said he injected the horses a week ago with a supplement provided to him by the Venezuelan-owned team’s veterinarian in Florida. Crespo said that he did not know if he would ever be the same again.

Tennessee set an American record in the 4x800-meter relay on Saturday to complete a rare triple in the Penn Relays at Franklin Field, finishing in 8 minutes 17.91 seconds. Tennessee is just the third program and sixth women’s team to take the distance medley and the 4x1,500- and 4x800-meter events in the 115-year history of the meet.

Alexa Glatch of the United States upset Iveta Benesova, 6-1, 6-2, to give the Americans a 1-1 tie with the Czech Republic in the opening singles of the Fed Cup semifinals. Petra Kvitova defeated Bethanie Mattek-Sands, 6-3, 7-6 (2), in the first match on the indoor hardcourt at Rondo Arena in Brno.

Juan Pablo Montoya won the first pole of his Nascar career, taking the top starting spot for the Aaron’s 499 at Talladega Superspeedway to put himself in position for his first win on an oval. Since leaving Formula One in late 2006, Montoya has won only once, on a road course.

American sprinters won four of six races billed as “The US vs. The World” at the Penn Relays, beating rival Jamaica to win both the men’s and women’s 4x100- and 4x400-meter relays. In the women’s 4x400, the United States team of Monica Hargrove, Natasha Hastings, Allyson Felix and Sanya Richards won in 3 minutes 23.08 seconds after Hastings lost her left shoe during the exchange with Hargrove and ran her entire leg with a bare foot.

Duke swingman Gerald Henderson is entering the N.B.A. draft but is keeping open the option to return to Durham for his senior season. The university said in an announcement that Henderson had not hired an agent. In his junior year, Henderson led the Blue Devils with 16.5 points and scored at least 10 points in 31 games. If he stays in the draft, he would be the Blue Devils’ only regular starter not returning for next season.

A national spring game record crowd of 95,722 came out to watch Terrelle Pryor throw two long touchdown passes in 30 seconds, leading the Gray over the Scarlet, 23-3, at sun-drenched Ohio Stadium in Columbus. The attendance topped the 92,138 Alabama drew for Nick Saban’s coaching debut in 2007.

The defending champion Lorena Ochoa shot a four-under 69 in windy conditions to take a one-stroke lead over Suzann Pettersen into the final round of the L.P.G.A. Tour’s Corona Championship in Morelia, Mexico. Ochoa had a 20-under 199 total. After opening with consecutive bogey-free 65s, she had eight birdies, two bogeys and a double bogey.
Martin Lel of Kenya withdrew from Sunday’s London Marathon after failing to recover from a hip injury, thwarting his bid to become the first man to win it four times.
Jerry Kelly shot a bogey-free three-under-par 69 to increase his lead to three strokes at the Zurich Classic on Saturday in New Orleans.

Manchester United maintained its title charge by beating Tottenham, 5-2, after a remarkable second-half comeback wiped out visiting Tottenham’s two-goal advantage. United is 3 points clear at the top of the Premier League.

Jack Johnson scored two goals as the United States defeated Latvia, 4-2, in an opening-round game at the world championships in Bern, Switzerland. Drew Stafford and Patrick O’Sullivan also scored for the sixth-ranked Americans. Robert Esche stopped 18 shots for the United States.

An Op-Ed article on Wednesday, about Cleopatra, misstated the number of years since her death. It was 2,038 years ago, not 2,039.

In Europe, Fiat is well known for its mastery of diesel engines. In fact, one reason General Motors bought a 20 percent stake in Fiat's auto division back in 2000 was to help expand the diesel offerings of its Opel unit. That partnership didn't work out so well: G.M. paid Fiat $2 billion to extricate itself from the partnership four years later, although Opel did benefit from better diesel technology.

The Off the Shelf column last Sunday, a review of “The Cost of Capitalism,” referred incorrectly to the economist Hyman Minsky. Although he received master’s and doctoral degrees at Harvard, he spent most of his career at other schools; he was not known as “a Harvard economist.”.

An article last Sunday about writers’ twilight years misstated the ages of Charlotte Brontë and Flaubert when they died. Brontë was 38, not in her 40s. Flaubert was 58, not 68.

An article last Sunday about the history of wits in Congress misidentified the state that Senator John Sharp Williams represented and the party that Abraham Lincoln belonged to when he was a representative from 1847 to 1849. Senator Williams was from Mississippi, not Virginia, and Lincoln was a Whig. (The Republican Party was not founded until 1854.) The article also misstated the date of a scuffle in the House involving Representatives John Potter and William Barksdale. It was in February 1858, not the summer of 1958.

The antecedents of some of the teachings of the Redeemed Christian Church of God (Andrew Rice, April 12) are historically familiar, but the implications are fraught with potential danger. When Pastor Enoch Adeboye preaches that his followers “are a chosen people and have a special covenant with God,” he is merely echoing what other faiths have been claiming for centuries, starting with Judaism and continuing through Christianity (especially Calvinism and Mormonism) and Islam. But I wonder what Pastor Daniel Ajayi-Adeniran means when he speaks against “the gospel of tolerance” that has contributed to “moral decadence”? With the exception of Judaism, the above-mentioned have all been and are proselytizing faiths; faiths that have been and still are all too quick, in their extreme forms, to condemn or eliminate those who don’t accept their version of the truth. We live in a religiously diverse nation and world. Without toleration and respect for the faiths of others, including the views of those who reject religious faith completely, we will continue to make war on our fellow human beings based on the self-serving provincialism of these pastors and their ilk across the religious spectrum.

According to Wyatt Mason’s article on Frederick Seidel (April 12), anthologists keep leaving him out. “From one major anthology of poetry, the Oxford, he was excluded for 47 years, and he still won’t be found in another, the Norton.” For the record, Seidel is represented with two substantial poems in “The Oxford Book of American Poetry” (2006). His work also appears in three of the last five volumes in the annual “Best American Poetry” series as well as in previous editions assembled by Jorie Graham (1990) and A. R. Ammons (1994). Only two editions of “The Oxford” appeared in the 47 years prior to 2006. When Oxford published F. O. Matthiessen’s selection in 1950, Seidel was 14. If Richard Ellmann had chosen Seidel for the 1976 book, he would have been the youngest contemporary poet in the volume, with one book to his name. Neither the 1950 nor the 1976 edition was revised when reprinted. To say that Seidel “was excluded for 47 years” from the Oxford is a little like saying that The New York Times Magazine has ignored him for 73 years.

CALLAHAN--Nancy K. (nee Jones), accomplished aviator, oceanographer and business lawyer, died in Honolulu on April 5, 2009 after a long illness. She was 58. Ms. Callahan earned a juris doctor degree in 1976 with the first graduating class of the William S. Richardson School of Law of the University of Hawaii. She began her legal career in New York as an associate with the admiralty law firm of Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens. She then moved to the Legal Department of The Chase Manhattan Bank, where she became a Vice President and Senior Associate Counsel. Ms. Callahan was born in Sioux Falls, South Dakota on September 17, 1950, the daughter of Gardiner B. Jones, Jr., and Kathleen Orr Jones. She is survived by three daughters, Jane Callahan of Honolulu, Clare Callahan of Brooklyn, Hannah Callahan, a college student, and one son, Timothy Callahan, who is teaching in Shanghai, and by her former husband Joseph P. Callahan and also by two brothers, Gardiner B. Jones, III of Nashville, Tennessee, and Kinley C. Jones of Ewa Beach, Hawaii. Her parents and two sisters, Lucy and Margaret, predeceased her. A funeral service was held at Holy Nativity Church on Saturday, April 11.

Of the six hitters who began Saturday tied for the most strikeouts in the National League, only one seems as if he did not belong. Cameron Maybin and Jordan Schafer are talented rookies becoming acclimated to major league pitching. Prince Fielder is a slugger who struck out 135 times last season. Lance Berkman was bothered early by shoulder soreness. Mark Reynolds set a single-season record in 2008 by striking out 204 times. That leaves David Wright, who had 20 strikeouts in 66 at-bats (77 plate appearances) after Saturday's game against the Nationals -- or one every 3.85 times up. On Saturday, he went 0 for 3 with one strikeout. Since 2006, Wright has gradually struck out less often -- once every 5.85 plate appearances in 2006 to 6.18 in 2007 to 6.24 in 2008.
