SHAPIRO--Jacob Aron (October 24, 1982) of Leonia, NJ, died in a tragic automobile accident Friday, April 17th in St. Helena, CA. He was the beloved son of Catherine and Jonathan Shapiro, the younger brother of Joshua and Jeremy, brother-in-law of Amy, uncle to Benjamin, grandson of Samuel L. Shapiro, nephew to many aunts and uncles and cousin to Nicholas, Matthew and Rachael. He was also beloved by a worldwide network of close, enduring and extraordinary friends. He was a graduate of the Fieldston School, Class of 2001 and Hamilton College, Class of 2005, where he was an economics major and an All-Conference soccer player. From 2006-2008, he was a sushi chef at Mamasake in Squaw Valley, CA and a celebrated member of the Lake Tahoe community. Since January 2009, he was a student at the Culinary Institute of America at Greystone. Jacob had an insatiable appetite and gusto for life. He traveled the world with an almost unimaginable enthusiasm and joy. He was an accomplished and skilled athlete and voracious dancer. He had a smile with wattage. He loved and was loved. A star who shone brightly, Jacob's memory will be carried in many, many hearts. Contributions to the "Following Your Dream" Scholarship made payable to the CIA Scholarship Fund in memory of Jacob Shapiro can be sent to the Culinary Institute of America at Greystone, 2555 Main Street, St. Helena, CA 94574.

When Vladimir Guerrero went on the disabled list, the popular thinking was that the power-hitting prospect Brandon Wood would get his chance in what has been a weak Los Angeles Angels lineup. Wood, left, had a strong spring and had four home runs in six Class AAA games. But Manager Mike Scioscia said Wood's stay may be short as the team fiddles with its pitching. Wood was first available on Wednesday, but Scioscia started the light-hitting Maicer Izturis at designated hitter and batted him third. On Friday, Robb Quinlan was the D.H. Go figure. Joel Hanrahan blew his first two save opportunities with Washington and had an earned run average of 9.00. Then the closer-in-waiting Garrett Mock was promoted, and Hanrahan notched his next two saves, with two scoreless innings. WALBRIDGE--Cope B.,95, died peacefully at his home in Blue Bell, PA on April 19th with his family around him. Born in Chestnut Hill, Pa., he attended Chestnut Hill Academy, the Adirondack-Florida School, and St. Paul's School in New Hampshire. He graduated with the Yale University class of 1935 and the Yale School of Architecture class of 1939. Mr. Walbridge served in the U.S. Navy during World War II, teaching radar and aircraft recognition in Pensacola, FL. Moving to New York City, he joined the architecture firm of O'Connor & Kilham, which designed buildings for schools and colleges. In 1947 he married Elizabeth Mason, a parnership that was to last 62 years. Mr. Walbridge had an outstanding singing voice and was active in amateur theatrical productions in New York City. A long time member of the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd., he is one of the few to have performed a lead role in every Gilbert and Sullivan operetta. He also performed regularly for the Amateur Comedy Club and the York Players. His hospitality was legendary. He and his wife hosted rehearsals and try-outs at their Manhattan house for decades. They also provided long-term housing for friends, children of friends, and relatives. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Elizabeth Mason Walbridge, and his three children: Charles, Elizabeth, and Margaret. A memorial service at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Whitemarsh, PA. is scheduled for Wednesday, April 29th at 11:30am. A gathering in their New York City home is planned for a later date. The Blue Hill Troupe has set up a fund in Mr. Walbridge's memory. Checks should be made out to Blue Hill Troupe Ltd. mentioning the Cope Walbridge memorial in the memo. Their address is Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd P.O. Box 286800, Yorkville Station, New York, NY 10128.

To the Editor: Christopher Shaw's article ''In the Dordogne, Canoeing Into Prehistory'' (April 5) brought back very good memories of a day I spent in the area visiting two of France's treasures. Both of them are gone now. The Lascaux caves were closed to the public in 1963, and Josephine Baker died in 1975. In 1962, 19 years old and living in Paris, I visited my girlfriend in Sarlat, where she worked in an orphanage. One morning, the chaplain took us to tour the Lascaux caves. We were the only ones in the caverns, which added a reflective tone to our transport back tens of thousands of years.

JUST what the world was waiting to hear about on Earth Day: a vegetable-friendly, at least partly biodegradable racing car. A team from the Warwick Innovative Manufacturing Research Center at the University of Warwick in Britain said it had built a Formula 3 car that runs on 30 percent biodiesel derived from chocolate waste, with a race-spec steering wheel partly made of carrots and other root vegetables. Parts of the front wing and the mirrors are made of potato starch and flax fiber. No gingerbread or jelly beans were harmed in the making of the car.

WALBRIDGE--Cope B.,95, died peacefully in Blue Bell, PA on April 19th. Born in Chestnut Hill, PA, he graduated from St. Paul's School in 1931, Yale University in 1935 and Yale School of Architecture in 1939. He served in the U.S. Navy during WWII. In 1947 he married Elizabeth Mason and worked for the architecture firm of O'Connor & Kilham. He was an active amateur actor and singer for the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd., with leads in many Gilbert and Sullivan operettas. He also performed with the Amateur Comedy Club and the York Players. He is survived by his wife and three children. A memorial service is on Wednesday, April 29th at 11:30am at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Fort Washington, PA. A gathering in New York City is planned for a later date.

During morning announcements at Clinton Elementary School in Maplewood, two students leaned into the microphone to recite the two green tips of the day: ''When it is cold in your house, instead of turning up the heat, put on a sweater or use a blanket,'' followed by, ''When you outgrow your clothes, you can cut them into scraps to sew them into a beautiful memory quilt,'' the latter conjuring up images of overeager children rifling through their dresser drawers with scissors in hand. Saving energy and recycling old things are major themes of Patty O'Neill, Clinton's principal of two years. Her first priority was to get recycling bins in every classroom and the lunchrooms, so teachers and students can dump paper, plastics, aluminum and cardboard.

Quality Road, an early Kentucky Derby favorite, jogged a mile and three-quarters Saturday at Belmont Park without discomfort a day after having a quarter crack in his right front hoof laced. His trainer, Jimmy Jerkens, said it was uncertain whether he would ship the colt to Churchill Downs for the Derby. Jerkens said the colt's hoof was dry and there was no blood seeping after the workout. He said jogging is much easier on a horse's feet, but that it isn't the ideal way to condition a horse to go ''a mile and a quarter against the best horses in the nation.''

LUTTINGER--Dr. Lionel, 89, physical chemist. Lionel Luttinger died on Tuesday, March 17, due to complications following surgery. Born in 1920, he lived most of his childhood in New York City where his father (a prominent leftist doctor and medical researcher) introduced him to radical politics from a young age. Inspired by his father, he later became very involved in union organizing in the late 1930s and early 40s. After serving in the army during World War II, he worked at the Kellex corporation on the Manhatten Project. After this, he went to college at CCNY, and got a degree in chemistry. He earned a Ph.D in Physical Chemistry from Brooklyn Polytechnic, and went on to a post-doc at Yale. Dr. Luttinger spent much of his professional career working in the industrial sector, specializing in polymer chemistry, reverse osmosis, and environmental chemistry. His work resulted in numerous patents in these fields, including those for the chemistry behind glow sticks, photogrey lenses (a precursor to the Transitions lenses for glasses that become darker in sunlight), a process for purifying gold, and amergize, a petroleum additive that allows oil to burn more efficiently. A catalyst he developed for the synthesis of polyacetylene is known as the Luttinger catalyst. After raising his children in Connecticut and Pennsylvania, Lionel lived mostly in Brooklyn Heights in his later years. After retiring he became very involved in writing his memoirs as well as fiction. In 2007, he moved out to Iowa City to be nearer to his daughter Amy and her children. Dr. Luttinger is survived by his five children (Andrey, Amy, Karl, Tanya, and Nina Luttinger), seven grandchildren (Hannah Pomales, Celeste Alexander, Alexander Kaaret, Maija Liisa Luttinger, Zachery James, Owen James, and Xeno Madrone), and his sister Judy Florence.

di MONTEZEMOLO--Catherine Murray, of Southampton, New York died on Wednesday, April 22nd. She was 83. "Cathy" was predeceased in 2003 by her husband of 45 years, Alessandro di Montezemolo, a charming Italian nobleman who was an equestrian Champion and later CEO of Marsh & Mclennan Companies. She is survived by three sisters, Patricia Wood, Jeanne Vanderbilt and Elizabeth Conniff. She is also survived by many nephews and nieces including Robin Pickett and Hilary Geary Ross. Catherine graduated from the Convent of the Holy Child and spent the next 35 years at Vogue Magazine where she became Fashion Editor. She was instrumental in developing a young market which included names such as Ann Fogarty, Judy and Jill, Junior League. Later she developed a rising market: Sportswear--including designers such as Clare Mcardell, Caroline Schnurer, Sydney Wragge. After another 12 years as Senior V.P. and Fashion Director at Lord & Taylor she retired to her beloved Southampton to devote more time to her two favorite charities -- The Southampton Fresh Air Home and the Southampton Hospital. She served actively on each board, chairing many of their more important fund raisers. Honors given her during this period were numerous. Born into the well known Murray family of Southampton, She more than held her own with her famous sisters in the fields of charity, fashion and sports. For many years she lead all leagues in beauty and style. Contributions may be made to Southampton Hospital (240 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968) or the Southampton Fresh Air Home (36 Barkers Island Road, Southampton, NY 11968). A Memorial service will be held on Saturday, May 23rd, 2009 at 5pm at the Dune Church, Southampton, New York.

THE NEWS The White House and Senate Democrats signaled that they would oppose the creation of a special commission to investigate the Bush administration's approval of harsh interrogation techniques that critics call torture. BEHIND THE NEWS Pressure has been rapidly building for a full inquiry, especially after the release of memos detailing the legal rationale for allowing the techniques and a suggestion from Mr. Obama that he would be open to such an inquiry. But Mr. Obama told House leaders who favor it that an inquiry would be an unwise, backward-looking distraction, sapping energy and public attention away from tackling the nation's more pressing problems.

Saying that the government must act ''the same way any responsible family does in setting its budget,'' President Obama called for Congress to pass legislation that would require lawmakers to offset any new tax cuts or spending increases with equivalent tax increases or spending cuts. The legislation, dubbed ''PAYGO,'' for ''pay as you go,'' has become a rallying cry for fiscally conservative Democrats, who are pushing for it to be applied to the health care reform legislation that the White House is hoping will pass this year. But speaking in his weekly address to the nation on Saturday, Mr. Obama said that he wanted it applied more broadly.

RABINOWITZ--Richard W. "Dick", in his 85th year. Dick of Armonk, NY, passed away early Sunday morning (April 19, 2009) at Northern Westchester Hospital after a protracted illness. Born May 14, 1924, in New Haven, CT, to Morris and Beatrice, he graduated from Yale University (B.A., 1945; A.M., 1951); Yale Law School (LL.B., 1950); Harvard University (Ph.D., 1956). Dick studied Japanese while serving his country in WWII. While working on his doctoral degree in Japan, he became one of a handful of foreign lawyers ever admitted to the Japanese Bar, and was admitted to the Korean Bar as well. He practiced law in Tokyo for more than 35 years as a founding partner of what was then the largest and most well-known firm in Japan, Anderson Mori & Rabinowitz. He returned to the United States in 1991, teaching at Harvard and Yale Law Schools. From 1995 until his death, he was Of Counsel to Tozai Sogo Law Office, also of Tokyo, Japan. A lover of Jazz since his early days at University, Dick wept when listening to Billie Holiday, and had great reverence for Count Basie, Duke Ellington and Coleman Hawkins, who, as he explained, got him through many late night study sessions. A high school ice hockey goalie, his devotion to the sport only intensified with age. It was not uncommon for him to schedule his work and naps around what game was on, and was loyal to the game, not a team. Dick is survived by his wife of 57 years, Janice Hope Rabinowitz (Rosenbaum), and their three children, Ann Akiko Rabinowitz Dantzig (Armonk, NY) and her longtime partner John Diacnois, John Makoto Rabinowitz (Benicia, CA) and his wife Loan, Anthony Carl Rabinowitz (South Lake Tahoe, CA) and his wife Lisa, two granddaughters Natasha Chieko and Alexia Haruko Dantzig, and John's children Ari and Alix Diaconis Contributions in Dick's memory may be made in the United States to the Ken Hamilton Caregivers Center, Northern Westchester Hospital Center, 400 East Main Street, Mt. Kisco, New York, 10549; in Japan, contributions are welcome the Library at the International House of Japan (Kokusai Bunka Kaikan), 5-11-16 Roppongi, Minato-ku, Tokyo 106-0032 Japan.

DAVIS--Shulamith, on April 19, 2009 at age 78. Cherished wife of Bernard, mother of Peter and Robert. Taffy will always be remembered for her acts of kindness and love of family and friends. Contributions: The Ossining Children's Center, 90 S. Highland Ave., Ossining, NY.

HAYES--Bebba Chalmers, died in her 95th year, at Hightstown, New Jersey, having lived a good deal longer than she intended as she often told her family. She grew up in New York City, but her connection with Italy was lifelong, beginning with summers spent on the farm near Florence where her mother had been born, and continuing with yearly travel in Europe and beyond as she accompanied her husband, Alfred, who was an international banker, and for many years President of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. After Brearley and Vassar she studied painting in New York, producing some quite-wonderful work that now hangs in the houses of her children, Tita Gratwick of Philadelphia and Tom Hayes of Cambridge, Mass. She is survived also by five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. She lived, for most of her adult life, in New Canaan, Connecticut, and spent many summers in Wainscott, Long Island, where she will be buried alongside her husband. She was a woman of strong likes (for example, Jane Austen, her principal companion in her last, bedridden years) and dislikes (for example, George W. Bush). Her outspoken style endeared her to her friends, and irritated some other people. She maintained her keen interest in her family even in the last days before her death, deprecating her own routine as humdrum and not worth discussing, but curious to know what everyone else in her family was up to.

LALLY--Franca Pironti, the founder of Parliamo Italiano Italian Language School, died at home on the evening of Tuesday, April 21st at the age of 81, surrounded by family. She was the loving mother of Kevin, Alexandra, Cherida, Brendan, and Fiona, the mother in law of Frederick Peters, Stuart Shultz, Linda Lally, and Joseph Ogilvie, and the beloved grandmother of Justin, Clelia, Jack, Bart, Max, Oliver, Simon, Francesca, Jude, Liam and Josephine. Born in Spoleto, Italy in 1927, Franca was the daughter of Professor Francesco Pironti and his wife Teresa. She met and married Captain John Lally, a British officer stationed in Naples, in 1946. They moved intrepidly through life, creating opportunity in each of the many countries in which they lived before settling in 1966 at 132 East 65th Street, where they created a salon of family, friends, artists, educators, and students which influenced everyone who was drawn in by its magnetic pull. Franca and John opened Parliamo Italiano in 1978, and Franca designed and implemented the curriculum which made it one of the most successful language programs in the city. She continued to teach classes until a few months ago. We will remember with love and admiration her courage, her enormous intellect, her commitment to high moral principles, and her generous and loving heart which drew so many to her. May she be reunited now with her beloved John. The family will receive friends at an Open House at Parliamo Italiano Italian Language School, 132 East 65th Street, between 4 and 7pm on Sunday, April 26th. There will be a memorial service at a later date.

TROMMER--Kenneth A. Kane Lodge No. 454 F. & A. M. mourns with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed Brother, suddenly on March 8 from a heart attack, in New Bern, NC. Ken was a member of the Craft for over 20 years and was highly respected and loved by the brethren. For many years he was the general manager of J. Press in New York City. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Phyllis, son Marshall, daughters Deirdre, Kerrie and Valerie, four grandchildren and many friends. His personal charm, warmth and humor shall be greatly missed. Paul D. Reitz, Secretary Stephen A. Rumpf, Master

THE WILD SIDE Bright light has a powerful effect on our body clocks, and if we don't see much of it -- and many office workers do not -- then our circadian health suffers. Till Roenneberg, a professor at Ludwig Maximilians University in Munich, has developed a questionnaire that determines an individual's proclivity to ''morningness'' and ''eveningness.'' He has coined the phrase ''social jet lag'' to describe the persistent mismatch between people's biological clocks and the demands of their jobs or education. It is bad enough for ''larks,'' who tend to be up early, and late-rising ''owls,'' whose genes cause a mismatch between modern life and the ancient human body clock. For ''hummingbirds,'' the 70 percent to 80 percent of us who manage the 24-hour solar cycle well, working night shifts or burning the proverbial candle at both ends, the implications are far-ranging for learning, memory, performance and quality of life. Roenneberg's call to employers to say to their workforce, ''Please wake up in your own time and come in when you are ready,'' is provocative but a challenge that we have not been meeting.

COMRAS--Joseph, 75. Real estate developer and financier passed April 23. He was a loving husband, father, brother and grandfather. He was a legend in his time and a pillar of strength and courage. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. He is survived by his devoted wife, Libby, his loving sons David, Richard and Michael, daughters-in-law Randi, Susan and Jamie, adoring sister and brother-in-law Bobbi and Herbie, grandchildren Ashley, Bryan, Jared, Jordyn, Dylan and Mikayla, and extended family the Baldors and Walkers. Over the past 49 years, Joe, has been one of the most prolific commercial and residential developers in New York City and Miami Beach. Joe began his career as Vice President and partner at one of the country's largest mortgage banking firms, Sonnenblick- Goldman New York. Joe was a member of the Real Estate Board of New York, the Urban Land Institute, and the International Council of Shopping Centers, as well as serving as Trustee of the National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine and a Founder of Mt. Sinai MedicalCenter. Joe was the co-founder of The Comras Company, which today, is at the forefront of retail development and leasing on Miami Beach and Dade County. The Company has been instrumental in bringing many of the world's leading retailers to the area. Joseph Comras aka "Papa Joe" had an unbridled passion for classic cars and boats and lived life to the fullest. He will be greatly missed by all! Donations can be made to Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Miami Beach, 4302 Alton Road, Miami Beach, Fl 33140 (305-674-2959), or The National Jewish Center, 1400 JacksonStreet, Denver, Col- orado 80206 (303-388-4461).

CLAYTON--Joe Don, born September 3, 1934, in Sentinel, OK, passed away on April 18, 2009 in New Lebanon, NY. Prior to 2002, he resided in Brooklyn Heights, NY for over 35 years. Mr. Clayton graduated in 1957 from Yale University, B.A. in history. Joe was awarded a Keasbey scholarship to attend Oxford University's New College and achieved a Doctorate of Philosophy in 1959. In 1964 he was awarded a LL.B from Yale Law School. Joe practiced corporate law in New York City for 30 years with three law firms: Davis, Polk & Wardwell; Mudge Rose Guthrie & Alexander; and retired from White & Case in 1999. Throughout his life Joe's passion was music. At Yale, Joe was active in many singing groups, including the Whiffenpoofs, and was President of The Yale Glee Club. Mr. Clayton is survived by his wife, Denise; three children: Thomas, Katherine, and Andrew; and five grandchildren. The family will initially hold a private ceremony. In June, a service will be held to celebrate his life and his love of music at The Tannery at The Darrow School in New Lebanon, NY.

LYONS--Josephine, died on April 5, 2009. We honor the memory of Josephine Lyons, a girl from Cincinnati who came to New York in her twenties, stayed at the Barbizon, became a Miss Subways, produced (famously) for NBC news, worked for Arthur Godfrey, CBS, Benton & Boles, Ted Bates, Kenyon & Eckhardt, and covered presidential conventions for radio news. A unique and amazing character, Jo adored theater, museums, and great restaurants, and introduced her nephews and nieces to the arts and culture of the city. She was a good friend of the International Center for Photography, a member of the Coffee House and the Overseas Press Club, and a founding member of New York Women in Film. An enthusiastic traveler, Jo had friends in the great cities of the world. A lifelong democrat, Jo fundraised for Hillary Clinton. Jo was loved by many friends and family members who will carry on her torch. A remembrance party will be held on May 23 in New York City. For information -- jolyonsservice@gmail.com

We’re not critics, but from here at our anchorman’s chair at ArtsBeat we’d like to point you to Sunday’s episode of “Breaking Bad.” Much as we enjoyed it for its guest performance by D.J. Qualls (who we’ll always love for “Hustle & Flow”), the episode was stolen by Bob Odenkirk. Over the weekend, Mr. Odenkirk made his first appearance as Saul Goodman, a follicly-challenged lawyer who’s called upon to help Walter (Bryan Cranston) and Jesse (Aaron Paul) out of a jam, but who may have an ulterior motive or two up his rumpled sleeves. You can get a taste of Mr. Odenkirk’s work in this behind-the-scenes segment hosted by the “Breaking Bad” creator Vince Gilligan:

When you settle a lawsuit by agreeing to travel to Hawaii, are you really being punished at all? The rock band Aerosmith agreed to play a makeup show in Maui to help resolve a class-action suit by fans who were disappointed when the group pulled out of a concert there in 2007, The Associated Press reported. In September 2007, the band was scheduled to play a show at Maui’s War Memorial Stadium but canceled abruptly, citing logistical problems. Lawyers for the more than 8,000 fans who filed the suit said that Aerosmith had passed them over to play a concert in Chicago and to perform a private show at a car dealership in Oahu. A date for the makeup performance in Maui has not been set, but a lawyer representing the fans said that it would probably be in September or October, and that all original ticket holders would receive free tickets.

No matter how bad this recession gets, you’ll probably never see Robert De Niro behind the wheel of a taxicab again. But if you’d like to see the actual hack license Mr. De Niro wielded while he was preparing for his role in “Taxi Driver,” along with other artifacts and papers from 68 of his other films, they’re now easy enough to find. On Monday, the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin announced that it had made available more than 1,300 boxes of papers, film, movie props and costumes donated by Mr. De Niro to researchers and the public. The collection, which has been appraised at $5 million, covers Mr. De Niro’s career from the 1968 Brian De Palma feature “Greetings” through 2005’s “Hide and Seek,” and includes everything from the leopard-print boxing robe the actor wore in “Raging Bull” to the coats he donned as the Creature in “Frankenstein.”

The composer John Adams and the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne were among the five recipients of the National Endowment for the Arts‘ 2009 Opera Honors, the agency announced on Monday. The three other recipients are Julius Rudel, the veteran conductor of New York City Opera and the founding artistic director of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts; the director and librettist Frank Corsaro; and the general director Lotfi Mansouri, who introduced the use of supertitles in opera. In a release, the agency said that it had chosen Mr. Adams, the composer of “Nixon in China” and “Doctor Atomic,” and the other artists for their “extraordinary contributions to opera in the United States.” Each honoree will receive a grant of $25,000 and will be celebrated at a program in Washington on Nov. 14.

Several works by the artist James Rosenquist were lost when a brush fire on Saturday destroyed two homes, an office and a studio that the artist kept in Aripeka, Fla., The St. Petersburg Times reported. Mr. Rosenquist, 75, who alongside Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein is considered a seminal figure in the Pop Art movement, was unharmed as were his office staff members. The Times said that the fire began around 3 a.m. on Saturday morning and was believed to be contained when it flared up again and exploded a propane tank in Mr. Rosenquist’ s studio. After controlling the blaze on Sunday afternoon, firefighters told The Times that it had covered 62 acres, and that they considered it suspicious and were investigating its cause. Among the works the artist said he lost was a mural commissioned by the government of France that measured 133 feet high by 24 feet wide.

The Polish pianist Krystian Zimerman surprised his audience during a recital Sunday at the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles when he announced that he would no longer perform in the United States in protest of the country’s military policies, the Web site of The Los Angeles Times reported. Mr. Zimerman was about to play Karol Szymanowski’s “Variations on a Polish Folk Theme,” his final piece of the evening, when he told concertgoers that he would not continue to perform in a country whose military, he said, wants to take over the world. “Get your hands off my country,” Mr. Zimerman said, according to the report. In 2006, Mr. Zimerman halted a performance at Carnegie Hall when he believed he observed a concertgoer recording the recital. A Steinway grand piano that he traveled with was destroyed by the Transportation Security Administration amid heightened security after the 9/11 attacks, apparently because the piano’s glue resembled a compound used in explosives.

Two weeks ago, I took some time to make a trip to Brooklyn to visit a tailoring company run by a man named Martin Greenfield. It was a hike, I got lost, but I finally found the brick factory in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Formerly called Three G's, Martin Greenfield Tailoring is a pretty incredible place run by a no less incredible man. In all my years in fashion I've never seen anything like it: a factory in the truest sense of the word, down to the creaky wood boards that make up the open loft floors. It's a living anachronism, perfectly art directed for a movie set. Martin Greenfield, a Holocaust survivor, has been working at the factory since 1947 when he started as a floor boy. In the late 1970's he purchased the company and he now turns out old-school tailoring like very few others do. He is the keeper of the rapidly disappearing art of handmade tailoring, crafting suits for companies like Neiman Marcus and Brooks Brothers, and, once upon a time, for customers like Bill Clinton and the late Paul Newman. Not one to live in the past, Greenfield is also working with younger, fashion-minded designers (who would probably not appreciate my mentioning them here!), who sought him out for his mastery of the art of tailoring. Costume designers eager to recreate period perfection utilize his expertise and history to help tell their sartorial stories. (He showed me a few pieces from an upcoming cable TV series that he is working on.) Greenfield is filled with stories and is generous with the telling as he walked me through the cutting and sewing floors, past walls filled with photographs and laminated articles. He flipped through books of the finest fabrics from Loro Piana and the like while he talked about the new softer shoulder he was crafting for a particular suit. It was inspiring and heartening to spend a short afternoon with someone with such passion and knowledge ... I'm feeling for Martin Greenfield.

I can't stop thinking about an article this weekend that, while it mentioned food only incidentally, did touch on the current interest in culinary homesteading -- all the do-it-yourselfers who are canning, pickling, tending backyard chicken coops, and planting kitchen gardens.Writing in The New York Times, Elizabeth Giddens told the story of her house in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and how over 150 years or so the history of the house has encapsulated the neighborhood's, and the city's. Built some time around the Civil War when the area around it was largely farmland, the house was bought in 1883 by Hugo Tollner, whose father had founded the legendary Gage & Tollner restaurant in downtown Brooklyn. Tollner fils threw parties for the local gentry that got written up in the newspaper, including one in honor of the Lenox Euchre Club that featured dancing to a string orchestra in the parlor and a light midnight meal.

General Motors will phase out the Pontiac brand in 2010, said Fritz Henderson, president and chief executive of G.M., in a press conference this morning. I had heard that G.M. was giving up on Pontiac last week, at virtually the same time G.M.'s car delivery guys were taking away the test car I'd been driving for a week: a "liquid red" Pontiac G8 GXP. So in some small measure, the news, though anticipated, was personal. I felt as though I were losing my new best friend.

In February 2008, I brought my 91-year-old mother home from the hospital for the last time. Frail and frightened, she was lying on a gurney amid oxygen masks and catheters and I.V. drips, her hands swathed in large boxing-style gloves to prevent her from pulling out the tubes. Hardest for me were her piteous cries. And what was all this suffering accomplishing? She would not be cured. There is no cure for dementia.

diMONTEZEMOLO--Catherine. The Officers and the Board of Directors of the Southampton Fresh Air Home mourn the loss of Catherine diMontezemolo, a devoted and most beloved member of our Board. Cathy's industry and wisdom, her grace and grit; and her love for the children, were without equal. As a Director, Cathy set the highest standard and was an incomparable role model for us all. The rebels said the cease-fire was in response to calls from the United Nations and many foreign governments for a pause in the fighting, but military analysts said it appeared to be a reflection of the rebels' severely weakened position.

GRADUATE education is the Detroit of higher learning. Most graduate programs in American universities produce a product for which there is no market (candidates for teaching positions that do not exist) and develop skills for which there is diminishing demand (research in subfields within subfields and publication in journals read by no one other than a few like-minded colleagues), all at a rapidly rising cost (sometimes well over $100,000 in student loans). Widespread hiring freezes and layoffs have brought these problems into sharp relief now. But our graduate system has been in crisis for decades, and the seeds of this crisis go as far back as the formation of modern universities. Kant, in his 1798 work ''The Conflict of the Faculties,'' wrote that universities should ''handle the entire content of learning by mass production, so to speak, by a division of labor, so that for every branch of the sciences there would be a public teacher or professor appointed as its trustee.''
GERBER--Jordan. My heart is with my children and grandchildren who lost their loving father, grandfather and friend. Ellen

For all the intrigue that had surrounded the mayoral elections in Sochi, Acting Mayor Anatoly N. Pakhomov managed to avoid confronting his critics -- or even acknowledging their existence -- until Friday, when he was outfoxed by a grandmaster. Mr. Pakhomov, who has the support of the Kremlin, appeared to sail to victory in Sunday's election and would lead the city during the 2014 Winter Olympics here. With little time left in the campaign, he attended a ceremony on Friday in a village near Sochi commemorating the Armenian genocide during World War I, a crucial gesture to the city's large Armenian population. He delivered a short address that was respectful, if a bit wooden, and then stepped back to polite clapping, making room for a row of schoolgirls to recite verses that they had memorized.

Union leaders said Sunday that they had reached an agreement with Chrysler that meets federal requirements for the automaker to receive more financing. The deal includes Fiat, the Italian automaker with which Chrysler was ordered by the government to form an alliance before Thursday.

It was a routine call last Thursday from a diligent high school nurse that put health detectives in New York City on the trail of a swine flu outbreak. Over the next few days, things unfolded much like a criminal investigation, with alert epidemiologists cast in the role of the police officer who remembers information on a wanted poster. But as so often happens in New York, the arrest -- or in this case, getting the evidence that clinched the diagnosis -- was almost prevented by a traffic jam.

GERBER--Jordan. The Gerber family is deeply saddened to announce the death of Jordan Gerber. Jordan, known to many as "Jordy", died peacefully after a sudden illness on April 23rd, surrounded by his family. He was 70 years old. A life-long resident of New York, Jordy maintained homes on the Upper East Side and in Westhampton Beach. After founding and operating The New York Jean Company, his successful denim business, where he became known as "The King of Jeans", he "retired" and joined his sons Scott, Rande and Kenny in the creation of Gerber Group, which owns and operates more than 30 bars and restaurants nationwide, including Stone Rose in the Time Warner Center and Whiskey Blue in the W Hotel. Jordy's role at the Gerber Group included oversight of construction projects for the company and, more importantly, served as a primary point of contact between management and the thousands of employees who adored him. The familial relationship Jordy built with his employees helped foster the outstanding customer service that has become a trademark of the Gerber Group's success. Jordy's extended family very clearly included both the Gerber Group's employees and its celebrity clientele. Born in Brooklyn, New York he was a graduate of Oceanside High School and Boston University where he was a member of the Phi Epsilon Chi fraternity. He was also a passionate sportsman who loved spending time outdoors and enjoyed the beauty of the Hamptons. Jordy is survived by his beloved wife Kelly, sons Scott (wife Tracey), Rande (wife Cindy Crawford) and Kenny, daughter Sophie, grandchildren (who called him PeaPa) Chase, Owen, Georgia, Presley and Kaia, sisters Joni and Cassie, nieces Wendee and Jessie and nephews Doug, Nick, Tommy and Hawke. The family wishes to extend their gratitude to the caregivers at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City for their compassion and care. A celebration of Jordy's life will be held on Tuesday, April 28th at Stone Rose Lounge in the Time Warner Center from 6-9 pm. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting donations be made in the name of Jordan Gerber to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation (www.jdrf.org). Please see the link to memorial donation on the site.

MELODY GARDOT ''My One and Only Thrill'' (Verve) Melody Gardot, an unflappable young singer-songwriter from Philadelphia, approaches the art of the love song warily. On her second album, ''My One and Only Thrill,'' she contemplates romance from any angle involving need. She has a knack for the melodramatic but also for a kind of minimalism: she knows the power of modest gestures and meaningful inflections.

Any counterculture embraced by enough people becomes culture; works of art meant as blows against orthodoxy become classics worthy of enshrinement. A case in point is Terry Riley's ''In C,'' whose 45th anniversary was celebrated at Carnegie Hall on Friday night. When Mr. Riley created the piece, in 1964, modern music had long been dominated by serialism: rigorously controlled, intellectual in its appeal, often bone dry. Mr. Riley's simple recipe -- performers repeat each of 53 melodic kernels for as long as they like against a pulsating C in octaves, ending when everyone has played every section -- asserted a view of music as a communal action and a key to transcendence.

CALLAHAN--Nancy K. (nee Jones), accomplished aviator, oceanographer and business lawyer, died in Honolulu on April 5, 2009 after a long illness. She was 58. Ms. Callahan earned a juris doctor degree in 1976 with the first graduating class of the William S. Richardson School of Law of the University of Hawaii. She began her legal career in New York as an associate with the admiralty law firm of Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens. She then moved to the Legal Department of The Chase Manhattan Bank, where she became a Vice President and Senior Associate Counsel. Ms. Callahan was born in Sioux Falls, South Dakota on September 17, 1950, the daughter of Gardiner B. Jones, Jr., and Kathleen Orr Jones. She is survived by three daughters, Jane Callahan of Honolulu, Clare Callahan of Brooklyn, Hannah Callahan, a college student, and one son, Timothy Callahan, who is teaching in Shanghai, and by her former husband Joseph P. Callahan and also by two brothers, Gardiner B. Jones, III of Nashville, Tennessee, and Kinley C. Jones of Ewa Beach, Hawaii. Her parents and two sisters, Lucy and Margaret, predeceased her. A funeral service was held at Holy Nativity Church on Saturday, April 11.

Hong Kong, the epicenter of a SARS outbreak six years ago, announced some of the toughest measures anywhere on Sunday in response to a swine flu outbreak in Mexico and the United States. Officials urged residents not to travel to Mexico, and they ordered the immediate detention at a hospital of anyone who arrived with a fever and symptoms of a respiratory illness after traveling in the previous seven days through a city with a laboratory-confirmed outbreak.

Mexico's tourism industry was in crisis even before the government announced the presence of a deadly influenza virus a few days ago and began handing out surgical masks by the millions and shuttering virtually all public gathering spots in the capital. The industry has been grappling in recent months with fears that Mexico's drug war has made the country too risky to visit. Now comes a mysterious virus that runs the risk of turning the country into a no-go zone in the minds of many travelers.

Shonn Greene went from spending game days as a tailback for the University of Iowa to watching parts of the games at an Iowa store, from carrying the ball on occasion to carrying furniture around for $8 an hour. This was no smooth ride to the N.F.L. After becoming academically ineligible for the 2007 season, Greene was forced to leave school. The new game plan was for him to lift his grades at Kirkwood Community College, a junior college in Iowa, and he would work to pay for it.

MEG & DIA ''Here, Here and Here'' (Sire/Warner Brothers) When the Utah sister duo Meg & Dia released its strong breakthrough album, ''Something Real'' (Doghouse), in 2006, it was a heady time for mainstream emo, with a generation of tattooed young men expressing themselves in scabrous fashion. And while that album had only a few strands of emo's punk DNA, it was just enough to stand out as a possible corrective to that genre's mopey egotism. At the very least, it proved that young women could whine just as compellingly as young men.

MIKE JONES ''The Voice'' (Ice Age/Asylum/Warner Brothers) Who says Mike Jones hasn't grown in the four years since the release of ''Who Is Mike Jones?,'' his major-label debut? He's been through label squabbles, released a string of stalled singles and shed a significant part of his signature paunch. And perhaps most important, he's changed his phone number. The number (281) 330-8004 was as visible a calling card as anything else about this Houston rapper -- he wore T-shirts bearing it and repeated it incessantly during songs. But now (281) 206-4336 shares his truth, at least some of the time. One call (of several) to that number Sunday morning was met with a recording: ''I lost 50 pounds. I look a little different, but I'm still the same dude.''

The new face of the National League East has a starting rotation that averages 24 years of age and a lineup anchored by a 25-year-old shortstop. The new face of the division is so youthful, allowances must be made for its unsightly outbreaks: the bullpen meltdowns, the boneheaded base running and the other blemishes that can make the headlining Florida Marlins homely. Which look will the Marlins show the Mets when they arrive at Citi Field on Monday for a three-game divisional series? The devil-may-care abandon that fueled the Marlins' 11-1 start or the self-conscious strivers who have since lost six in a row, including a 13-2 demolition by the Phillies on Sunday?

ORLECK--Thelma. January 18, 1917-April 26, 2009, 92, died peacefully in her home in Thetford Center, Vermont, with her children and grandchildren close to her. The daughter of Harry Hershenson and Anna Alper, she was born in Brooklyn, New York in 1917 where she lived for most of her life. On June 12, 1938 she married Norman Orleck with whom she enjoyed a legendarily loving relationship - raising two children, throwing unforgettable costume parties in the basement, working side by side in a series of candy stores, luncheonettes and a gift store then putting on records and dancing all night. They were inseparable for 43 years until he died in her arms on the dance floor in 1980. Thelma found solace and intellectual passion in competitive contract bridge. She was a Life Master and a dazzling bridge strategist right up to the end of her life. She moved up to Vermont last year, where she was just beginning to make a new community of friends at Upper Valley bridge clubs when she became ill. In Vermont as in Brooklyn, she was loved by all who knew her. She was predeceased by her husband Norman Orleck and by her companion of 24 years, George Berger. She is survived, and will be deeply and forever missed, by her two children Jerry Orleck and Annelise Orleck, by her sister Mildred Katz, her grandchildren Lawrence Orleck, Jonathan Orleck, Evann Orleck-Jetter and Raphael Orleck-Jetter, her great-granddaughter Genevieve Piper Orleck, her daughters-in-law Alexis Jetter and Joanne Sherman and her grand-daughters-in-law Kelli Orleck and Sy Ingoglia. She taught us all to make love and joy a part of every day. Funeral services will be at Kirschenbaum Chapel at 1153 Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn at noon on Tuesday April 28.

Long lines of Wagner buffs stretched from the entryways of the Metropolitan Opera into Lincoln Center Plaza on Monday night as people waited to enter the house for the evening’s performance of “Das Rheingold,” the first installment of the second complete “Ring” cycle this season, performed within the span of six days, as is done at the Wagner Festival in Bayreuth. So chances are that most of those waiting to take their seats on Monday night will be in the same seats for “Die Walküre” on Tuesday, “Siegfried” on Thursday and “Götterdämmerung” on Saturday. (The third and last cycle begins on Monday.)

Updated | 12:58 p.m. Barlow-Hartman Public Relations, a New York agency with a portfolio of Broadway productions, including “Billy Elliot,” “In the Heights,” “Next to Normal” and “Wicked,” said Tuesday that it was ceasing operations. In a statement, the partners John Barlow and Michael Hartman said that the firm would close on June 14, its 10th anniversary.

Update | 6:46 p.m. At the end of last year Sotheby’s laid off about 15 percent of its global work force. On Tuesday, the ailing auction house announced that it was planning a further 5 percent drop in its head count. Salaries will be reduced for top employees, too, and the company plans to implement an unpaid furlough as well as a reduction in pension contributions for those working in the United States.

The film “Rudo y Cursi,” screening this week at the Tribeca Film Festival and opening in theaters on May 8, reunites Gael García Bernal and Diego Luna onscreen for the first time since “Y Tu Mamá También” (released in the United States in 2002). In the new film, the two play brothers who compete on rival soccer teams. I chatted with them about their lifelong friendship and the performing they did together as children.

Investment losses are forcing the J. Paul Getty Trust, parent of the Getty Museum in Los Angeles, to cut 14 percent of its work force, or 205 jobs, and to delay some exhibitions and acquisitions, the institution said Monday. The budget cuts, intended to reduce spending by 24 percent in the fiscal year that begins July 1, come as the value of the trust’s endowment, one of the largest to benefit any art institution, has fallen to $4.2 billion as of March 31, down from a peak of $6.4 billion two years ago. The trust, which in addition to the museum supports art research and conservation and offers grants to other arts organizations, plans to cut its spending to $220 million in the new fiscal year. The trust said it would lay off 97 employees, with the rest of the personnel cuts coming through attrition or elimination of open positions.

Two very different cultural worlds collided on Sunday when the Bravo series “Inside the Actors Studio” and its erudite presenter, James Lipton, played host to the cast of the irreverent Fox animated series “Family Guy”: the creator Seth MacFarlane (who provides the voices of Peter, Stewie, Brian and Quagmire); Alex Borstein (who plays Lois); Seth Green (Chris) and Mike Henry (Cleveland, among many others).

The four finalists for the Turner Prize, the prestigious British award given annually to an artist under the age of 50, were announced on Tuesday. In a news release, the Tate Britain museum said that the shortlist consisted of Enrico David, 43, a surrealist who creates paintings, drawings and sculptures; Roger Hiorns, 34, a site-specific artist whose 2008 work “Seizure” filled a derelict London apartment with blue crystals; Lucy Skaer, 34, who creates drawings, sculptures and films from found photographs; and Richard Wright, 49, who creates wall paintings in unexpected locations. Works by the finalists will be exhibited at Tate Britain beginning on Oct. 7, and the winner (who receives about $36,400) and runners-up (who each receive about $7,300) will be announced on Dec. 7.

Updated | 2:11 p.m. Though the Phish shows that will open this summer’s season at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater are already sold out, the Wantagh, N.Y., performance space will offer plenty of other opportunities for rocking out. The promoter Live Nation announced the rest of the theater’s summer shows, which include the country artists Kenny Chesney, Miranda Lambert and Lady Antebellum on June 24; Judas Priest and Whitesnake on July 12; the Rock the Bells tour with Nas, The Roots and Common on July 19; and the Allman Brothers Band on Aug. 27. Also, the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., announced its summer schedule, which starts on May 29 with George Strait, Blake Shelton and Julianne Hough, and also features REO Speedwagon, Styx and .38 Special on June 24; Crosby Stills & Nash on Aug. 11; and Aerosmith and ZZ Top on Sept. 12. More information on both sites can be found at livenation.com.

The good news: the average reading and math scores for the nation's 9- and 13-year-olds are up since the early 1970s. The bad news: the scores for 17-year-olds are unchanged in the same periods. Those were the findings, released on Tuesday, of the National Assessment of Educational Progress, a federal test considered to be the best measure of long-term trends in math and reading abilities.

The Directors Guild of America has officially signed on as a backer of the so-called "French solution," a proposed law that would allow owners of movies, TV shows and other copyrighted material to present evidence of illegal downloading to a quasi-governmental board. The Brazilian-born designer Francisco Costa logs in a lot of time on the usual Paris-Milan-London fashion circuit, but the Creative Director of Calvin Klein still makes a point of heading back to his native country about once a year. "I try to go somewhere besides where I grew up," says Costa, who was raised in the small town of Guarani, a few hours from Rio. Last month, he headed to Salvador, in the state of Bahia, the center of the country's Afro-Brazilian culture. " It was really my first time there, but the people were so friendly, the Baroque architecture was stunning and there's so much history and religion." Always the aesthete, Costa took plenty of photographs. He shares a few of his favorite snapshots with The Moment.

The Monday vote to merge two of Hollywood's top talent agencies - William Morris and Endeavor - into a new mega-agency to be called William Morris Endeavor Entertainment has dominated most of the chatter in Hollywood over the last 24 hours. Arlen Specter's party switch isn't all that startling. Richard Shelby and Ben Nighthorse Campbell switched to the Republicans right after the 1994 election, without (as far as I know) facing the same kind of primary challenge. The Lede continues to follow the conversation about the swine flu outbreak online, pointing out the good, and not so good, information to be gleaned from the Web.

As we noted on The Lede on Monday, fears of a swine flu pandemic have spread quickly across the Web. At least some of that fear has been based on misinformation, or an unwillingness to wait until scientists have had time to develop solid information about this new strain of the flu -- like where it started, how dangerous it really is and what steps the world might take to stop it from spreading. In our post yesterday, we pointed out that there are also some sources of useful information online, like the C.D.C.'s Swine Flu F.A.Q. -- "Swine Flu and You." Today The Lede will continue to follow the conversation about the outbreak online, pointing out the good, and not so good, information to be gleaned from the Web.

The publishing industry is hurting, and carmakers are hurting -- so it's not a great time to be publishing magazines about cars. That helps explain why Source Interlink, the media company that publishes Motor Trend and Hot Rod magazines, is taking a pit stop in bankruptcy protection.

The Dutch designers Viktor and Rolf don't just put on runway shows, they stage spectacles that border on performance art. Like the time they placed the model Maggie Rizer on a rotating pedestal and then layered her Russian Doll style in a mountain of clothing until only her little pea-sized head poked out of the top. Or the season they tap-danced their way through their own Busby Berkeley-esque finale. The relentlessly performative aspect of their work is occasionally lost on the fashion world but it plays very well as theater. In fact, the designers are currently working on their second collaboration with the director and artist Robert Wilson for whom they are creating the costumes for an upcoming production of the romantic opera "Der Freischutz" (The Freeshooter) by Carl Maria Von Weber at the Festspielhaus Baden-Baden in Germany. The Moment caught up with the Dutch duo behind the scenes.

It has been more than a half-century since New Yorkers last flocked in great numbers to see cyclists tear around banked velodrome tracks at the center of Manhattan. Easy to forget, then, that Madison Square Garden, in its earlier incarnation off 26th Street and Madison Avenue, played host to major races watched by tens of thousands of spectators (some undoubtedly attracted, in the days before Nascar, by the prospect of spectacular crashes.) Or that team racing events known as "Madisons" -- devised in the early part of last century to mitigate racer fatigue in events that could stretch to six days -- were invented here, under some pressure from local lawmakers and the news media. Velodromes also existed in the Bronx and in Coney Island in Brooklyn. (Both were destroyed by fire.)

Lance Armstrong will miss this week’s Tour of the Gila in New Mexico. Organizers blamed what they say is a rarely enforced International Cycling Federation rule. It would have been Armstrong’s first race since he broke his collarbone last month.

The composer John Adams and the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne, above, were among the five recipients of the National Endowment for the Arts’ 2009 Opera Honors, the agency announced on Monday. The three others are Julius Rudel, the veteran conductor of New York City Opera and the founding artistic director of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts; the director and librettist Frank Corsaro; and the general director Lotfi Mansouri, who introduced the use of supertitles in opera. The agency said it had chosen Mr. Adams, the composer of “Nixon in China” and “Doctor Atomic,” and the other artists for their “extraordinary contributions to opera in the United States.” Each will receive a grant of $25,000 and will be celebrated at a program in Washington on Nov. 14.

No matter how bad this recession gets, you’ll probably never again see Robert De Niro behind the wheel of a taxi. But if you’d like to see the actual hack license that Mr. De Niro wielded while he was preparing for his role in “Taxi Driver,” along with artifacts and papers from 68 of his other films, they’re now easy enough to find. On Monday the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin announced that it had made available to researchers and the public the more than 1,300 boxes of papers, film, movie props and costumes donated by Mr. De Niro, above. The collection covers his career from the 1968 Brian De Palma feature “Greetings” through the 2005 film “Hide and Seek.” It includes the leopard-print boxing robe Mr. De Niro wore in “Raging Bull” and the coats he wore as the Creature in “Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein.”.

The Polish pianist Krystian Zimerman surprised his audience during a recital on Sunday at the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles when he announced that he would no longer perform in the United States in protest of the country’s military policies, the Web site of The Los Angeles Times, latimes.com, reported. Mr. Zimerman was about to play Karol Szymanowski’s “Variations on a Polish Folk Theme,” his final piece of the evening, when he told concertgoers that he would not continue to perform in a country whose military, he said, wants to take over the world. “Get your hands off my country,” Mr. Zimerman said, according to the report. In 2006 Mr. Zimerman halted a performance at Carnegie Hall when he believed he observed a concertgoer recording the recital. Amid heightened security after the 9/11 attacks, a Steinway grand piano that he traveled with was destroyed by the Transportation Security Administration, apparently because the piano’s glue resembled a compound used in explosives.

A Nicollette Sheridan-less “Desperate Housewives” on ABC drew Sunday night’s largest audience, 13.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. But ABC finished second in total viewers. CBS won the night with “60 Minutes” (10.4 million), “The Amazing Race” (10.3 million), “Cold Case” (10.5 million) and “The Unit” (8.9 million). NBC, in third place, broadcast “Dateline” (5.1 million) and “The Celebrity Apprentice” (8.2 million). Fox lagged behind in fourth place with its comedy lineup. That network’s new animated series, “Sit Down, Shut Up,” garnered 4.2 million viewers, a million less than its debut a week ago.

Several works by the artist James Rosenquist were lost when a brush fire on Saturday destroyed two homes, an office and a studio that he kept in Aripeka, Fla., The St. Petersburg Times reported. Mr. Rosenquist, 75, who along with Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein is considered a seminal figure in the Pop Art movement, was unharmed, as were his office staff members. The Times said that the fire began around 3 a.m. on Saturday and was believed to be contained when it flared up again and exploded a propane tank in Mr. Rosenquist’s studio. After controlling the blaze on Sunday afternoon, firefighters told The Times that it had covered 62 acres and that they considered it suspicious and were investigating its cause. Among the works Mr. Rosenquist said he lost was a mural commissioned by the government of France that measured 133 feet high by 24 feet wide.

When you settle a lawsuit by agreeing to travel to Hawaii, are you really being punished at all? Aerosmith agreed to play a makeup show in Maui to help resolve a class-action suit by fans who were disappointed when the group pulled out of a concert there in 2007, The Associated Press reported. In September 2007 the singer Steven Tyler, right, and the rest of the band were scheduled to play at the War Memorial Stadium in Maui but canceled abruptly, citing logistical problems. Lawyers for the more than 8,000 fans who filed the suit said that Aerosmith had passed them over to play a concert in Chicago and to perform a private show at a car dealership in Oahu. A date for the makeup performance in Maui has not been set, but a lawyer representing the fans said that the show would probably be in September or October and that all original ticket holders would be admitted free.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has established a memorial fund for the acquisition of works by the street photographer Helen Levitt, who died in March, The Associated Press reported. The Met said that the Helen Levitt Memorial Fund had been created through a planned gift from Kathy Levitt, the photographer’s sister-in-law, who has promised a gift of 12 photographs. The Met now has 43 Levitt photographs and will have 12 on display from May 11 through Aug. 30. ... “Paved Paradise Redux: The Art of Joni Mitchell,” the cabaret drag show in which John Kelly performs the songs of Ms. Mitchell, will come to New York this summer. The show will run from June 18 through 27 at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side. Mr. Kelly will also perform songs by Ms. Mitchell in “Songs for a Shiny Hot Night” at Castle Clinton in Battery Park on Aug. 6 as part of the River to River Festival. ... Judy Collins will perform a free concert at Governors Island in July as part of the Folks on the Island series, said Trinity Wall Street, which is sponsoring the event with the Governors Island Alliance. The concert will take place on July 26 at 2 p.m. on the lawn on Colonels’ Row.

The Broadway production of “Impressionism,” which opened on March 24 to largely negative reviews, will close on May 10, its publicist announced on Sunday night. “Impressionism,” directed by Jack O’Brien and starring Jeremy Irons and Joan Allen, above, will have played 23 previews and 56 regular performances when it closes. The play by Michael Jacobs, about a New York art gallery owner (Ms. Allen) and a photojournalist (Mr. Irons), took the somewhat unusual route of having its world premiere on Broadway, rather than first opening in an out-of-town theater or off Broadway. Ms. Allen had not been seen on Broadway since 1989, when she starred in Wendy Wasserstein’s “Heidi Chronicles,” and it was Mr. Irons’s first Broadway appearance since 1985, when he was in “The Real Thing” by Tom Stoppard.

The composer John Adams and the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne, above, were among the five recipients of the National Endowment for the Arts' 2009 Opera Honors, the agency announced on Monday. The three others are Julius Rudel, the veteran conductor of New York City Opera and the founding artistic director of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts; the director and librettist Frank Corsaro; and the general director Lotfi Mansouri, who introduced the use of supertitles in opera. The agency said it had chosen Mr. Adams, the composer of ''Nixon in China'' and ''Doctor Atomic,'' and the other artists for their ''extraordinary contributions to opera in the United States.'' Each will receive a grant of $25,000 and will be celebrated at a program in Washington on Nov. 14.

MARCHI--John J. The City University of New York mourns the passing of former State Senator John J. Marchi, who will be forever identified as an enduring champion of The College of Staten Island, its status as a senior college and its current physical campus. Marchi was uniquely sensitive to and supportive of CUNY's overall vital educational mission, its urban orientation and its place in the national marketplace of public higher education. During a career that spanned a half century, he served as the lead sponsor in the State Senate of laws that helped to transform CUNY into the nation's leading urban public university. These included legislation to create the groundbreaking SEEK program; to separate the CUNY community colleges from SUNY's jurisdiction; and to designate CSI and The New York City College of Technology as senior colleges. In 2006, the CUNY Board of Trustees approved the naming of CSI's Building 2N -- which houses the History and Political Science departments -- as John J. Marchi Hall. We extend our sincere condolences to the Marchi family. Benno Schmidt Chairperson Matthew Goldstein Chancellor

When you settle a lawsuit by agreeing to travel to Hawaii, are you really being punished at all? Aerosmith agreed to play a makeup show in Maui to help resolve a class-action suit by fans who were disappointed when the group pulled out of a concert there in 2007, The Associated Press reported. In September 2007 the singer Steven Tyler, right, and the rest of the band were scheduled to play at the War Memorial Stadium in Maui but canceled abruptly, citing logistical problems. Lawyers for the more than 8,000 fans who filed the suit said that Aerosmith had passed them over to play a concert in Chicago and to perform a private show at a car dealership in Oahu. A date for the makeup performance in Maui has not been set, but a lawyer representing the fans said that the show would probably be in September or October and that all original ticket holders would be admitted free.

The Polish pianist Krystian Zimerman surprised his audience during a recital on Sunday at the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles when he announced that he would no longer perform in the United States in protest of the country's military policies, the Web site of The Los Angeles Times, latimes.com, reported. Mr. Zimerman was about to play Karol Szymanowski's ''Variations on a Polish Folk Theme,'' his final piece of the evening, when he told concertgoers that he would not continue to perform in a country whose military, he said, wants to take over the world. ''Get your hands off my country,'' Mr. Zimerman said, according to the report. In 2006 Mr. Zimerman halted a performance at Carnegie Hall when he believed he observed a concertgoer recording the recital. Amid heightened security after the 9/11 attacks, a Steinway grand piano that he traveled with was destroyed by the Transportation Security Administration, apparently because the piano's glue resembled a compound used in explosives.

Eighteen years out of training, and I still find myself struggling to understand the moral imperatives of medical practice. Not long ago, as part of my hospital duties, I cared for a man who could no longer swallow. This dysphagia was his only medical complaint, one that had sneaked up on him over the course of a month. He simply couldn't find the muscular strength to propel food and liquid down to his stomach.

MARSHALL--Arthur K.,died April 27 at age 85. He was a longtime resident of Leonia and recently Fort Lee, NJ. Born February 25, 1924 to parents David and Jeanette, he was happily married for 57 years to Helene Horowitz Marshall. He will be missed by his wife, children David, Cindy, and Karen, their spouses Candace, Kathy, and Donald, grandchildren Anya, Jeremy, Daniel, and Mikayla, sister-in-law Estelle, and loving relatives. His brother Stephen predeceased him. Arthur was born in Brooklyn, attended Erasmus High School, served in the U.S. Army as a meteorologist in the Philippines, and received a B.S. from NYU. He ran his own company as a manufacturer's representative and was active in civic and cultural activities. A Lifetime member of the Players' Guild of Leonia and Chairman of the Leonia Adjustment Board, he worked to support public schools, and served on the board and taught at the Institute of New Dimensions. After a rich and full life, including 21 years when his investment in living was more powerful than cancer, he died with peace and grace, having said goodbye to his beloved family. Donations to: Players' Guild of Leonia, Box 131, Leonia, NJ. 07605. Friends may visit with family Wednesday April 29, 7-9pm and Friday May 1, 3-5pm. Memorial service to be scheduled.

For hundreds of unlucky immigrants, the death of a wife or husband has been quickly followed by an order to leave the country. It's called the ''widow penalty,'' a tragic quirk in federal law that unfairly punishes recently married immigrants whose citizen spouses die before their green-card paperwork is processed. United States Citizenship and Immigration Services, which handles applications for legal permanent residence, says its hands are tied. According to its interpretation of the law, if a citizen dies before the agency acts on his or her petition for a spouse's green card -- and if the marriage is less than 2 years old -- the surviving spouse automatically ceases to be a spouse.

In late 2007, there was the first crack of daylight into the government's use of waterboarding during interrogations of Al Qaeda detainees. On Dec. 10, John Kiriakou, a former C.I.A. officer who had participated in the capture of the suspected terrorist Abu Zubaydah in Pakistan in 2002, appeared on ABC News to say that while he considered waterboarding a form of torture, the technique worked and yielded results very quickly. Mr. Zubaydah started to cooperate after being waterboarded for ''probably 30, 35 seconds,'' Mr. Kiriakou told the ABC reporter Brian Ross. ''From that day on he answered every question.''

After months of discussion and rumors, two of the entertainment industry's largest talent agencies, William Morris and Endeavor, agreed on Monday to merge as William Morris Endeavor Entertainment. Hollywood is scrambling to shore up traditional movie, television and music businesses that are struggling with a digital revolution, while reaching for a grip on forms of entertainment that are still taking shape.

Several works by the artist James Rosenquist were lost when a brush fire on Saturday destroyed two homes, an office and a studio that he kept in Aripeka, Fla., The St. Petersburg Times reported. Mr. Rosenquist, 75, who along with Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein is considered a seminal figure in the Pop Art movement, was unharmed, as were his office staff members. The Times said that the fire began around 3 a.m. on Saturday and was believed to be contained when it flared up again and exploded a propane tank in Mr. Rosenquist's studio. After controlling the blaze on Sunday afternoon, firefighters told The Times that it had covered 62 acres and that they considered it suspicious and were investigating its cause. Among the works Mr. Rosenquist said he lost was a mural commissioned by the government of France that measured 133 feet high by 24 feet wide.

DORSETT--Burt N.,of Naples, Florida, died on April 26th at home with his wife and children at his side. He moved to Naples in 2004 after residing in New York City since 1970. He was 78 and lived an active and enjoyable life until the end. Mr. Dorsett, a native of Chicago, Illinois, attended the Masonic Children's Home, an orphanage in La Grange, Illinois, throughout his childhood and high school years, while attending Lions Township High School, where he was President of the Student Council. Upon high school graduation, Mr. Dorsett was a scholarship student at Dartmouth College, in Hanover, New Hampshire, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1953. Following college he was employed by E.I. duPont De Nemours in Seaford, Delaware, before moving his family to the Cambridge area to attend Harvard Business School, where he obtained a Masters in Business Administration in 1959. Mr. Dorsett was a consultant at Booz, Allen & Hamilton, in New York City from 1959 to 1962; then lived in Rochester, New York, from 1962 to 1970, where he was Vice President, Investments, at the University of Rochester. During that time he was a Director and Chairman of the Portfolio Committee at the Chemical Fund, a Director of Garlock Inc., a Director of the Eberstadt Fund, and a Trustee of Monroe County Savings Bank. He was also a Director of the Convalescent Hospital for Children, and of the Community Chest, Rochester; and a Trustee of Keuka College, in Keuka, New York. He moved to Darien in 1970 to become Executive Vice President and a Trustee of the College Retirement Equities Fund (TIAA/CREF) in New York City. In 1979, Mr. Dorsett joined the Westinghouse Corporation to become President of Westinghouse Pension Investments Corporation. In 1986 he formed Dorsett McCabe Capital Management, Inc., in New York City, which he operated as Principal until 2004. Mr. Dorsett was a longtime Director and member of the Investment Committee of the American Psychological Association, a Director of the Research Corporation from 1972 to 1990, followed by continued service as a Director of Research Corporation Technologies from 1987 to 2002. He also served as a Director of many Mutual Funds from 1972 to 2006. In 2001, together with a gift from the Research Corporation Technologies, he endowed the Dorsett Fellowship in Applied and Professional Ethics at the Ethics Institute of Dartmouth College. At the time of his death, Mr. Dorsett was a Consultant to Leeb Capital Management, Inc., in New York City. He is survived by his wife of 28 years, Trixie Elaine Dorsett; his former wife Judith Dorsett; his children Jeffrey Dorsett of Connecticut, Deborah Dorsett of Vermont, and Mark Dorsett and his wife Sharon, of Maine, and his sister Jean Glore of California, and eight wonderful grandchildren, Danielle, Clayton, Michael, Laura, Spencer, Carter, Chapin and Campbell. He was pre-deceased by his daughter Cynthia Dorsett in 1979. A Reception in his memory will be held in Naples at The Club, Pelican Bay, from 5:00 to 7:00 pm, Saturday, May 2nd, and in New York City on May 27th, 2009. Gifts may be made to the Dorsett Fellowship in Applied and Professional Ethics, at the Ethics Institute, Dartmouth College, 6031 Haldeman Center, Hanover, New Hampshire 03755.

HONG KONG -- Sorting through the ''marquee flus'' of recent years -- SARS, avian flu and now swine flu -- is complicated. The three come from different viruses and carry different kinds of danger, depending on ease of transmission and virulence. As a benchmark, the deadliest influenza pandemic in the past century, the Spanish influenza of 1918 to 1919, had an estimated mortality rate of around 2.5 percent but killed tens of millions of people because it spread so widely.

No matter how bad this recession gets, you'll probably never again see Robert De Niro behind the wheel of a taxi. But if you'd like to see the actual hack license that Mr. De Niro wielded while he was preparing for his role in ''Taxi Driver,'' along with artifacts and papers from 68 of his other films, they're now easy enough to find. On Monday the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin announced that it had made available to researchers and the public the more than 1,300 boxes of papers, film, movie props and costumes donated by Mr. De Niro, above. The collection covers his career from the 1968 Brian De Palma feature ''Greetings'' through the 2005 film ''Hide and Seek.'' It includes the leopard-print boxing robe Mr. De Niro wore in ''Raging Bull'' and the coats he wore as the Creature in ''Mary Shelley's Frankenstein.''

A bucket of baseballs was crushed to the nether regions of Citi Field on Monday night, but only one hit plopped into the stands. It was sent there by Mets catcher Omir Santos, their backup turned starter, for a grand slam that had furious competition as the most unforeseeable event of the game. It was rarer, perhaps, than a Mets starter pitching six innings. Or their dysfunctional offense erupting for a six-run first inning. Or their fans rewarding Santos, whose name they did not know a week ago, with an extended standing ovation, which he answered with an enthusiastic curtain call.

Cathy served the Board twice as its President, then Chairman and at her passing was Chair Emeritus. We are deeply grateful for the many years of guidance and friendship she gave us. We extend our deepest sympathies to Cathy's family. The Officers and Directors of the Southampton Fresh Air Home

It was the spring break trip they had dreamed of all year: white-sand beaches, a quarter-mile-long swimming pool, young people from all over the world. Esti Lamonaca and her friends spent five months planning a trip to Mexico to celebrate their senior year of high school. They chose the Oasis Cancun, better known for college partying than high school vacations (''The center of spring break action,'' raves one student travel Web site). Ms. Lamonaca persuaded her parents to let her go if she paid her own way -- so she worked every day after school to save up about $1,200.

One reason the Jets' call to Plaxico Burress's agent last week is so titillating: Despite all the excitement surrounding the team's acquisition of quarterback Mark Sanchez, they did not do anything about finding him someone to throw the ball to. For now, Sanchez's best option is Jerricho Cotchery. On Monday the Jets had nothing new to say about Burress, but that is nearly as important as what General Manager Mike Tannenbaum said in a statement Sunday night that confirmed his conversation with the agent Drew Rosenhaus.

For all that scientists have learned about influenza since the catastrophic pandemic of 1917-19, one thing has not changed: the predictably unpredictable nature of the viruses that cause it. The sudden detection of the new swine influenza virus, A(H1N1), occurred just as scientists were focusing wary eyes on behavioral changes observed in another virus, the A(H5N1) bird flu strain, in Egypt. Virologists have tracked the avian virus since its discovery in Hong Kong in 1997.

The United Nations senior representative to Darfur, Rodolphe Adada, told the Security Council on Monday that the situation there had become ''a low-intensity conflict in danger of a serious escalation,'' stressing the reduction of killings to a rate of 130 to 150 per month. Mr. Adada declined to characterize the conflict as a continuing genocide, a term that the United States has used. He said that though the United Nations was concerned about the dangers posed by Sudan's decision to expel aid groups from Darfur, ''the solution relies on the government.'' NEIL MacFARQUHAR

Quality Road, who has been troubled by foot problems since running away with the Florida Derby on March 28, will miss the Kentucky Derby, his trainer, Jimmy Jerkens, said Monday. Quality Road missed a planned breeze at Belmont Park on Monday, and Jerkens, along with the colt's owner, Edward Evans, said that Quality Road would now aim for the Preakness Stakes on May 16 and the Belmont Stakes on June 6, depending on how quickly he recovers from a quarter crack, or split hoof wall, in his right front foot.

A vaccine that protects babies against fatal bacterial infections was introduced in Rwanda last week, its first distribution in a third world country. The pneumococcal conjugate vaccine has been sold under the Prevnar brand name in the United States since 2000, and Rwanda will get three million doses -- enough for all its children under age 5 -- donated by Wyeth Pharmaceuticals.

AS the swine flu threatens to become the next pandemic, the biggest questions are whether its transmission from human to human will be sustained and, if so, how virulent it might become. But even if this virus were to peter out soon, there is a strong possibility it would only go underground, quietly continuing to infect some people while becoming better adapted to humans, and then explode around the world.

(13) AT HOME IN UTOPIA In this ''Independent Lens'' documentary Michal Goldman and Ellen Brodsky chronicle the development of the United Workers Cooperative Colony, one of several apartment co-ops built by garment workers in the Bronx during the 1920s as part of the cooperative movement. The trend included restaurants, dairies and, outside the city, recreational facilities like Camp Nitgedeiget -- a Yiddish term translating into Camp No Worries -- where workers could vacation in the country for just a few dollars, above right. Built on social and economic reform, the movement ultimately persuaded 24 states to enact emergency legislation against mortgage foreclosures. Linda Lavin narrates. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Capt. Richard Phillips talks about being held hostage by pirates.

The Obama administration dispatched high-level officials from several agencies Monday to allay concerns about swine flu and to demonstrate that it was fully prepared to confront the outbreak even as the president said there was ''not a cause for alarm.'' Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, and Dr. Richard E. Besser, the acting director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said the administration was prepared to respond to any further spread of the swine flu virus.
