The Metropolitan Museum of Art has established a memorial fund for the acquisition of works by the street photographer Helen Levitt, who died in March, The Associated Press reported. The Met said that the Helen Levitt Memorial Fund had been created through a planned gift from Kathy Levitt, the photographer's sister-in-law, who has promised a gift of 12 photographs. The Met now has 43 Levitt photographs and will have 12 on display from May 11 through Aug. 30. ... Barack Obama's presidency seems to be altering the public perception of race relations in the United States. Two-thirds of Americans now say race relations are generally good, and the percentage of blacks who say so has doubled since last July, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News poll. Despite that, half of blacks still say whites have a better chance of getting ahead in American society, the poll found. Black Americans remain among the president's staunchest supporters; 70 percent of black respondents now say the country is headed in the right direction, compared with 34 percent of whites.

A Nicollette Sheridan-less ''Desperate Housewives'' on ABC drew Sunday night's largest audience, 13.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. But ABC finished second in total viewers. CBS won the night with ''60 Minutes'' (10.4 million), ''The Amazing Race'' (10.3 million), ''Cold Case'' (10.5 million) and ''The Unit'' (8.9 million). NBC, in third place, broadcast ''Dateline'' (5.1 million) and ''The Celebrity Apprentice'' (8.2 million). Fox lagged behind in fourth place with its comedy lineup. That network's new animated series, ''Sit Down, Shut Up,'' garnered 4.2 million viewers, a million less than its debut a week ago.

Shares of GlaxoSmithKline and Roche, makers of prescription flu treatments, rose Monday amid expectations that the swine flu scare would lift demand for their products. There were no immediate signs of shortages of flu drugs. Roche, the Swiss maker of Tamiflu, said Monday that the World Health Organization has enough stockpiled to treat up to 5 million people, on top of millions more doses held by governments. Tamiflu has been stockpiled for years by governments, companies and health authorities. Still, shares of Roche rose 4.1 percent in Zurich, and GlaxoSmithKline rose 5 percent in London after the W.H.O. warned that the new A (H1N1) swine flu virus, which originates in pigs, could become a pandemic. The disease has killed more than 100 people in Mexico and isolated cases have been detected in countries around the world.

Colson Whitehead is a living example of why your mother warned you about fooling around with BB guns. He has a BB embedded perilously close to his left eye, a relic of a shooting contest not unlike the one he describes in his new novel, ''Sag Harbor.'' ''Sag Harbor,'' which came out on Monday, is, strictly speaking, Mr. Whitehead's fourth novel. It's also a first novel that he has only just now got around to writing: an autobiographical, first-person, adolescent-coming-of-age story -- exactly the kind of book he was determined not to write when he was getting started. That was in the early 1990s, he explained recently. Just out of Harvard, he was working at The Village Voice Literary Supplement, where one of his jobs was opening the mail. ''I opened all these books,'' he said, ''and I became very aware of how many really boring first novels there were. I decided I didn't want to do what everyone else was doing.''

The Broadway production of ''Impressionism,'' which opened on March 24 to largely negative reviews, will close on May 10, its publicist announced on Sunday night. ''Impressionism,'' directed by Jack O'Brien and starring Jeremy Irons and Joan Allen, above, will have played 23 previews and 56 regular performances when it closes. The play by Michael Jacobs, about a New York art gallery owner (Ms. Allen) and a photojournalist (Mr. Irons), took the somewhat unusual route of having its world premiere on Broadway, rather than first opening in an out-of-town theater or off Broadway. Ms. Allen had not been seen on Broadway since 1989, when she starred in Wendy Wasserstein's ''Heidi Chronicles,'' and it was Mr. Irons's first Broadway appearance since 1985, when he was in ''The Real Thing'' by Tom Stoppard.

PLAYER In M.L.S., Clint Mathisscored what could be the league's goal of the week in Real Salt Lake's 6-0 victory over visiting New England on Saturday night. From a Javier Morales corner kick, Mathis, waiting unmarked near the edge of the penalty area, rocketed a volley with the outside of his left foot from 14 yards that beat Brad Knighton high to the near post. Salt Lake scored all six of its goals in the second half. CLUBS In Mexico, an outbreak of swine flu, which has killed more than 100 people in the past weeks, prompted soccer officials to bar fans from three first-division matches, including the game between Chivas Gualadajara and Pumas. Saturday's game between Pachuca and Cruz Azul was also played in an empty stadium in the state of Hidalgo. And on Sunday, the cavernous Azteca stadium in Mexico City was without fans for the game between América and Tecos.

The appeal of Scripture springs eternal, something Broadway and Hollywood have exploited for decades. Now there's David M. Sanborn -- an actor from a family of past and present Christian relief workers -- who has brought his one-man musical, ''King David,'' to the Promise Theater, infusing the Books of Samuel with the aesthetics of both. The idea of this family-friendly show -- the book and songs are a collaboration between the good-looking, hard-working Mr. Sanborn and his mother, Ellen, who also directed it -- involves Mr. Sanborn's impersonating Hollywood actors (like Jimmy Stewart, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sean Connery) as he inhabits the figures in the life of David (including Saul, Goliath, the prophet Nathan and others).

DeSCHERER--Bernard. The Board of Directors and staff of the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation express our deepest sympathy on the loss of Bernard DeScherer. We send our condolences to his son, our Board President, Richard K. DeScherer, Dick's wife Jennie, their children and all members of the DeScherer family.

REIS--Ruthanne (Abram), of Washington, DC and Augusta, GA, died in Augusta on April 19, 2009. Ruthanne was born in Fitzgerald, GA on June 9, 1920, the daughter of Sam and Irene Abram. Predeceased by her husband Harold Reis, noted Washington lawyer. Mother of Alan Reis (Dana) of New York City, Kate Grogan (Kevin) of Augusta, and Deborah Kennedy (Lee Bragg) of Manchester, ME. Predeceased by her siblings Dr. Lewis Abram, Morris Abram, and Jeanette Bernstein. A graduate of the University of Georgia, she was one of the first woman air traffic controllers, finishing that career at Washington National Airport (Reagan). The last sixty years of her life were devoted to the welfare and happiness of her family and friends, all of whom will miss her greatly.

FEDERAL prosecutors last week persuaded a judge to stop a group of Bernard L. Madoff's victims from using an involuntary bankruptcy filing to claim more than $100 million of his personal assets. The prosecutors' argument was simple: preserving Mr. Madoff's assets for eventual forfeiture to the government is the best way to ensure as much money as possible is returned to the victims of his Ponzi scheme in an equitable manner. Most people would assume that this is business as usual, that the government routinely seizes the assets of criminals and returns them to victims. After all, criminals should not have ill-gotten houses, cars and yachts waiting for them when they finish their sentences. But the reality is that the government's focus on seizing Mr. Madoff's assets for restitution is unusual. Lawbreakers are rarely forced to give up the proceeds of their crimes.

Six years after their discovery, the extinct little people nicknamed hobbits who once occupied the Indonesian island of Flores remain mystifying anomalies in human evolution, out of place in time and geography, their ancestry unknown. Recent research has only widened their challenge to conventional thinking about the origins, transformations and migrations of the early human family. Indeed, the more scientists study the specimens and their implications, the more they are drawn to heretical speculation.

SALMON--Alfred, 87, of New York City, born in Wiesbaden, passed away on April 26, 2009. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife of 59 years, Roselle, his children Robert, Daniel and his wife Ellie; grandchildren Lisa, Scott, Joel, Karen and Marni; his brother Otto and his wife Anne, sister Ruth Aach and sister-in-law Marga Marx. Services will be held Tuesday, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory should be made to: Jawonio Foundation at: 260 Little Tor Road, New City, NY 10956.

When Michael Gregory, a 24-year-old musician, started to watch a lot of television news during the recent presidential election campaign, he decided that what America’s pundits and anchors really needed was a little remixing. So he started creating musical mash-ups of news clips he found on YouTube and used a bit of technical wizardry known as “Auto-Tuning” to transform the talking heads into singing heads.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Wednesday morning.

The tenor Rolando Villazón “needs surgery as soon as possible” because of a cyst on his vocal cords and is canceling performances until the end of year, his managers said Wednesday, according to Agence France-Presse. A statement from Universal Music Classical Management and Productions said that Mr. Villazón’s doctor expected him back on stage “around the end of the year,” AFP said. The first cancellation was of a show in Berlin scheduled for Thursday. Earlier this month, Mr. Villazón, 37, withdrew from his remaining performances of the Donizetti opera “L’Elisir d’Amore” at the Metropolitan Opera. The Met said that Mr. Villazón had canceled due to an acute case of laryngitis.

The Brooklyn-based indie-rock duo MGMT has won a settlement from France’s governing political party, which the band was threatening to sue for using its music without permission, Reuters reported. In February, the band demanded that it should be compensated by the Union for a Popular Movement, the party of President Nicolas Sarkozy, which used the MGMT song “Kids” at its national congress in January, as well as in two online videos and at a public function for the party leader, Xavier Bertrand. At the time, the party said the use of the song was an unintentional mistake, and offered the band one euro (approximately $1.32) in symbolic damages. But on Tuesday a lawyer for the band said that the party had agreed to pay a more substantial settlement; asked if the settlement was around $39,000, the lawyer told Reuters, “There has been an agreement of that order.”

While the protagonists of “The Wiz” search for a home, a brain, a heart and courage, the coming Encores! Summer Stars production of the musical at New York City Center has found its Dorothy: the R&B star Ashanti will make her stage debut in the role, City Center said Wednesday in a news release. Devotees of Ashanti, whose songs include “Foolish” and “What’s Luv,” will note that this is only the second most esoteric adaptation of “The Wizard of Oz” she has been attached to; she also played the role of Dorothy in the made-for-television movie “The Muppets’ Wizard of Oz.”

A computer technician in Hong Kong was found guilty Wednesday of illegally distributing more than 1,000 photos of the singer and actor Edison Chen performing sex acts with other Asian stars, Agence France-Presse reported. In 2008, Sze Ho-chun, an employee of a Kowloon computer shop, was among nine people arrested by the Hong Kong police after photos and videos began appearing on the Internet depicting Mr. Chen in sexually explicit scenes with what appeared to be several of Asia’s best known pop stars. Prosecutors said that Mr. Sze obtained about 1,300 photos of Mr. Chen when the performer brought his computer to a repair shop in 2006, and that Mr. Sze put the images on CDs for other customers. In the ensuing scandal, Mr. Chen announced that he had retired from the Hong Kong entertainment industry. Mr. Sze remains in custody and is expected to be sentenced on May 13.
Psychiatrist. Sleuth. Sir Robin. David Hyde Pierce has played them all. (In “Frasier,” “Curtains” and “Monty Python’s Spamalot,” of course.)

The Miami rapper Rick Ross has the best-selling album in the country this week. “Deeper Than Rap” (Def Jam), his third solo release, reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart with 158,000 copies sold in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Other high-charting new records include Depeche Mode‘s “Sounds of the Universe” (EMI), which reached No. 3 with 80,000 sales; and “Asleep in the Bread Aisle” (Universal Motown) by the comic Pennsylvania rapper Asher Roth, which opened at No. 5 with 65,000. Last week’s best-seller, the “Hannah Montana: The Movie” soundtrack (Disney), dropped to No. 2 with 104,000 sales, and Rascal Flatts‘s “Unstoppable” (Lyric Street) is No. 5 in its third week out, with 68,000.

Steven Soderbergh‘s latest film, “The Girlfriend Experience,” is being shown at the Tribeca Film Festival this week and opens in theaters on May 22. Made with high-definition cameras, nonprofessional actors and a lot of improvisation, the movie tells the story of an escort who provides her services to wealthy New Yorkers. I asked Mr. Soderbergh about the kinds of projects he’s drawn to when deciding what to work on next.

“Vegas: Based on a True Story,” a narrative film in competition at the Tribeca Film Festival, follows a family that has struggled in the past with compulsive gambling. A visit from a stranger and the promise of riches bring back old obsessions and threaten to destroy the family. The New York filmmaker Amir Naderi, originally from Iran, discusses shooting his latest film on location in the Las Vegas area, away from the glamour of the Vegas Strip.

My Thursday column is about the extraordinary failure of police around the country to test rape kits promptly. Many kits are never tested, and others wait for a year before they are tested. There are a range of reasons, including the cost, but I think the underlying one is a deeply embedded skepticism among many veteran police officers about many rape cases, a sense that often it isn't a truly serious crime.

Houston Dynamo striker Brian Ching is probably the best (only male?) pro soccer player ever produced by the state of Hawaii. He is the club's career-leading scorer and helped the Dynamo to back-to-back Major League Soccer titles in 2006 and 2007. He has surprising skill for a big guy (6 feet 1) and remains in the mix as the United States national team sets its sights on the 2010 World Cup in South Africa. Perhaps it's no surprise that Ching has selected an Ultimate XI that hues to dangerous offensive players.

The Mets have had trouble catching the ball in left field, hitting with runners in scoring position, getting their starting pitchers to go deep into games and coming back to win games. The gross domestic product report released Wednesday was unquestionably depressing: the economy shrank at an annualized rate of 6.1 percent in the first quarter of this year, after a 6.3 percent annualized decline in the last quarter of 2008. We are at the stage now with Derby preparations in which the contenders have completed all of their major works. Certainly a few will have short "pipe-openers" over the next few days (quarter-mile or three-eighths workouts to open up the airways a little more), but for the most part it's now about keeping your horse happy and mentally prepared for the big race. This close to a race, there is not much to do to make your horse run faster. But you can certainly ruin things and have him run slower.

Epidemiologists didn't expect a swine flu outbreak, but did fashion designers see it coming? Judging from all the masks, veils, balaclavas and assorted head gear that recently came down the runway, it's hard not to wonder. The World Health Organization gives fairly loose mask guidelines (you can even fashion one yourself out of "readily available materials"), but we still wouldn't chance it with a Comme des Garçons shroud or even a Margiela face stocking. To be on the safe side, make your statement with colored markers or take a breather from the style scene and go back to basics.

In her online series for The New York Times, "Recipes for Health" author Martha Rose Shulman offers delicious foods that also reflect scientific thinking about health. Last week she responded to dozens of reader questions about healthy eating, "Recipes for Health: Talk to the Chef."

Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Broderick expect to welcome twin girls in several months, the couple confirmed yesterday. They are being carried by a surrogate mother, after years of unsuccessfully trying to make their six-year-old son into a big brother the more old-fashioned way.

Goshen Capital Partners, the hedge fund that recorded a whopping 73 percent gain last year betting against the market, posted returns of 6.8 percent in the first quarter, according to the firm's most recent letter to investors.

Worried about swine flu, 20th Century Fox says it has canceled Hugh Jackman's trip to Mexico this week to promote the upcoming "X-Men Origins: Wolverine." The film is opening Friday in the U.S., but Fox had already decided to postpone the Mexican opening after several cinema chains closed down to ride out the flu panic. So it wasn't a huge surprise that the studio also decided to postpone the gala premiere that Mr. Jackman was to attend.

Update | 4:36 p.m. In a match played with such pace that it made yesterday's semifinal look like a game of mahjong, Manchester United defeated Arsenal 1-0 to take a narrow lead in the Champions League two-game semifinal series. United had many good scoring opportunities, including a laser-like shot in the second half from Cristiano Ronaldo (almost identical to the one he scored against Porto in the quarterfinal) that hit the crossbar.

When the morning commute goes well -- the train is on time, you find a seat, no one nearby is yakking on a cell phone, the guy sitting next to you is not playing his iPod so loudly that the boom, boom, boom makes your head hurt -- it can be a tiny respite in an otherwise hectic day. You can read the morning paper or that novel that has had you so engrossed. You can reflect or even organize yourself for the day ahead. You can shut out the morning rush -- kids, shoes, backpacks, those bills you meant to mail, keys, a hunt for a parking space -- and start afresh on a new day.

The 100th day has officially arrived for President Obama and his administration, a benchmark buffeted by some unpredictable outside events resembling anything but a "Hallmark" card (as his aides derided the traditional hoopla marking the milestone).

To most people, frugal travel means getting around by foot, bike, bus and low-cost airlines. But for Randy Sturrock and Marianne Edwards, a Canadian couple in their late 50s, the RV is their preferred mode of inexpensive transportation. In 2000, the couple set off on their first adventure, a year-long trek from their home in southern Ontario down through the Dakotas to Utah, Texas, California and Arizona. Along the way, they discovered that not only did they love the experience of the RV, but how much it saved them in travel costs. Since then, they've taken three, five-month RV trips, and now provide money-saving guidance to RV newbies via their Web site, frugal-rv-travel.com. Ms. Edwards spoke with me from Ontario about free campgrounds, great views and the joy of living without reservations.

The America’s Cup champion Alinghi of Switzerland was ordered to tell a New York State court why it should not be held in contempt for refusing to comply with an order that its one-on-one showdown against the American crew BMW Oracle Racing be held in February. The New York State Supreme Court, acting on a request by San Francisco’s Golden Gate Yacht Club, scheduled a hearing for May 14. It was the latest twist in a fight that has delayed a conventional, multi-challenger America’s Cup and led to a rare showdown between Alinghi and BMW Oracle Racing that will be contested in multi-hulled boats.

An overdose of selenium most likely caused the death last week of 21 horses at the United States Open Polo Championship, Florida’s state veterinarian said. “Signs exhibited by the horses and their rapid deaths were consistent with toxic doses of selenium,” Thomas J. Holt, the state veterinarian, said in a statement.

All nine Mexican First Division games this weekend will be played behind closed doors, a move aimed at stemming the spread of swine flu. FIFA, in agreement with the World Anti-Doping Agency, set out plans for drug-testing top-level players in 2009. The new antidoping rules begin Friday as a pilot project created after FIFA objected to players being held to the toughest standards of the new WADA code, which governs all other sports. FIFA called it a “football-specific approach to an effective and efficient antidoping program.”.

After some confusion over the rules that govern races in the United States, Lance Armstrong will be able to test himself in a five-day stage race after all. Armstrong, the seven-time Tour de France winner, will line up Wednesday to race at the Tour of the Gila, a race in New Mexico. For Armstrong, who had 12 screws implanted into his broken collarbone last month, the event will serve as a dress rehearsal for the Giro d’Italia in May.

An article on April 14 about John Grunsfeld, an astronaut who is scheduled to lead the final servicing mission for the Hubble Space Telescope, referred incorrectly to the capacity of the indoor pool where Dr. Grunsfeld does some training for the mission. The pool holds 6 million gallons, not 11 million. The article also described incorrectly the events leading to his decision to return to the United States after working in Tokyo. Dr. Grunsfeld was living in a Zen monastery, meditating in the morning and then going to work at the University of Tokyo. He came home early one day and found the monks watching baseball on television, breaking the spell of his experience there. He did not find the monks playing baseball.

The Global Update on Tuesday, using information from a scientist about the introduction of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine in Rwanda, misstated the number of doses of vaccine the country will receive and the age of the children who will be covered. Rwanda is to get 2.5 million doses, not 3 million, and those will be for all children 1 and younger, not all children under age 5.

Smith, the New York Senate majority leader, misquoted Mr. Smith, who supports the bill. Referring to the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, Mr. Smith’s mentor, who opposes the bill, Mr. Smith said, “He looks at it as a religious matter, and I look at it as a legal matter.” Mr. Smith did not say, “He looks at it as a religious matter, and I look at it as a political matter.”.

Even without the injured contestant Melissa Rycroft, ABC’s 90-minute installment of “Dancing With the Stars” lifted the network to No. 1 on Monday night, with an average audience of 19.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS was runner-up over all, winning the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: Miami” (12 million), which outperformed ABC’s “Castle” (8.4 million) and NBC’s “Medium” (6.7 million) in its time slot. CBS’s comedy lineup also remained strong, including “Two and a Half Men” (14.1 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (11.3 million), which bested ABC’s new sitcom “Surviving Suburbia” (9.9 million). Fox ranked third for with “House” (11.4 million) and “24” (10.6 million), while NBC lagged behind in fourth with “Chuck” (6.1 million) and “Heroes” (6.4 million).

After canceling tapings on Thursday and Friday because he was being treated at a Southern California hospital for a sudden illness, Jay Leno returned to “The Tonight Show” on Monday. After a videotaped comedy skit in which the “Insider” host Nancy O’Dell spotted Mr. Leno leaving a hospital (toting nine baby dolls and shouting, “Take that, Octo-mom!”), the comedian told his audience that he had come down with a 103-degree fever. In his monologue, Mr. Leno joked about his hospital stay (“I heard this screaming — doctors in the next room were trying to revive NBC’s prime-time schedule.”) and said that Conan O’Brien, his appointed “Tonight Show” successor, had tried to suffocate him. Mr. Leno had not missed a scheduled episode of “The Tonight Show” since 2003, when he swapped jobs with Katie Couric, who was then a host of NBC’s “Today” show. He had never missed one because of illness since he became the show’s host in 1992.

The four finalists for the Turner Prize, the prestigious British award given annually to an artist under the age of 50, were announced on Tuesday. In a news release, the Tate Britain museum said that the shortlist consisted of Enrico David, 43, a surrealist who creates paintings, drawings and sculptures, bottom left, above; Roger Hiorns, 34, a site-specific artist whose 2008 work “Seizure,” bottom right, filled a derelict London apartment with blue crystals; Lucy Skaer, 34, who creates drawings, sculptures and films from found photographs, top left; and Richard Wright, 49, who creates wall paintings in unexpected locations, top right. Works by the finalists will be exhibited at Tate Britain beginning on Oct. 7, and the winner (who receives about $36,400) and runners-up (who each receive about $7,300) will be announced on Dec. 7.

Though the Phish shows that will open this summer’s season at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater are already sold out, the Wantagh, N.Y., performance space will offer plenty of other opportunities to rock out. The promoter Live Nation announced the rest of the theater’s summer shows, which include the country artists Kenny Chesney, above, Miranda Lambert and Lady Antebellum on June 24; Judas Priest and Whitesnake on July 12; the Rock the Bells tour with Nas, the Roots and Common on July 19; and the Allman Brothers Band on Aug. 27. Also, the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., announced its summer schedule, which starts on May 29 with George Strait, Blake Shelton and Julianne Hough, and also features REO Speedwagon, Styx and .38 Special on June 24; Crosby Stills & Nash on Aug. 11; and Aerosmith and ZZ Top on Sept. 12. More information on both theaters can be found at livenation.com. ... The Village Voice announced that it would hold its annual Siren Music Festival on July 18 at Coney Island in Brooklyn. The Voice said that performers at this year’s festival would include Built to Spill, the Raveonettes, Frightened Rabbit, Grand Duchy, Monotonix and Micachu & the Shapes, with more artists to be announced.

Barlow-Hartman Public Relations, a New York agency that represents Broadway and Off Broadway productions, including “Billy Elliot,” “Next to Normal” and “Wicked,” announced on Tuesday that it will dissolve on June 14 and that the two lead partners would create separate ventures. The partners, John Barlow and Michael Hartman, said that the split was amicable and reflected their evolving individual interests. Mr. Barlow said he initially considered creating his own agency, taking along some of the firm’s shows that he represented, but decided that once he was ready to undertake his new venture he wanted to work with other arts organizations as well as theater. Mr. Hartman, will form a new business, the Hartman Group, on June 15; it will represent Barlow-Hartman’s current projects as well as other productions, and absorb the current Barlow-Hartman staff. Barlow-Hartman opened for business on June 14, 1999, and has represented numerous Broadway shows, including “The Producers,” “Dirty Rotten Scoundrels” and “The Pillowman.”.

Sotheby’s announced on Tuesday that it was planning a 5 percent cut in its global work force. The measure is in addition to a 15 percent cut at the end of 2008. Salaries will be reduced for top employees, too, and the company plans unpaid furloughs as well as a reduction in pension contributions for those working in the United States. Sotheby’s expects to save about $160 million this year. As part of this restructuring plan, it said it would save $15 million from staff cuts alone. A publicly traded company, Sotheby’s also announced on Tuesday that it would reduce its dividend to 20 cents a share from 60 cents. Sotheby’s officials said they had not laid off any art experts yet and probably wouldn’t until after the important New York auctions in May.
The lead producer of “Next to Normal” took the unusual step of moving a show that had already opened in New York to an out-of-town theater for an overhaul.

Investment losses are forcing the J. Paul Getty Trust, parent of the Getty Museum in Los Angeles, to cut 14 percent of its work force, or 205 jobs, and to delay some exhibitions and acquisitions, the institution said Monday. The budget cuts, intended to reduce spending by 24 percent in the fiscal year that begins July 1, come as the value of the trust’s endowment, one of the largest to benefit any art institution, has fallen to $4.2 billion as of March 31, down from a peak of $6.4 billion two years ago. The trust, which in addition to the museum supports art research and conservation and offers grants to other arts organizations, plans to cut its spending to $220 million in the new fiscal year. The trust said it would lay off 97 employees, with the rest of the personnel cuts coming through attrition or elimination of open positions.

The Broadway debut of Neil LaBute, “reasons to be pretty,” has had a tough time at the box office since it opened April 2, and last week was the toughest yet. Despite favorable reviews and award nominations, the production grossed $104,247, and only 29.6 percent of the seats were filled by paying customers for performances from April 20 through 26. The show’s grosses fell from $146,762 the previous week, when it played to a paid house of 48 percent. The week before that, the gross was $157,040, with 55 percent of the seats filled. Jeffrey Richards, the lead producer, said in an interview that there was “room for improvement” in the numbers but added that there had been no discussion among producers and investors about closing the show. “We have a very reasonable break-even” dollar figure, that is, grosses sufficient to cover weekly operating costs, Mr. Richards said, declining to reveal that number.

MARCHI--Senator John Marchi, St. John's School of Law notes with sorrow the passing of a most distinguished alumnus, supporter, and friend. New York State Senator John Marchi graduated from St. John's School of Law in 1949. He was a World War II veteran who was first elected to the Senate in 1957. He served until his retirement in 2006, having one of the longest-serving careers of an elected official in the country. Senator Marchi was a tireless leader and advocate for the people of Staten Island. In 1971, St. John's University awarded him an honorary Doctor of Laws degree and in 2006 St. John's Law School and the Law School Alumni Association presented him with the John J. Murphy Award, which is given to a graduate in recognition of distinguished service to the public, the profession and the Rule of Law. The St. John's community and its Alumni Association will miss the friendship of this dedicated alumnus.

The joint judiciary committee of the Legislature approved a bill to allow same-sex marriage in the state, setting the stage for the House and Senate to vote on it as soon as next week. Eleven of the 14 committee members voted in favor of the bill, two voted against it and one proposed letting voters decide the matter in a referendum. Gov. John Baldacci, a Democrat, has not said whether he will sign the bill. The New Hampshire House of Representatives approved a same-sex marriage bill last month, and the Senate is scheduled to take it up Wednesday.

This article is by Jim Rutenberg, Peter Baker and Bill Vlasic. WASHINGTON -- By the time he sat down in the Oval Office to brief Michigan's Congressional delegation, President Obama had made up his mind. Days earlier, he had decided to oust the head of General Motors and give it and Chrysler weeks to fix themselves. If they could not, he was prepared to let them go bankrupt, a prospect fraught with economic and political repercussions.

BARZELAY Professor Martin E.,of Southampton, New York, died on Monday, April 27 at the age of 91. He deeply loved and was devoted to his wife of 67 years, Muriel, and his son, Douglas. The son of the late Maurice E. and Mary Barzelay, he was born and raised in Malden, Mass. He received a BSME from Northeastern University in 1939 and an MS from Harvard University in 1941. After serving as an aircraft designer during WWII, he joined the faculty of Syracuse University in 1947, becoming Professor of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering in 1953 until his retirement in 1978. During his tenure, his areas of interest included aircraft design, heat transfer and safety engineering, on which he acted as a consultant to NASA. He was a Visiting Professor at Harvard in 1963-64. After retiring from Syracuse University, he built an active and thriving consulting engineering practice, specializing in safety engineering and in accident analysis and reconstruction. He was the author of several treatises and numerous articles in his fields of expertise. For many years he was a leader of the reform movement in the Democratic Party in Syracuse and was active in statewide politics as well. He was also a highly accomplished painter and many of his works are in private collections around the country. Until his final illness, he also retained his keen interests in gardening and in the computer, a technology he embraced avidly in his 80s. He was fortunate to have lived a full, active and productive life, as he wished to live it, with his vibrant intellect and strong will intact and the welfare of his close-knit and loving family always uppermost in his mind. Donations, in lieu of flowers, may be made to the Southampton Hospital Foundation, 240 Meetinghouse Lane, Southampton, NY 11968, where a fund has been established in his memory. A commemoration of his life will be held on Sunday, May 3rd at 4pm in Parrish Memorial Hall, Southampton.

It was only five years ago that opposition to same-sex marriage was so strong that Republicans explicitly turned to the issue as a way to energize conservative voters. Yet today, as the party contemplates the task of rebuilding itself, some Republicans say the marriage issue may be turning into more of a hindrance than a help. The fact that a run of states have legalized same-sex marriage in recent months -- either by court decision or by legislative action -- with little backlash is only one indication of how public attitudes about this subject appear to be changing.

PICKETT--Linda, 82. Daughter of Jamaican immigrants Passmore and Agnes Lindsay. Born 1926 in Manhattan and raised in the Bronx with her siblings Edsel, John, Lloyd and Martha. Married Alfred Pickett in 1947 and became a Harlem resident while working and raising her family. As a working mom, she held several jobs highlighted by a 20 year career at the W.T. Grant Foundation primarily as a Program Officer. Linda and Al became Roosevelt Island pioneers in 1975 where they were actively involved in a variety of activities. They also began their worldwide travels together. Beginning in 1990 Linda spent her retirement years as a passionate world traveler, active volunteer for many organizations, avid reader - book club member, a loyal arts supporter and generous philanthropist while still enjoying her Roosevelt Island home. Linda passed away peacefully at home on March 24, 2009 after a courageous and heartfelt battle with pancreatic cancer. Linda is survived by her sister Martha Dunlap, brothers Edsel and Lloyed Lindsay, son Steve along with many nephews and nieces, godchildren, dear friends, associates and neighbors. Please join the family in Celebrating Linda's almost 83 years of vibrant, loving and benevolent life. In lieu of flowers or gifts, please take a moment to remember Linda's smile and spirit during her time with you.

On nytimes.com this evening (and in Friday’s paper), I’ve written an article about a high school senior in Los Angeles who has set an ambitious goal for himself: to raise more than $25,000 through merit scholarships. His name is Brennan Jackson, and he is hoping that he might relieve his parents of the burden of paying for his education at the University of California at Berkeley next year.

Chrysler, the third-largest American auto company, will seek bankruptcy protection and enter an alliance with the Italian automaker Fiat, the White House announced Thursday.
